→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 69
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Monopoly Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/monopoly/monopoly.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/monopoly/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>A board</li>\n<li>Two dice</li>\n<li>Tokens for each player</li>\n<li>32 houses and 12 Hotels</li>\n<li>16 Chance and 16 Community Chest cards</li>\n<li>28 Title Deed cards for each property</li>\n<li>Money</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n<ol>\n<li>Place the board on a table.</li>\n<li>the Chance and Community Chest cards face down on their allotted spaces on the board.</li>\n<li>Each player chooses one token to represent them while traveling around the board.</li>\n<li>Each player is given $1500 divided as follows:</li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>2 x $500's, 2 x $100's, 2 x $50's, 6 x $20's, 5 x $10's, 5 x $5's, and 5 x $1's.</p>\n\n\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Bank</h2>\n\n<p>Select someone as banker. If this person also plays, then he must keep his personal funds separated from those of the bank.</p>\n\n<p>The Bank holds:</p>\n\n<ul>\n\n</ul>\n\n\n<p>The Bank pays salaries and bonuses. The Bank collects all taxes, fines, loans and interest, and the price of all properties which it sells and auctions.</p>\n\n<p>The Bank can't go broken, if the Bank runs out of money, the Banker may issue as much as needed by writing on any ordinary paper.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/monopoly/bank.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>Become the wealthiest player through buying, renting and selling of property and force other players into bankruptcy.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>Starting with the Banker, each player throws the dice. The player with the highest total starts the play.</p>\n\n<p>Then each player places his token on the corner marked \"GO\", and throw the dice and move his the number of spaces indicated by the dice.</p>\n\n<p>The tokens remain on the spaces occupied and proceed from that point on the player's next turn.</p>\n\n<p>Two or more tokens may rest on the same space at the same time.</p>\n\n<p>If one or both dice roll off the board, or land on or lean against a card deck, the roll is invalid. Roll them again.</p>\n\n<p>Depending on the space the token reaches, you may buy the property, or be obliged to pay rent, pay taxes, draw a Chance or Community Chest card, Go To Jail, or etc...</p>\n\n<p>If you throw doubles, you move your token and are subject to any privileges or penalties pertaining to the space on which you land. Then you can throw again and move your token as before.</p>\n\n<p>But watch out, if you ever throw doubles three times in succession, you have to go immediately to jail.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Go</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/monopoly/monopoly-go.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Each time a player's token lands on or passes over GO, whether by throw of the dice or by drawing a card, the Banker pays that player a $200 salary.</p>\n\n<p>However, $200 is paid only once each time around the board. If a player, passing \"GO\" on the throw of the dice, lands 2 spaces beyond it on \"Community Chest\", or 7 spaces beyond it on \"Chance\", and draws the card \"Advance to GO\", he collects $200 for passing \"GO\" the first time and another $200 for reaching it the second time by instructions on the card.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Buying Property</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/monopoly/title-deed.gif\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>When you land on an unowned property you can buy that property from the Bank at its printed price.</p>\n\n<p>You receive the Title Deed card showing ownership.</p>\n\n<p>If you do not wish to buy the property, the Bank sells it at thru an auction to the highest bidder. The buyer pays to the Bank the amount of the bid in cash and receives the Title Deed card for that property.</p>\n\n<p>Any player, including the one who declined the option to buy it at the printed price, may bid and bidding may start at any price.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Paying Rent</h2>\n\n<p>When you land on a property that is owned by another player, the owner collects rent from you in accordance with the list printed on its Title Deed card.</p>\n\n<p>If the property is mortgaged, its Title Deed card is placed face down in front of the owner and he can not collect a rent.</p>\n\n<p>It is an advantage to hold all the Title Deed cards in a color-group because the owner may then charge double rent for unimproved properties in that color-group. This rule applies to unmortgaged properties even if another property in that color-group is mortgaged.</p>\n\n<p>It is more advantageous to have houses or hotels on properties because then rents become much higher.</p>\n\n<p><i>Note: The owner may not collect the rent if they fail to ask the rent before the next player throws his dice.</i></p>\n\n<br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/monopoly/community-chest.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Chance And Community Chest</h2>\n\n<p>When you land on either of these spaces, take the top card from the deck indicated, and follow the instructions on the card.</p>\n\n<p>Return the card face down to the bottom of the deck.</p>\n\n<p>The \"Get Out of Jail Free\" card is held until used and then returned to the bottom of the deck.</p>\n\n<p>If the player who draws it does not wish to use it, then they may sell it to another player at a price agreeable to both.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Income Tax</h2>\n\n<p>When you land on \"Income Tax\" you have two options:</p>\n\n<ol>\n\n</ol>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Jail</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/monopoly/jail.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>You land in Jail when:</p>\n\n<ul>\n\n</ul>\n\n\n<p>When you are sent to Jail, you must move directly into Jail and you can not collect $200 salary if you need to pass to Go. Also your turn ends when you are sent to Jail.</p>\n\n<p>If you are not \"sent to jail\" but in the ordinary course of play lands on that space, you are \"Just Visiting\" and you move ahead in the usual manner on your next turn.</p>\n\n<p>A player gets out of Jail by:</p>\n\n<ul>\n\n</ul>\n\n\n<p>Even though you are in Jail, you may buy and sell property, houses and hotels and collect rents.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Free Parking</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/monopoly/free-parking.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>This is just a \"free\" resting place, so the player landing on it doesn't receive money, property, reward or penalty of any kind.</p>\n\n<p>Try to avoid to come here early in game, but later on the game it can be a great target.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Houses And Hotels</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/monopoly/monopoly-houses.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>When a player owns all the properties in a color-group, he or she may buy houses from the Bank.</p>\n\n<p>You may buy as many houses as your judgment and financial standing will allow, but you cannot erect more than one house on any one property of any color-group until you have built one house on every property of that group.</p>\n\n<p>The price you must pay the Bank for each house is shown on your Title Deed card for the property on which you erect the house.</p>\n\n<p>The owner still collects double rent from an opponent who lands on the unimproved properties of his/her complete color-group.</p>\n\n<p>When a player has four houses on each property of a complete color-group, they may buy a hotel from the Bank and erect it on any property of the color-group. Only one hotel may be erected on any one property.</p>\n\n<p>As you build evenly, you must also break down evenly if you sell houses back to the Bank.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Building Shortages</h2>\n\n<p>When the Bank has no houses to sell, players wishing to build must wait for some player to return or sell their houses to the Bank before building.</p>\n\n<p>If there are a limited number of houses and hotels available and two or more players wish to buy more than the Bank has, the houses/hotels will be sold at auction to the highest bidder.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Selling Property</h2>\n\n<p>Unimproved properties, railroads and utilities may be sold to any player as a private transaction for any amount the owner can get.</p>\n\n<p>However, properties can not be sold to another player if buildings are standing on any properties of that color-group.</p>\n\n<p>The buildings must be sold back to the Bank before the owner can sell any property of that color-group.</p>\n\n<p>Houses and Hotels can be sold back to the bank at any time for one-half the price paid for them.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/monopoly/title-deed.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Mortgages</h2>\n\n<p>Unimproved properties can be mortgaged through the Bank at any time. The mortgage value is printed on each Title Deed card.</p>\n\n<p>When properties has buildings, then these must be sold back to the back at half price first.</p>\n\n<p>No rent can be collected on mortgaged properties or utilities.</p>\n\n<p>In order to lift the mortgage, the owner must pay the Bank the amount of mortgage plus 10% interest.</p>\n\n<p>When all the properties of a color-group are no longer mortgaged, the owner may begin to buy back houses or hotels.</p>\n\n<p>The player who mortgages property retains possession of it and no other player may secure it by lifting the mortgage from the Bank.</p>\n\n<p>But the owner may sell this mortgaged property to another player at any agreed price and the new owner can lift the mortgage by paying off the mortgage plus 10% interest to the Bank.</p>\n\n<p>When the mortgage if not lifted at once, you must pay the Bank 10% interest when you buy the property and if you lift the mortgage later you must pay the Bank an additional 10% interest.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Bankruptcy</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/monopoly/bankruptcy.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>You are declared bankrupt if you owe more than you can pay to another player or to the Bank.</p>\n\n<p>If your debt is to another player, you must turn over all that you have to that player.</p>\n\n<p>If you own houses or hotels, you must return these to the Bank in exchange for money to the extent of one-half the amount paid for them and this cash is given to the creditor.</p>\n\n<p>If you have mortgaged property you also turn this property over to your creditor but the new owner must at once pay the Bank the amount of interest on the loan, which is 10% of the value of the property.</p>\n\n<p>Should you owe the Bank, instead of another player, more than you can pay, you must turn over all assets to the Bank. In this case, the Bank immediately sells by auction all property except buildings.</p>\n\n<p>Money can be loaned to a player only by the Bank (by mortgaging property) and no other player may borrow from or lend money to another player.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>Bankrupt players must retire from the game and the last player left in the game is the winner..</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>How to play a short game</h3>\n\n<p>There are some <a href=\"fast-monopoly.php\">additional rules to play Monopoly faster.</a></p>\n\n<br>\n\n<br><h2>Other Monopoly Editions</h2><ul><li><a href=\"anti-monopoly-rules.php\">Anti-Monopoly</a></li><li><a href=\"city-game-rules.php\">Monopoly City</a></li><li><a href=\"cheaters-edition.php\">Monopoly Cheaters Edition</a></li><li><a href=\"deadpool-game-rules.php\">Monopoly Deadpool</a></li><li><a href=\"deal-game-rules.php\">Monopoly Deal</a></li><li><a href=\"fortnite.php\">Monopoly Fortnite</a></li><li><a href=\"millennials-game-rules.php\">Monopoly for Millennials</a></li><li><a href=\"frozen-game-rules.php\">Monopoly Frozen II</a></li><li><a href=\"game-of-thrones-game-rules.php\">Monopoly Game of Thrones</a></li><li><a href=\"friends.php\">Monopoly Friends</a></li><li><a href=\"gamer-game-rules.php\">Monopoly Gamer</a></li><li><a href=\"junior-game-rules.php\">Monopoly Junior</a></li><li><a href=\"junior-electronic-banking-game-rules.php\">Monopoly Junior Electronic Banking</a></li><li><a href=\"junior-party-game-rules.php\">Monopoly Junior Party</a></li><li><a href=\"ms-monopoly-game-rules.php\">Ms. Monopoly</a></li><li><a href=\"marvel-avengers-game-rules.php\">Monopoly Marvel Avengers</a></li><li><a href=\"longest-game-ever-rules.php\">Monopoly -   293 
  294 if (existingRule) {
  295   // Update existing rule
→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 70
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Scrabble Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/scrabble/scrabble.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/scrabble/select-starter.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Place all letter tiles in the pouch or facedown besides the board. Then mix or shuffle them.</p>\n\n<p>Draw a letter to decide who will start to play. The one with the letter closest to \"A\" starts. A blank title beats any letter.</p>\n\n<p>When both players draw the same letter, draw another one. Now return all letters to the pool and remix (shuffle) them.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/scrabble/scrabble-rack.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>the players draw seven new letters each and put them on their racks.</p>\n\n<p>Pick also a player to keep score on paper.</p>\n\n<p>Finally, the players should agree which dictionary they will use, in case of a challenge.</p>\n\n<p>All words labeled as a part of speech (including those listed of foreign origin, and as archaic, obsolete, colloquial, slang, etc). are permitted with the exception of the following: words always capitalized, abbreviations, prefixes and suffixes standing alone, words requiring a hyphen or an apostrophe.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>The players form words on the gameboard using letters from their racks. Each letter has a different value.</p>\n\n<p>On the board, some premium squares can increase the letter or word value. The player with the highest final score wins the game.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/scrabble/first-word.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The first player combines 2 or more of his or her letters to form a word. He places this word on the board to read either across or down with one letter on the center square. Diagonal words are not allowed.</p>\n\n<p>Since it uses a \"premium square\", the score for this first word is doubled. Count and announce the score for that turn.</p>\n\n<p>Complete the turn by drawing as many new letters as you placed on the board.</p>\n\n<p>Then draw as many new letters as you played; You must always keep 7 letters on your rack (as long as there are enough tiles left).</p>\n\n<p>The play passes to the next player left.</p>\n\n<p>Each in turn, every player adds one or more letters to those already played to form new words.</p>\n\n<p>All letters played on a turn must be placed in one row across or down the board, to form at least one complete word. If, at the same time, they touch others letters in adjacent rows, those must also form complete words, crossword fashion, with all such letters. The player gets full credit for all words formed or modified on his or her turn.</p>\n\n<p>New words may be formed by:</p>\n\n<p>\n\n</p><ul>\n<li>Adding one or more letters to letters already on the board.</li>\n<li>Placing a word at right angles to a word already on the board. The new word must use one of the letters already on the board or must add a letter to it.</li>\n<li>Placing a complete word parallel to a word already played so the adjacent letters also form complete words.</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n\n\n<p>No tile may be shifted or replaced after it has been played and scored.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h3>Blanks</h3>\n\n<p>The two blank tiles may be used as any letters. When playing a blank, you must state which letter it represents. It remains that letter for the rest of the game.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>You may use a turn to exchange all (or some of) your letters:</p>\n\n<ul>\n\n<li><p>Place your discarded letter(s) facedown.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Draw the same number of letters from the pouch.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Mix the discarded letter(s) into the pouch.</p></li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<p>You can not exchange tiles if there are fewer than 7 tiles left.</p>\n\n<p><b>Ending the Game:</b> The game ends when all letters have been drawn and one player uses his or her last letter or when all possible plays have been made.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Scoring</h2>\n\n<br>\n\n<ol id=\"tps\">\n\n<li><p>The scorekeeper writes the score of each player on the scorepad after each turn. Use a score pad or piece of paper to keep a tally of each player's score, entering it after each turn.</p>\n\n<p>The value of each letter is indicated by a number at the bottom of the tile. The score value of a blank tile is zero.</p>\n\n</li>\n\n<li><p>The score for each turn is the sum of the letter values in each word(s) formed or modified on that turn.</p>\n\n<p>Additional points obtained from placing letters on premium squares.</p>\n\n</li>\n<li><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/scrabble/special-squares.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p><b>Premium Letter Squares:</b> A blue square doubles the score of a letter placed on it.</p>\n\n<p>A green square triples the letter score of a letter placed on it.</p>\n\n</li>\n\n<li><p><b>Premium Word Squares:</b> The score for an entire word is doubled when one of its letters is placed on a red square.</p>\n\n<p>It is tripled when one of its letters is placed on an orange square. If a word covers two premium word squares, the score is doubled then re-doubled, or tripled then re-tripled.</p>\n\n\n\n</li>\n\n<li><p>Letter and word premiums count only on the turn in which they are played. Letters already played on premium squares count later at face value.</p>\n\n</li>\n\n<li><p>When a blank tile is played on a red or orange square, the value of the word is still doubled or tripled.</p>\n\n</li>\n\n<li><p>When two or more words are formed in the same play, each is scored. The common letter is counted for each word.</p>\n\n</li>\n\n<li><p><b>BINGO!</b> If you play 7 tiles on a turn, it's a Bingo and you can add 50 bonus points to your score.</p>\n\n</li>\n\n<li><p><b>Unplayed Letters:</b> When the game ends, each player's score is reduced by the sum of his unplayed letters.</p>\n\n<p>In addition, if a player has used all of his or her letters, the sum of the other players' unplayed letters is added to that player's score.</p>\n\n</li>\n\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/scrabble/scrabble-finish.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h2>End of the game</h2>\n\n<p>The game ends when all letters have been drawn and one player uses his or her last letter; or when all possible plays have been made.</p>\n\n<p>The player with the highest final score wins the game.</p>\n\n<p>In case of a tie, the player with the highest score before deducting or adding unplayed letters wins.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"tips.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Scrabble Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:46:12.214Z"),
            ~~~~~~~~~

        ?   game?: GameUpdateOneRequiredWithoutRulesNestedInput
          }
        })

→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 71
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Risk Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/risk/risk.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/risk/components_.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n<ul><li>Gameboard</li><li>5 armies with 40 infantry</li><li>12 cavalry</li><li>and 8 artillery each</li><li>deck of 43 cards</li><li>2 reference cards</li><li>5 dice</li><li>Instructions</li></ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Game Board</h3>\n\n<p>The game board is a map of 6 continents divided into 42 territories. Each continent is a different color and exists of 4 to 12 territories.</p>\n\n<p>The numbers along the bottom (southern) edge of the board indicate the number of armies you will receive for a set of cards you trade in.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/risk/board.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h3>The Armies</h3>\n\n<p>There are six complete sets of armies, each containing three types:</p>\n<ol>\n<li>Infantry (worth l)</li>\n<li>Cavalry (worth 5 Infantry)</li>\n<li>Artillery (worth 10 Infantry, or 2 Cavalry)</li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>Start the game by placing Infantry pieces. Later, you can trade in 5 Infantry for 1 Cavalry, or 2 Cavalry (or 1 Cavalry and 5 Infantry) for 1 Artillery.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Cards</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>42 Cards are marked with a territory and a picture of Infantry, Cavalry, or Artillery.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Two \"wild\" cards marked with all three pictures, but no territory.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>12 Secret Mission cards used only in Secret Mission Risk. These cards are only used in the secret mission variation, else you have to remove them.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/risk/cards2.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<div class=\"box red_border yellow5_bg\">\n\n<p>To conquer the world by occupying all territories on the board. You need to eliminate all your opponents.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<p>Select a color and, depending on the number of players, count out the \"armies\" you'll need to start the game.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>If 2 are playing, see <a href=\"risk-for-2-players.php\">special instructions</a>.</li>\n<li>If 3 are playing, each player counts out 35 Infantry.</li>\n<li>If 4 are playing, each player counts out 30 Infantry.</li>\n<li>If 5 are playing, each player counts out 25 Infantry.</li>\n<li>If 6 are playing, each player counts out 20 Infantry.</li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Roll one die. Whoever rolls the highest number takes one Infantry piece from his or her pile and places it onto any territory on the board, thus claiming that territory.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Starting to the left of the first player, in turn, everyone places one army onto any unoccupied territory. Continue until all 42 territories have been claimed.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>After all 42 territories are claimed, each player in turn places one additional army onto any territory he or she already occupies.</p>\n\n<p>Continue in this way until everyone has run out of armies. There is no limit to the number of armies you may place onto a single territory.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Shuffle the pack of RISK cards (maybe, remove the Mission cards) and place the cards face down by the side of the board.</p>\n\n<p>This pack forms the draw pile.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Whoever placed the first army opens the game.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>On your turn, try to capture territories by defeating your opponents' armies. But be careful: Winning battles will depend on careful planning, quick decisions, and bold moves.</p>\n\n<p>You will have to place your forces wisely, attack at just the right time and fortify your defenses against all enemies.</p>\n\n<div class=\" notepad\">\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> At any time during the game, you may trade in Infantry pieces for the equivalent in Cavalry or Artillery if you need to, or wish to.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"box yellow2_border grey4_bg\">\n\n<p>Each of your turns consists of three steps, in this order:</p>\n<ol>\n<li>Getting and placing new armies.</li>\n<li>Attacking.</li>\n<li>Fortifying your position.</li>\n</ol>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n<h2>I. Placing New Armies</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/risk/troops.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>At the beginning of each turn, calculate how many new armies you can add to your territories based on:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>The number of territories you occupy.</li>\n<li>The value of the continents you control.</li>\n<li>The value of the matched sets of RISK cards you trade in.</li>\n<li>The specific territory pictured on a traded-in card.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Territories</h3>\n\n<p>At the beginning of every turn (including your first), count the number of territories you currently occupy, then divide the total by three (ignore any fraction).</p>\n\n<p>The answer is the number of armies you receive. Place the new armies on any territory you already occupy.</p>\n\n<div class=\"box box_radius box_border\">\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> 11 territories = 3 armies, 14 territories = 4 armies, 17 territories = 5 armies. You will always receive at least 3 armies on a turn, even if you occupy fewer than 9 territories.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Continents</h3>\n\n<p>In addition, at the beginning of your turn, you will receive armies for each continent you control. (To control a continent, you must occupy all its territories at the start of your turn).</p>\n\n<div class=\"box yellow2_border\">\n\n<p>The number of extra armies is different for each continent:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Asia: 7</li>\n<li>Nort America: 5</li>\n<li>Europe: 5</li>\n<li>Africa: 3</li>\n<li>South America: 2</li>\n<li>Australia: 2</li>\n</ul>\n\n</div>\n\n<p>These numbers can be different depending on the version of Risk you are playing. To find the exact number of armies, look at the chart in the lower left-hand corner of the game board.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Risk Cards</h2>\n\n<h3>Earning Cards</h3>\n\n<p>At the end of any turn in which you have captured at least one territory, you will earn one (and only one) RISK card.</p>\n\n<p>You are trying to collect sets of 3 cards in any of the following combinations: 3 cards of the same design (Infantry, Cavalry, or Artillery), 1 each of 3 designs, or any 2 plus a \"wild\" card.</p>\n\n<p>If you have collected a set of 3 RISK cards, you may turn them in at the start of your next turn, or you may wait. But if you have 5 or 6 cards at the beginning of your turn, you must trade in at least one set and may trade in a second set if you have one.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Trading in Cards for Armies</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/risk/trading.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>At the beginning of subsequent turns, you may trade in matched sets of cards and take additional armies based on the total number of sets anyone has traded in so far. For quick reference, keep traded-in cards face down under the bottom edge of the game board to mark the value (in armies) of the next trade.</p>\n\n<p>After the sixth set has been traded in, each additional set is worth 5 more armies. Example: If you trade in the seventh set, you get 20 armies; if you trade in the eighth, you get 25 armies, and so on.</p>\n\n<p>\"First\" and \"second\" set, etc., refer to sets traded in by anyone during the game. Thus, if you trade in the 3rd set in the game, you receive 8 armies, even if itis the first set you have traded in.</p>\n\n<p>Occupied territories: If any of the 3 cards you trade in shows the picture of a territory you occupy, you receive 2 extra armies. You must place both those armies onto that particular territory.</p>\n\n<div class=\" notepad\">\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> On a single turn, you may receive no more than 2 extra armies above and beyond those you receive for the matched sets of cards you trade in.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"infobox\"><div class=\"info-icon\"><i></i></div><div class=\"infobox-body\">\n\n<p><b>Tip:</b> No matter how many armies you receive at the start of your turn, deploy them carefully-either to prepare for an attack or to defend against one.</p>\n\n<p>It is a an excellent military strategy to move your armies to the front, heavily fortifying territories that border enemy territories.</p>\n\n</div></div>\n\n<br>\n<h2>II. Attacking</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/risk/attacking.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>After placing your armies at the beginning of your turn, decide if you wish to attack at this time.</p>\n\n<p>The object of an attack is to capture a territory by defeating all the opposing armies already on it. The battle is fought by a roll of the dice. Study the board for a moment. Do you want to attack?</p>\n\n<p>If you choose not to attack, pass the dice to the player on your left. You may still fortify your position if you wish. If you decide to attack, you must follow these rules:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>You may only attack a territory that's adjacent (touching) to one of your own, or connected to it by a dashed line.</p>\n\n<div class=\"box box_radius box_border\">\n\n<p>Examples: Greenland may attack the Northwest Territory, Ontario, Quebec, and Iceland. North Africa may attack Egypt, Western Europe, and Brazil. At the western and eastern edges of the board, Alaska is considered adjacent to and may attack, Kamchatka.</p>\n\n</div>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>You must always have at least two armies in the territory you're attacking from.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>You may continue attacking one territory until you have eliminated all armies on it, or you may shift your attack from one territory to another, attacking each as often as you want and attacking as many territories as you like during one turn.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>To Attack</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/risk/dice.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>First, announce both the territory you're attacking and the one you are attacking from. Then roll the dice against the opponent who occupies the opposing territory.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>Before rolling, both you and your opponent must announce the number of dice you intend to roll, and you both must roll at the same time.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>You, the attacker, will roll 1, 2 or 3 red dice: You must have at least one more army in your territory than the number of dice you roll.</p>\n\n<div class=\"infobox\"><div class=\"info-icon\"><i></i></div><div class=\"infobox-body\">\n\n<p><b>Hint:</b> The more dice you roll, the higher your odds of winning. Yet the more dice you roll, the more armies you may lose, or be required to move into a captured territory.</p>\n\n</div></div>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>The defender will roll either 1 or 2 white dice: To roll 2 dice, he or she must have at least 2 armies on the territory under attack. Hint: The more dice the defender rolls, the higher his or her odds of winning, but the more armies he or she may lose.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>To Decide a Battle</h3>\n\n<p>Compare the highest die each of you rolled. If yours (the attackers) is higher, the defender loses one army from the territory under attack.</p>\n\n<p>But if the defender's die is higher than yours, you lose one army from the territory you attacked from; put it back in your clear plastic box.</p>\n\n<p>If each of you rolled more than one die, now compare the two next-highest dice and repeat the process.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/risk/battle.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>III. Fortifying your Position</h2>\n\n<p>No matter what you have done on your turn, you may end your turn by fortifying your position.</p>\n\n<p>You are not required to win a battle or even to try an attack to do so.</p>\n\n<p>Some players refer to this as the \"free move\".</p>\n\n<p>To fortify your position, move as many armies as you would like from one (and only one) of your territories into one (and only one) of your adjacent territories.</p>\n\n<p>Remember to move troops towards borders where they can help in an attack and leave at least one army behind.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<div class=\"box red_border yellow5_bg\">\n\n<p>The winner is the first player to eliminate every opponent by capturing all 42 territories on the board.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"continents.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Risk Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:46:16.361Z"),

            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Clue Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clue/mrblack-murderd.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>Clue Game Board which shows 9 rooms</li>\n<li>6 colored tokens, each representing one of the suspects: Colonel Mustard (yellow), Miss Scarlet (red), Professor Plum (purple), Mr. Green (green), Mrs. White (white) and Mrs. Peacock (blue).</li>\n<li>6 miniature weapons: Rope, Lead Pipe, Knife, Wrench, Candlestick, Revolver</li>\n<li>Pack of cards: 1 card for each of the 6 Suspects, 6 Weapons and 9 Rooms</li>\n<li>Note books</li>\n<li>Case File Confidential envelope</li>\n<li>One die</li>\n</ul>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clue/board.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<p>Take that Suspect token and place it on the assigned starting space.</p>\n\n<p>If fewer than 6 are playing, be sure to place the remaining tokens onto the appropriate names because they might be involved in the crime!</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Place each of the weapons ad random in a room.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Sort the cards by type into three groups: Suspects, Rooms and Weapons.</p>\n\n<p>Shuffle each group face-down, draw one card from each group and slide them into the \"Case File Confidential\" envelope. Place it onto the \"X\" in the center of the board.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Shuffle the three piles of remaining cards together and deal them face down clockwise around the table.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>If you wish, check out the cards that are in your hand. You can also cross them off in your notebook as possibility.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clue/object.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Mr. Boddy is found death in one of the rooms of his mansion.</p>\n\n<p>The players must determine the answers to these three questions: Who killed him? Where? and with What Weapon?</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>Miss Scarlett opens the game, the turns continue clockwise around the table.</p>\n\n<p>On each turn, a player try to reach a different room of the mansion to investigate.</p>\n\n<p>To start your turn, move your token by rolling the die or use a Secret Passage when you are in a corner room.</p>\n\n<p>If you roll the die, you move your token that many spaces:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Horizontally or vertically, forward or backward, but not diagonally.</li>\n<li>You are not allowed to enter the same space twice on the same turn.</li>\n<li>You may not enter on a space that is already occupied by another player.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>If you move through a Secret Passage, you don't need to roll and you can move immediately to the other room. This ends your movement.</p>\n\n<p>It is possible that your opponents might block any and all doors and trap you in a room. In that case, you have to wait for someone to move or un-block a door to leave!</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clue/rooms.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Suggestions</h2>\n\n<p>When you enter a room, you can make a suggestion by naming a suspect, murder weapon and the room you just entered.</p>\n\n<p>e.g. \"The crime was committed by Mr. Green in the lounge with a knife\".</p>\n\n<p>The named suspect and weapon are moved into the room you entered.</p>\n\n<p>Then your opponents (starting by the left player) must (if possible) prove that your suggestion is false by showing you one card that matches your suggestion.</p>\n\n<p>If the first player can't disprove, the next player must try it, etc... until all players have passed.</p>\n\n<p>As soon as someone shows you one of the cards, it is prooved that it can't be in the envelope and you can cross it off in your notebook as a possibility.</p>\n\n<p>If no one is able to prove your suggestion false, you may either end your turn or make an accusation.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> the suggestion is always made for the room your token is at that moment.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Accusing</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clue/clue-enveloppe.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If you think you have solved the crime (by deduction), you can end your turn by making an accusation and name any three elements.</p>\n\n<p>you can say: \"I accuse (suspect) of committing the crime in the (room) with the (weapon)\".</p>\n\n<p>Then, you must look secretly at the cards in the envelope to check if your suggestion is correct.</p>\n\n<p>If you are correct, you can place the 3 cards face-up on the table to prove it and you won the game!</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> You can only make one accusation during a game. If your accusation is wrong, you lost and you must leave the game (and board).</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"suggestions.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Clue Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:46:19.301Z"),

→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 73
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Chess Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/chess/chess.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<p>Chess is a game played between two opponents on opposite sides of a board containing 64 squares of alternating colors.</p>\n\n<p>The player using the white pieces moves first in Chess. Players generally decide who will get to be white by chance such having one player guess the color of the hidden pawn in the other player's hand.</p>\n\n<p>Each player is obligated to move on their turn.</p>\n\n<p>There are six kinds of pieces in chess: king, queen, rook, bishop, knight and the pawn.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/chess/opening.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The chessboard is laid out so the white color square in the bottom right-hand side.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>The second row is filled with 8 pawns.</li>\n<li>The rooks go in the corners</li>\n<li>then the knights</li>\n<li>then the bishops</li>\n<li>then the queens (white queen on white, black queen on black)</li>\n<li>the king on the remaining square.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>The goal of the game is to checkmate the other king. Checkmate happens when the king is in a position to be captured and cannot escape from capture.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Video Tutorial</h2>\n\n<iframe width=\"560\" height=\"420\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Bzhx3zra5QM\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"autoplay; encrypted-media\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Check, Checkmate and Stalemate</h2>\n\n<p>A check is an immediate threat to capture the king.</p>\n\n<p>In the following move, the player whose king is in check must get his king out of check.</p>\n\n<p>This can be done by:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>moving the king to a space where the king is no longer in check</li>\n<li>interposing a piece between the threatening piece and the king</li>\n<li>by capturing the threatening piece</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>If the king is in check and there is no legal move which gets the king out of check, the king is said to be checkmated and the game is over.</p>\n\n<p>The game is drawn when the player to move has no legal move and his king is not in check. The game is said to end in 'stalemate'.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>How The Pieces Move</h2>\n\n<h4>Pawn</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/chess/pawn.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Pawns are unusual because they move and capture in different ways. They move forward, but capture diagonally.</p>\n\n<p>Pawns can move only one square forward and may not move backwards.</p>\n\n<p>The first time each pawn is moved from its initial position, it has the option to advance two squares.</p>\n\n<p>Any piece directly in front of a pawn (friend or foe) blocks its advance.</p>\n\n<p>The eight pawns are set on rows two.</p>\n\n<p>The pawn is maybe the least powerful piece in chess, but it can promote to any other piece.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<h4>Capturing</h4>\n\n<p>A pawn captures diagonally one square forward and to the left or right.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h4>Promotion</h4>\n\n<p>A pawn that advances to the opposite side of the board is promoted to another piece of that player's choice of a queen, rook, bishop, or knight of the same color.</p>\n\n<p>The pawn is immediately replaced by the new piece and the choice of promotion is not limited to captured pieces.</p>\n\n<p>Players may have as many as ten knights, ten bishops, ten rooks or nine queens.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h4>En Passant</h4>\n\n<p>An even more unusual move is the en passant capture which is French for \"in passing\".</p>\n\n<p>If a pawn moves out two squares on its first move and lands to the side of an opponent's pawn, that other pawn has the option of capturing the first pawn as it passes by.</p>\n\n<p>This special move must be done immediately after the first pawn has moved past, otherwise the option to capture it is no longer available.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Bishop</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/chess/bishop.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The bishop moves diagonal and has no restrictions in distance (1 square, 2 squares, 3 squares, ..)..</p>\n\n<p>The bishop stays always on its starting color, which can be seen as a little weakness.</p>\n\n<p>The bishop is placed on the 3rd and 6th column.</p>\n\n<p>Bishops cannot jump over other pieces (enemy or own pieces).</p>\n\n<p>For: <a href=\"bishop.php\">more information about the bishop</a>.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Knight</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/chess/knight.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>A knight moves unusal:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>two squares horizontally and one square vertically</li>\n<li>two squares vertically and one square horizontally</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>The complete move therefore looks like the shape of letter \"L\".</p>\n\n<p>Knights are placed on the 2nd and 7th columns.</p>\n\n<p>The knight can jump over all other pieces to its destination.</p>\n\n<p>For: <a href=\"knight.php\">more information about the knight</a>.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Rook</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/chess/rook.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The rook moves horizontally or vertically and has no restrictions in distance (1 square, 2 squares, 3 squares, ..)..</p>\n\n<p>Rooks are set on the 1st and 8th column.</p>\n\n<p>Rooks can be powerfull when they protect each other.</p>\n\n<p>Rooks cannot jump over other pieces (enemy or own pieces).</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Queen</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/chess/queen.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The queen moves horizontally, vertically and diagonal and has no restrictions in distance (1 square, 2 squares, 3 squares, ..)..</p>\n\n<p>The queen can be seen as the most powerful piece.</p>\n\n<p>The queens are set up on 4th column.</p>\n\n<p>It cannot capture nor move trough a piece on its own side.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>King</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/chess/king.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The king moves horizontally, vertically and diagonal and only 1 square.</p>\n\n<p>A king can also not move onto a square that is threatened by an opponents piece.</p>\n\n<p>The king is the most important piece, when you loose him, you are lost.</p>\n\n<p>The king is placed on the 5th column.</p>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<h5>Castling</h5>\n\n<p>Castling consists of moving the king two squares toward either one of the original rooks, then moving the rook onto the square over which the king crossed.</p>\n\n<p>Castling is allowed when:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>it must be the king's first move</li>\n<li>it must be the rook's first move</li>\n<li>no squares between them are occupied</li>\n<li>the king is not in check</li>\n<li>he king will not move across or end its movement on a square that is under enemy control.</li>\n</ul>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Draws</h2>\n\n<p>Sometimes a chess game don't end with a winner but with a draw.</p>\n\n<p>There are 5 reasons why a chess game may end in a draw:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>both players agree to draw</li>\n<li>there are not enough pieces left to force a checkmate</li>\n<li>the same exact position is repeated 3x times</li>\n<li>no pawn was moved and no piece was captured during 50 consecutive moves</li>\n<li>the game is in stalemate</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Time Control</h2>\n\n<p>A regular chess clock is used to limit the length of a game.</p>\n\n<p>These clocks count the time that each player separately takes for making his own moves.</p>\n\n<p>If you run out of time, you lose the game.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"chess-openings.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Chess Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:46:22.829Z"),

            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Checkers Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/checkers/checkers.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>A classic 8x8 chessboard, only the dark squares are used.</p>\n\n<p>It is positioned so that each player has a light square on the right side corner.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>24 discs (12 of 2 colors)</p>\n\n<p>Typically, they are flat and round. The color of one set is black and the other red or white or beige.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Tutorial Video</h2>\n\n<iframe width=\"560\" height=\"420\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Wi42a6bTgl0\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"autoplay; encrypted-media\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/checkers/checkers.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Checkers is played by two players.</p>\n\n<p>Each player begins the game with 12 discs and places them on the 12 dark squares closest to him or her.</p>\n\n<p>Black opens the game, then players alternate their turns.</p>\n\n<p>Randomly determine who gets the black pieces first. When playing a series of games, the players alternate who gets the black pieces.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Move</h2>\n\n<p>The pieces always move diagonally and single pieces are always limited to forward moves.</p>\n\n<p>A piece making a non-capturing move may move only one square.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Capture</h2>\n\n<p>To capture a piece of your opponent, your piece leaps over one of the opponent's pieces and lands in a straight diagonal line on the other side. This landing square must be empty.</p>\n\n<p>When a piece is captured, it is removed from the board.</p>\n\n<p>Only one piece may be captured in a single jump, but multiple jumps are allowed on a single turn.</p>\n\n<p>If a player is able to make the capture, then the jump must be made.</p>\n\n<p>If more than one capture is available, then the player decides if he prefers this or not.</p>\n\n<p>Single pieces may shift direction diagonally during a multiple capture turn, but must always jump forward (toward the opponent).</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Upgrade a piece to a King</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/checkers/king.png\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>When a piece reaches the furthest row, it is crowned and becomes a king.</p>\n\n<p>One of the pieces which had been captured is placed on top of the king so that it is twice as high as a single piece.</p>\n\n<p>Kings are limited to moving diagonally but can move both forward and backward.</p>\n\n<p>Kings may combine jumps in several directions (forward and backward) on the same turn.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>A player wins the game when the opponent cannot make a move.</p>\n\n<p>This happens usually because all of the opponent's pieces have been captured, but it could also be because all of his pieces are blocked in.</p>\n\n<br><br>\n\n<div class=\"box box_border\">\n\n<h3>Additional Rules</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>In official games, five minutes are allowed for each move. In the case where there is only one possible jump available, the player has only one minute in which to make it.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>If the player whose move it is touches a piece that can be played, the player must move that piece or forfeit the game.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>If during 20 moves (10 by each player), only kings have changed position and there appear to be repeating movements, then a referee will step in to determine the winner according to who holds the strongest position.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>It is prohibited to annoy or distract your opponent. This includes making signs or sounds, pointing or hovering over the board with your hands or other body parts, needlessly delaying your moves, blowing smoke in your opponent's face, or appearing at the table dressed in a provocative manner.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n</div>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"tips.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",

→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 75
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Backgammon Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/backgammon/backgammon.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>Double-side Game board</li>\n<li>30 Playing pieces</li>\n<li>2 Dice</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>To win by moving all of your checkers to your home board and then bear them all off.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p>Set up the board like this and figure out which is your home board so you'll know where it is that you have to move your checkers to before you can begin to bear them off.</p>\n\n<p>Both players roll one dice each and the higher roll indicates who is to go first. The player throwing the higher number now moves his checkers according to the numbers showing on both dice. After the first roll, the players throw two dice and take alternate turns.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Tutorial Video</h2>\n\n<iframe width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"//www.youtube.com/embed/vdnO_3BiprA?rel=0\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Gameplay</h2>\n\n<h3>Throwing the dice and moving</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/backgammon/board2.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The roll of the dice indicates how many points, or pips, the player is to move his checkers. The checkers are always moved forward in the direction indicated in the diagram above.</p>\n\n<p>The following rules apply:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p>A checker may be moved only to an open point, one that is not occupied by two or more opposing checkers.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>The numbers on the two dice constitute separate moves. For example, if a player rolls 5 and 3, he may move one checker five spaces to an open point and another checker three spaces to an open point, or he may move the one checker a total of eight spaces to an open point, but only if the intermediate point (either three or five spaces from the starting point) is also open.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>If you are lucky you might roll doubles. This is when both dice are the same and means you can move double the amount. For example, if you were to roll 6 and 6 you would be able to move 6 four times and you may move any combination of checkers you feel is best. You lucky sod.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>A player must use both numbers of a roll if this is legally possible (or all four numbers of a double). When only one number can be played, the player must play that number.</p></li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>Or if either number can be played but not both, the player must play the larger one. When neither number can be used, the player loses his turn. In the case of doubles, when all four numbers cannot be played, the player must play as many numbers as he can.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Hitting And Entering</h3>\n\n<p>A point occupied by a single checker is called a blot and if an opposing checker lands on it then this checker is removed from the board and placed on the bar. Therefore it's best to try and keep your checkers in groups of two or more so that they cannot be attacked.</p>\n\n<p>If a player has one or more checkers on the bar, they cannot resume playing until they have succeeded in returning their pieces to the homeboard of their opponent. They do this by rolling a number that corresponds to an open point on the opposing home board.</p>\n\n<p>If white had two checkers on the bar and rolled a 3 and 4 in the first example they could not move and would lose a turn and in the second example they could return both checkers to play and simultaneously remove an opponents checker to the bar.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Bearing Off</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/backgammon/board1.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Once a player has moved all their pieces to their home board, they can start bearing off. A player bears off a checker by rolling a number that corresponds to the point on which the checker resides, and then removing that checker from the board.</p>\n\n<p>Thus, rolling a 4 permits the player to remove a checker from the fourth point.</p>\n\n<p>If there is no checker on the point indicated by the roll, the player must move instead by moving a checker on a higher point (in the case of rolling a 4, he could move a checker on the fifth or sixth point instead).</p>\n\n<p>If there are no checkers on higher-numbered points, the player is permitted (and required) to remove a checker from the highest point on which one of his checkers resides.</p>\n\n<p>A player is under no obligation to bear off if he can make an otherwise legal move.</p>\n\n<p>A player must have all of his active checkers in his home board in order to bear off. If a checker is hit during the bear-off process, the player must bring that checker back to his home board before continuing to bear off. The first player to bear off all fifteen checkers wins the game.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/backgammon/box.png\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>The first player to move his or her playing pieces off the board wins the game.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"buy-backgammon.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Backgammon Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:46:29.240Z"),
            ~~~~~~~~~

        ?   victoryConditions?: String | NullableStringFieldUpdateOperationsInput | Null,
        ?   game?: GameUpdateOneRequiredWithoutRulesNestedInput
          }
        })

            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Yahtzee Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/yahtzee.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>1 Yahtzee Dice cup</li>\n<li>5 Dice</li>\n<li>10 Bonus Chips</li>\n<li>80 Score Cards.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p>Roll a die to see who starts. Play continues clockwise.</p>\n\n<p>Write each player's name on the score card, in the order of play (pen not included).</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<div class=\"box grey2_border red_bg\">\n\n<p>Roll dice to get the highest score after all 13 rounds.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<div class=\"box red_border\">\n\n<p>In Short:</p>\n<ol>\n<li>Roll up to 3 times each turn to rack up the best possible score.</li>\n<li>Decide which dice combo you're going for.</li>\n<li>After each turn, write your score in one empty box on the score card.</li>\n</ol>\n\n</div>\n\n<p>Each player in turn places all 5 dice in the cup, shakes the cup and rolls out the dice. Each turn consists of a maximum of three rolls.</p>\n\n<p>The first roll must be made with all five dice. If the player chooses to roll a second and, if desired, a third time, he may pick up any or all the dice and roll again.</p>\n\n<p>It is the skillful use of these two optional rolls of the dice that can turn an unlucky first or second roll into a high-scoring turn. A score must be entered after the last roll in the appropriate box or a zero entered in a box of the player's choice.</p>\n\n<p>Each player keeps his own score on a YAHTZEE score card to be marked with the player's name.</p>\n\n<p>To determine who goes first, each player places all five dice in the dice cup and rolls out all the dice; the player with the highest total starts the game. The play then continues clockwise.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Tutorial Video</h2>\n\n<iframe width=\"560\" height=\"420\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/6kxYPfRoHlY\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"autoplay; encrypted-media\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Turn</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/box.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Fill in one empty box in the column under your name each turn.</p>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Your first roll:</h5>\n\n<p>Roll all 5 dice.</p>\n\n<p>If you get the exact combo you want, mark your score card right away. Otherwise, continue with your 2nd roll.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Your second roll:</h5>\n\n<p>Set aside any keepers' and re-roll the rest.</p>\n\n<p>Hate them all? Re-roll them all.</p>\n\n<p>If you get the exact combo you need, mark your score card. Otherwise, continue with your 3rd roll.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Your third and final roll:</h5>\n\n<p>If you still haven't nailed a combo, or just want to maximize your score:</p>\n\n<p>Roll some or all of your dice (as above), even any keepers you might have set aside.</p>\n\n<p>You must enter a score at the end of this roll, whether or not you like your dice.</p>\n\n<p>If your roll doesn't suit any of your empty boxes, you have to enter a zero somewhere. BUT scoring even a single die value is better than a zero.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Scoring</h2>\n\n<p>There are 13 scoring boxes. On each completed turn, the player must score in one of the 13 boxes. The boxes may be filled in any order, according to the player's best judgment.</p>\n\n<p>The score card has an upper section and a lower section:</p>\n\n<h4>Upper Section</h4>\n\n<p>The upper section contains six boxes labelled 1 to 6 ( \"Aces\", \"Twos\", \"Threes\", \"Fours\", \"Fives\" and \"Sixes\").</p>\n\n<p>When a player chooses to score in the Upper Section, he counts and adds only the dice with the same number and enters the total of these dice in the appropriate box.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/game1.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>If a player, on his turn, rolls and elects to take his score in the Upper Section, he would enter 9 in the \"Threes\" box.</p>\n\n<p>But he is also allowed to score a 2 in the \"Twos\" Box or a 4 in the \"Fours\" box. The players can also score a zero in the Aces box.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/score-sheet.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>Lower Section</h4>\n\n<p>In the lower section, you score for various combinations and they are played exactly as indicated:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<h4>3 of a kind</h4>\n\n<p>The \"3 of a kind\" box may be filled in only if the dice show at least 3 of the same number. For example:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/game3.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<br>\n\n<p>This would score 18 (total of all dice).</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h4>4 of a kind</h4>\n\n<p>Score the total of all dice provided they include 4 dice of the same number. For example:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/game4.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>This would score 14 (total of all dice) in the \"4 of a kind\" box.</p>\n\n<p>(You may also score in \"3 of a kind\" or in the upper section).</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h4>Full House</h4>\n\n<p>You need to roll both a \"3 of a kind\" and a pair. A \"Full House\" scores 25 points.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/game5.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>(You may also score in \"3 of a kind\" or in the upper section).</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h4>Small Straight</h4>\n\n<p>This is any sequence of four numbers, such as:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/game6.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>The 5th die can be any number. Any \"Small Straight\" is valued at 30 points.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h4>Large Straight</h4>\n\n<p>This is a sequence of five numbers, either:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/game7.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>A \"Large Straight\" is valued at 40 points.</p>\n\n<p>(You may also score a Large Straight in the Small Straight box).</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h4>Chance</h4>\n\n<p>This offers a player the opportunity to score on any turn where he does not choose to score in any of the other open boxes. Mark score by totalling number of points on all dice.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/game9.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>This combination scores 24 points.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h4>Yahtzee</h4>\n\n<p>This is any \"five of a kind\". Score 50 points in the \"Yahtzee\" box.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/game8.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Bonus</h2>\n\n<div class=\"box grey4_border\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/game2.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>You get a bonus of 35 points if the total number of points you scored in the upper section is 63 or higher.</p>\n\n<p>(For quick calculation, 63 may be reached by scoring 3 \"Aces\", \"Twos\", and so on through \"Sixes\"). A bonus can be obtained by having a total of 63 points or more scored in any manner in the Upper Section</p>\n\n<br>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>If you roll multiple Yahtzee, you can rack up a seriously high score.</p>\n\n<p>If you roll a Yahtzee and you already filled in the Yahtzee box with a 50 , you get a 100-point bonus!</p>\n\n<p>Take one bonus chip, then place a checkmark in the Yahtzee bonus box . Then fill in one of the 13 boxes on your score card according to the Joker Rules (see below).</p>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Joker Rules</h2>\n\n<p>Score the total of all 5 dice in the appropriate Upper Section box.</p>\n\n<p>If this box has already been filled in, score a follows in any open Lower Section Box:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>3 of a Kind: total of all 5 dice</li>\n<li>4 of a Kind: total of all 5 dice</li>\n<li>Full House: 25 points</li>\n<li>Small Straight: 30points</li>\n<li>Large Straight: 40 points</li>\n<li>Chance: total of all 5 dice</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>If the appropriate Upper Section box and all Lower Section boxes are filled in, you must enter a zero in any open Upper Section box.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<div class=\"box red_border box_shadow\">\n\n<h3>Play Online</h3>\n\n<p>Do you want to play this great game online now? We offer a free online game on this website.</p>\n\n<p><a href=\"game.php\">Click here to play</a> and to enjoy. Good luck.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<a href=\"game.php\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/yatzy.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</a>\n\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"box silver_bg\">\n\n<h3>Probabilities</h3>\n<ul>\n<li><b>Two of a Kind</b>: 60.19%</li>\n<li><b>Three of a Kind</b>: 15.43%</li>\n<li><b>Four of a Kind</b>: 1.93%</li>\n<li><b>Full House</b>: 3.86%</li>\n<li><b>Small Straight</b>: 12.35%</li>\n<li><b>Large Straight</b>: 3.09%</li>\n<li><b>Yahtzee</b>: 0.08%</li>\n</ul>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<div class=\"box grey2_border red_bg\">\n\n<p>The player with the highest grand total at the end of all 13 rounds is the winner.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"box box_radius box_border\">\n\n<h3>Turn Example</h3>\n\n<h5>First Roll</h5>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/game10.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>You could roll again for Fours, \"3 of a Kind\" or Large Straight.</p>\n\n<p>You've already a Small Straight, so, it's risky, but the 2/3/4/5 gives you a good chance of rolling either an Ace or a Six in the next two rolls. You decide to set aside the Small Straight and reroll one die.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h5>Second Roll</h5>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/game11.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>You roll a Two. You could reroll the die again for your Large Straight, or set aside the two Twos for a \"3 of a Kind\". You decide to set aside the twos and reroll the remaining 3 dice.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h5>Third and Final Roll</h5>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/yahtzee/game12.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>You roll 1 Two and 2 Threes. You could score 6 points for Twos, 12 points for \"3 of a Kind\", or 25 points for \"Full House\".</p>\n\n<p>You decide on the Full House because this combination can be tough to roll later in the game. Also, you are ahead in the Upper Section, so you may not need 3 Twos for your 35-point Bonus.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"tips.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",

→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 76
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>UNO Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/uno/uno.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/uno/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n<ul>\n<li>112 cards as follows:</li>\n<li>19 Blue cards - 0 to 9</li>\n<li>19 Green cards - 0 to 9</li>\n<li>19 Red cards - 0 to 9</li>\n<li>19 Yellow cards - 0 to 9</li>\n<li>8 Skip cards - 2 each in Blue, Green, Red and Yellow</li>\n<li>8 Reverse cards - 2 each in Blue, Green, Red and Yellow</li>\n<li>8 Draw 2 cards - 2 each in Blue, Green, Red and Yellow</li>\n<li>4 Wild cards</li>\n<li>4 Wild Draw 4 cards</li>\n<li>4 Blank Cards</li>\n<li>Instructions</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>The first player to play all of the cards in their hand in each round scores points for the cards their opponents are left holding. The first player to score 500 points wins the game.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p>Each player draws a card. Player with the highest point value is the dealer. Shuffle the deck. Each player is dealt 7 cards.</p>\n\n<p>Place the remaining cards facedown to form a draw pile. Turn over the top card of the draw pile to begin a discard pile. If the top card is a Wild or Wild Draw 4, return it to the deck and pick another card. For all other cards, see directions that follow.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Special Cards</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/uno/draw2.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Draw 2 Card</h4>\n\n<p>When you play this card, the next person to play must draw 2 cards and forfeit his/her turn.</p>\n\n<p>If this card is turned up at the beginning of play, the first player must draw two cards. This card may only be played on a matching color or on another Draw 2 card.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/uno/reverse.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<h4>Reverse Card</h4>\n\n<p>This card reverses direction of play. Play to the left now passes to the right, and vice versa.</p>\n\n<p>If this card is turned up at the beginning of play, the player to the right now plays first, and play then goes to the right instead of left.</p>\n\n<p>This card may only be played on a matching color or on another Reverse card.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/uno/skip.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<h4>Skip Card</h4>\n\n<p>The next person in line to play after this card is played loses his/her turn and is \"skipped\".</p>\n\n<p>If this card is turned up at the beginning of play, the first player (the player to the left of the dealer) is skipped.</p>\n\n<p>This card may only be played on a matching color or on another Skip card.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/uno/wild.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<h4>Wild Card</h4>\n\n<p>When you play this card, you may change the color being played to any color (including the current color) to continue play. You may play a Wild card even if you have another playable card in hand.</p>\n\n<p>If this card is turned up at the beginning of play, the person to the left of the dealer chooses the color to begin play and plays the first card.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/uno/wild4.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<h4>Wild Draw 4 Card</h4>\n\n<p>This card allows you to call the next color played and requires the next player to pick 4 cards from the DRAW pile and forfeit his/her turn. However, there is a hitch!</p>\n\n<p>You can only play this card when you don't have a card in your hand that matches the color of the card previously played. If turned up at the beginning of play, return this card to the deck and pick another card.</p>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> A Player may play a \"Wild Draw Four\" card even if they have a matching number or word card of a different color in their hand. If you suspect that a player has played a Wild Draw 4 card illegally, you may challenge them.</p>\n\n<p>A challenged player must show his/her hand to the player who challenged. If the challenged player is guilty, he/she must draw the 4 cards. If the challenged player is not guilty, the challenger must draw the 4 cards, plus 2 additional cards.</p>\n\n<p>Only the person required to draw the 4 cards can make the challenge.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<p>What are these extra cards for?</p>\n\n<h4>Blank Card</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/uno/blank.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>This is a special card that you may use in one of two ways. If a card from your UNO deck is lost or damaged you may use the Blank Card as a replacement.</p>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> If you find that your deck is missing one of the yellow 7's you would simply replace it by taking the yellow Blank Card, marking a \"7\" on it and adding it back into the deck.</p>\n\n<p>If your family has a special UNO rule you prefer to play with, you may write that rule on the Blank Cards and add them straight to the deck.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/uno/cards.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Player to the left of the dealer plays first. Play passes to the left to start. Match the top card on the DISCARD pile either by number, color or word.</p>\n\n<p>For example, if the card is a Green 7, you must play a Green card or any color 7. Or, you may play any Wild card or a Wild Draw 4 card. If you don't have anything that matches, you must pick a card from the DRAW pile. If you draw a card you can play, play it.</p>\n\n<p>Otherwise, play moves to the next person. Before playing your next to last card, you must say \"UNO\". If you don't say UNO and another player catches you with just one card before the next player begins their turn you must pick FOUR more cards from the DRAW pile.</p>\n\n<p>If you are not caught before the next player either draws a card from the DRAW pile or draws a card from their hand to play, you do not have to draw the extra cards. Once a player plays their last card, the hand is over. Points are tallied (see Scoring section) and you start over again.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Going Out</h2>\n\n<p>If you forget to say, \"UNO\" before your card touches the DISCARD pile, but you \"catch\" yourself before any other player catches you, you are safe and not subject to the 4- card penalty.</p>\n\n<p>You may not catch a player for failure to say \"UNO!\" until his/her second-to-last card touches the DISCARD pile. Also, you may not catch a player for failure to say it after the next player begins his/her turn. \"Beginning a turn\" is defined as either drawing a card from the DRAW pile or drawing a card from your hand to play.</p>\n\n<p>If the last card played in a hand is a Draw 2 card or Wild Draw 4 card, the next player must draw 2 or 4 cards, depending upon the card played. These cards are counted when points are totaled.</p>\n\n<p>If no one is out of cards by the time the DRAW pile is depleted, reshuffle the DISCARD pile and continue play.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Scoring</h2>\n\n<p>If you are first to get rid of all your cards, you get points for the cards left in the other players hands. Use the included score pad to record your score after each hand. Each card is worth the following:</p>\n\n<table class=\"table table-condensed table-striped border\">\n<thead>\n<tr><th>All number cards (0-9)</th><th>Face Value</th></tr></thead>\n<tbody>\n<tr><td>Draw 2</td><td>20 Points</td></tr>\n<tr><td>Reverse</td><td>20 Points</td></tr>\n<tr><td>Skip</td><td>20 Points</td></tr>\n<tr><td>Wild</td><td>50 Points</td></tr>\n<tr><td>Wild Draw 4</td><td>50 Points</td></tr>\n<tr><td>Blank</td><td>?</td></tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/uno/score.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The <b>winner is the first player to reach 500 points</b>. However, the game may be scored by keeping a running total of the points each player is caught with at the end of each hand.</p>\n\n<p>When one player reaches 500 points, the player with the lowest points is the winner.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Reneging</h2>\n\n<p>You may choose not to play a playable card from your hand. If so, you must draw a card from the DRAW pile. If playable, that card can be played, but you may not play a card from your hand after the draw.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Check other UNO Versions</h2>\n\n<ul><li><a href=\"angry-birds-game-rules.php\">UNO Angry Birds</a></li><li><a href=\"attack-game-rules.php\">UNO Attack</a></li><li><a href=\"blast-game-rules.php\">UNO Blast</a></li><li><a href=\"boom-o-game-rules.php\">UNO Boom-o</a></li><li><a Invalid `prisma.gameRule.update()` invocation in
