→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 82
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>BANG! Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/bang/bang.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<p>BANG! is a shootout game, in Spaghetti Western style, between a group of Outlaws and the Sheriff, who is their primary target.</p>\n\n<p>The Deputies incognitos help the Sheriff, but there is also a Renegade pursuing his own goal! In BANG! each player plays one of these roles, and represents a famous Wild West inspired character.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/bang/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n<ul>\n<li>7 Roles: 1 Sheriff, 2 Deputies,<br>3 Outlaws, 1 Renegade</li>\n<li>16 Characters</li>\n<li>7 Summary cards</li>\n<li>80 Playing cards</li>\n<li>30 Bullets</li>\n<li>7 Playing boards;</li>\n<li>Instructions</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<div class=\"box grey4_border box_shadow\">\n\n<p>Each player has his own goal:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/bang/game8.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p><b>Sheriff:</b> must eliminate all the Outlaws and the Renegade, to protect law and order.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/bang/game8_.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p><b>Outlaws:</b> they would like to kill the Sheriff, but they have no scruples \" about eliminating each other to gain rewards!</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/bang/game9_.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p><b>Deputies:</b> they help and protect the Sheriff, and share his same goal, W at all costs!</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/bang/game9.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p><b>Renegade:</b> he wants to be the new Sheriff; his goal is to be the last character in play.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p>(Before the first game remove carefully the bullet tokens from their frames). Each player takes a playing board (place it in front of you to hold your role, your character, your weapon and your bullets).</p>\n\n<p>Take as many role cards as the number of players, divided as follows:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><b>4 players:</b> Sheriff, 1 Renegade, 2 Outlaws</li>\n<li><b>5 players:</b> Sheriff, 1 Renegade, 2 Outlaws, 1 Deputy</li>\n<li><b>6 players:</b> Sheriff, 1 Renegade, 3 Outlaws, 1 Deputy</li>\n<li><b>7 players:</b> Sheriff, 1 Renegade, 3 Outlaws, 2 Deputy</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Shuffle the cards reveals himself by turning his card face up. All other players look at their role but keep it secret.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/bang/game10.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Shuffle the characters and give one face up to each player. Each player now announces the name of his character and reads his ability. Each player takes as many bullets as shown on his character.</p>\n\n<p>The Sheriff plays the game with one additional bullet: if his character card shows three bullets, he is considered for all effects to have four; if he has four bullets, then the Sheriff plays with five.</p>\n\n<p>Put the remaining roles, boards and character cards back in the box.</p>\n\n<p>Shuffle the playing cards, and give each player as many cards, face down, as the bullets he has. Put the remaining playing cards face down in the middle of the table, as a draw pile. Leave room for the discard pile.</p>\n\n<div class=\" notepad\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/bang/game12.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> for your first few games, you can try a simplified version of the game by removing all cards with the symbol of a book before getting started.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Characters</h4>\n\n<p>Each Western character has some special abilities, which make you unique. The bullets you have show how many life points you begin the game with, i.e. how many times you can be hit before being eliminated from play.</p>\n\n<p>Moreover, the bullets indicate how many cards the player can hold in his hand at the end of his turn (hand size limit).</p>\n\n<div class=\"box box_radius box_border\">\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> Jesse Jones has 4 life points: he can be hit four times before being eliminated from the game. Moreover, he can hold up to four cards in his hands at the end of his turn.</p>\n\n<p>If during game Jesse loses one life point and he is down at 3, he can only hold up to three cards in his hand at the end of his turn. But fear not! Life points can be recovered!</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>The Sheriff begins. The game is played in turns, in clockwise order. Each player's turn is divided into three phases:</p>\n\n<div class=\"box yellow2_border\">\n<ol>\n<li>Draw two cards;</li>\n<li>Play any number of cards;</li>\n<li>Discard excess cards.</li>\n</ol>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n<h2>1. Draw two cards</h2>\n\n<p>Draw the top two cards from the draw pile. As soon as the draw pile is empty, shuffle the discard pile to create a new playing deck.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>2. Play any number of cards</h2>\n\n<p>Now you may play cards to help yourself or hurt the other players, trying to eliminate them. You can only play cards during your turn (exception: Missed! and Beer, see below).</p>\n\n<p>You are not forced to play cards during this phase. You can play any number of cards; there are only three limitations:</p>\n\n<div class=\"box yellow2_border\">\n<ul>\n<li>you can play only 1 BANG! card per turn; (this applies only to BANG! cards, not to cards with the symbol)</li>\n<li>you can have only 1 copy of any one card in play; (one card is a copy of another if they have the same name)</li>\n<li>you can have only 1 weapon in play. (when you play a new weapon, discard the one you have in play)</li>\n</ul>\n\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"box box_radius box_border\">\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> If you put a Barrel in play, you cannot play another one, since you would end up having two copies of the same card in front of you.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<p>There are two types of cards: brown-bordered cards (= play and discard) and blue-bordered cards (= weapons and other objects).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/bang/game13.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<b>\n\n</b><p><b>Brown-bordered cards</b> are played by putting them directly into the discard pile and applying the effect described with text or with symbols on the cards (illustrated in the next paragraphs).</p>\n\n<p><b>Blue-bordered cards</b> are played face up in front of you (exception: Jail). Blue cards in front of you are hence defined to be \"in play\".</p>\n\n<p>The effect of these cards lasts until they are discarded or removed somehow (e.g. through the play of a Cat Balou), or a special event occurs (e.g. in the case of Dynamite). There is no limit on the cards you can have in front of you provided that they do not share the same name.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>3. Discard Excess Cards</h2>\n\n<p>Once the second phase is over (you do not want to or cannot play any more cards), then you must discard from your hand any cards exceeding your hand-size limit.</p>\n\n<p>Remember that your hand size limit, at the end of your turn, is equal to the number of bullets (i.e. life points) you currently have.</p>\n\n<p>Then it is the next player's turn, in clockwise order.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Distance Between Players</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/bang/game14.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The distance between two players is the minimum number of places between them, counting clockwise or counterclockwise (see figure). The distance is very important, because all cards with a sight take it into account.</p>\n\n<p>Normally you can reach only targets (players or cards) within a distance of 1 (note the <img src=\"scraped_rules/images/bang/game11.jpg\"> of your Colt .45 on your playing board).</p>\n\n<p>When a character is eliminated, he is no longer counted when evaluating the distance: some players will get \"closer\" when someone is eliminated.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Eliminating a character</h3>\n\n<p>When you lose your last life point, you are eliminated and your game is over, unless you immediately play a Beer (see below).</p>\n\n<p>When you are eliminated from the game, show your role card and discard all the cards you have in hand and in play.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Penalties and Rewards</h3>\n\n<div class=\"box yellow2_border\">\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>If the Sheriff eliminates a Deputy, the Sheriff must discard all the cards he has in hand and in play.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Any player eliminating an Outlaw (even if the eliminating player is himself an Outlaw!) must draw a reward of 3 cards from the deck.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>The game ends when one of the following conditions is met:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>the Sheriff is killed. If the Renegade is the only one alive, then he wins. Otherwise, the Outlaws win;</p></li>\n\n<li><p>all the Outlaws and the Renegade are killed. The Sheriff and his Deputies win.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<div class=\"box box_radius box_border\">\n\n<p><i>Example 1:</i> All the Outlaws are eliminated, but the Renegade is still in play. In this case, the game continues. The Renegade must now face the Sheriff and his Deputies alone.</p>\n\n<p><i>Example 2:</i> The Sheriff is killed, but all Outlaws are eliminated, and one Deputy and the Renegade are still in play. The game ends with the Outlaws winning! They achieved their goal at the cost of their own lives!</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<h4>New Game</h4>\n\n<p>If you play more than one game in a row, players still \"alive\" at the end of the game may choose to keep their character (but not the cards in hand or in play!) for the following game; players which have been eliminated must draw a new character randomly.</p>\n\n<p>If you want to give each player the opportunity of playing the Sheriff, you may decide, before starting the game, to pass this role among players from game to game, randomly assigning the other roles.</p>\n\n<p>Now that you are familiar with the rules, let's see the cards of BANG! in detail!</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<div class=\"infobox\"><div class=\"info-icon info-icon3\"><i></i></div><div class=\"infobox-body\">\n\n<h3>Remember</h3>\n<ul>\n<li>Any card with a Missed! symbol can be used to cancel the effect of a card with a BANG! symbol</li>\n<li>you can only play one BANG! card per turn, but you can play any number of other cards which show the symbol</li>\n<li>you cannot have two cards with the same name in front of you</li>\n<li>you can only have one weapon in play, but at least you always have a Colt .45</li>\n<li>weapons do not change the distance between players, they represent only your shooting range</li>\n<li>Beer has no effect when there are only 2 players left in the game</li>\n<li>when you are losing your last life point, you can only play a Beer, and not a Saloon.</li>\n</ul>\n\n</div></div>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Curiosity</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/bang/game59.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>In order to keep track of your life points, you can use another character card, from the ones left over. Turn it face down and cover / uncover the bullets by sliding your character card on it, just like in the picture.</p>\n\n<p>This makes easier to bring BANG! with you and play it anywhere!</p>\n\n<p><i>Jesse Jones with three life points.</i></p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"cards.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "BANG! Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:47:30.063Z"),

  294 if (existingRule) {
  295   // Update existing rule
→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 83
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Codenames Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/codenames/codenames.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<h2>Game Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/codenames/components.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p>Players split up into two teams of similar size and skill. You need at least four players (two teams of two) for a standard game.</p>\n\n<p>Each team chooses one player to be their spymaster. Both spymasters sit on the same side of the table. The other players sit across from their spymasters.</p>\n\n<p>They are field operatives.</p>\n\n<p>Randomly choose 25 codenames and place them on the table in a 5-by-5 grid.</p>\n\n<p>Note: While shuffling the codename cards, be sure to flip over half the deck once in a while. This will mix the words more thoroughly.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>The key</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/codenames/key.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Each game has one key that reveals the secret identities of the cards on the table. The spymasters should choose the key card randomly and slide it into the stand between them.</p>\n\n<p>Any side can be up. Don't think about it. Just slide it into the stand. And don't let the field operatives see it.</p>\n\n<p>The key corresponds to the grid on the table. Blue squares correspond to words that Blue Team must guess (blue agents). Red squares correspond to words that Red Team must guess (red agents).</p>\n\n<p>Pale squares are innocent bystanders, and the black square is an assassin who should never be contacted at all.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Starting team</h2>\n\n<p>The four lights around the edge of the key card indicate which team starts. The starting team has 9 words to guess. The other team has 8. The starting team will give the first clue of the game.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Agent cards</h2>\n\n<table>\n\n<tbody><tr><td width=\"300\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/codenames/red.jpg\" class=\"board\"><br><span class=\"fontbig\">8 red agents</span></td>\n\n<td><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/codenames/blue.jpg\" class=\"board\"><br><span class=\"fontbig\">8 blue agents</span></td></tr>\n\n</tbody></table><br><br>\n\n<p>The red agent cards go in a stack in front of the red spymaster. The blue agent cards should be in front of the blue spymaster. This helps everyone remember which team they are on.</p>\n\n<div class=\"fontbig\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/codenames/double-agent.jpg\" class=\"board\"><br>1 double agent</div>\n\n<p>The double agent belongs to whichever team starts. Flip it to that team's color. It will be one of that team's agent cards for the duration of the game.</p>\n\n<table class=\"\">\n\n<tbody><tr><td width=\"300\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/codenames/innocent.jpg\" class=\"board\"><br><span class=\"fontbig\">7 innocent bystanders </span></td>\n\n<td><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/codenames/assassin.jpg\" class=\"board\"><br><span class=\"fontbig\">1 assassin</span></td></tr>\n\n</tbody></table><br><br>\n\n<p>The innocent bystander cards and the assassin should be kept in between, where both spymasters can reach them easily.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Tutorial Video</h2>\n\n<iframe width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"//www.youtube.com/embed/CgIEasXPiuU?rel=0\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>Teams take turns. The starting team is indicated by the 4 lights on the edges of the key card.</p>\n\n<h3>Giving a clue</h3>\n\n<p>If you are the spymaster, you are trying to think of a one-word clue that relates to some of the words your team is trying to guess. When you think you have a good clue, you say it. You also say one number, which tells your teammates how many codenames are related to your clue.</p>\n\n<p>Example: Two of your words are NUT and BARK. Both of these grow on trees, so you say tree: 2.</p>\n\n<p>You are allowed to give a clue for only one word (cashew: 1 ) but it's fun to try for two or more. Getting four words with one clue is a big accomplishment.</p>\n\n<h4>One Word</h4>\n\n<p>Your clue must be only one word. You are not allowed to give extra hints. For example, don't say, \"This may be a bit of a stretch…\" You are playing Codenames. It's always a bit of a stretch.</p>\n\n<p>Your clue cannot be any of the codenames visible on the table. On later turns, some codenames will be covered up, so a clue that is not legal now might be legal later.</p>\n\n<h3>Making contact</h3>\n\n<p>When the spymaster gives a clue, his or her field operatives try to figure out what it means. They can debate it amongst themselves, but the spymaster must keep a straight face.</p>\n\n<p>The operatives indicate their official guess when one of them touches one of the codenames on the table.</p>\n\n<ul>\n\n<li><p>If the field operative touches a card belonging to his or her team, the spymaster covers the word with an agent card in that color. The team may guess another word.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>If the field operative touches an innocent bystander, the spymaster covers it with an innocent bystander card. This ends the turn.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>If the field operative touches a card belonging to the other team, the word is covered by one of the other team's agent cards. This ends the turn. (And it helps the other team).</p></li>\n\n<li><p>If the field operative touches the assassin, the word is covered by the assassin card. This ends the game! The team that contacted the assassin loses.</p></li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<p>Tip: Before saying your clue out loud, make sure it doesn't relate to the assassin.</p>\n\n<h4>Number of Guesses</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/codenames/board.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The field operatives must always make at least one guess. Any wrong guess ends the turn immediately, but if the field operatives guess a word of their team's color, they can keep guessing.</p>\n\n<p>You can stop guessing at any time, but usually you want to guess as many words as the spymaster said. Sometimes you might even want to guess one more:</p>\n\n<p>Example: Red Team's first clue was tree: 2. The red operative wanted to guess ORANGE and NUT.</p>\n\n<p>She guessed ORANGE first. That was an innocent bystander, so she did not get a chance to guess NUT.</p>\n\n<p>Blue Team took a turn and correctly guessed two words. Now it is Red Team's turn again.</p>\n\n<p>The red spymaster says river: 3. The red operative is pretty sure the AMAZON is a river, so she touches that card. The spymaster covers it with a red agent card, so she gets to go again. A river has a BED, so she touches that codename. It's also red, so she can go again.</p>\n\n<p>She's not sure of the third river word. She picks NUT. This has nothing to do with river. She is guessing a word from the previous clue.</p>\n\n<p>NUT is a red word. The operative has made 3 correct guesses for the clue river: 3. She is allowed one final guess. She can try to find the third river word, or she can try to find the other tree word. Or she can stop at three and let Blue Team have a turn.</p>\n\n<p>You are allowed only one extra guess. In the example above, the red operative would be allowed 4 guesses because her spymaster said the number 3. When the field operatives say they are done guessing (or when they guess wrong) it is the other team's turn.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game flow</h2>\n\n<p>Spymasters take turns giving clues. Each turn covers up at least one word, which makes guessing progressively easier.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the game</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/codenames/spymaster.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The game ends when one team has all their words covered. That team wins.</p>\n\n<p>It is possible to win on the other team's turn if they guess your last word.</p>\n\n<p>The game can end early if a field operative makes contact with the assassin. That operative's team loses.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Setup for the Next Game</h3>\n\n<p>Do other people want a chance to be spymasters? Setup for the second game is easy. Remove the cards covering the codenames and put them back in their stacks.</p>\n\n<p>Now just flip over the 25 codenames, and you're ready to go!</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>What's the timer for?</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/codenames/box.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Sorry. We almost forgot. You see, we don't use the sand timer very often.</p>\n\n<p>If a player is thinking too long, any player can flip the sand timer and ask the slow player to make a decision before time runs out.</p>\n\n<p>If you are having trouble, you can even use the sand timer on yourself. If you can't find a good clue before time runs out, just give a clue for your hardest word and keep thinking while the other team plays.</p>\n\n<p>If you prefer to play with strict time limits, you can download our timer app at codenamesgame.com.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"valid-clues.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",

→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 84
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Dixit Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dixit/dixit.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<h2>Game Components</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>One game board inside the box (scoring track)</li>\n<li>84 cards</li>\n<li>36 voting tokens in 6 different colours numbered from 1 to 6</li>\n<li>6 wooden rabbits (rabbeeples)</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dixit/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p>Each player chooses one rabbit and place it on the 0 space of the scoring track. Shuffle the 84 images and give 6 of them to each player. Make a draw pile with the remaining cards.</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>With 4 players, each one takes 4 voting tokens (from 1 to 4).</li>\n<li>With 5 players, each one takes 5 voting tokens (from 1 to 5).</li>\n<li>With 6 players, each one takes 6 voting tokens (from 1 to 6).</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<p>Note: Do not show your hand of cards to anyone.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<h3>The storyteller</h3>\n\n<p>One player is the storyteller for the turn. He looks at the 6 images in his hand. From one of these, he makes up a sentence and says it out loud (without showing the card to the other players).</p>\n\n<p>The sentence can take different forms: it can be made of one word or more, it can even be a sound. The sentence can be either invented or be inspired from an existing work of art (poetry or song sample, movie title, proverb, etc).</p>\n\n<p>Who is the storyteller for the first turn? The first player who has found a sentence declares she'll be the storyteller for the first turn.</p>\n\n<h3>Choosing a card for the storyteller</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dixit/cards.jpg\" class=\"\">\n\n<p>The other players select amongst their 6 images the one that best matches the sentence made up by the storyteller.</p>\n\n<p>Then, each of them gives their selected card to the storyteller, without showing it to the others.</p>\n\n<p>The storyteller shuffles his card with all the received cards. He then randomly places them face up on the table. The card on the left will be number 1, the one next to it will be number 2, and so on...</p>\n\n<h3>Finding the storyteller's image: the vote</h3>\n\n<p>The goal of the other players is to find which image is from the storyteller amongst the displayed ones. Each player secretly votes for the card that he believes belongs to the storyteller (who doesn't vote).</p> <p>To do so, he places face down in front of him the voting token corresponding to the image he voted for. Once everybody has voted, all the voting tokens are revealed and placed on their corresponding images.</p>\n\n<p>Note: You're not allowed to vote for your own image.</p>\n\n<h3>End of turn</h3>\n\n<p>Each player draws cards into his hand until he has 6. The storyteller for the new turn is the player to the left of the current one (and we keep going clockwise for the following turns).</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Scoring</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dixit/scoring.png\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If all the players have found the storyteller's image, or if none have found it, then the storyteller doesn't score any points and everyone else scores 2 points.<!--</p-->\n\n</p><p>In any other case, the storyteller scores 3 points and so do the players who found his image.</p>\n\n<p>Each player, except the storyteller, scores one point for each vote that was placed on his or her image.</p>\n\n<p>The players move their rabbits along the scoring track by the same number of spaces as points scored.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the game</h2>\n\n<p>The game ends when the last card has been drawn. The player who's the furthest on the scoring track is the winner.</p>\n\n<p>Each player then counts the number of unit squares in his/her remaining pieces (1 unit square = -1 point).</p>\n\n<p>A player earns +15 points if all his/her pieces have been placed on the board plus 5 additional bonus points if the last piece placed on the board was the smallest piece (one square).</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"tips.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",

          where: {
            id: 85
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Telestrations Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/telestrations/telestrations.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<p>WELCOME to Telestrations, the visual version of the classic \"telephone\"game... where your sketches &amp; guesses can create laugh-out-loud party fun! It's the game where you DRAW what you see, then GUESS what you saw!</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/telestrations/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n<ul>\n<li>142 \"This Side\" &amp; \"That Side\"Cards in Card Box (over 1,700 words),</li>\n<li>8 Erasable Sketch Books</li>\n<li>8 Dry-Erase Markers</li>\n<li>8 Clean-Up Cloths</li>\n<li>60 Second Timer</li>\n<li>1 Die</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p>Place card box, sand timer, clean-up cloths &amp; die in center of the group.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Decide as a group which cards everyone will be using, \"THIS SIDE\" or \"THAT SIDE\".</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Each player selects a sketch book, one marker &amp; one card.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Write your name in the front of your sketch book and remember the color of your coil.</p></li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n\n<p>Now The Fun Can Begin.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>1. Getting A Word</h2>\n\n<p>Select a player to roll the die to start the round. Match the number rolled to the word on your card. Secretly write it in your book. Don't say it loud or show it to anyone!</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/telestrations/game1.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> If there is a blank space on your card that matches the number rolled, you get to make up any word(s) you want. If you see an underlined category, such as \"TV SHOW\", you get to make up any word(_) in that category.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/telestrations/game1_.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>If you see me on the bottom of your card you get to pick any word you want from the card!</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>2. How Many Are Playing</h2>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/telestrations/even.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Turn to 'SKETCH IT\" page 1. Get ready to secretly draw your word. Now continue on to step 3.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/telestrations/sketchit.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/telestrations/odd.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Turn to \"SKETCH IT\" page 1 and then...</p>\n\n<h5>PASS BOOK TO PLAYER ON LEFT!</h5>\n\n<p>That player secretly looks at your word, then gets ready to draw it on \"SKETCH IT\" page 1. Now continue on to setp 3.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n<h2>3. Sketching</h2>\n\n<p>Everyone should now be on \"SKETCH IT\" page 1.</p>\n\n<p>Flip the timer. You have 60 seconds to secretly draw the word. When time's up, take a couple seconds to finish up.</p>\n\n<p>Don't leave it blank! Turn to page 2 to hide your sketch &amp; pass open book to player on your left.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/telestrations/game4.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>4. Guessing</h2>\n\n<p>Now everyone should be on \"GUESS IT\" page 2.</p>\n\n<p>Flip back to the previous page &amp; take a few seconds to secretly look at the sketch. Then return to page 2 to write your guess. Flip forward to next page &amp; pass open book to player on your left.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/telestrations/game5.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>5. Round &amp; Round it Goes</h2>\n\n<p>Flip the 60 second timer... everyone continues to sketch, pass &amp; guess until players get their own book back. Note the color of your sketch book coil to ensure it is your book.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/telestrations/game6.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>6. The Big Reveal</h2>\n\n<p>Now that everyone has their own book back, it's time for the Big Reveal! Take turns flipping through &amp; sharing the SKETCHIN &amp; GUESSIN' outcomes in your book!</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/telestrations/game7.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h3>Helpful Hints</h3>\n\n<h5>Sketchin' Hints</h5>\n\n<p>No letters or numbers, your best to draw your word, me, it will lead to the most fun!</p>\n\n<h5>Guessin' Hints</h5>\n\n<p>Don't just put a question mark or leave the page blank. Write any guess... no matter how silly it may seem.</p>\n\n<h5>Passin' Hints</h5>\n\n<p>When you're finished sketchin' or guessin', flip forward a page and wait until all players are ready. Everyone passes open books at the same time.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Are You A Winner</h2>\n\n<p>Did you have fun? Well, then you've won! What about keeping score? If you'd like to do so, there are two options in the \"scoring'' section.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>New Game</h2>\n\n<p>Wanna play again? I don't blame you! Here's whatcha do... First, everyone erase pages 1 - 8. Next. return used cards to the card box &amp; everyone gets a new card. To mix it up, reverse passing direction for another round of fun &amp; laughter.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Scoring</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/telestrations/scoring.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>So you wanna keep score? Each player will use the score sheet in the front of their book to record their points during each reveal.</p>\n\n<p>A game is played in 3 rounds. After 3 rounds total up your points.The player with the most points... well you know!</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Friendly Scoring</h4>\n\n<p>After you reveal the outcomes in your own book:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p>Give 1 point to the player with your favorite SKETCH in your book.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Give 1 point to the player with your favorite GUESS in your book.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Give yourself 1 point if the last guess matches your secret word. MARKER &amp; BOOK CARE</p></li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Competitive Scoring</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/telestrations/scoring2.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>As you reveal the outcomes in your own book, everyone can score points:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p>Guessers earn 1 point if their guess matches the secret word or previous guess.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Sketchers earn 1 point if their sketch helps a guesser make a match</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Give yourself 1 point if the last guess matches the secret word.</p></li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Twist Things Up</h2>\n\n<p>Here are some fun game play twists for next time:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p>Switch seats or remember to reverse passing direction.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Sketch with your less dominant hand.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Create your own cards with words themed to different categories such as TV shows, movies, famous people, cartoon characters, superheroes, food, animals, sports, family, the 80s (any decade)...or customize words to your next event, like a family reunion, baby shower, bridal shower, block party, etc.</p></li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n\n<blockquote class=\"white\">\n\n<h4>Marker &amp; Book Care</h4>\n\n<p>Make sure all sketch book pages are completely erased and clean before storing back inside game box, as ink may stain the pages. Recap markers after use. If a marker dries out, use any dry-erase marker and keep on playing.</p>\n\n<p>Dry-erase markers may stain fabrics and some surfaces. Protect play area before use. Avoid contact with carpet, clothing, walls and furniture. Keep away from eyes and skin.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"after-dark.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Telestrations Game Rules",

→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 86
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Wavelength Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/wavelength/wavelength.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div><link href=\"https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=&amp;display=swap\" rel=\"stylesheet\">\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/wavelength/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n<ul>\n<li>The Device</li>\n<li>84 spectrum cards</li>\n<li>3 Scoring tokens</li>\n<li>Custom plastic tray</li>\n<li>Rulebook</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Overview</h2>\n\n<p>Wavelength is a social guessing game where two teams compete to read each other's minds.</p>\n\n<p>Teams take turns rotating a dial to where they think a target is located along a spectrum that's hidden behind a screen.</p>\n\n<p>One player from the active team-the Psychic-knows where the target is, but can only give a clue ON THE SPECTRUM between two opposing concepts. After that, their team- mates have to guess where the target is.</p>\n\n<p>Your team's goal:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/wavelength/game.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Turn the red dial as close to the center of the colored target as you can.</p>\n\n<p>Here's the twist:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/wavelength/game1.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>The target is completely hidden behind this blue screen and is in a random location each round.</p>\n\n<p>Fortunately, one of your teammates is psychic and knows exactly where the target is!</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/wavelength/game2.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>They draw a card that has two opposing concepts on it, like \"Underrated - Overrated\" or \"Hot - Cold\".</p>\n\n<p>The psychic gives a clue where the target is located on the spectrum between the two concepts.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/wavelength/game3.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>In this example, the target is slightly to the \"hot\" side, so the Psychic says \"Coffee\" since coffee is hot, but not the hottest thing imaginable.</p>\n\n<p>Now it's up to the psychic's team to discuss the clue and decide where to turn the dial.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/wavelength/game4.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Everyone thinks out loud and ponders very dumb ideas-all while the other team poisons your brain with bad suggestions.</p>\n\n<p>Finally, the psychic opens the screen to reveal whether the dial is in the target area.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/wavelength/game5.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>The closer to the center of the target, the more points your team scores! (The other team also gets a chance to score).</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/wavelength/game6.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Wavelength takes less than a minute to set up and is played entirely in the box: you can just pass the game around without ever taking anything out. To start, place the device (the big plastic thing with the dial and rotating wheel) into the slot in the middle of the box's tray.</p>\n\n<p>Then insert the 3 tokens-the \"heads\" and guessing piece-into their various slots. The diagram on the left shows where everything goes.</p>\n\n<p>Now divide into 2 teams of roughly the same size. Then decide who on those teams will be the Psychics (clue givers) for the first round.</p>\n\n<p>The team that goes first starts at O points. The team that goes second starts at 1 point. We call the teams Left Brain and Right Brain, but you can call yourselves anything you like.</p>\n\n<p>That's it! You're ready to play Wavelength.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>How the game progresses:</p>\n<ol type=\"A\">\n<li><b>Psychic Phase:</b> Current team's Psychic gives clue.</li>\n<li><b>Team Phase:</b> Psych ic's team discusses and turns dial.</li>\n<li><b>Left/right Phase:</b> Other team guesses left/right.</li>\n<li><b>Scoring Phase:</b> Psychic reveals target and points are given.</li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>After Scoring, the other team begins their round UNLESS the catch up rule is triggered, detailed in the next section.</p>\n\n<p>Play continues like this, with teams take turns giving clues, with a new player being the Psychic each time.</p>\n\n<div class=\"box silver2_bg box_radius\">\n\n<h4>An important catch up rule</h4>\n\n<p>No matter how much a team is losing in Wavelength, there's always a chance to catch up. If the Psychic's team scores 4 points, and is still losing to the other team after that round's scoring, they immediately take another turn (with a different player as Psychic).</p>\n\n<p>This means that a team down 9-0 could hypothetically take 3 turns in a row and win.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n<h2>A. Psychic Phase</h2>\n\n<p>Each round begins with the current team's Psychic spinning the wheel to randomize the target's location, drawing a wavelength card, and giving a clue ON THE SPECTRUM between the two concepts on the card.</p>\n\n<p>The Psychic should do all of this secretly, so players on both teams can't see where the target is.</p>\n\n<p>Here's the official order the Psychic should go in (it's a little over-detailed, but in practice it's easy):</p>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<p><b>Close the screen:</b> Rotate the screen using the plastic handle until it's entirely closed and clicks into place.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p><b>Choose a wavelength:</b> Draw 1 wavelength card from the deck. They're double sided, and the Psychic can choose the side they want to use for their clue. On most cards there's a \"normal\" side and a \"weird\" side. Don't think too hard about it: just pick the one you find most interesting!</p>\n\n<p>Place the card in the slot in front of the device, with your chosen side facing forward, and read the card text so both teams can hear.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p><b>Randomize the target location:</b> Turn the wheel-using your fingers along the wavy edges-until you're sure that the target is in a completely random position. The plastic screen should be CLOSED while you spin: you can't keep it open to select the target's location.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p><b>Open the screen:</b> Using the plastic handle, open the screen and look at where the target is located. You should always open the screen COMPLETELY, even if you can see the target with it partially open: otherwise, players watching you will be able to guess the general target location.</p>\n\n<p>Very infrequently, the target's center (the 4 point wedge) won't be visible at all. If that happens, close the screen and spin again. If the center target is ever partially in view on the left or right extreme, that's valid-even if it's just a sliver.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p><b>Give a clue:</b> Look at where the target's center is located spatially along the visible area of the wheel. Now think of a clue that is conceptually where the target is located ON THE SPECTRUM between the two concepts on your card. Rules for how to give clues can be found later in this book.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p><b>Close the screen:</b> Using the plastic handle, close the screen completely. Now turn the box to face your team, so they can interact with the device.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n\n<p>Now the psychic stops communicating entirely!</p>\n\n<p>After the Psychic has given their clue, they are no longer allowed to say ANYTHING-not even clarifications-and must keep an entirely straight face.</p>\n\n<p>If a Psychic ever gives away the target location after giving their clue, either verbally or nonverbally, it's up to everyone playing to decide whether to penalize the team.</p>\n\n<p>We tend to just let the Psychic give a new clue with a new card and target location, but we're generous that way.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>B. Team Phase</h2>\n\n<p>After the Psychic gives their clue, it's up to the rest of their team to READING THEIR MIND and turn the dial as close to the center of the target area as they can.</p>\n\n<p>This is the core of the game and it is almost entirely free of rules: teammates can discuss, debate, and argue in any way they like.</p>\n\n<p>After the Psychic's team has come to an agreement, they let the other team know that they've finalized their dial position.</p>\n\n<p>During this phase, just keep a couple things in mind:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>Don't use percentages or numbers as shorthand for where to turn the dial.</p>\n\n<p>Since Wavelength is based off of gut feelings, you should restrict yourselves to saying things like \"way more to the right\", or \"down a little\" rather than \"turn it to 25%\".</p>\n\n<p>There's no penalty associated with doing this-you should just avoid it in the spirit of the game.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Everyone on the team has the right to turn the dial at any time. It's up to the team to determine how to negotiate this.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>C. Left/right Phase</h2>\n\n<p>In Wavelength, BOTH teams always have a chance to score points from a clue.</p>\n\n<p>After the Psychic's team has finalized their dial position, the other team gets to guess whether the center of the target (the 4 point wedge) is to the left or right of the dial. This discussion should be fairly brief, since it's a simple binary choice: LEFT or RIGHT.</p>\n\n<p>The team makes their guess by placing the marker in either the LEFT or RIGHT slot next to the wavelength card.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<div class=\"box box_radius box_border\">\n\n<p>For example, the image below shows the team guessing LEFT, i.e. they think the Psychic meant to convey something MORE HOT than the current team guessed.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/wavelength/game7.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>D. Scoring Phase</h2>\n\n<p>Once both teams have finalized their guesses, it's time for the most exciting part of the game: THE REVEAL. The Psychic opens the screen to reveal the target. Their team scores points if the dial is within the colored target area, as listed on the colored wedges (2-4 points).</p>\n\n<p>If the dial is ever on an edge between two results, the Psychic's team always scores the better of the two results.</p>\n\n<p>The other team scores 1 point if they correctly guessed whether the target is to the left or right of the final dial position. If the Psychic's team guessed perfectly (the 4 point wedge), the other team cannot score.</p>\n\n<p>Move each team's scoring marker by those amounts.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<div class=\"box box_radius box_border\">\n\n<h4>Psychic Team</h4>\n\n<p>Scores the number of points printed on the wedge that the dial is in. Below, the team scores 3 points.</p>\n\n<h4>Other Team</h4>\n\n<p>Scores by guessing if the center of the target is to the left or right of the dial.</p>\n\n<p>Below, if the team had guessed LEFT, they would score 1 point.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/wavelength/game8.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>Once a team has reached 10 points, the game ends and the t<b>eam with the highest score wins</b>!</p>\n\n<p>If there's a tie, each team takes a final sudden death turn. The team that scores the most points that round wins (including the LEFT/RIGHT guess). If there's still a tie, repeat until a team has won.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<div class=\"box tucked_corner\">\n\n<h3>Cooperative Mode</h3>\n\n<br>\n\n<p>In this mode, everyone wins or loses together as a single team. It works really well with 2-5 players, but you can play at any size. The rules are mostly the same, except:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>To start, put 7 random wavelength cards in the card slot. When that deck runs out, the game is over. Then use the chart on the right to determine how well you did!</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Points works the same as usual, except the center wedge is only worth 3 points-but you ALSO get to draw a bonus card to add to the deck, adding an extra round to the game.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Skip the left/right guessing phase.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<table class=\"table table-condensed table-striped border\">\n<thead>\n<tr><th>Score</th><th>How you did</th></tr></thead>\n<tbody>\n<tr><td>0-3</td><td>Are you sure it's plugged in?</td></tr>\n<tr><td>4-6</td><td>Try turning it off and back on again</td></tr>\n<tr><td>7-9</td><td>Blow into the bottom of the device</td></tr>\n<tr><td>10 - 12</td><td>Not bad! Not great, but not bad</td></tr>\n<tr><td>+13-15</td><td>So Close</td></tr>\n<tr><td>+16 - 18</td><td>You won!</td></tr>\n<tr><td>+19 - 21</td><td>You're on the same...wavelength</td></tr>\n<tr><td>+22 - 24</td><td>Galaxy brain</td></tr>\n<tr><td>25+</td><td>Insane</td></tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n\n\n</div>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"clue-giving.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Wavelength Game Rules",

  293 
  294 if (existingRule) {
  295   // Update existing rule
→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 87
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Just One Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/just-one/just-one.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>110 cards</li>\n<li>7 easels</li>\n<li>7 erasable felt markers</li>\n<li>Rulebook</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>Just One is a cooperative party game. You all play together to get the best score!</p>\n\n<p>Together, make one of the players - the active player - guess a Mystery word by secretly writing a clue on your easel.</p>\n\n<p>Choose your clue without coordinating with each other and be original so as not to write the same clue as ano- ther player, as all identical clues will be canceled before the active player gets to see them.</p>\n\n<p>At the end of the game, tally your score based on the number of Mystery words found.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p>Shuffle the cards and randomly draw 13 to create a face-down deck in the middle of the table. Return the remaining cards to the box, they will not be used this game.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Give an easel and an erasable felt marker to each player.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Randomly choose a player to be the first active player.</p></li>\n</ol>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/just-one/game1.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>The game plays out in a succession of turns and ends when the deck of cards is empty.</p>\n\n<p>Each turn is divided into 4 phases:</p>\n<ol>\n<li>choose the mystery word</li>\n<li>Clue selection</li>\n<li>Comparing clues</li>\n<li>Guess</li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n<h2><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/just-one/game4.jpg\"> Choose The Mystery Word</h2>\n\n<p>The active player draws the top card of the deck without looking at it, and places it on their easel so that all of the other players can see the words (one of the sides of the easel has a support to hold the card).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/just-one/game13.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>The player then chooses a number between 1 and 5 to tell the other players which Mystery word they have to provide a clue for.</p>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> If players don't know the chosen word, they can ask the active player to choose a different number.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/just-one/game5.jpg\"> Clue Selection</h2>\n\n<p>Without communicating with each other and without showing it to anyone each player writes one clue on their easel. That clue must be composed of a single word.</p>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> a digit, a number, an acronym, an onomatopoeia, or a special character are all considered to be words.</p>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> 007 is allowed to help someone guess Bond, just like Riiiiiinnng or SMS are allowed to help someone guess Telephone, and $ is allowed to help someone guess America.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/just-one/game9.jpg\"> Invalid Clues</h3>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>The Mystery word but <b>written differently</b>.</p>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> Shurt is not allowed when trying to make the player guess Shirt.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>The Mystery word written in a <b>foreign language</b>.</p>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> Buisson is not allowed if the word to be guessed is Shrub.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>A word from the <b>same family</b> as the Mystery word.</p>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> Princess is not allowed if the word to be guessed is Prince.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>An <b>invented word</b>.</p>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> Swee'ting is not allowed to try to help someone guess Cake.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>A word <b>phonetically identical</b> to the Mystery word, but the meaning of which is different.</p>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> Whether is not allowed to try to get someone to guess Weather.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/just-one/game6.jpg\"> Comparing Clues</h2>\n\n<p>Once all players have written their clues, the active player closes their eyes.</p>\n\n<p>During this time, the other players turn their easels around and compare their clue with the other players. All identical or invalid clues are cancelled. To cancel a clue, simply tip the easel over to hide the clue.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/just-one/game10.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/just-one/game11.jpg\"> Identical Clues</h3>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>Two identical words.</p>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> Mouse and Mouse are identical.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Variants from the same word family.</p>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> Prince and Princess are considered to be identical.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Variants of the same word: plurals, gender differentiations, and spelling mistakes don't count as actual differences. Example: Prince and Princes, Actor and Actress, Philosophy and Filosofie are identical.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> If all clues have been cancelled, place the Mystery word's card back in the box and move directly to the End of turn phase.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/just-one/game7.jpg\"> Guess</h2>\n\n<p>Once the identical or invalid clues have been cancelled, ask the active player to open their eyes and try to guess the Mystery word with the help of the remaining clues. To do this, they're allowed <b>ONLY ONE GUESS</b>.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Results</h3>\n\n<h4><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/just-one/game15.jpg\"> Success</h4>\n\n<p>If the active player correctly guesses the Mystery word: place this card face up next to the deck.</p>\n\n<h4><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/just-one/game16.jpg\"> Failure</h4>\n\n<p>If the active player makes a wrong guess : return this card AND the top card of the deck to the game box.</p>\n\n<h4><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/just-one/game17.jpg\"> Skip</h4>\n\n<p>If the active player chooses not to answer and skips their turn : return this card to the game box.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Notes:</b></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>If the active player's guess has the same pronunciation as the Mystery word, that guess is considered to be valid.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>If the player gives a wrong guess during the final turn, also remove a card previously guessed successfully.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Turn</h2>\n\n<p>The player to the left of the active player becomes the new active player. A new turn begins.</p>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> make sure to properly erase your old clue between turns.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>The game ends when the deck is empty.</p>\n\n<p>Count the number of successfully guessed cards and compare your total with this table to get your score:</p>\n\n<table class=\"table table-condensed table-striped border\">\n<thead>\n<tr><th>Successful Cards</th><th>Score</th></tr></thead>\n<tbody>\n<tr><td>13</td><td>Perfect score! Can you do it again?</td></tr>\n<tr><td>12</td><td>Incredible! Your friends must be impressed!</td></tr>\n<tr><td>11</td><td>Awesome! That's a score worth celebrating!</td></tr>\n<tr><td>9-10</td><td>Wow, not bad at all!</td></tr>\n<tr><td>7-8</td><td>You're in the average. Can you do better?</td></tr>\n<tr><td>4-6</td><td>That's a good start. Try again!</td></tr>\n<tr><td>0-3</td><td>Try again, and again, and again.</td></tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n\n<blockquote class=\"white\">\n\n<h3>Variant For 3 Players</h3>\n\n<p>With 3 players, the game plays out according to the standard rules as previous stated, with the exception of the following change:</p>\n\n<p>During setup, players each take two easels. During the choice of clues, they write one clue on each of their easels. Each player therefore provides 2 clues instead of a single one.</p>\n\n<p>Identical clues are also cancelled during the Comparison Phase of clue selection.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"buy-just-one.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Just One Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:47:52.322Z"),
            ~~~~~~~~~

  295   // Update existing rule
→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 88
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Camel Up Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/camel-up.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<h2>Game Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<ul>\n<li>1 Pyramid</li>\n<li>1 Game board</li>\n<li>5 Camels</li>\n<li>5 Dice</li>\n<li>40 Race Betting cards</li>\n<li>8 Desert tiles</li>\n<li>15 Leg Betting tiles</li>\n<li>5 Pyramid tiles</li>\n<li>50 Egyptian Pound coins</li>\n<li>20 Egyptian Pound cards</li>\n<li>1 Leg Starting Player marker</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<ol>\n\n<li><p>Place the Game board in the middle of the table.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Place the 5 Pyramid tiles as a stack onto their space on the Game board.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Sort the Leg Betting tiles by their color (5 colors in total). Then stack the 3 tiles of each color in the following manner: the 2-money tile on the bottom, the 3-money tile in the middle, and the 5-money tile on top. Then place each stack onto the space of its color on the Game board.</p></li>\n<li><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/5camels.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Place the 5 Camels onto the tents next to the Leg Betting tiles, each onto the tent of its color.</p>\n\n</li>\n<li><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/poundcoinscards.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Sort the Egyptian Pound coins and cards by their values and place them as a supply next to the Game board. This supply is called the \"bank\".</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Give each player the 5 Race Betting cards of one character as well as the Desert tile of that character. Return any spare Race Betting cards and Desert tiles to the box.</p>\n\n<p>Each player keeps his hand of five cards hidden from the other players and places his Desert tile in front of him.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/racebettingcards.jpg\" class=\"margin-bottom-10\">\n\n</li>\n<li><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/pounds.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Give each player starting capital of 3 Egyptian Pounds, which he places in front of him.</p></li>\n<li><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/startingplayermarker.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Give the Leg Starting Player marker to the youngest player.</p></li>\n<li><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/pyramid.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Now, the youngest player determines the starting positions of the Camels by taking the 5 Dice and rolling them together. Then he takes the 5 Camels from their tents and places each onto a specific space of the Race track: Each Camel whose matching Die has a facing up, he must place onto space 1 (the space with flag 1).</p> <p>Each Camel whose matching Die has a facing up, he must place onto space 2. Each Camel whose matching Die has a facing up, he must place onto space 3. Finally he stacks up all Camels which stand together on the same space.</p></li>\n\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>The movement of the Camels</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/movementofcamels.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>The Camels move clockwise around the Race track. During the game, the players move the Camels using the Pyramid.</p>\n\n<p>When a player turns the Pyramid upside down and pushes the slider, he reveals 1 colored Die. Then he must move the Camel of the revealed color as many spaces forward as the Die shows.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/camelstack.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h4>Camel stack</h4>\n\n<p>Camels on the same space always form a Camel stack. If a Camel is moved that is part of a Camel stack, it carries along all Camels that sit on top of it. Any Camels beneath it are left where they are.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/camelunit.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h4>Camel unit</h4>\n\n<p>Since sometimes single Camels and sometimes Camel stacks are moved, we use the term Camel unit. A Camel unit consists either of a single Camel or a stack of Camels.</p>\n\n<p>If a Camel unit ends its movement on a space where there is another Camel unit, it jumps on top of that other unit.</p>\n\n<p>Important: For all purposes of ranking, a Camel that sits on top of another Camel is always considered ahead of the Camel it sits on.</p>\n\n<h3>The Legs</h3>\n\n<p>The race comprises several Legs. A Leg ends when the last of the 5 Dice has come out of the Pyramid and the respective Camel has moved. Right at the end of each Leg, a Leg scoring round occurs, in which players receive or lose money according to the tiles they have acquired during the Leg.</p>\n\n<p>Afterwards, a new Leg starts by returning the acquired tiles to the game board and the 5 Dice to the Pyramid.</p>\n\n<h3>Money</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/poundcoinscards.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>The currency in this game is Egyptian Pounds (from now on also referred to as EP). You must store your money publicly in front of you. However, you may stack it up in any way you want.</p>\n\n<p>For the duration of the race, no player is obliged to disclose his exact amount of money.</p>\n\n<p>At any time during the game, you may exchange money one-to-one with money from the bank (for example, exchanging five 1 Pound coins for one 5 Pound coin and so on).</p>\n\n<p>No player can drop below 0 EP. This means when you do not have the money to pay a lost bet, you are spared from doing so.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>The player with the Leg Starting Player marker begins the first Leg (and thus the game) by performing exactly 1 action.</p>\n\n<p>Then the player to his left performs 1 action, then the next player and so on. Therefore, play proceeds continuously in a clockwise direction. There are 4 possible actions.</p>\n\n<p>When it is your turn, you must choose and perform exactly 1 of them:</p>\n\n<ol>\n\n<li><p>Take the top Leg Betting tile of any stack (and thus back the Camel of that color to win the current Leg).</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Place your Desert tile onto the Race track.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Take 1 Pyramid tile and then move 1 Camel via the Pyramid.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Bet on the overall winner OR overall loser by placing 1 of your Race Betting cards face down onto the appropriate Betting space.</p></li>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p>The game ends as soon as the first Camel crosses the finish line. Then a final Leg scoring round occurs, as well as an End scoring round for the overall winning Camel and the overall losing Camel.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/legbettingtile.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h3>I. Take 1 Leg Betting tile</h3>\n\n<p>Take the top Leg Betting tile from any stack on the Game board and place it in front of you. By doing this, you back the Camel of that color (which means that you hope it will be in the lead at the end of the Leg).</p>\n\n<p>There is no limit to the number of Leg Betting tiles you may collect throughout the Leg. You may even have several of the same color lying in front of you.</p>\n\n<h3>II. Place your Desert tile</h3>\n\n<p>Place your Desert tile onto an empty space of the Race track (that has no Camels or Desert tile on it). However, you are not allowed to place it onto a space that is adjacent to a space that already contains a Desert tile. Also, you may never place your Desert tile onto space 1 of the Race track.</p>\n\n<p>If your Desert tile is already on the Game board, you may use this action to move it to a different space (following the same rules).</p>\n\n<p>When you place (or move) your Desert tile, you can either place it with its Oasis side up or with its Mirage side up. Depending on the side, the Desert tile will influence the movement of Camels that stop on the tile in different ways.</p>\n\n<h3>III. Take 1 Pyramid tile</h3>\n\n<p>Take the top Pyramid tile from the stack on the Game board and place it in front of you.</p>\n\n<p>Then immediately take the Pyramid, shake it thoroughly, and reveal one Die from it.</p>\n\n<p>How to use the Pyramid:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/howusepyramid.jpg\" class=\"margin-bottom-10\">\n\n<p>Note: If no Die appears, turn the Pyramid back up and shake it once more before trying the steps above again.</p>\n\n<p>After you have revealed the Die, move the Camel of its color as many spaces forward as shown on the Die: 1, 2, or 3 spaces.</p>\n\n<p>Remember: If you move a Camel that is part of a Camel stack, it carries along all Camels that sit on top of it (and forms a Camel unit with them).</p>\n\n<p>Example: The orange Die is revealed and shows a 3. The orange Camel moves 3 spaces forward carrying along the yellow Camel.</p>\n\n<p>If a Camel unit ends its movement on a space where there is another Camel unit, it jumps on top of that other unit.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/example4.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Example: The white Die is revealed and shows a 2. The white Camel moves 2 spaces forward, carrying along the green Camel. Since the yellow Camel is already on the space on which they end their movement, white and green jump on top of it as a unit.</p>\n\n<h4>Desert tiles</h4>\n\n<p>If a Camel unit ends its movement on a space that is occupied by a Desert tile, the owner of that tile immediately receives 1 Egyptian Pound from the bank. Also (depending on which side of the tile is facing up) the Camel unit must immediately move 1 additional space forward or 1 space backward:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/oasis.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>If the tile has its Oasis side facing up, the Camel unit moves 1 space forward. If it thereby lands on a space where there is another Camel unit, it jumps on top of that unit as usual.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/mirage.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>If the tile has its Mirage side facing up, the Camel unit moves 1 space backward. If it thereby lands on a space where there is another Camel unit, however, it is placed underneath that unit.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<p>In both cases, the Desert tile remains on its space (at least until the next Leg scoring round).</p>\n\n<p>After you have moved the appropriate Camel, place the revealed Die onto the tent of its color. This way, everybody can keep track of which Dice are already out of the Pyramid.</p>\n\n<p>Keep the acquired Pyramid tile lying in front of you. In the next Leg scoring round, you will receive 1 Egyptian Pound for each Pyramid tile you have acquired during the Leg.</p>\n\n<h3>IV. Bet on the overall winner or overall loser</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/winner.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>As your action, you can bet on the overall winner. This means, you secretly back the Camel that you believe will be in the lead at the end of the game. To do this, secretly choose 1 of your Race betting cards (in the color of the Camel you think will win) and put it face down onto the Betting space for the overall winner.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/loser.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>You may instead bet on the overall loser (backing the Camel that you believe will be last on the Race track at the end of the game) by secretly choosing 1 of your Race Betting cards and putting it face down onto the Betting space for the overall loser.</p>\n\n<p>If there are already any cards on your chosen Betting space, you simply put yours on top of those cards.</p>\n\n<p>Once placed, a card must stay where it is, even if you later realize you backed the wrong Camel. However, as long as you have cards in hand, you may always choose as your action to place 1 of them onto either Betting space.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of a Leg</h2>\n\n<p>When a player takes the last Pyramid tile from the Game board, he first reveals the last Die from the Pyramid and moves the respective Camel as usual. Then, before the next player takes his turn, a Leg scoring round occurs for all players:</p>\n\n<p>Start by giving the Leg Starting Player marker to the player that sits to the left of the player who just took the last Pyramid tile (so you will remember who will start the next Leg).</p>\n\n<p>Then see which Camel is in the lead (on the space farthest along the Race track). If there is a stack of Camels in the lead, the leading Camel is the one on top of the stack.</p>\n\n<p>Now, each player gains or loses Egyptian Pounds according to the Pyramid and Leg Betting tiles lying in front of him.</p>\n\n<p>Each player adds up his total amount and then takes it from (or pays it to) the bank accordingly.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/leg1.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>For each Leg Betting tile of the leading Camel, the player gains the number of Egyptian Pounds printed in large on the tile: 5, 3, or 2.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/leg2.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>For each Leg Betting tile of the Camel in second place, the player gains 1 EP.</p>\n\n<p>For each Leg Betting tile of any other Camel, the player loses 1 EP.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/leg3.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>For each Pyramid tile, the player gains 1 EP.</p>\n\n<p>Example: In the Leg scoring round, the green Camel is in the lead. The yellow Camel is in second place. Martina has the following tiles in front of her, which give her 9 Egyptian Pounds in total:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/9pounds.jpg\" class=\"margin-bottom-10\">\n\n<p>After all players have collected (or paid) their money, return all Leg Betting tiles and all Pyramid tiles to the appropriate spaces on the Game board (in the same way as in the setup). Also, remove any Desert tiles from the Game board and return them to their owners.</p>\n\n<p>Finally, return the 5 Dice from the tents to the Pyramid. Then the player with the Leg Starting Player marker starts the new Leg.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/end.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>As soon as the first Camel unit crosses the finish line, the race ends immediately. Now, carry out the Leg scoring round one last time (as described on the left).</p>\n\n<p>After this final Leg scoring round, the End scoring round for the overall winner and overall loser occurs. For this, first attend to the face-down card deck on the Betting space for the overall winner. Remember: the card on the bottom was the first card placed, the card on top the last. Turn the entire deck face up, so that now the card placed first is face up on top while the card placed last is on the bottom. Now players gain or lose money according to the cards they have placed. Start at the top and go through the face-up deck card by card.</p>\n\n<p>Only cards that show the actual winning Camel grant money:</p>\n\n<p>The player (if any) that placed the first card showing the actual winner of the race receives 8 Egyptian Pound from the bank. </p>\n\n<p>The player (if any) who placed the second card showing the winner receives 5 EP, the third player 3 EP, the fourth player 2 EP, all others 1 EP.</p>\n\n<p>Remember: this only applies to cards showing the actual winner. For each card in the deck that shows any Camel other than the winner, the owner of that card must pay 1 EP to the bank.</p>\n\n<p>After going through the deck for the overall winner, go through the deck of cards for the overall loser in the same way. The overall loser, of course, is the least advanced Camel (in the case of a stack, it is the Camel on the bottom of the stack).</p>\n\n<p>Example: The green Camel is the winner of the race, the white Camel the loser. The decks on the Betting spaces give the respective owners of the cards EP as follows:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/camel-up/endexample.jpg\" class=\"margin-bottom-10\">\n\n<p>After the End scoring round, all players count their money. The player who collected the most Egyptian Pounds wins the game. In the case of a tie, the victory is shared.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"buy-camel-up.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Camel Up Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:47:58.299Z"),
            ~~~~~~~~~
        ?   language?: String | StringFieldUpdateOperationsInput,
        ?   setupInstructions?: String | NullableStringFieldUpdateOperationsInput | Null,
        ?   victoryConditions?: String | NullableStringFieldUpdateOperationsInput | Null,
        ?   game?: GameUpdateOneRequiredWithoutRulesNestedInput
          }
        })

Unknown argument `updatedAt`. Available options are marked with ?.

            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Love Letter Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/love-letter/love-letter.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/love-letter/compoments.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h2>Game Components</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>16 game cards</li>\n<li>4 reference cards</li>\n<li>tokens of affection</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p>Shuffle the 16 cards to form a face-down draw deck. Remove the top card of the deck from the game without looking at it.</p>\n\n<p>If you are playing a two-player game, take three more cards from the top of the deck and place them to the side, face up. They will not be used during this round.</p>\n\n<p>Each player draws one card from the deck. This is the player's hand, and is kept secret from the others.</p>\n\n<p>Whoever was most recently on a date goes first (if tied, the younger player wins the tie).</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/love-letter/zegel.png\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>In the wake of the arrest of Queen Marianna for high treason, none was more heartbroken than her daughter, Princess Annette. Suitors throughout the City-State of Tempest sought to ease Annette's sorrow by courting her to bring some joy into her life.</p>\n\n<p>You are one of these suitors, trying to get your love letter to the princess. Unfortunately, she has locked herself in the palace, so you must rely on intermediaries to carry your message.</p>\n\n<p>During the game, you hold one secret card in your hand. This is who currently carries your message of love for the princess.</p>\n\n<p>Make sure that the person closest to the princess holds your love letter at the end of the day, so it reaches her first!</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/love-letter/love.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Love Letter is played in a series of rounds. Each round represents one day. At the end of each round, one player's letter reaches Princess Annette, and she reads it.</p>\n\n<p>When she reads enough letters from one suitor, she becomes enamored and grants that suitor permission to court her. That player wins the princess's heart and the game.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Taking a Turn</h3>\n\n<p>On your turn, draw the top card from the deck and add it to your hand. Then choose one of the two cards in your hand and discard it face up in front of you. Apply any effect on the card you discarded. You must apply its effect, even if it is bad for you.</p>\n\n<p>All discarded cards remain in front of the player who discarded them. Overlap the cards so that it's clear in which order they were discarded. This helps players to figure out which cards other players might be holding.</p>\n\n<p>Once you finish applying the card's effect, the turn passes to the player on your left.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Out of the Round</h3>\n\n<p>If a player is knocked out of the round, that player discards the card in his or her hand face up (do not apply the card's effect) and takes no more turns until next round.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Honesty</h3>\n\n<p>A player could cheat when chosen with the Guard, or fail to discard the Countess when that player has the King or Prince in hand. We suggest that you don't play with knaves who cheat at fun, light games.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/love-letter/cards.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>End of a Round</h3>\n\n<p>A round ends if the deck is empty at the end of a turn. The royal residence closes for the evening, the person closest to the princess delivers the love letter, and Princess Annette retires to her chambers to read it.</p>\n\n<p>All players still in the round reveal their hands. The player with the highest ranked person wins the round. In case of a tie, the player who discarded the highest total value of cards wins.</p>\n\n<p>A round also ends if all players but one are out of the round, in which case the remaining player wins.</p>\n\n<p>The winner receives a token of affection. Shuffle all 16 cards together, and play a new round following all of the setup rules.</p>\n\n<p>The winner of the previous round goes first, because the princess speaks kindly of him or her at breakfast.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/love-letter/box.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h2>End of the game</h2>\n\n<p>A player wins the game after winning a number of tokens based on the number of players:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>2 Players: 7 tokens</li>\n<li>3 Players: 5 tokens</li>\n<li>4 players: 4 tokens</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"the-people.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
