          where: {
            id: 90
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Exploding Kittens Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/exploding-kittens.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<h2>Game Components</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Deck of cards</li>\n<li>Rules Booklet</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/components.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/setup1.png\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Remove all the Exploding Kittens <s class=\"tokenlabel\">4</s> and Defuse cards <s class=\"tokenlabel\">6</s> from the deck.</p>\n\n<p>Shuffle the remaining deck and deal 4 cards face down to each player.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/deal.png\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Deal 1 Defuse card to each player so that everyone has a hand of 5 cards total. Keep your hand secret.</p>\n\n<p>Insert enough Exploding Kittens back into the deck so that there is 1 fewer than the number of people playing. Remove any extra Exploding Kittens from the game.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/setup2.png\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Insert the extra Defuse cards back in the deck.</p>\n\n<p>Shuffle the deck, and put it face down in the middle of the table. This is your Draw Pile</p>\n\n<p>Pick a player to go first. (Some sample criteria: most impressive beard, most intimidating odor, shortest spleen, etc).</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>If you explode, you lose. if you don't explode, YOU WIN and all of the other cards</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>You'll have a deck of cards containing some Exploding Kittens. You play the game by putting the deck face down and taking turns drawing cards off the top until someone draws an Exploding Kitten.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/how-it-works.png\"><br>\n\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<p>Play a card from your hand by placing it face up on top of the Discard Pile, and following the instructions on the card. Or play no cards at all; that's cool too.</p>\n\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>After you follow the instructions on a card or play a Pair, you can play more cards. You can play as many cards as you'd like.</p>\n\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Finally, end your turn by drawing a card from the top of the Draw Pile into your hand and hoping it's not an Exploding Kitten.</p>\n\n<p>(This is different from most other games in that you end your turn by drawing a card).</p>\n\n<p>Play continues clockwise around the table.</p>\n\n</li>\n\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Notes:</h4>\n\n<p>You can count the cards left in the Draw Pile. You won't ever run out of cards in the Draw Pile, so there's never a need to reshuffle.</p>\n\n<p>There is no maximum or minimum hand size. If you run out of cards in your hand, there's no special action to take. Keep playing. You'll draw at least 1 more card on your next turn.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/cards.png\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Cards</h2>\n\n<h3><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/defuse.png\"> Defuse (6 cards)</h3>\n\n<p>If you drew an Exploding Kitten, you can play this card instead of dying. Place your Defuse card in the Discard Pile.</p>\n\n<p>Then take the Exploding Kitten, and without reordering or viewing the other cards, secretly put it back in the Draw Pile anywhere you'd like.</p>\n\n<p>Want to screw over the player right after you? Put the Kitten right on top of the deck. If you'd like, hold the deck under the table so that no one else can see where you put it. Now the next player goes (unless you must take multiple turns).</p>\n\n<h3><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/nope.png\"> Nope (5 cards)</h3>\n\n<p>Stop any action except for an Exploding Kitten or a Defuse card. Imagine that any card (or Pair or Special Combo) beneath a Nope card no longer exists.</p>\n\n<p>You can also play a Nope on another Nope to negate it and create a Yup, and so on.</p>\n\n<p>You can play a Nope card at any time before an action has begun, even if it's not your turn.</p>\n\n<h3><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/exploding.png\"> Exploding Kitten (4 cards)</h3>\n\n<p>You must show this card immediately. Unless you have a Defuse card, you're dead. Discard all of your cards, including the Exploding Kitten.</p>\n\n<h3><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/attack.png\"> Attack (4 cards)</h3>\n\n<p>End your turn(s) without drawing and force the next player to take 2 turns in a row. The victim of this card takes a turn as normal (play cards, then draw). Then, when their first turn is over, it's their turn again. (If the victim of an Attack card plays an Attack card, their turns are immediately over, and the next player must take 2 turns).</p>\n\n<h3><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/skip.png\"> Skip (4 cards)</h3>\n\n<p>Immediately end your turn without drawing a card. (If you play a Skip card as a defense to an Attack card, it only ends 1 of the 2 turns. 2 Skip cards would end both turns).</p>\n\n<h3><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/favor.png\"> Favor (4 cards)</h3>\n\n<p>Force any other player to give you 1 card from their hand. They choose which card to give you.</p>\n\n<h3><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/shuffle.png\"> Shuffle (4 cards)</h3>\n\n<p>Shuffle the Draw Pile thoroughly and randomly without viewing the cards. (Useful when you know there's an Exploding Kitten coming).</p>\n\n<h3><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/future.png\"> See the future (5 cards)</h3>\n\n<p>Peek at the top 3 cards from the Draw Pile and put them back in the same order. Don't show the cards to the other players.</p>\n\n<h3><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/cats.png\"> Cat Cards (4 of each type)</h3>\n\n<p>Some cards don't have any instructions on them. These cards are powerless on their own, but can be played in Pairs or Special Combos.</p>\n\n<p>If you play matching pairs with no instructions on them, pick another player and steal a random card from their hand.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Example Turn</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/exploding-kittens/example.png\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>You decide to play a see the future card.</p>\n\n<p>While viewing the 3 top cards, you see that the card you're about to draw is an Exploding Kitten.</p>\n\n<p>You decide to play an attack card to end your turn and force the next player to take 2 turns.</p>\n\n<p>but then another player plays a Nope card which cancels your attack, so it's still your turn.</p>\n\n<p>You don't want to draw that top card and die, so you play a Shuffle card and randomly shuffle the Draw Pile.</p>\n\n<p>With the deck freshly shuffled, you draw the top card to end your turn and hope it's not an exploding kitten.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"special-combos.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Exploding Kittens Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:48:19.367Z"),
            ~~~~~~~~~

→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 91
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Twilight Imperium Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/twilight-imperium.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>Throughout a game of Twilight Imperium, players will barter, plot, and wage war upon one another to complete objectives. The first player to accumulate 10 victory points claims the Imperial Throne and wins the game.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n<ul>\n<li>17 Faction Sheets</li>\n<li>6 Command Sheets</li>\n<li>51 System Tiles</li>\n<li>354 Plastic Units</li>\n<li>8 Strategy Cards</li>\n<li>8 Ten-Sided Dice</li>\n<li>1 Victory Point Track</li>\n<li>59 Planet Cards</li>\n<li>40 Objective Cards</li>\n<li>80 Action Cards</li>\n<li>50 Agenda Cards</li>\n<li>41 Promissory Note Cards</li>\n<li>1 Speaker Token</li>\n<li>122 Technology Cards</li>\n<li>1 Custodians Token</li>\n<li>62 Unit Upgrade Technology Cards</li>\n<li>2 Creuss Alpha/Beta Wormhole Tokens</li>\n<li>1 Naalu \"0\" Token</li>\n<li>2 Nekro X/Y Assimilator Tokens</li>\n<li>48 Trade Good and Commodity Tokens</li>\n<li>272 Command Tokens</li>\n<li>289 Control Tokens</li>\n<li>49 Infantry Tokens</li>\n<li>49 Fighter Tokens</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Units</h3>\n\n<p>During a game of Twilight Imperium, each player's units are represented by plastic figures. There are three types of units: ships, ground forces, and structures.</p>\n\n<h4>Ships</h4>\n\n<p>Ships represent spacefaring units. Players use these units to engage one another in space combat and expand their empires to new systems.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game20.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>Ground Forces</h4>\n\n<p>Ground forces represent foot soldiers. Players use these units to invade planets or defend their own territories.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game20_.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>Structures</h4>\n\n<p>Structures represent military installations built by an empire to support its war effort.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game21.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>Reinforcements</h4>\n\n<p>A player's personal supply of unused units and unused command tokens is his reinforcements. When producing units and gaining command tokens during the game, players will take those components from their reinforcements.</p>\n\n<h3>Systems And Planets</h3>\n\n<p>The game board for Twilight Imperium is formed using modular system tiles. Each tile represents a single system in the galaxy, which may contain one or more planets or other celestial bodies.</p>\n\n<h5>Placing Units On System Tiles</h5>\n\n<p>When a unit is placed in a system, it is placed in one of two areas on the tile. Structures and ground forces are usually placed on planets, while ships are placed in space-the star-filled area surrounding the planets.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game18.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>Planets</h4>\n\n<p>As players move about the galaxy and expand their empire beyond their home systems, they will gain control of new planets.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game17.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>When a player gains control of a planet, he takes that planet's card from either the deck of planet cards or from the player who controlled it previously and places it facedown in his play area.</p>\n\n<p>Each planet card displays two values: resources on the left in yellow and influence on the right in blue. Players spend resources to acquire new units and technologies. Players spend influence to gain command tokens and to vote during the agenda phase.</p>\n\n<p>If a player ever controls a planet, but has no units on that planet, he places one of the control tokens that matches his faction on that planet to mark that he controls it.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game22.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>First-Game Setup</h2>\n\n<p>When playing for the first time, players perform the following steps to set up the game. Some components are not used during the first game, and are explained in detail at the end of this booklet.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game23.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h5>1. Determine Speaker:</h5>\n\n<p>Randomly determine one player to take the speaker token. This player is the speaker and will go first when the game begins.</p>\n\n<h5>2. Assign Factions:</h5>\n\n<p>Each player controls a faction with unique strengths and weaknesses. Each faction has a sheet which shows the attributes and abilities of that faction's units as well as abilities unique to the faction itself. Gather the following faction sheets:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/f1.jpg\"> The Xxcha Kingdom</li>\n<li><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/f2.jpg\"> The Federation of Sol</li>\n<li><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/f3.jpg\"> The Emirates of Hacan</li>\n<li><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/f4.jpg\"> The Barony of Letnev</li>\n<li><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/f5.jpg\"> The Sardakk N'orr</li>\n<li><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/f6.jpg\"> The Universities of Jol-Nar</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>The speaker deals one random faction sheet from the list above to each player.</p>\n\n<h5>3. Gather Faction-specific Components:</h5>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game25.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Each player takes the following components that match his faction:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>1 home system tile</li>\n<li>17 control tokens</li>\n<li>16 command tokens</li>\n<li>2 technology cards</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Each player's faction-specific components contain a faction symbol that matches the symbol on his faction sheet. Each player places his faction sheet and all of his faction's components in front of him. Return all unused faction components to the game box.</p>\n\n<h5>4. Choose Color:</h5>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game25_.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Each player chooses a color and takes the following components that match his chosen color:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>59 plastic units</li>\n<li>1 command sheet</li>\n<li>25 technology cards</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Each player slides the edge of his command sheet under his faction sheet and places the other components nearby.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game26.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h5>5. Gather Starting Planet Cards:</h5>\n\n<p>Each player takes the planet cards that correspond to the planets in his home system and places them faceup near his faction sheet.</p>\n\n<h5>6. Create Game Board:</h5>\n\n<p>Players create the game board using the diagram that corresponds to the number of players. Experienced players create a custom game board at the start of each game, as explained later.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game31.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h5>7. Place Custodians Token:</h5>\n\n<p>Place the custodians token in the center of the game board on Mecatol Rex.</p>\n\n<h5>8. Shuffle Common Decks:</h5>\n\n<p>Shuffle the action, agenda, stage I objective, stage II objective, and secret objective cards into separate decks and place them near the game board.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game29.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game32.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h5>9. Create Supply:</h5>\n\n<p>Create separate piles near the game board for trade good, infantry, and fighter tokens.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game33.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h5>10. Gather Strategy Cards:</h5>\n\n<p>Place each of the eight strategy cards faceup in the common play area within reach of the speaker.</p>\n\n<h5>11. Gather Starting Components:</h5>\n\n<p>Each player takes the starting technology and starting units listed on the back of his faction sheet. Each player places the technology cards faceup near his faction sheet and the starting units in his home system. If a player has multiple planets in his home system, it is recommended that he place his space dock and infantry on the planet with the highest resource value.</p>\n\n<p>Each player places three command tokens in his tactic pool, three command tokens in his fleet pool (ship silhouette side up), and two command tokens in his strategy pool. These pools are located on the player's command sheet.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game30.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>12. Prepare Objectives:</h4>\n<ol type=\"I\">\n<li>Each player draws one secret objective and keeps it hidden from other players.</li>\n<li>Place the victory point track near the game board with its 0-10 side faceup. Then, each player places one of his control tokens on space \"0\" of the track.</li>\n<li>The speaker draws five stage I objective cards from the deck and places them facedown in a row above the victory point track. Then, he draws five stage II objective cards from the deck and places them facedown in a row below the victory point track.</li>\n<li>The speaker reveals the first two stage I objectives.</li>\n</ol>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game34.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>Twilight Imperium is played over a series of game rounds, each of which contains the following four phases that players must resolve in order.</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p><b>Strategy Phase:</b> During this phase, each player chooses a strategy card. These cards provide players with powerful abilities to use during the action phase. Each card also has a number that determines turn order for the game round.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Action Phase:</b> During this phase, the majority of the game's action occurs. This includes moving units, producing units, resolving combat, and using strategy cards.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Status Phase:</b> During this phase, players perform cleanup steps in preparation for the next game round.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Agenda Phase:</b> During this phase, players vote on political agendas, which can have lasting ramifications in the game. The agenda phase is added to the game after a player gains control of Mecatol Rex.</p></li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>These phases repeat in successive game rounds until one player accumulates 10 victory points and wins the game.</p>\n\n<p>These phases are described in detail in the following sections.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>1. Strategy Phase</h2>\n\n<p>During the strategy phase, players take turns selecting a strategy card that provides them with a unique action they can use during the action phase. First-time players may not know which strategy card to choose and should consult the strategy card overviews at the bottom of this page and the next.</p>\n\n<p>Beginning with the speaker and continuing clockwise, each player chooses one of the strategy cards from the common play area and places it faceup near his faction sheet. After a player chooses a strategy card, it is not available for other players during this game round.</p>\n\n<p>Each strategy card has a number between \"1\" and \"8\" in the upper-right corner. During the action phase, players take turns in order according to the number printed on their chosen strategy card, starting with \"1\". This is called initiative order.</p>\n\n<p>After each player has chosen a strategy card, the speaker places one trade good on each strategy card that was not chosen. During future strategy phases, when a player chooses a strategy card that has one or more trade goods on it, he gains those trade goods.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h3>Strategy Card Overview</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game37.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>1. <b>Leadership</b>: A player might choose this card to gain more command tokens, enabling him to perform more actions during the action phase.</p>\n\n<p>2. <b>Diplomacy</b>: A player might choose this card if he feels threatened, to prevent other players from attacking his system.</p>\n\n<p>3. <b>Politics</b>: A player might choose this card to draw action cards, increasing the variety of abilities that are available to him.</p>\n\n<p>4. <b>Construction</b>: A player might choose this card to produce planetary structures, such as space docks and PDS units.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>2. Action Phase</h2>\n\n<p>The action phase is the main phase of the game, during which players produce units, move ships, enact strategies, and interact with other players.</p>\n\n<p>During the action phase, players take turns in initiative order. While a player is taking a turn, he is the active player, and he can perform one action. After each player has taken a turn, player turns begin again in initiative order. Initiative order may repeat in this manner several times within a single action phase. The action phase does not end until each player has passed (see below).</p>\n\n<p>There are three types of actions: tactical actions, strategic actions, and component actions. They are described in detail later.</p>\n\n<p>If a player does not wish to perform an action during his turn, he may pass. After a player passes, his turn is skipped for the remainder of the action phase. A player cannot pass until he has performed his strategic action, which is explained later. After each player has passed, the game round continues to the status phase.</p>\n\n<h3>Tactical Action</h3>\n\n<p>A tactical action allows a player to move ships, initiate combat, invade planets, produce units, and otherwise interact with the game board.</p>\n\n<p>To understand a tactical action, players need to understand many other game concepts, such as movement and combat. For this reason, the steps of a tactical action are summarized below, but are not described in detail until later.</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p><b>Activation:</b> The active player must activate a system by taking a command token from his tactic pool and placing it in that system.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Movement:</b> The active player may move ships into a system from any number of other systems. Ships can also transport ground forces from one system to another.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Space Combat:</b> If multiple players have ships in the active system, they resolve a space combat.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Invasion:</b> The active player may commit ground forces to land on planets in the active system. If another player has units on those planets, the players resolve a ground combat.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Production:</b> If the active player has a space dock in the active system, he can produce units by spending resources.</p></li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>A player might not resolve all of the above steps during every tactical action. For example, a player may choose not to move units during the \"Movement\" step but may still produce units during the \"Production\" step.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h3>Strategy Card Overview</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game39.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>5. <b>Trade</b>: A player might choose this card to gain trade goods and commodities, which he could use to produce additional units or trade to other players.</p>\n\n<p>6. <b>Warfare</b>: A player might choose this card to allow some of his ships to move twice, or to build a unit and move it during the same game round.</p>\n\n<p>7. <b>Technology</b>: A player might choose this card to research a new technology that would grant him a new ability or unit upgrade.</p>\n\n<p>8. <b>Imperial</b>: A player might choose this card to draw an additional secret objective, granting him additional routes to victory.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<h3>Strategic Action</h3>\n\n<p>Each strategy card has both a primary ability and a secondary ability.</p>\n\n<p>When a player performs a strategic action, he resolves the primary ability of his strategy card. After resolving this ability, each other player may resolve the secondary ability of that strategy card. The active player cannot resolve the secondary ability of his own strategy card.</p>\n\n<p>After each player has had an opportunity to resolve a strategy card's secondary ability, the active player exhausts that strategy card by flipping it facedown. Players cannot resolve abilities on exhausted strategy cards, but the exhausted cards' numbers are still used to determine initiative order.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game43.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>A player cannot pass during the action phase unless his strategy card is exhausted. This means that each player must perform a strategic action at some point during the action phase, which guarantees that each other player has an opportunity to resolve the secondary ability of that strategy card. A player who has passed during the action phase can still resolve the secondary ability of other players' strategy cards.</p>\n\n<h3>Component Actions</h3>\n\n<p>A component action is an action that is printed on a game component. Many action cards, faction sheets, and even some technology cards have component actions. Each of these effects is preceded by the word \"Action\".</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game38.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<h3>Key Concept: Command Sheet</h3>\n\n<p>Successfully navigating the action phase in Twilight Imperium requires careful management of command tokens. When a player gains a command token, he places it in any one of three pools: the tactic pool, the fleet pool, or the strategy pool.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game44.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>Tactic Pool</h4>\n\n<p>During the action phase, players may spend command tokens from their tactic pool to perform tactical actions.</p>\n\n<h4>Fleet Pool</h4>\n\n<p>Players place command tokens in their fleet pool with the ship silhouette faceup. Players do not spend these command tokens like the command tokens in their other pools.</p>\n\n<p>Instead, the number of tokens in a player's fleet pool is the maximum number of ships, excluding fighters, that he can have in each system.</p>\n\n<p>If a player ever has more ships in a system than he has tokens in his fleet pool, he must return ships from that system to his reinforcements until the number of ships in that system no longer exceeds the number of tokens in his fleet pool.</p>\n\n<h4>Strategy Pool</h4>\n\n<p>Most of the secondary abilities on strategy cards require a player to spend a token from his strategy pool to resolve the ability. Players will want to keep tokens in their strategy pool so that they can use the secondary abilities of the other players' strategy cards.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n<h2>3. Status Phase</h2>\n\n<p>During the status phase, players perform various upkeep tasks, including repairing units and scoring objectives. To resolve the status phase, players perform the following steps in order:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p><b>Score objectives:</b> In initiative order, each player may score up to one public and one secret objective if he fulfills those cards' requirements. This is the main way in which players gain the victory points they need to win the game. Objectives are described in detail later.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Reveal public objective:</b> The speaker flips the next unrevealed public objective card faceup. The first stage II objective is not revealed until all stage I objectives have been revealed.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Draw action cards:</b> Each player draws one card from the top of the action card deck.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Remove command tokens:</b> Each player removes all of his command tokens from the game board and returns them to his reinforcements.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Gain and redistribute command tokens:</b> Each player gains two command tokens from his reinforcements. Then, he may redistribute any of the command tokens on his command sheet by moving them between his tactic, fleet, and strategy pools.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Ready cards:</b> Each player readies all of his exhausted cards, including planet, technology, and strategy cards.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Repair units:</b> Some units may have been turned on their side during the action phase to mark that they have been damaged. Players repair these units during this step by turning them upright. This is described in detail later.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Return strategy cards:</b> Each player returns his strategy card to the common play area. Then, if the custodians token is no longer on Mecatol Rex (the planet in the center of the game board) the game round continues to the agenda phase. Otherwise, a new game round begins with the strategy phase.<br><br><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game45.jpg\"></p></li>\n</ol>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<h3>Key Concept: Readied And Exhausted Cards</h3>\n\n<p>Many cards have a readied and an exhausted state. An exhausted card is flipped facedown, indicating that the values and abilities on the front of the card cannot be used.</p>\n\n<p>During the status phase, all exhausted cards are readied. A readied card is flipped faceup, indicating that the values and abilities on the front of the card can be used.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game47.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n<h2>4. Agenda Phase</h2>\n\n<p>After the custodians token has been removed from Mecatol Rex, a new phase is added to each round for the remainder of the game: the agenda phase.</p>\n\n<p>During this phase, the galactic council convenes to discuss issues that affect the entire galaxy. Players vote for outcomes on two agendas, establishing laws and policies that have lasting repercussions.</p>\n\n<p>Voting on agendas is described in detail later.</p>\n\n<p>After resolving this phase, a new game round begins with the strategy phase.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>A game of Twilight Imperium immediately ends when one player has gained 10 victory points. Players gain victory points by completing objectives. There are two types of objectives:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p><b>Public objectives:</b> During setup, the speaker reveals two public objectives, and more are revealed throughout the game. Any number of players can score each of these objectives.</p>\n\n<p><i>Important:</i> A player cannot score public objectives if he does not control all of the planets in his home system.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p><b>Secret objectives:</b> Each player begins the game with one secret objective that he may look at but must keep hidden from other players. A player can score his own secret objectives but not those belonging to other players.</p>\n\n<p><i>Important:</i> A player cannot have more than three total scored and unscored secret objectives. If he draws a secret objective and has more than three, he must choose one of his unscored secret objectives and return it to the deck. Then, he shuffles the secret objective deck.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Objective Timing</h3>\n\n<p>Each objective specifies when a player can score it, either during the status phase or during the action phase. This timing is indicated directly below a card's title. If a player scores an objective during the status phase, he must fulfill the requirement on the card during the \"Score Objectives\" step of the status phase to score that objective.</p>\n\n<p>For example, if an objective states that a player must control six planets outside of his home system, he must control those planets when he scores the objective- having controlled those planets earlier is not sufficient.</p>\n\n<p>Players can score some objectives by spending resources, influence, or tokens, as described by the objective card. To score such an objective, a player must pay the specified cost at the time indicated on the card.</p>\n\n<p>If an objective's timing specifies \"Action Phase\", a player can score it during the action phase immediately after he fulfills its requirements.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Scoring Objectives</h3>\n\n<p>If a player fulfills an objective's requirements at the time indicated on the card, he can score it. To do so, he advances his token on the victory point track a number of spaces equal to the value of the objective card.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/twilight-imperium/game48.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h3>Scoring a Two-Point Objective</h3>\n\n<p>After scoring an objective, a player places a control token from his supply on that objective card to indicate that he has scored it and cannot score it again this game. If he scored a secret objective, he places the card faceup in front of him before placing a control token on it.</p>\n\n<p><b>Important:</b> Each player can only score one public and one secret objective during each status phase and each step of the action phase.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>The Winner - Imperium Rex</h3>\n\n<p>The game can end early if no player has scored 10 victory points and there are no more objectives to reveal.</p>\n\n<p>When the speaker would reveal an objective but cannot, the game immediately ends and the <b>player with the most victory points wins the game.</b></p>\n\n<p>If there is a tie, the player among the tied players who is earliest in initiative order wins the game.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Three- And Four-player Games</h3>\n\n<p>When playing the game with three or four players, players implement the following rules:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><b>The strategy phase:</b> After each player has chosen one strategy card during the strategy phase, players repeat the strategy card selection process until each player has chosen a second strategy card from the available cards.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Initiative order:</b> Each player's lowest-numbered strategy card is used to determine his placement in initiative order.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Passing:</b> A player cannot pass during the action phase unless both of his strategy cards are exhausted.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"tactical-action.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Twilight Imperium Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:48:26.983Z"),
            ~~~~~~~~~

        ?   victoryConditions?: String | NullableStringFieldUpdateOperationsInput | Null,
        ?   game?: GameUpdateOneRequiredWithoutRulesNestedInput
          }
        })

[2025-08-15T14:48:53.931Z] [UltraBoardGames] ERROR: ❌ Database error for orleans: 
Invalid `prisma.gameRule.update()` invocation in
E:\King Dice\scripts\scrape-ultrabg-rules.js:296:29

  293 
  294 if (existingRule) {
  295   // Update existing rule
→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 92
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Orléans Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/orleans.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n<ul>\n<li>1 Large Game Board</li>\n<li>1 Small \"Beneficial Deeds\" Board</li>\n<li>4 Player Boards</li>\n<li>4 Followers Bags</li>\n<li>4 Merchant Tokens</li>\n<li>40 Trading Stations</li>\n<li>28 Wooden Cubes</li>\n<li>104 Character Tiles</li>\n<li>90 Goods</li>\n<li>16 Technology Tiles</li>\n<li>14 Citizen Tiles</li>\n<li>47 Coins</li>\n<li>20 Place Tiles</li>\n<li>18 Hour Glass Tiles</li>\n<li>2 Overview Cards</li>\n<li>1 Start Player Token</li>\n<li>1 rulebook</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<p>Each player takes: 1 Followers Bag, 5 coins, 1 Player Board, 10 Trading Stations, 7 markers (wooden cubes), 1 Merchant Token and 1 set of Followers (a farmer, a Boatman, a Craftsman, and a Trader).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game14.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Place your Trading Stations and coins in front of you. Place the 4 Followers of your color on the Market Spaces of your Player Board.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Place the large game board (places and terrain) and the \"Beneficial Deeds\" board on the table.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Place the Technology Tiles in a stack on the appropriate space of the game board.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Remove the \"Pilgrimage\" Tile (lighter hue) from the deck of Hour Glass Tiles, then shuffle the remaining tiles. Place the shuffled stack of tiles face down on the appropriate space of the game board and put the \"Pilgrimage\" Tile on top. The game will always start with the \"Pilgrimage\" event during the first round.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Place 1 marker from each player on the first space of each of the Character Tracks as well as the Development Track.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Sort the neutral Character Tiles (without the marking in player color) by profession and place them on the appropriate buildings on the game board.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game9.jpg\"><br><br>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Put the coins on the table close at hand.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game11.jpg\"><br><br>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Place 13 Citizen Tiles on the marked spaces on the game board and the \"Beneficial Deeds\" board. Put the remaining tile on the table.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Sort the Place Tiles by the Roman numerals on the reverse side and place them in separate stacks on the table.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game21.jpg\"><br><br>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Shuffle the Goods Tiles face down and place them face up on the Road and Waterway Spaces, one tile per space. In 4-player games, every such space receives a tile (whereas in 2- and 3-player games some spaces remain empty).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game17.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Sort the remaining Goods Tiles and place them face up on the appropriate spaces of the Goods Market (on the left side of the game board).</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Place your Merchant Token in Orleans.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h5>3-player Game:</h5>\n\n<p>Remove the Followers of the unused player color from the game. Remove 2 each of the neutral \"Farmer\", \"Boatman\", \"Craftsman\", and \"Trader\" Character Tiles from the game. Remove 3 each of the \"Knight\", \"Scholar\", and \"Monk\" Character Tiles from the game.</p>\n\n<p>Remove 6 Goods Tiles from the game at random. Do not place any Goods Tiles on spaces marked with \"4\". Those spaces remain empty.</p>\n\n<h5>2-player Game:</h5>\n\n<p>Remove the Followers of the unused player colors from the game. Remove 4 each of the neutral \"Farmer\", \"Boatman\", \"Craftsman\", and \"Trader\" Character Tiles from the game. Remove 6 each of the \"Knight\", \"Scholar\", and \"Monk\" Character Tiles from the game.</p>\n\n<p>Remove 12 Goods Tiles from the game at random. Do not place any Goods Tiles on spaces marked with \"3\" or \"4\". Those spaces remain empty.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>You are now ready to play!</p>\n\n</li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>You are trying to achieve dominance in various areas in medieval France. You will get goods, coins, and victory points via production, trade, development, and by committing to the common good.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>The youngest player receives the Start Player Token. <img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game22.jpg\"></p>\n\n<p>The game is played over 18 rounds, with each round being comprised of 7 phases.</p>\n\n<h3>Phase 1</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game23.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p><b>Hour Glass:</b> The Start Player draws the topmost Hour Glass Tile from the stack and turns it face up. The Hour Glass Tiles determine the length of the game.</p>\n\n<p>The game ends at the end of the round in which the 18th and last tile is drawn. Each Hour Glass Tile also introduces an event that will affect the current round.</p>\n\n<p>There are 6 different types of events Except Pilgrimage, events are resolved in Phase 6: \"Event\".</p>\n\n<h3>Phase 2</h3>\n\n<p><b>Census:</b> Determine who has the most and who has the least Farmers. The player whose marker is furthest ahead on the Farmers Track receives 1 coin from the supply. If there is a tie, no player receives the coin.</p>\n\n<p>The player whose marker is furthest behind on the track must pay 1 coin to the supply. If there is a tie, no player has to pay the coin.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game24.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> The blue player receives a coin and the red player must pay a coin.</p>\n\n<p><b>Please note:</b> In the 2-player game, the player who is behind on the track does not have to pay a coin. The player who is ahead still receives a coin.</p>\n\n<h3>Phase 3</h3>\n\n<p><b>Followers:</b> Draw Character Tiles from your Followers Bag and place them on the Market. You may draw a number of Character Tiles from your bag equal to or lower than the number indicated by your marker on the Knights Track.</p>\n\n<p>At the beginning of the game, this number is 4. Place the drawn tiles on the Market Spaces of your Player Board. You may not draw more tiles than you can fit in your Market.</p>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> Character Tiles that you do not use remain on your Market, thus taking up space that you might need when drawing tiles.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game25.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> The green player may draw 4 tiles from his bag. The yellow and blue player may each draw 6 tiles, and the red player may even draw 8 tiles from his bag.</p>\n\n<h3>Phase 4</h3>\n\n<p><b>Planning:</b> You may use the Character Tiles from your Market to activate actions in Places. You may leave Character Tiles on your Market to use them in subsequent rounds.</p>\n\n<p>Each Place provides a specific action and requires a certain set of Character Tiles to activate. (Some Place Tiles only require a single tile for activation or none at all).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game26.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> You need a boatman and a craftsman to receive another farmer.</p>\n\n<p>Place the required Character Tiles on the corresponding Action Spaces of the Place you want to activate. A Place is considered activated as soon as all of its Action Spaces have a tile. You can carry out the action during the following or during a future Action Phase.</p>\n\n<p>You are not required to place all required tiles during the same Planning Phase. You may place some now and the rest in subsequent rounds. As long as you have not placed all of the required tiles, you have not activated the action and may not play it.</p>\n\n<h3>Phase 5</h3>\n\n<p><b>Actions:</b> You may carry out the actions of the Places you activated, i.e. where you placed a Follower (or Technology Tile) on every required space.</p>\n\n<p>Beginning with the Start Player and in clockwise order, each player may carry out 1 action or pass. If you pass, you cannot carry out any more actions during that round.</p>\n\n<p>After you played an action, remove the Followers from that action (e.g. the Boatman and the Craftsman from the Farm House) and put them back into your bag.</p>\n\n<p><b>Please note:</b> Technology Tiles remain on the Action Spaces you placed them until the end of the game.</p>\n\n<p>You may carry out your actions in any order. You are not required to carry out an activated action. You may pass even if you could carry out more actions.</p>\n\n<p>The Action Phase ends when all players have passed. If you pass, you cannot participate in the current Action Phase anymore. Activated actions that you did not use this round remain activated and can be used in a subsequent round. Do not remove Character Tiles from actions you have not used yet.</p>\n\n<h3>Phase 6</h3>\n\n<p>Event: Resolve the event shown on the Hour Glass Tile of this round. (The event affects all players. See below for details on the events).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game27.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h3>Phase 7</h3>\n\n<p>Start Player: The current Start Player passes the Start Player Token to the player to his left.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game22.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>The Actions/Places</h2>\n\n<p><b>Every Place represents a specific action.</b> Your Player Board features the most common Places. As the game progresses, you can acquire additional Places.</p>\n\n<p>You can play an action if it is activated (all spaces occupied). After you played an action, you remove the Character Tiles (but not the Technology Tiles) used to activate it and return them to your Followers Bag.</p>\n\n<p>The Places and their actions in detail:</p>\n\n<h3>Farm House</h3>\n\n<p>Take a <b>Farmer Tile</b> from the Farm House on the game board and put the Farmer into your bag.</p>\n\n<p>Then advance your marker one space on the Farmers Track and receive the depicted good. The position of your marker on this track also plays a role during Phase 2: \"Census\".</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game30.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h3>Village</h3>\n\n<p>In the Village, you can receive another <b>Boatman, Craftsman, or Trader</b>. You can choose one of the following actions (Boatman, Craftsman, Trader):</p>\n\n<blockquote class=\"white\">\n\n<h4>1.boatman</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game32.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Take a <b>Boatman Tile</b> from the game board and put it into your Followers Bag. Then advance one space on the Boatmen Track and receive the depicted number of coins.</p>\n\n<p>On the last space of that track, the first player to get there receives a Citizen Tile instead of coins.</p>\n\n<h4>2.craftsman</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game35.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Take a <b>Craftsman Tile</b> from the game board and put it into your Followers Bag. Then advance one space on the Craftsmen Track and receive a Technology Tile.</p>\n\n<p>Put the Technology Tile next to your Player Board. You may only use it after you pass.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game37.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p><b>Technology:</b> You can place the Technology Tile on an Action Space of your choice to replace the required Character Tile for the rest of the game.</p>\n\n<p>You do not remove the Technology Tile after you played the action. It remains on its space until the end of the game.</p>\n\n<p><b>Constraints:</b></p>\n<ul>\n<li>The first Technology Tile you place in a game must replace a Farmer.</li>\n<li>Subsequent Technology Tiles may replace any Character Tile except Monks.</li>\n<li>Monks can never be replaced with Technology Tiles.</li>\n<li>You may not place more than 1 Technology Tile at one Place.</li>\n<li>You may not place a Technology Tile at a Place that only requires a single Character Tile.</li>\n<li>You may not move a Technology Tile after you placed it.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h4>3. Trader</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game36.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Take a <b>Trader Tile</b> from the game board and put it into your Followers Bag. Then advance one space on the Traders Track and expand your city with a Place Tile.</p>\n\n<p><b>Expanding the City:</b> You may choose a Place Tile. There are two types of Place Tiles, I and II. When you advance on the Traders Track for the first time, you may only choose a tile from stack I.</p>\n\n<p>Every other time you advance on the track, you may choose a tile from stack I or II. Place the chosen Place Tile next to your Player Board. You now have another Place you can activate or use its special ability.</p>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> The players may look through the stacks of Place Tiles at any time.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<h3>University</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game34.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Take a <b>Scholar Tile</b>f rom the game board and put it into your Followers Bag. Then advance one space on the Scholars Track and receive the depicted number of Development Points. For each Development Point you receive during the game, advance your marker one space on the Development Track.</p>\n\n<h3>Castle</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game33.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Take a <b>Knight Tile</b> from the game board and put it into your Followers Bag. Then advance one space on the Knights Track. The Knights Track indicates how many Followers you may draw from your bag and place on your Market in Phase 3.</p>\n\n<p>At the beginning of the game, you may draw 4 Followers each round. You can increase this number by recruiting Knights.</p>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> When you get your fourth Knight, this number (7) does not increase, but you may receive a Citizen Tile if you are the first player to get there.</p>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> Once your marker moves onto the last space of a track, you may no longer take the corresponding action.</p>\n\n<h3>Monastery</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game31.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Take a <b>Monk Tile</b> from the game board and put it into your Followers Bag. There is no additional bonus like with the other actions.</p>\n\n<p>Monks can be used in place of any of the other Character Tiles. (However, the inverse is not true. You cannot use another Character Tile or a Technology Tile in place of a Monk).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game41.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h3>Ship</h3>\n\n<p>Move your Merchant Token from its current location along a Waterway (blue connection) to an adjacent town. If there is a Goods Tile on the way, you may take it. If there are multiple goods, you may take one of them. Place the Goods Tile next to your Player Board.</p>\n\n<h3>Wagon</h3>\n\n<p>This action is similar to the \"Ship\" action, but rather than moving along a Waterway, move your Merchant Token along a Road (brown connection).</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Guildhall</h2>\n\n<p>Build a Trading Station in the town in which your Merchant Token is present if there is no Trading Station in that town already (regardless of which player it belongs to). Each town can only have one Trading Station.</p>\n\n<p>Exception: In Orleans, each player may build one Trading Station.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Scriptorium</h2>\n\n<p>You receive 1 Development Point. Advance your marker one space on the Development Track.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game48.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Town Hall</h2>\n\n<p>During the Planning Phase, you can place 1 or 2 Character Tiles in the Town Hall. (The Town Hall does not require both spaces be occupied in order to activate).</p>\n\n<p>When using the \"Town Hall\" action, move one or both Character Tiles from the Town Hall to any free appropriate spaces on the \"Beneficial Deeds\" board. You receive the depicted reward (1, 2, or 3 coins, and in case of Canalization 1 coin or 1 Development Point) for each character.</p>\n\n<p>When you complete a Beneficial Deed (i.e. you place a tile on the last remaining unoccupied space), you receive the Citizen Tile of that Beneficial Deed.</p>\n\n<p>You cannot replace the Character Tiles required for Beneficial Deeds with other tiles (like Monks). You must always use the exact Character Tiles as shown on the spaces. Character Tiles used for Beneficial Deeds remain there for the rest of the game.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game49.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Please note: You may not place the Followers of your color (i.e. your initial Farmer, Boatman, Craftsman, and Trader) in the Town Hall.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game51.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>The Development Track</h2>\n\n<p>Some spaces of the Development Track show coins or contain a Citizen Tile. If you move your marker onto or past a space with coins, you receive the depicted amount of coins from the supply. If you are the first player to move onto or past a space with a Citizen Tile, you receive that tile.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game52.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p><b>Development Status Spaces</b> indicate your state of development. If you move onto or past such a space, your Development Status immediately becomes the depicted value. At the beginning of the game, this value is 1.</p>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> Your Development Status affects the \"Income\" event (you receive a number of coins equal to your Development Status), the Hospital, as well as the victory point value of your Citizen Tiles and Trading Stations at the end of the game.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>The game ends after 18 rounds. Before you proceed with the scoring, the player who has built the most Trading Stations receives the remaining Citizen Tile. If there is a tie, no player receives the tile. Then determine your final scores. You score victory points (VP) for:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/orleans/game54.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n<ul>\n<li><b>Coins:</b> 1 VP per coin</li>\n<li><b>Brocade:</b> 5 VP</li>\n<li><b>Wool:</b> 4 VP</li>\n<li><b>Wine:</b> 3 VP</li>\n<li><b>Cheese:</b> 2 VP</li>\n<li><b>Grain:</b> 1 VP</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><b>Trading Stations and Citizen Tiles:</b> Each Trading Station you have built and every Citizen Tile you have collected is worth a number of VP equal to your Development Status.</p>\n\n<p>The player with the most VP wins. In case of a tie, the player further ahead on the Development Track wins. If still tied, there are multiple winners.</p>\n\n<p><i>(Example:</i> Klemens has built 5 Trading Stations and collected 2 Citizen Tiles. His current Development Status is 4, as indicated by the Development Track. He receives (5+2) x 4 = 28 VP).</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Torture (Bankruptcy)</h2>\n\n<p>Every time you must pay something (e.g. during Census or Taxes) and you cannot do so, you must undergo torture. You must replace every missing coin with something else from this list:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>a Trading Station (an already built one or one from your supply)</li>\n<li>a Follower (draw a random one from your bag; as long as you draw a Follower of your color, put the Follower back into the bag and draw again)</li>\n<li>a Development Point (move your marker on the Development Track one space to the left, but not onto or past a space with coins)</li>\n<li>a Goods Tile</li>\n<li>a Place Tile</li>\n<li>a Technology Tile</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>You may replace missing coins with any mix of items from this list (e.g. if you owe 5 coins, you may replace them with 1 Follower, 2 Trading Stations, and 2 Development Points).</p>\n\n<p>All items lost in this process are removed from the game. Only Development Points can be re-gained.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h4>General Rules of the Game</h4>\n\n<br>\n\n<h5>Running Out Of Tiles:</h5>\n\n<p>Character, Technology, and Goods Tiles are limited in this game. You cannot gain a tile if it is not available anymore. When you run out of a particular tile, you can no longer play an action that provides that tile.</p>\n\n<p>Events may result in certain tiles becoming available again (Harvest, Plague). When this happens, you can play the corresponding actions again. When there are not enough coins in the supply (temporarily), players cannot receive coins (at the moment).</p>\n\n<h5>Checking On Your Followers</h5>\n\n<p>At any time during the game, you may look into your bag to see how many and which Followers you have in there. (When you fi nish looking, shuffl e the tiles in your bag so that you cannot draw particular tiles on purpose).</p>\n\n<h5>Empty Roads Or Waterways</h5>\n\n<p>You may use empty Roads and Waterways. You just do not receive a good.</p>\n\n<h5>Marked Followers</h5>\n\n<p>The marked Followers of your color (which you received during setup) always remain with you (either in your bag or on your board). You cannot use them for Beneficial Deeds nor lose them to the Plague nor pay with them during Torture.</p>\n\n<h5>Placed Character Tiles</h5>\n\n<p>You cannot move a Character Tile from one Action Space to another. However, when drawing Followers from your bag during Phase 3: \"Followers\", for each Follower that you decline to draw, you may move a Character Tile from an Action Space to your Market. (Example: Stefan may draw 6 Followers. He only draws 4 Followers and moves 2 Followers from Action Spaces to his Market).</p>\n\n<h5>Payments</h5>\n\n<p>Pay coins into the general supply and take coins from there when you receive them.</p>\n\n<h4>Turn Order</h4>\n\n<p>Most phases can be played simultaneously. In Phase 4 (Planning), start planning at the same time. Then tell the other players when you are done planning. If need be, do this in turn order, i.e. beginning with the Start Player and in clockwise order. Likewise, resolve payments in that same order.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"events.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Orléans Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:48:53.929Z"),

E:\King Dice\scripts\scrape-ultrabg-rules.js:296:29

  294 if (existingRule) {
  295   // Update existing rule
→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 93
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Istanbul Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/istanbul.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<h2>Game Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<ul>\n<li>16 Place tiles (places)</li>\n<li>5 Wheelbarrows (player boards)</li>\n<li>15x Wheelbarrow extensions</li>\n<li>7x Stickers for the Governor, Smuggler and Merchants</li>\n<li>26 Bonus cards</li>\n<li>16 Mosque tiles</li>\n<li>10 Demand tiles</li>\n<li>Coins (30 x 1 lira, 15 x 5 lira, 12 x 10 lira)</li>\n<li>4 Mail indicators</li>\n<li>5 Overviews</li>\n<li>1 Starting player marker</li>\n<li>1 Governor and Smuggler</li>\n<li>32 Rubles</li>\n<li>2 Dice</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/Istanbul-play.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Lay out the 16 Place tiles in a 4x4 grid. This is 1 considered the game board. When playing for the first time, we recommend you use the \"Short paths\" layout, in which the Place tiles are laid out according to their blue numbers as shown below.</p>\n\n<p>Note: In a 2-player game: place the Merchant discs of the unused colors on the Mosques 14 15 and the Gemstone Dealer 16.</p>\n\n<p>Randomly determine a Start player. He gets 2 Lira and the Starting player marker. In clockwise order, each other player gets 1 more Lira than the player to his right. Then each player draws a Bonus card from the top of the stack.</p>\n\n<p>Sort the Mosque tiles by color and then by their number of goods symbols in 4 stacks (so that the tile on top of each stack shows 2 symbols) and place them on the two Mosques 14 15. Place 1 Ruby per player on each of the Mosques.</p>\n\n<p>Note: With 5 players: Only place 4 Rubies on each of the Mosques. With 3 players: Remove the tiles with 5 symbols from the game. With 2 players: Remove the tiles with 3 and 5 symbols from the game.</p>\n\n<p>Per player, place 1 Ruby and 3 Wheelbarrow extensions on the Wainwright 1. Place Rubies on the Gemstone Dealer 16 and the Sultan's Palace 13 beginning with the top space on the right.</p>\n\n<p>Continue to the space for the appropriate number of players. Place 1 Ruby on each space and leave the remaining spaces empty.</p>\n\n<p>Place the Mail indicators in the top row of the Post Office 5. Shuffle the 5 dark Demand tiles and place them face-up in a stack on the Large Market 10. Repeat this procedure for the Small Market 11 using the light Demand tiles.</p>\n\n<p>Determine the starting Places of the Governor and the Smuggler. For each of them, roll both dice and place the token on the Place tile with the appropriate number.</p>\n\n<p>Shuffle the Bonus cards and place them face-down in a stack as well as the coins and dice next to the game board. Each player chooses a color and takes the wooden components in that color.</p>\n\n<p>Also, take a Wheelbarrow and an Overview and place them in front of you.</p>\n\n<p>Place the 4 Goods indicators on the grey spaces of your Wheelbarrow. Place your Family members on the Police Station 12. Stack your 4 Assistant discs and place your Merchant disc on top of this stack. Then place these stacks on the Fountain 7. Place the 5th Assistant of each player easily accessible next to the game board.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Tutorial Video</h2>\n\n<iframe width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"//www.youtube.com/embed/ZEOD3Wdlucg?rel=0\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game play</h2>\n\n<p>Beginning with the Start player you take turns in clockwise order.</p>\n\n<p>When the first player has collected 5 Rubies (in a 2-player game: 6 Rubies) on the appropriate spaces of his Wheelbarrow, you complete the current round. After this round the game ends.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h2>Game Turn</h2>\n\n<p>A turn consists of 4 phases but, most of the time, only the 2 phases \"Movement\" and \"Action\" are actually played.</p>\n\n<p>The other phases, the so-called \"Encounters\"(blue background below), will only take place when your Merchant encounters other tokens.</p>\n\n<p>On your turn, you may use any number of Bonus cards and the special abilities of your Mosque tiles.</p>\n\n<p>You must always go through the following phases in the given order regardless of whether you go through all of them or not!</p>\n\n<h3>I. Movement</h3>\n\n<p>Move your Merchant and the stack of Assistants under him (if any) by 1 or 2 Places. You may not move diagonally and you must end up on a different Place than you started at.</p>\n\n<p>You then have the following three options at the Merchant's Target Place:</p>\n\n<ul>\n\n<p><b>Pick up an Assistant</b></p>\n<li><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/movement1.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If one of your Assistants was present at the target place already, put your stack on top of that Assistant (see fig. on the right). He will leave that place as part of the stack during the next Movement phase.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Leave an Assistant behind</b></p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/movement2.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If none of your Assistants was present at the target place, remove the bottommost Assistant from your stack and place him next to it. He will be left behind at that place during the next Movement phase.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>If you cannot or do not want to pick up an Assistant or leave one behind, your turn ends immediately (exception: Fountain 7).</p></li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<p>Note: If you have the yellow Mosque tile, you may pay 2 Lira to take an Assistant back from another Place and add him to your Merchant stack.</p>\n\n<h3>II. Encounters with other Merchants</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/encounters.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If there are any other Merchants at the Target Place, you have to pay each of them 2 Lira. Your turn ends immediately if you cannot or do not want to pay.</p>\n\n<p>Exception: You don't have to pay other Merchants at the Fountain 7.</p>\n\n<p>Special case in a 2-player game: If you encounter a neutral Merchant (ie of an unused color), pay the 2 Lira into the general supply. Then roll both dice to determine a new position for this neutral Merchant and place him there.</p>\n\n<h3>III. Action</h3>\n\n<p>You may carry out the action that the target place provides. If you cannot or do not want to carry it out, you may proceed with phase 4 (Encounters).</p>\n\n<h3>IV. Encounters with ...</h3>\n\n<h4>other Family members</h4>\n\n<p>If there are other players' Family members at the Target Place, you must catch them and send them all to the Police Station 12 (unless they are there already).</p>\n\n<p>As a reward for catching them, you may take 1 Bonus card or 3 Lira from the general supply for each such Family member. If you catch more than 1 Family member, you may take a different or the same reward for each of them (you do not get any reward in the Police Station).</p>\n\n<h4>the Governor</h4>\n\n<p>You may draw 1 Bonus card from the face-down stack and put it into your hand. If you do, either pay 2 Lira or discard 1 Bonus card from your hand.</p>\n\n<h4>the Smuggler</h4>\n\n<p>You may gain 1 good of your choice.</p>\n\n<p>If you do, either pay 2 Lira or 1 good.</p>\n\n<p>If you used the ability of the Governor or Smuggler, roll both dice and place the appropriate token on the Place indicated by the result of the dice roll (according to the large brown number). Roll separately if you used them both.</p>\n\n<p>Note: You may discard the Bonus card or pay the good you received from the Governor or Smuggler in order to move them.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Bonus Cards</h2>\n\n<p>On your turn, you may play any number of Bonus cards. Place every used or discarded Bonus card on the face-up discard pile on the Caravansary 6.</p>\n\n<p>When taking a Bonus card, draw it from the face-down draw pile (exception: Caravansary 6). Shuffle the discard pile to form a new face-down draw pile as soon as the draw pile runs out. You may keep any number of Bonus cards in your hand.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/bonuscards.jpg\" class=\" border\">\n\n<br><br>\n<h2>Places and their actions</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/wainwright.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h3>Wainwright</h3>\n\n<p>Pay 7 Lira into the general supply to take a Wheelbarrow extension from the Wainwright and place it in your Wheelbarrow.</p>\n\n<p>As soon as you complete your Wheelbarrow, i.e. once you have extended it for the 3rd time, immediately and only once take 1 Ruby off the Wainwright and place it on your Wheelbarrow.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/fabric.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h3>Fabric/Spice/Fruit Warehouse</h3>\n\n<p>Move the Goods indicator of the respective good as far to the right as possible. If you have the green Mosque tile, you may pay 2 Lira to gain 1 additional good of any type.</p>\n\n<h3>Post Office</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/postoffice.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>You receive the resources that are depicted on the 4 uncovered spaces. Then move the leftmost Mail indicator of the top row down to the bottom row. If all Mail indicators are already in the bottom row, move them all back to the top row.</p>\n\n<p>Example: You receive 3 Lira, 1 yellow and 1 red good. Then you move the Mail indicator off the blue good onto the yellow one.</p>\n\n<h3>Caravansary</h3>\n\n<p>Take 2 Bonus cards into your hand and discard 1 Bonus card from your hand.</p>\n\n<p>Note: When taking Bonus cards with this action (and only with this one), you may also take them from the top of the face-up discard pile.</p>\n\n<h3>Fountain</h3>\n\n<p>Return any number of your Assistants to your Merchant stack.</p>\n\n<p>The Fountain is the only Place where you do not need to have an Assistant there to carry out the action and you do not have to pay other Merchants if they are present.</p>\n\n<p>If you send your Family Member to the Fountain, your Assistants are still returned to your Merchant stack.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/blackmarket.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h3>Black Market</h3>\n\n<p>Gain 1 red or 1 yellow or 1 green good. Roll both dice: If you rolled 7 or 8: Gain 1 blue good. If you rolled 9 or 10: Gain 2 blue goods. If you rolled 11 or 12: Gain 3 blue goods.</p>\n\n<p>You may also roll the dice first and gain the one additional good afterwards.</p>\n\n<p>If you have the red Mosque tile, you may turn one die to \"4\" after the roll or re-roll both dice.</p>\n\n<h3>Tea House</h3>\n\n<p>Announce a number between 3 and 12. Then roll both dice. If you roll equal to or greater than the announced number, take the announced number of Lira from the general supply.</p>\n\n<p>Otherwise, only take 2 Lira.</p>\n\n<p>If you have the red Mosque tile, you may turn one die to \"4\" after the roll or re-roll both dice.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/market.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h3>Small/Large Market</h3>\n\n<p>Sell 1-5 of the goods that are depicted on the Demand tile. Move the Goods indicators on your Wheelbarrow accordingly. Then take the revenue from the general supply according to the table.</p>\n\n<p>Finally, move the current Demand tile to the bottom of the stack.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/police.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h3>Police Station</h3>\n\n<p>If your Family member is in the Police Station, \"free\" it and send it to another Place. Then carry out the action of that Place. Your Family member does not have any encounters.</p>\n\n<p>While at other Places, your Family member may be caught by other Merchants and sent back to the Police Station. As a reward, the catching player will get 1 Bonus card or 3 Lira.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/sultan.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h3>Sultan's Palace</h3>\n\n<p>Deliver all the goods that are not covered by a Ruby to the Sultan.</p>\n\n<p>As a reward, take the next available Ruby from the track and place it on your Wheelbarrow. Consequently, the next Ruby will be more expensive.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/mosque.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h3>Small/Great Mosque</h3>\n\n<p>Take 1 Mosque tile. To do so, your Wheelbarrow must carry the goods that are depicted on the Mosque tile in the required quantities.</p>\n\n<p>Then pay 1 of the depicted goods. Each Mosque tile provides a special ability (see below or blue texts). You may only have one copy of each tile.</p>\n\n<p>As soon as you acquire both tiles of one Mosque, immediately and only once take 1 Ruby from that Mosque and place it on your Wheelbarrow.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/gemstone.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h3>Gemstone Dealer</h3>\n\n<p>Pay a number of Lira into the general supply equal to the biggest number that is not covered by a Ruby.</p>\n\n<p>Then take the next available Ruby from the track and place it on your Wheelbarrow. Consequently, the next Ruby will be more expensive.</p>\n\n<p>Example: The biggest number that is not covered by a Ruby is 15. So you have to pay 15 Lira to get the next Ruby from the track.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Mosque Tiles</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/redtile.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p><b>Red tile</b></p>\n\n<p>At the Tea House 9 and the Black Market 8 , you may turn 1 die to \"4\" after the roll or re-roll both dice (1x).</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/bluetile.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p><b>Blue tile</b>\n\n</p><p>Immediately take the 5th Assistant of your color from the general supply and place him under your Merchant.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/greentile.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p><b>Green tile</b></p>\n\n<p>When using one of the three Warehouses 2 3 4 , you may pay 2 Lira to gain 1 additional good of any type.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/yellowtile.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p><b>Yellow tile</b></p>\n\n<p>Once on your turn, you may pay 2 Lira to return an Assistant to your Merchant stack.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the game</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/istanbul/box.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The first player to collect 5 Rubies (in a 2-player game: 6 Rubies) triggers the end of the game.</p>\n\n<p>When this happens, complete the current round. Then each player may use his leftover Bonus cards that provide goods or money. This may matter for the tie-breaker.</p>\n\n<p>The player with the most Rubies wins.</p>\n\n<p>Ties are broken in the following order: most leftover Lira, most leftover goods on the Wheelbarrow, most leftover Bonus cards. If these have not resolved the tie, there are multiple winners.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"buy-istanbul.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Istanbul Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:49:05.824Z"),
