[2025-08-15T14:49:27.913Z] [UltraBoardGames] ERROR: ❌ Database error for caverna: 
Invalid `prisma.gameRule.update()` invocation in
E:\King Dice\scripts\scrape-ultrabg-rules.js:296:29

  293 
  294 if (existingRule) {
  295   // Update existing rule
→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 94
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Caverna Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/caverna.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<p>In this game, you take the roles of adventurous dwarfs living reclusively in caves where you dig for ore and rubies and furnish caverns to become living and working areas.</p>\n\n<p>You need ore to craft weapons to undertake expeditions in search of adventure and loot. Rubies are a valuable and highly flexible good: you can trade them for other goods and landscape tiles at any time.</p>\n\n<p>Outside your caves, you will look after your sustenance by felling trees, raising farm animals and doing some agriculture.</p>\n\n<p>At the end of the game, the wealthiest dwarf will win.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n<ul>\n<li>300+ wooden pieces for animals, resources and dwarfs</li>\n<li>60+ acrylic nuggets for ore and ruby</li>\n<li>7 large Home boards</li>\n<li>1 small and large basic game board</li>\n<li>1 small and large additional game board</li>\n<li>1 two-sided basic game board</li>\n<li>4 longish supply boards</li>\n<li>16 punchboards with over 400 pieces</li>\n<li>30 cards</li>\n<li>1 score sheet</li>\n<li>1 rulebook</li>\n<li>1 appendix</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<h4>Your Personal Playing Areas</h4>\n\n<p>Each player chooses a color and takes the Home board and the 5 Dwarfs and 3 Stables of that color.</p>\n\n<p>Place 2 of the 5 Dwarfs side by side in the \"Entry- level dwelling\" on your Home board. Keep the remaining 3 Dwarfs and Stables next to your Home board as your personal supply.</p>\n\n<p>(Return the Dwarfs, Stables and Home boards of the leftover colors to the game box).</p>\n\n<p>Then take one of each of the 2 different Overview cards.</p>\n\n<p>Randomly determine the player who gets the Starting player token. The Starting player and the player to his left each get 1 Food. The third player gets 2 Food. Each other player gets 3 Food.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game1.jpg\"><br>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p>We recommend you cover the Dwarfs in your supply with Stables to avoid using them by accident before you are allowed to.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game2.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Players get a different number of Food depending on their position in the turn order.</p>\n\n<h4>The Game Boards With Action Spaces</h4>\n\n<p>Place the two single -sided basic game boards with Round spaces 1 to 3 and 4 to 12 next to each other.</p>\n\n<p>Shuffle the 7 Harvest markers and place them face -down (with the grey rune symbol facing up) on the Round spaces 6 to 12, one marker per space. Place the \"Harvest events\" card next to the game boards.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game9.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<p>In a 2-player game, remove one of the Harvest markers with a green leaf from the game. Then distribute the remaining 6 markers among the Round spaces 6 to 12 leaving space 9 empty.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game10.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Place the third basic game board to the left of the first two. Turn it to the appropriate side depending on the number of players (1 to 3, or 4 to 7 players).</p>\n\n<p>There are two additional game boards.</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>In games with 5 to 7 players, the larger additional game board is used. Turn it to the appropriate side depending on the number of players (5, or 6 to 7 players).</p></li>\n\n<li><p>The smaller additional game board is used in games with 3 or 7 players.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Place the required additional game boards to the left of the basic ones.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game11.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>The Supply Boards and Furnishing Tiles</h4>\n\n<p>The supply boards are double-sided. One side is used in the Introductory game, the other side is used in the Full game. The Full game comes with a larger variety of Furnishing tiles. (Put the unused Furnishing tiles back into the game box when playing an Introductory game).</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p>When playing with 6 or 7 players, we recommend that you start with the Full that you start with the Full game to make sure that there is a sufficient number of Furnishing tiles in play.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>Place the Furnishing tiles on the appropriate spaces on the supply boards. There is more than one ordinary \"Dwelling\" tile. Place some of them on the appropriate space on the supply board and keep the rest next to it as a reserve.</p>\n\n<p>There is a sufficient number of ordinary \"Dwelling\" tiles (costing 4 wood and 3 stone). You do not need to put all of them on the supply board. Replenish them incrementally from time to time when needed.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game13.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>The Action Space Cards</h4>\n\n<p>Shuffle the 12 Action space cards. Keep them face-down while shuffling.</p>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<p>In the 2-player game, only 11 Action space cards are used. Remove the \"Exploration\" card with the \"Level 4 expedition\" from the game. (Cover the unused Round space 9 with a Dwarf card).</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>Rearrange the shuffled Action space cards into a face-down stack as follows without looking at them.</p>\n\n<p>The 12 Action space cards rearranged after shuffling. You can fan them out or keep them in a stack.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game14.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>Put the three stage 4 cards at the bottom of the stack, on top of them the three (or two) stage 3 cards, and on top of those the two ordinary stage 2 cards.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Put the card for round 4 on top of these. (This card says \"Wish for children \" on one side and \"Urgent wish for children\" on the other side. Right now it does not matter which side faces up).</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Finally, put the three stage 1 cards on top of the stack.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h4>The Landscape Tiles</h4>\n\n<p>Sort the landscape tiles by type and put them in separate stacks. There are 3 types of both, single tiles and twin tiles.</p>\n\n<h4>The Building Materials, Animals and Weapon Strength Markers</h4>\n\n<p>Separate the remaining components and keep them in separate piles next to the game boards. All the animals may be kept in one pile and all the building materials in another. You do not need to sort the Weapon strength markers by number.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game12.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>You will place single and twin tiles on your Home boards during the course of the game. Fields and Meadows (which can be further upgraded to Pastures) can be placed on Forest spaces; Caverns and Tunnels (which can be further upgraded to Mines) can be placed on Mountain spaces.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game8.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Your Home board consists of two parts (see below). On the left side, there is a Forest that you will cut down during the course of the game.</p>\n\n<p>On the right side, there is a Mountain with an entrance to your cave system, which currently consists of two Caverns.</p>\n\n<p>One of these is the \"Entry-level dwelling\" and has been furnished for 2 Dwarfs and a pair of animals. The other Cavern is still empty, but is ready to be furnished.</p>\n\n<p>Your first two Dwarfs live in the entry-level room of your cave system. If you want to grow your Dwarf family, you will need to add more Dwellings. There are Furnishing tiles for this purpose as you have already seen during setup.</p>\n\n<p>Each of your Dwarfs may take one action per round - the available actions are displayed on the game boards. You will place your Dwarfs, one at a time, in clockwise order on Action spaces until all players have placed their Dwarfs on the game boards.</p>\n\n<p>The goal of your actions is to collect Food for your Dwarfs and to develop your Home board to be worth a lot of Gold points at the end of the game. Let us have a look at what you can do with your Home board and what you get Gold points for.</p>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<p>Caverns can be furnished like the one at the bottom of this illustration or they can be empty like the one at the top. Dwellings are special types of furnished Caverns. There are a lot of other ways to furnish a Cavern.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>When placing your Dwarfs on the game boards, you will eventually get in one another's way. Each Action space may only be occupied by a single Dwarf. The Dwarfs only return home after they have all been placed. Then they are placed again in the next round.</p>\n\n<p>While reading the rules, you may come back to the following section every now and then to get a better view of the context. This section is not required for understanding the rules. Any information found here is also explained elsewhere in the rule book.</p>\n\n<h4>To get a grasp of what happens on your home boards</h4>\n\n<p>You cut the Forest on your Home board to get Wood and cut through the Mountain to get Stone. You need these building materials to furnish the hollowed out spaces of your Mountain. Outside the Mountain, you can use the cleared Forest land to do agriculture and raise Farm animals to feed your little family.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game16.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game7.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>Weapons And Expeditions</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game17.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Veteran \"Agricola\" players may be highly interested in what the Weapons are for. In Caverna, your Dwarfs gather Ore to forge Weapons. The strength of a Weapon is determined by the amount of Ore used in the process and is increased by 1 after each Expedition.</p>\n\n<p>Depending on its level, an Expedition may yield 1 to 4 loot items. What these items will be depends on the strength of the Weapon that has been used (see the Overview card).</p>\n\n<p>A newly forged Weapon can only have an initial strength equal to or lower than 8. This strength can be increased over the course of the game to the maximum strength value of 14.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game20.jpg\"><br>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p>The special thing about the 'Cave Farmers' is the two groups that emerge when playing with a lot of players: one group goes after Weapons, the other one pursues the peaceful route.</p>\n\n<p>Members of the same group, of course, will compete for the same resources. Be vigilant about the competition within your group, so you do not lose against the other one.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote class=\"white\">\n\n<h4>Number Of Components</h4>\n\n<p>The only components that are purposely limited in number (apart from the unique Furnishing tiles) are the 5 Dwarfs and 3 Stables of each player. Any other components are considered to be unlimited. If you run out of any such component, use the Multiplication markers or improvise. Put a good token on a Multiplication marker to indicate 4 tokens of that type.</p>\n\n<p>There are markers depicting 8 animals of a specific type. These can be used on Large pastures with a Stable. Also, there are markers for 10 units of a specific type of building material or for 5 Rubies.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game21.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<br>\n\n<p>You can \"multiply\" animals as well. This Large pasture is currently holding 4 Wild boars.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<h4>Let us have a look at the Scoring Pad</h4>\n\n<p>At the end of the game, the player with the most Gold points wins. In the following example, we will have a look at the ways you can score points. The numbers in parentheses are the points gained in the example.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game22.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>This section consists of two parts. At first, we will look at the course of a round. Then we will explain the actions.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Turn</h2>\n\n<p>Each of the 12 rounds goes through five phases that are played one after another in the order described here.</p>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<p>In the 2-player game, there are only 11 rounds to play.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p>Players who have already played 'Agricola' only need to read the brown sentences. All the other rules are the same in both 'Caverna' and 'Agricola'.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>The five phases of a turn are:</p>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Add a new Action space</h5>\n\n<p>At the beginning of each round, turn over the top Action space card and put it on the appropriate space on the basic game boards.</p>\n\n<p>This is where you will place the first Action space card in Round 1.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Replenish accumulating spaces</h5>\n\n<p>Place goods from the general supply on the Action spaces that require them. These Action spaces show an arrow.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Work phase</h5>\n\n<p>In clockwise order, take turns to place 1 Dwarf per turn on an Action space on the game boards. Then carry out the actions on that space. Each Action space may only be occupied by a single Dwarf.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Return home</h5>\n\n<p>After all Dwarfs have been placed on Action spaces, return your Dwarfs to their Dwellings.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game26.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h5>Harvest time</h5>\n\n<p>At the end of most of the rounds, there is a harvest: collect Grain and Vegetables, feed your family, and breed your animals.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n<h2>1. Add a New Action Space</h2>\n\n<p>Turn over the top Action space card from the stack and put it on the empty Round space with the lowest number. (The Round spaces are numbered 1 to 12).</p>\n\n<p>The new Action space adds to the number of available actions. It can be used by any player in the Work phase of this and all subsequent rounds.</p>\n\n<p>From the start of round 6, you must also turn the Harvest marker on the Round space where the new Action space card is placed face-up. Leave the marker on the grey rune space.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game29.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n\n<p>The first Round space reminds you to check if you need additional game boards</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game30.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>There is a grey rune symbol on the back side of each Harvest marker, and a green leaf or red question mark on the front side.</p>\n\n<p>If the Harvest marker shows a green leaf, there will be a normal harvest at the end of the round.</p>\n\n<p>If it shows a red question mark, the harvest will be played differently.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<blockquote class=\"white\">\n\n<h5>Special Cases When Adding A New Action Space</h5>\n\n<p>The \"Wish for children\" Action space card will always come into play in round 4. Initially, place it with the \"Wish for children\" side facing up on the game board. Turn it to the other side that says \"Urgent wish for children\" as soon as you add the \"Family life\" Action space card in stage 3.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game31.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>That's the way it is with small families: Over time a wish for children will become an urgent wish.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<p>In the 2-player game, the last round of stage 3 - round 9 - is skipped, as the \"Exploration\" Action space card was removed from the game.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n<h2>2. Replenish Accumulating Spaces</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game34.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>On many Action spaces, there is a special arrow and a background illustration indicating that this space has to be replenished with goods every round. These Action spaces are called \"accumulating spaces\".</p>\n\n<p>Accumulating spaces have to be replenished even if there are goods left on them from previous rounds. \"3 Wood\" and an arrow, for instance, indicate that you put 3 Wood on that Action space every round.</p>\n\n<p>There is an exception: \"3 (1) Wood\" and an arrow, for instance, indicate that you put 1 Wood on that Action space every round - unless that Action space is empty, in which case you put 3 Wood on it. Read the icons of other Action spaces accordingly. \"1 Grain (1 Vegetable)\" on the \"Sustenance\" Action space, for instance, means you have to put 1 Grain on that space if it is empty, and 1 Vegetable instead if not.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p>Details on replenishing accumulating spaces:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>When replenishing, take the required goods from the general supply.</li>\n<li>There is no upper limit for the number of goods on an accumulating space.</li>\n<li>If you run out of a specific good, use the Multiplication markers or improvise (see page 5)</li>\n</ul>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n<h2>3. Work Phase</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game35.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>Beginning with the Starting player and in clockwise order, take turns to pick up a single Dwarf from your cave and place it on an unoccupied Action space. Then carry out the depicted action immediately. Play continues until all Dwarfs of all players have been placed in this fashion.</p>\n\n<p>Please note the play order of Dwarfs: You have to place your Dwarfs in ascending order of their Weapon strength, beginning with your unarmed Dwarfs (i.e. those without a Weapon) and followed by your armed ones (i.e. those bearing a Weapon).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game36.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Each Action space can only be used by one Dwarf in a round.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game37.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Whenever you take building materials, Grain, Vegetables, Food or Rubies, the tokens are placed in your personal supply in view of the other players. Animals may not be placed in your supply; they must be placed directly on your Home board.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h5>Details on the Work Phase</h5>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>Animals that you gain during the Work phase but that you cannot or do not want to accommodate on your Home board may be converted into Food immediately (according to the conversion table on your Home board).</p></li>\n\n<li><p>You can only place Dwarfs from your cave. You may not use the Dwarfs in your personal supply (as they have not been born yet, if you will, but they can be introduced later).</p></li>\n\n<li><p>On your turn, you can only ever place one Dwarf at a time.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>You may not place a Dwarf on an Action space without performing at least one of its actions.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Due to the \"Family growth\" action (see page 15), some players may have fewer Dwarfs than others in their caves. If a player runs out of Dwarfs during a round, this player is skipped. Only the players that have Dwarfs left in their caves continue to play them one by one as described.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>On some Action spaces you have to choose one out of several options (\"either ... or\").</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Other Action spaces allow you to take any number of the available actions (\"and/or\", \"and then/or\").</p></li>\n\n<li><p>There are two Action spaces that have a mandatory primary action and an optional follow-up action (\"and then\"). In case of the \"Urgent wish for children\" Action space, you have to use the first action in order to use the second one at all.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n<h2>4. Return Home</h2>\n\n<p>Remove your Dwarfs from the game boards and return them to their Dwellings.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h5>Details on Returning Home</h5>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>It does not matter how you distribute the Dwarfs among the Dwellings in your cave system.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>You may never have more Dwarfs in play than available room in your cave. This is why each of your tired Dwarfs will always find a place to sleep.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>It is best to place your Dwarfs side by side in your cave so that your opponents can easily see which of your Dwarfs have a Weapon and what strengths these Weapons have.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n<h2>5. Harvest Time</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game41.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>During the Harvest time, players have to sustain their families. Some rounds do not end with a harvest, others do. A harvest goes through three sub-phases that are played in the following order.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Sub-phase 1: <b>The Field phase</b>.</h5>\n\n<p>Remove 1 Grain or Vegetable token from each sown Field on your Home board and place it in your personal supply. (See page 14 for information on how to grow crops).</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Sub-phase 2: <b>The Feeding phase</b>.</h5>\n\n<p>In the Feeding phase, you have to feed your Dwarfs by paying 2 Food per Dwarf in your cave. Offspring that were born during the current round from a \"Family growth\" action only consume 1 Food for this round, but will require 2 Food in future harvests.</p>\n\n<p>If you do not have enough Food, you may convert goods into Food or you will have to take Begging markers.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h4>Begging Markers</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game42.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If you cannot or do not wish to produce the required Food, you must take 1 Begging marker for each missing Food. You may not give up Dwarfs to avoid the need to feed them.</p>\n\n<p>At the end of the game, you will lose 3 Gold points for each Begging marker. There is no way to return Begging markers once you have taken them.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Sub-phase 3: <b>The Breeding Phase</b>.</h5>\n\n<p>If you have at least 2 Farm animals of the same type, you get exactly 1 additional (baby) animal of that type - but only if the new animal can be accommodated on your Home board.</p>\n\n<p>Baby animals and parent animals may not be converted into Food immediately after the birth. You have to accommodate them on your Home board first.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game43.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>The player in this example has built a Stable in the Forest just outside his cave. Now he is able to keep up to 3 Wild boars.</p>\n\n<p>Therefore, his Wild boars can breed a piglet (despite the fact that they currently do not seem to be interested in each other at all).</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h5>Details On Breeding</h5>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>You get all of your baby animals at the same time, not one by one.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>You can only get at most one animal per type in each harvest.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Dogs are not considered Farm animals. They do not breed.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>The animals breed regardless of where the parent animals are placed on your Home board. The parents may be in separate areas.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Which Rounds end with a Harvest?</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Rounds 1 To 4</h5>\n\n<p>In the first four rounds, there is only one harvest: at the end of the third round. The first two rounds do not have a harvest at all. At the end of round 4, there is no harvest but instead you have to pay 1 Food per Dwarf in your cave (even for offspring Dwarfs). There is no Field or Breeding phase at this time.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Rounds 5 To 12</h5>\n\n<p>By default there will be a harvest at the end of rounds 5 to 12.</p>\n\n<p>This may change if a Harvest marker shows a red question mark. (Harvest markers have been placed on Round spaces 6 to 12 during setup). The change depends on the number of question marks that have already been revealed.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>As explained on the \"Harvest events\" card, there is no harvest at the end of the round in which the first question mark is revealed (like at the end of rounds 1 and 2).</p></li>\n\n<li><p>At the end of the round when the second question mark is revealed, instead of a harvest, you have to pay 1 Food per Dwarf in your cave (even for offspring Dwarfs; like at the end of round 4).</p></li>\n\n<li><p>When the third question mark is revealed, you have to decide individually whether you want to play the Field phase or the Breeding phase of the Harvest time at the end of the round.<br><br>You cannot play both these phases, but you must still play the Feeding phase. Each player may choose differently.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>To keep track of how many question marks have been already revealed, place them on the \"Harvest events\" card (from top to bottom) after they have been resolved.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p>You will need a lot of Food for your hungry Dwarfs due to the high number of harvests in this game.</p>\n\n<p>On the other hand, you will collect crops more frequently and your animals will breed more often. If you take the right steps to feed your family early on, it will not be as hard as it seems.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>In this example, the first question mark has already been resolved. When the next one is revealed, all players will have to pay 1 Food for each of their Dwarfs.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game44.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Food Conversion Rules</h3>\n\n<p>To feed your Dwarfs, you may convert goods into Food at any time (without constraints). There is a Food conversion table at the bottom right of your Home board that summarizes the following Food conversion rules:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game45.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>You can buy Food with Gold. Pay one more Gold than the amount of Food you wish to get. (For instance, 1/2/3/.. Food cost 2/3/4 Gold, respectively. Gold is available in denominations of 1, 2 and 10.</p>\n\n<p>You may change your Gold at any time. You cannot spend the Gold points that are awarded at the end of the game for things like Mines or Meadows. Keep in mind that each Gold is worth 1 point at the end of the game).</p>\n\n</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<p>In addition, you can convert animals and crops into Food.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>Sheep are each worth 1 Food, Wild boars 2 Food, and Cattle 3 Food. A single Donkey is worth 1 Food, but 2 Donkeys are worth 3 Food.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Each Grain is worth 1 Food, and Vegetables are worth 2 Food.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Rubies could be exchanged for goods like Wild boars and Vegetables that are each worth 2 Food; therefore, you can convert Rubies into 2 Food directly.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Dogs and the building materials Wood, Stone and Ore are not worth any Food. (Nor are Dwarfs, by the way).</p>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game46.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<br>\n\n<p>The Food conversion table on your Home board summarizes the Food conversion rules.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p>Now you know how to play a round. If you go back to pages 4 to 6, you might notice what we have not talked about yet: which actions you can take to become a wealthy dwarf. Let us have a look at the remaining rules by explaining the Action spaces.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>As most of the following rules will be new to veteran 'Agricola' players as well, we will now stop using brown color to mark new stuff.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>The Actions</h2>\n\n<p>Some Action spaces are already available at the beginning of the game, others will become available later. Some Action spaces are only available with a certain number of players.</p>\n\n<p>We will now explain the Action spaces grouped by type in the following order.</p>\n<ol>\n<li>Action spaces for twin tiles</li>\n<li>Action spaces for family growth</li>\n<li>Action spaces for goods and mines</li>\n<li>Action spaces for animals</li>\n<li>Action spaces for weapons</li>\n<li>Starting player</li>\n<li>Imitation</li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>Check here <a href=\"actions.php\">all detailed information about the actions</a>.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game119.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The game ends at the end of round 12. Use the scoring pad to determine the final scores. There are several different categories for which you can get Gold points. The player who has the most Gold points wins the game. (In case of a tie, there are multiple winners).</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><b>1 Gold per Farm animal and Dog:</b> Each animal is worth 1 Gold point at the end of the game, even Dogs. (Dogs are not considered Farm animals).</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>-2 Gold per missing type of Farm animal:</b> At the end of the game, you should have at least 1 Sheep, 1 Donkey, 1 Wild boar and 1 Cattle. You lose 2 Gold points for each- of these types that you do not have on your Home board. (You do not need to have any Dogs).</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>1/2 Gold per Grain (rounded up):</b> Count all of your Grain tokens - both those in supply and those still left on Fields. Divide this number by 2 and round it up. This is the number of Gold points you get for Grain.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>1 Gold per Vegetable:</b> Count all of your Vegetable tokens - both those in your supply and those still left on Fields. You get this number of Gold points for Vegetables.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>1 Gold per Ruby:</b> At the end of the game, each Ruby is worth 1 Gold point.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>1 Gold per Dwarf:</b> At the end of the game, each of your Dwarfs is worth 1 Gold point.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>1 Gold per unused space:</b> Count the number of spaces on your Home board that have no tile or Stable on them. You lose 1 Gold point for each such space. The two pre-printed Caverns of your cave system are considered used. (Unfurnished Caverns are also considered used).</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Gold for Furnishing tiles, Pastures and Mines:</b> Add up the Gold point values on all of your tiles. Small pastures are worth 2 Gold points, Large pastures are worth 4 Gold points (regardless of the type and number of animals on those tiles).<br><br>Ore mines are worth 3 Gold points, Ruby mines are worth 4 Gold points (regardless of whether they hold a Donkey or not). The value of a Furnishing tile is printed on the right of the tile, right under the name of the tile.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Bonus points for Parlors, Storages and Chambers:</b> Most of the Furnishing tiles called Parlors, Storages and Chambers (indicated by the yellow name tag) may be worth Bonus points depending on the condition they impose.<br><br>The scoring pad has multiple lines for Bonus points. You can use one line per Furnishing tile that you get Bonus points for. (Details on the Furnishing tiles can be found on page A3 of the appendix).</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Gold coins and Begging markers:</b> Add up the values on your Gold coins and subtract 3 Gold points from that for each Begging marker you have.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h5>Details on Bonus Points</h5>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>Bonus points for the Weaving parlor, Milking parlor, Fodder chamber, Food chamber and Treasure chamber are awarded as \"Bonus points\" (even though you could add them to other categories).</p>\n\n<p>Minus points prevented by the Writing chamber have to be adjusted in the respective categories.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game115.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<br>\n\n<p>If you have the Weaving parlor, you will get points for Sheep twice: in the category \"1 Gold per Farm animal\" and in the category \"Bonus points for Parlors\".</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<br>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>As with the Writing chamber, Bonus points for the Hunting parlor, Beer parlor, Blacksmithing parlor and Spare part storage are not awarded as \"Bonus points\" on the scoring pad.</p>\n\n<p>These tiles allow you to exchange goods for Gold before scoring. (If you forgot to do so but notice it just before scoring, you may still do it).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/caverna/game116.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<br>\n\n<p>If you have the Writing chamber, your minus points in the \"-2 Gold per missing type of Farm animal\", \"-1 Gold per unused space\" and \"Begging markers\" categories will be reduced.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"actions.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n</blockquote>",
            rulesText: "Caverna Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:49:27.910Z"),
            ~~~~~~~~~

The goal is to score the most points by fighting against and/or running from the Dragon that you just woke.</p>\n\n<p>But beware, your fellow adventurers may hinder (or aid) you in your strategy and the final scoring of treasure cards, gold coins, and bonus points will vary depending on which of 3 ways the games end, so watch your step! â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"dragon-rampage/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Area Control</a><a>Dice</a><a>Dice Rolling</a><a>Fantasy</a><a>Card Drafting</a><a>Game Rules</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"dragon-rampage/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Dragon Rampage Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/ascension/components.jpg\" width=\"300\" alt=\"\"></div>\n<h4>Components</h4>\n\n\n<ul>\n<li>6 Character Mats</li>\n<li>6 Character Decks</li>\n<li>6 Sets of Hero Action Tokens</li>\n<li>50 Coins</li>\n<li>1 Game Board</li>\n<li>6 Sets of 12 Dragon Wound Cubes</li>\n<li>30 Hero Wound Tokens</li>\n<li>1 Treasure Deck</li>\n<li>7 Special Action Dice</li>\n<li>1 Movement Die</li>\n<li>Dragon Rampage Deck</li>\n<li>6 Player Movement Tokens</li>\n<li>1 First Player Token</li>\n<li>1 Re-Roll Token</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Object of the Game</h4>\n\n\n\n<p>Dragon Rampage is a game for 3 to 5 players. The goal is to score the most points by fighting against and/or running from the Dragon that you just woke.</p>\n\n<p>But beware, your fellow adventurers may hinder (or aid) you in your strategy and the final scoring of treasure cards, gold coins, and bonus points will vary depending on which of 3 ways the games end, so watch your step! â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"dragon-rampage/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Area Control</a><a>Dice</a><a>Dice Rolling</a><a>Fantasy</a><a>Card Drafting</a><a>Game Rules</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"games-of-art/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Games of Art Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/ascension/games-of-art.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div><p>Games mean many things to many people; to me they are an art form of great potential beauty. Just as a composer's creation is brought to life by the performing musicians, a game inventor's creation is brought to life by the players of the game.</p>\n\n<p>When the creation is inspired and the players are talented, a true work of art results.</p>\n\n<p>In creating the seven games in this book I have attempted to add a new visual dimension to the art of games. As each is played, a colorful drawing is formed. Because these drawings are reminiscent in style of the works of different modern masters of abstract art - some well known, others not so well - I have named the games in honor of the artists. â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"games-of-art/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"warage/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Warage Card Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/ascension/warage.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div><p>Warage is a turn based strategy card game with gameplay similar to a traditional role-playing game. Each player plays a hero characterized by race and class traits, which will grant the hero specific bonuses, abilities, and skills.</p>\n\n<p>In the 1st Edition, you will find:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><b>4 races:</b> Humans, Elves, Orcs, Angels</li>\n<li><b>3 classes:</b> Warrior, Paladin, Mage</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n\n<p>Warage is based on the clash of two or more heroes: a hero is created by choosing 1 race and 1 class card and can be equipped with weapons, armors, helms, spells and other items and abilites using the cards available in your hero deck. â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"warage/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Card Game</a><a>Fantasy</a><a>Dice Rolling</a><a>Deck / Pool Building</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"spite-and-malice/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Spite &amp; Malice Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/ascension/spite-and-malice.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div>\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Components</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>110 Cards</li>\n<li>Instructions</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Object of the Game</h4>\n\n\n\n<p>Be the first player to play all of the cards from your Card Stack.</p>\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Setup</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>Separate the cards into 2 decks and shuffle them separately.</p>\n\n<p>One deck will have the cards with the purple borders, like this.</p>\n\n<table class=\"image-description \"><tbody><tr><td>Bordered card</td></tr></tbody></table>\n\n<p>The other deck will have the cards with no borders, like this.</p>\n\n<table class=\"image-description \"><tbody><tr><td>Non-Bordered card</td></tr></tbody></table>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Set the deck of Non-bordered cards aside for a minute.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Deal 8 cards from the Bordered card deck face- down to form each player's Card Stack. Each player turns the top card of his/her stack faceup, creating an \"UP\" card. â€¦</p>\n</li>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</ul></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"spite-and-malice/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Card Game</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"robot-turtles/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Robot Turtles Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/ascension/robot-turtles.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div>\n\n\n<h4>Components</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>Game Board</li>\n<li>4 Robot Turtle Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Jewel Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Bug Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Code Card Decks</li>\n<li>20 Stone Walls</li>\n<li>12 Ice Walls</li>\n<li>4 Crates</li>\n<li>Instructions</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Object of the Game</h4>\n\n<p>At the Start of the Game, the Turtle Mover (grownup) should <b>read these rules out loud!</b> for the turtle masters (kids):</p>\n\n\n\n<p>\"The goal of the game is to get your Robot Turtle to the matching colored Jewel! When you land on the matching Jewel you can pick it up. Everyone who gets their Jewel wins!\"</p>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Game Play</h4>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<p>\"You are the Turtle Master. On your turn, you will decide which way you want your Turtle to turn or move. Select one of your Code Cards and place it in front of you but don't move your Turtle\". â€¦</p>\n</li>\n</ol></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"robot-turtles/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Children's Game</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"floating-market/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Floating Market Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/ascension/floating-market.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div>\n<h4>Components</h4>\n\n\n<ul>\n<li>30 Coin Cards</li>\n<li>35 Fruit Cards</li>\n<li>25 Player dice</li>\n<li>15 Customer Tokens</li>\n<li>7 Boat Tiles</li>\n<li>2 Ama dice (2/3 player only)</li>\n<li>2 Board dice</li>\n<li>2 Fixed Tiles</li>\n<li>1 Fruit Stand Tile</li>\n<li>1 Game Board</li>\n<li>1 Start Player Marker</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Story</h4>\n\n<p>Ama is tired. It has been a long day of chasing her grandchildren and she needs a break. Ama has been around for a long time and she has a few tricks up her sleeve. With the promise of her famous fruit salad, Ama sends her grandchildren down to the Damnoen Saduak Floating Market to collect fruit... and to get out of her hair! â€¦</p></div></a><br → 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 96
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Star Realms Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/star-realms/star-realms.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<p><i>This are the rules for a two-player game.</i></p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/star-realms/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>10 Explorer cards</li>\n<li>16 Scout cards</li>\n<li>4 Viper cards</li>\n<li>80 Trade Deck cards</li>\n<li>Authority cards, or some other means of keeping score</li>\n<li>Rulebook</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>Each player starts with a small personal deck of 10 cards representing their space armada. Each turn, players play cards to gain Trade, Combat and other effects.</p>\n\n<p>Trade (<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/star-realms/t.jpg\">) is used to buy more powerful cards to add to your deck.</p>\n\n<p>Combat (<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/star-realms/c.jpg\">) is used to attack your opponent or their Bases directly.</p>\n\n<p>Authority (<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/star-realms/a.jpg\">) is your score. Each player starts with a score of 50 Authority. If you reduce your opponent's Authority to zero, you win!</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p>Each player starts with a personal deck (containing 8 Scout cards and 2 Viper cards) and a score of 50 Authority. Leave space next to each personal deck for a discard pile. Place the 10 Explorer cards face up on the table.</p>\n\n<p>Shuffle the Trade Deck and place it face down on the table. Lay out 5 cards from the Trade Deck face up on the table. This is the Trade Row. Leave a space next to this for the Scrap Heap (a place to put cards that are removed from the game).</p>\n\n<p>Both players shuffle their personal decks. Randomly determine which player will play first. That player draws three cards (you always draw from your own personal deck), the other player draws five cards.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/star-realms/game1.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>Players alternate taking turns. Each turn has three phases. These phases are played in order:</p>\n<ol>\n<li>Main Phase</li>\n<li>Discard Phase</li>\n<li>Draw Phase</li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n<h2>1. Main Phase</h2>\n\n<p>During your Main Phase you may do any of the following, in any order you wish.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Play cards from your hand.</li>\n<li>Use abilities of Ships or Bases in play.</li>\n<li>Acquire Ships or Bases with Trade and place them in your discard pile.</li>\n<li>Attack your opponent or their bases with Combat.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>You may repeat any of these as many times as you like. For example, you may play two cards from your hand, acquire a card, then play another card from your hand, etc.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Playing Cards</h3>\n\n<p>There is no cost to play a card, just place it in play (face up on the table in front of you) and do what it says. There are two types of cards you can have in your deck, Ships and Bases.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Ships</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/star-realms/game2.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Ships provide a one-time effect each time you play them. Ships you put into play stay in play (face up in front of you) until your Discard Phase.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Bases</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/star-realms/game3.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Bases stay in play turn after turn until they are destroyed or scrapped. Each Base has a Defense that represents the amount of Combat that it must be hit within a single turn to destroy it.</p>\n\n<p>Some Bases (designated \"Outpost\") protect you and your other Bases. If you have an Outpost in play, you may not be attacked and your non-outpost Bases may not be attacked or targeted by your opponent until all of your Outposts are destroyed.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Using Abilities</h3>\n\n<p>White in play, some Ships and most Bases have abilities that can be used at any time during your Main Phase.</p>\n\n<p>Primary Base Abilities</p>\n\n<p>Most Bases have an ability in their main text box. For example, Blob Wheel gives you 1 Combat. Some Bases have \"or\" between multiple abilities. You may choose Bases. one of these abilities to use each turn. For example with Barter World, you may choose to gain 2 Authority or 2 Trade, but not both.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Ally Abilites</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/star-realms/game4.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Some ships and bases have Ally Abilites. This is in addition to whatever else the card does. Ally Abilites are indicated by a faction icon in the text box.</p>\n\n<p>On your turn, an Ally Ability is triggered as soon as you have another Ship or Base of that faction in play. Once triggered, an Ally Ability may be used at any time during your Main Phase.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Scrap Abilities</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/star-realms/game5.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Some Ships and Bases have a Scrap Ability. This is in addition to whatever else the card does. Scrap Abilities are indicated by a trash can icon in the text box.</p>\n\n<p>If you choose to use a cards Scrap Ability, remove the card from \"in play\" and place it in the Scrap Heap (the removed from the game pile). This card is no longer in your deck, so consider carefully if the ability is worth giving up that card forever! Scrapping a card in any other way does not give you the Scrap Ability.</p>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> when an Explorer is scrapped in any way, it is placed face up in the Explorer Pile, not in the Scrap Heap.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/star-realms/game7.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Scrapping Cards</h3>\n\n<p>Some cards allow you to scrap other cards from your hand, your discard pile or the Center Row. When you scrap a card in this way, place it in the Scrap Heap. The Center Row always has 5 cards in it, so if you scrap a card from the Trade Row, immediately replace it with the next card from the Trade Deck.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/star-realms/game6.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Acquiring Cards</h3>\n\n<p>Some of the Ships and Bases you play will give you Trade. When you gain Trade it goes into a \"Trade Pool\" which you may add to and use over the course of your Main Phase. Trade is used to acquire cards from the Trade Row or the Explorer Pile.</p>\n\n<p>A card's cost is found in the Trade symbol in its upper right hand corner. To acquire a card, subtract Trade from your Trade Pool equal to the card's cost and then put the acquired card directly into your discard pile.</p>\n\n<p>Acquiring a card doesn't count as playing it, so it doesn't go into play and you don't use its abilities. Any remaining Trade is saved and can be used to acquire additional cards this turn. Sometimes a card's ability will instruct you to \"Acquire a card\".</p>\n\n<p>In this case you get to acquire the card without using Trade. Remember, the Trade Row always has 5 cards in it, so if you acquire a card from the Center Row, immediately replace it with the next card from the Trade Deck.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Attacking</h3>\n\n<p>Some of the Ships and Bases you play will give you Combat. When you gain Combat it goes into a \"Combat Pool\" which you may add to and use over the course of your Main Phase.</p>\n\n<p>You may use Combat to attack your opponent or their Bases. To attack a Base, subtract Combat from your Combat Pool equal to the Base's Defense. That Base is destroyed and goes to your opponent's discard pile.</p>\n\n<p>Sometimes a card's ability will instruct you to \"Destroy target Base\". In this case, you destroy the Base without using Combat. To attack your opponent, subtract any amount of Combat from your Combat Pool, and lower your opponent's Authority by that amount.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/star-realms/game8.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>2. Discard Phase</h2>\n\n<p>In addition to a personal deck, each player has their own discard pile. When you discard or acquire cards, place them face up in your discard pile. Any player may look through your discard pile at any time.</p>\n\n<p>During your Discard Phase you:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Lose any Trade remaining in your Trade Pool.</li>\n<li>Lose any Combat remaining in your Combat Pool.</li>\n<li>Put all of your Ships that are \"in play\" into your discard pile.</li>\n<li>Put any cards left in your hand into your discard pile.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>3. Draw Phase</h2>\n\n<p>During your Draw Phase you: Draw 5 cards, then your turn ends.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> if you need to draw a card and your personal deck is empty, shuffle your discard pile and that becomes your new personal deck.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> At the beginning of your Draw Phase you have three cards left in your deck. Draw those three cards, shuffle your dis card pile into a new deck, then draw two more cards.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>The game ends when you are able to reduce your opponent's authority to zero and you are the winner.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"multiplayer-rules.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Star Realms Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:49:54.708Z"),

→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 98
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Clank! Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/clank.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div><link href=\"https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=&amp;display=swap\" rel=\"stylesheet\">\n\n\n<p>The passages beneath Dragon Keep are the most dangerous territory in the Realm. Only the greatest burglars can sneak in, steal from the dragon, and escape to tell the tale. So naturally, you and your fellow thieves have challenged each other to do just that.</p>\n\n<p>Along the way, you'll recruit allies and snatch up extra loot. But one false step and-Clank! Careless noise draws the dragon's attention, and each Artifact stolen increases its rage. You'd better hope your friends are louder than you are if you want to escape the depths alive…</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/components2.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n<ul>\n<li>Double-sided Game Board</li>\n<li>Reserve Cards</li>\n<li>Four 10-card Starting Decks</li>\n<li>Dungeon Deck (100 cards)</li>\n<li>7 Artifacts</li>\n<li>11 Major Secrets</li>\n<li>18 Minor Secrets</li>\n<li>2 Master Keys</li>\n<li>2 Backpacks</li>\n<li>3 Crowns</li>\n<li>3 Monkey Idols</li>\n<li>4 Mastery Tokens</li>\n<li>Gold</li>\n<li>120 Clank! Cubes (30 of each player color)</li>\n<li>Dragon Marker</li>\n<li>Four Player Pawns</li>\n<li>24 Dragon Cubes</li>\n<li>Dragon Bag</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br><br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/setup.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">A</s> Each player takes 30 Clank! cubes and places them in a personal supply in front of them.</p>\n\n<p>They also take a pawn of the matching color, and a 10-card deck containing the following:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>6 Burgles</li>\n<li>2 Stumbles</li>\n<li>1 Sidestep</li>\n<li>1 Scramble</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Place these tokens around the game board as follows:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/artifact.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">B</s> Place the seven Artifacts (valued from 5 to 30) face up on the spaces marked with the corresponding numbers.</p>\n\n<p>If playing with fewer than 4 players, before placing the Artifacts, shuffle them face down and select some at random to exclude from the game.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>With 3 players, return one Artifact to the box.</li>\n<li>With 2 players, return two Artifacts.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/secret.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">C</s> Shuffle the Major Secrets face down, then place one at random on each Major Secret space.</p>\n\n<p>There will be extra Major Secrets. Return them to the box unseen.</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">D</s> Shuffle the Minor Secrets face down, then place two at random on each Minor Secret space.</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">E</s> Place the Market Items on the Market area:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/masterkeys.jpg\"> Two Master Keys</p></li>\n\n<li><p><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/backpack.jpg\"> Two Backpacks</p></li>\n\n<li><p><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/crown.jpg\"> Three Crowns (valued 10, 9, and 8)</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">F</s> <img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/othertokens.jpg\"> Place the three Monkey Idols on the Monkey Shrine room.</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">G</s> <img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/artifact3.jpg\"> Place the Mastery tokens near the top left corner of the board, one for each player.</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">H</s> Place the Gold tokens (valued 1 and 5) in a Bank next to the game board.</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">I</s> Place the Dragon marker (black) on the Rage Track.</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>In a 4-player game, place it on the first space.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>In a 3-player game, place it on the second space.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>In a 2-player game, place it on the third space.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">J</s> Place the 24 dragon cubes (black) in the Dragon Bag, and set the bag next to the game board.</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">K</s> Place the Goblin monster card in Reserve, next to the game board, along with the piles of Mercenary, Explore, and Secret Tome cards.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/dragon.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">L</s> Shuffle the Dungeon Deck and deal six cards to form the Dungeon Row, face up on the table.</p>\n\n<p>If any of those cards have the Dragon Attack symbol along the right edge, replace them with other cards until none of them show the symbol, then shuffle any replaced cards back into the Dungeon Deck.</p>\n\n<p>Leave room next to the Dungeon Deck to form a Dungeon discard pile during the game.</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">M</s> Each player places their pawn just outside the dungeon, at the top of the game board, then shuffles their 10-card deck and draws five cards from it.</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">N</s> The sneakiest player gets to go first (or you may choose randomly). Play will proceed clockwise from there. The first player places 3 Clank! cubes in the Clank! Area. The second player places 2 Clank! The third and fourth players (if there are any) place 1 Clank! and 0 Clank!, respectively.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>CLANK! is a deck-building game. Each player has their own deck, and building yours up is part of playing the game. You start each of your turns with five cards in your hand, and you'll play them all in any order you choose.</p>\n\n<p>Most cards will generate resources, of which there are three different kinds:</p>\n\n<div class=\"box box_border\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/skill.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<h4>Skill</h4>\n\n<p>Skill is used to acquire new cards for your deck.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/sword.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<h4>Swords</h4>\n\n<p>Swords are used to fight the monsters that infest the dungeon.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/boots.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<h4>Boots</h4>\n\n<p>Boots which are used to move around the board.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n</div>\n\n<p>Every time you acquire a new card, you put it face up in your discard pile. Whenever you need to draw a card and find your deck empty, you shuffle your discard pile and turn it face down to form a new deck. With each shuffle, your newest cards become part of a bigger and better deck!</p>\n\n<p>Each player starts with the same cards in their deck, but they'll acquire different cards during their turns. Because cards can do many different things, each player's deck (and strategy) will become more and more different as the game unfolds.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Step 1: the Target</h3>\n\n<div class=\"box blue2_bg\">\n\n<p>The terms of this thieving challenge are clear: everyone must go into the dungeon and steal an Artifact. Escaping with your life is technically optional, although vastly preferable.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<p>During the game, you have two goals:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>Retrieve an Artifact token and escape the dragon by returning to the place you started, outside of the dungeon.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p>You can normally carry only one Artifact, and once you've picked one up, you're stuck with it. Choose carefully!</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Accumulate enough points with your Artifact and other loot to beat out your opponents and earn the title of Greatest Thief in the Realm!</p>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/artifact1.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<br>\n\n<p>Artifact isn't worth many points, but at least it's easy to get to. Make sure to gather more loot to keep pace with your rivals!</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\"><br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/artifact2.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<br>\n\n<p>Artifact is worth a lot more points, but the path to it is long and dangerous. Make sure you can escape the dungeon once you have it!</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Step 2: the Plan</h3>\n\n<div class=\"box blue2_bg\">\n\n<p>Stealing from the dragon is far from a simple job. You'll have to navigate through the ruins, deal with monsters, and acquire valuable treasures.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<p>During your turn, you can use the resources you've generated-Skill, Swords, and Boots-to take any of the following actions. You may take each action as many times as you like, as long as you have the resources to do so. You can wait and take your actions after you've played all of your cards, or you can take actions between cards if you wish.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Acquire a New Card for Your Deck.</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/corner.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>You can use Skill to acquire cards with blue banners from the Dungeon Row (which change throughout the game) or cards with yellow banners from the Reserve (which are the same in every game).</p>\n\n<p>The Skill Cost of a card is found in its lower right corner. Once you pay the cost, place the card in your discard pile; it is now part of your deck.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Use a Device.</h4>\n\n<p>Devices are the cards with purple banners in the Dungeon Row.</p>\n\n<p>Devices can be acquired with Skill, but they do not become part of your deck. Instead, you perform the USE text listed on the card and then place it in the Dungeon discard pile (next to the Dungeon Deck).</p>\n\n<p>The Skill Cost of a Device is found in its lower right corner.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Fight a Monster</h4>\n\n<p>Monsters are the cards with red banners in the Dungeon Row. Instead of acquiring monsters with Skill, you fight them using Swords.</p>\n\n<p><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/swords.jpg\"> The Swords required to defeat a monster are found in its lower right corner.</p>\n\n<p>When you fight a monster in the Dungeon Row, you gain the reward listed in its DEFEAT text. Then the card is placed in the Dungeon discard pile (not your own discard pile).</p>\n\n<p>You may also fight the Goblin in the Reserve. It is not discarded when defeated; each player may fight it multiple times each turn, earning its reward each time.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Buy From the Market.</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/market.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The Market is a series of spaces where merchants serve those exploring the dungeon. If you are in a Market room, you may make a purchase.</p>\n\n<p>All items at the Market cost 7 Gold. Place each item you buy in front of you, in your play area. Items available at the Market are described on the back of the rule book.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Move Through a Tunnel.</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/boots.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Boots are how you traverse the passages of the dungeon. Each Boot lets you move along one tunnel to a new room.</p>\n\n<p>Some tunnels have special rules:</p>\n\n<div class=\"box box_border\">\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>A tunnel with Footprint icons requires two Boots to traverse instead of one.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>A tunnel with Monster icons deals that much damage to you when you move through it. For each Sword you use, you take one less damage (but you don't have to use Swords to move through a Monster tunnel).</p></li>\n\n<li><p>You cannot use a tunnel with a lock icon unless you have a Master Key token (purchased from the Market) in your possession.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>A tunnel shaped like an arrow can only be used in the direction of the arrow-you normally can't move through it in the opposite direction.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n\n<p>When you move into a room, you can take one of the tokens there (Minor Secret, Major Secret, Monkey Idol, or Artifact) and put it in front of you.</p>\n\n<div class=\"box box_border\">\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>When you take an Artifact token, move the Dragon marker up one space along the Rage Track.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>You can only take one token when you move into a room. (If the room has more than one token in it, you must exit and re-enter to pick up another).</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>You can't take an Artifact token if you already have one.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>You don't have to take a token if you don't want to. (You might want to pass up one Artifact to go after a more valuable one elsewhere).</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>When you take a Minor or Major Secret token, reveal it.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/crystalcave.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Whenever you enter a Crystal Cave room, you become exhausted while wandering its maze-like passages and cannot use any more Boots this turn. You may still be able to move by Teleporting (described in Advanced Maneuvers), but you won't be able to use Boots until your next turn.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n</div>\n\n<p>There are two other common effects that your cards many have:</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>I. Gaining Gold.</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/2.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>When you gain Gold, take it from the Bank and put it in front of you. Each Gold is worth 1 point when the game ends, but you can also use it for other reasons during the game, such as buying items from the Market.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>II. Clank!</h4>\n\n<p>Some cards cause you to gain Clank! When this happens, add that many cubes from your personal supply to the Clank! Area of the game board. Some very sneaky cards cause you to remove Clank!</p>\n\n<p>For each negative Clank! you get, remove one of your Clank! from the Clank! Area. If you don't have enough Clank! there, you can instead avoid adding Clank! later in the turn if an effect would make you do so. Any leftover negative Clank! is lost when your turn ends.</p>\n\n<p>Once you've played all of your cards and used as much of your resources as you want to, your turn ends. Put all of the cards you played into your discard pile and draw five new cards in preparation for your next turn. Any Skill, Swords, or Boots you don't use are wasted, so make them count!</p>\n\n<div class=\"box gold_bg box_radius\">\n\n<p>The green player takes her turn by playing the following cards:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/cards.jpg\">\n\n<p>The green player carries out the text on her cards as soon as she plays them, adding 1 Clank! to the Clank! Area for her Stumble, and then removing it when she plays Move Silently.</p>\n\n<p>(She has another -1 Clank! left over from Move Silently, which she could use later in the turn if she were to make more Clank!) She has a total of two Boots, which she uses to move through two different tunnels. She ends up in a Crystal Cave room; she could not have moved farther this turn, even if she had more Boots.</p>\n\n<p>She uses her two Swords to Fight an Orc Grunt in the Dungeon Row. She gains 3 Gold ( from the Orc Grunt's Defeat text), and places the monster in the Dungeon discard pile.</p>\n\n<p>She uses her total 3 Skill to acquire a Kobold Merchant from the Dungeon Row, placing the card in her own discard pile. (She has just acquired the card; she won't get gold or skill from it until she reshuffles her discard pile, draws the card, and plays it).</p>\n\n<p>Having played all cards in her hand and used all the resources she can, the green player ends her turn.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Step 3: the Mark</h3>\n\n<div class=\"box blue2_bg\">\n\n<p>The queen of Dragon Keep is Nictotraxian-but we just call her \"Nicki\". She's not going to like us sneaking around her lair and taking her things.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/dragon.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>At the end of every turn, if any of the six spaces for cards in the Dungeon Row are empty, refill them with new cards from the Dungeon Deck. If any of the cards drawn have a Dragon Attack symbol, the dragon attacks! (But only once, no matter how many Dragon Attack symbols were revealed).</p>\n\n<p>To execute an attack, take all of the Clank! in the Clank! Area and put it in the Dragon Bag. Shake it up and draw a number of cubes from the bag equal to the number shown in the Dragon marker's current space of the Rage Track.</p>\n\n<p>Each black cube drawn is set aside, but each colored cube represents damage dealt to that player. (Undrawn cubes remain in the bag-they might still be drawn out later). The more Clank! you make, the more likely the dragon is to notice and attack you. Managing your noise level is key to survival!</p>\n\n<p>The dragon's rage increases throughout the game. Every time an Artifact is picked up, and whenever a Dragon Egg (a type of Minor Secret) is discovered, advance the Dragon marker one space along the Rage Track. This may cause more cubes to be drawn in the next attack. The more cubes being drawn, the deadlier the game becomes. Tread carefully!</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<div class=\"box gold_bg box_radius\">\n\n<p>At the end of the yellow player's turn, there are only three cards left in the Dungeon Row. Three cards are revealed from the top of the Dungeon Deck to fill the empty spaces. Two of them have the Dragon Attack symbol, triggering an attack this turn.</p>\n\n<p>All the cubes in the Clank! Area are placed in the Dragon Bag. The Dragon marker is currently on the fifth space of the Rage Track, so four cubes are drawn from the bag.</p>\n\n<p>One cube is black; it is set aside, affecting no one. The second is green, so the green player takes 1 damage. The last two cubes are both yellow, so the yellow player takes 2 damage.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Step 4: the Getaway</h3>\n\n<div class=\"box blue2_bg\">\n\n<p>Dungeon delving is not without its risks. A master thief must carefully manage their physical state to maximize both profit and survivability. Remember, the two greatest obstacles to spending money are being broke and being dead.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<p>Each player's health is tracked on a Health Meter at the bottom of the game board. When you take damage during the game-and you will take damage-place your cubes on the Health Meter of your color, starting from the left.</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>If the damage came from a dragon attack, use the cubes that were pulled from the Dragon Bag.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>If you chose to take damage by moving through a Monster tunnel without a Sword, take the cubes from your personal supply. You can't choose to take damage this way if it would completely fill your Health Meter!</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/heart.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>Some effects can heal damage you've taken. When you heal, take back a cube of your color from your Health Meter and put it in your personal supply. You can use it again later for more Clank!</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/getaway2.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n\n<p>If your Health Meter is ever completely filled, you are knocked out. What happens next depends on how successful you've been so far:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>If you have retrieved an Artifact and escaped the Depths area of the dungeon, you are rescued by the townsfolk and can count the points you've earned.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>If you haven't gotten an Artifact yet, or if you are still stuck in the Depths, then you can't be rescued. You lose the competition, which at this point is the least of your worries.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/artifact3.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>Once you've picked up an Artifact, you can also make your way back to the place you started, outside of the dungeon. If you make it all the way back before being knocked out, you will receive a Mastery token worth an additional 20 points!</p>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Remember, if you don't have an Artifact yet, you can't leave the dungeon, or even be rescued!</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Step 5: the End of the Line</h3>\n\n<div class=\"box blue2_bg\">\n\n<p>Good timing is crucial in this heist-getting caught by a dragon is far worse than being pinched by the authorities! But as in all heists, there's nothing wrong with throwing your rivals under the proverbial carriage once you've made your escape.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<p>Whenever a player leaves the dungeon or is knocked out, they no longer take normal turns. They add no more Clank! to the Clank! Area. Cards that affect all players don't affect them. If any cubes of their color are drawn from the Dragon Bag, no damage is dealt-they are treated like black cubes.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/endofline.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>In addition, the first time any player leaves the dungeon or is knocked out, that player moves their pawn to the first (leftmost) space of the Countdown Track near the entrance to the dungeon.</p>\n\n<p>On that player's next turn, instead of taking a normal turn, they move their pawn forward one space on the Countdown Track and execute that space's effects. (Other players who later leave the dungeon or get knocked out do not use the Countdown Track).</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>On the second through fourth spaces, this causes an instant Dragon Attack. Additional cubes are drawn from the Dragon Bag for each of these attacks: 1 extra for the second space, 2 extra for the third, and 3 extra for the fourth.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>On the fifth space, the dragon instantly knocks out all players still in the dungeon.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<p>Once all players are out of the dungeon or knocked out, the game ends. All players who escaped the dungeon (or at least the Depths) add up their score, counting the following:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/artifact3.jpg\"> The value of their Artifact.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/othertokens.jpg\"> Points from any other tokens they acquired.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/5.jpg\"> Points equal to the amount of Gold they accumulated.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clank/3.jpg\" class=\"floatl\"> Points awarded by cards in their deck. (The top right corner of each card shows the amount it's worth).</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<p>The <b>player with the most points is the winner</b> and is declared the Greatest Thief in the Realm! In the case of a tie, the tied player with the most valuable Artifact is the winner.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"clank-in-space-rules.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Clank! Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:50:22.796Z"),

Just as a composer's creation is brought to life by the performing musicians, a game inventor's creation is brought to life by the players of the game.</p>\n\n<p>When the creation is inspired and the players are talented, a true work of art results.</p>\n\n<p>In creating the seven games in this book I have attempted to add a new visual dimension to the art of games. As each is played, a colorful drawing is formed. Because these drawings are reminiscent in style of the works of different modern masters of abstract art - some well known, others not so well - I have named the games in honor of the artists. â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"games-of-art/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"warage/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Warage Card Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/flash-point/warage.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div><p>Warage is a turn based strategy card game with gameplay similar to a traditional role-playing game. Each player plays a hero characterized by race and class traits, which will grant the hero specific bonuses, abilities, and skills.</p>\n\n<p>In the 1st Edition, you will find:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><b>4 races:</b> Humans, Elves, Orcs, Angels</li>\n<li><b>3 classes:</b> Warrior, Paladin, Mage</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n\n<p>Warage is based on the clash of two or more heroes: a hero is created by choosing 1 race and 1 class card and can be equipped with weapons, armors, helms, spells and other items and abilites using the cards available in your hero deck. â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"warage/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Card Game</a><a>Fantasy</a><a>Dice Rolling</a><a>Deck / Pool Building</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"spite-and-malice/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Spite &amp; Malice Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/flash-point/spite-and-malice.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div>\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Components</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>110 Cards</li>\n<li>Instructions</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Object of the Game</h4>\n\n\n\n<p>Be the first player to play all of the cards from your Card Stack.</p>\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Setup</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>Separate the cards into 2 decks and shuffle them separately.</p>\n\n<p>One deck will have the cards with the purple borders, like this.</p>\n\n<table class=\"image-description \"><tbody><tr><td>Bordered card</td></tr></tbody></table>\n\n<p>The other deck will have the cards with no borders, like this.</p>\n\n<table class=\"image-description \"><tbody><tr><td>Non-Bordered card</td></tr></tbody></table>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Set the deck of Non-bordered cards aside for a minute.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Deal 8 cards from the Bordered card deck face- down to form each player's Card Stack. Each player turns the top card of his/her stack faceup, creating an \"UP\" card. â€¦</p>\n</li>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</ul></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"spite-and-malice/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Card Game</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"robot-turtles/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Robot Turtles Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/flash-point/robot-turtles.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div>\n\n\n<h4>Components</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>Game Board</li>\n<li>4 Robot Turtle Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Jewel Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Bug Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Code Card Decks</li>\n<li>20 Stone Walls</li>\n<li>12 Ice Walls</li>\n<li>4 Crates</li>\n<li>Instructions</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Object of the Game</h4>\n\n<p>At the Start of the Game, the Turtle Mover (grownup) should <b>read these rules out loud!</b> for the turtle masters (kids):</p>\n\n\n\n<p>\"The goal of the game is to get your Robot Turtle to the matching colored Jewel! When you land on the matching Jewel you can pick it up. Everyone who gets their Jewel wins!\"</p>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Game Play</h4>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<p>\"You are the Turtle Master. On your turn, you will decide which way you want your Turtle to turn or move. Select one of your Code Cards and place it in front of you but don't move your Turtle\". â€¦</p>\n</li>\n</ol></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"robot-turtles/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Children's Game</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"floating-market/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Floating Market Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/flash-point/floating-market.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div>\n<h4>Components</h4>\n\n\n<ul>\n<li>30 Coin Cards</li>\n<li>35 Fruit Cards</li>\n<li>25 Player dice</li>\n<li>15 Customer Tokens</li>\n<li>7 Boat Tiles</li>\n<li>2 Ama dice (2/3 player only)</li>\n<li>2 Board dice</li>\n<li>2 Fixed Tiles</li>\n<li>1 Fruit Stand Tile</li>\n<li>1 Game Board</li>\n<li>1 Start Player Marker</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Story</h4>\n\n<p>Ama is tired. It has been a long day of chasing her grandchildren and she needs a break. Ama has been around for a long time and she has a few tricks up her sleeve. With the promise of her famous fruit salad, Ama sends her grandchildren down to the Damnoen Saduak Floating Market to collect fruit... and to get out of her hair! â€¦</p></div></a><br
