  294 if (existingRule) {
  295   // Update existing rule
→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 104
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Village Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/village.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h2>Game Components</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>44 family members</li>\n<li>4 black monks</li>\n<li>1 sticker sheet</li>\n<li>1 starting player marker</li>\n<li>1 next starting player marker</li>\n<li>40 goods tiles</li>\n<li>24 customer tiles</li>\n<li>15 coins</li>\n<li>20 bags of grain</li>\n<li>3 setup cards</li>\n<li>1 mass overview card</li>\n<li>32 markers</li>\n<li>6 plague cubes</li>\n<li>72 influence cubes</li>\n<li>2 cloth bags</li>\n<li>4 farmyards</li>\n<li>1 game board</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p>Place the game board in the middle of the table. It shows the village with its various areas.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/setup.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>A) grain harvest<br>\n\n</p><p>B) family<br> C) crafts<br> D) market<br> E) travel<br> F) council chamber<br> G) church<br> H) well<br> I) village chronicle<br> J) anonymous graves</p>\n\n<p>Each player chooses a color. Take the farmyard of your color and place it in front of you. Your farmyard is home to your family members. In addition, you may store as many influence cubes and goods here as you want. Each farmyard can only store a maximum of 5 bags of grain, however. The life time track of your family runs around the edge of your farmyard.</p>\n\n<p>Take the 11 family members and 8 markers of your chosen color. Put your 4 family members with a \"1\" on your farmyard. This is the first generation of your family. The remaining family members are future generations. Since these are not born yet, set them aside in a general supply for now.</p>\n\n<p>Put one of your markers on the cloud on the right side of the bridge on your farmyard. Put another marker on the book (space \"0\" of the prestige track) in the upper left corner of the game board.</p>\n\n<p>Give each player 1 coin, which he places next to his farmyard. Place the remaining coins in a general supply next to the game board.</p>\n\n<p>Shuffle the customer tiles face down and put them next to the market as a face down pile. Depending on the number of players, turn a certain number of tiles face up and add them to the market:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>in a 4-player-game: put a tile on each of the 10 spaces.</li>\n<li>in a 3-player-game: the space labeled \"4\" remains empty.</li>\n<li>in a 2-player-game: the spaces labeled \"3\" and \"4\" remain empty Example for a 3-player-game.</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<p>If you play with fewer than 4 players, use family members of an unclaimed color to reduce the number of available spaces in the chronicle and the anonymous graves.</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>in a 3-player-game: put an unused family member on each space and grave labeled \"4\".</li>\n<li>in a 2-player-game: put an unused family member on each space and grave labeled \"3\" or \"4\".</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/nextplayer.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Put the next starting player marker on its designated space of the council chamber. Place the goods tiles (horses, oxen, wagons, plows, and scrolls) next to the game board as a general supply.</p>\n\n<p>Place the bags of grain, the influence cubes, and the plague cubes next to the game board as a general supply. Also place the green bag nearby. Put the 4 black monks in the black bag and place it below the church.</p>\n\n<p>Take the setup card that matches the number of players and place it nearby. Return the remaining two setup cards to the box. Also place the \"mass\" overview card near the game board. The oldest player becomes the starting player and receives the starting player marker.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>You must gain the most prestige points and the game ends when either the village chronicle or the anonymous graves are fully occupied. At that point you once more gain points for the different areas of the village.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/gameplay.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>The game is played over several rounds, during which you control the fate of your family members by placing them wisely in the village. Family members on your farmyard ensure a good harvest, in church they generate prestige points, and in the council chamber they give you both prestige points and privileges. Those who opt for traveling may receive prestige, influence, or money, depending on their destination. Family members in the craft buildings enable the production of goods. Goods and grain can be exchanged for prestige points at the market.</p>\n\n<p>The many different areas in the village allow for many different options. Each area has an associated action space where you can gain different types of influence cubes and trigger certain actions.</p>\n\n<p>That means you have to choose wisely, because the influence type and specific action rarely match...</p>\n\n<p>In addition, many of these actions cost time. And just like in real life, the oldest family members eventually pass away. When a family member dies, his career choice determines whether he gets a place in the village chronicle or not.</p>\n\n<p>At the beginning of each round, seed the action spaces with influence cubes and plague cubes. Then, beginning with the starting player, players take turns carrying out actions.</p>\n\n<p>On your turn, take one cube from an action space and perform that space's action. When the last cube is taken, the current round is finished. Begin a new round by once again filling the green bag and seeding the action spaces.</p>\n\n<h4>Influence cubes and plague cubes</h4>\n\n<p>Influence cubes are required for performing certain actions in the village. The following types of influence are available:</p>\n\n<table class=\"table border\">\n\n<thead>\n\n<tr><th width=\"150\">Color:</th><th>Represents:</th><th>Is required for:</th></tr>\n\n</thead>\n\n<tbody>\n\n<tr><td><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/orange.jpg\"> Orange</td><td>skill</td><td>crafts, travel</td></tr>\n\n<tr><td><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/green.jpg\"> green</td><td>persuasiveness</td><td>market, council chamber</td></tr>\n\n<tr><td><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/brown.jpg\"> brown</td><td>faith</td><td>church, travel</td></tr>\n\n<tr><td><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/pink.jpg\"> pink</td><td>knowledge</td><td>crafts, travel</td></tr>\n\n<tr><td><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/black.jpg\"> black</td><td colspan=\"2\">The black cubes are not a type of influence. They are plague cubes that reduce the life span of your family members.</td></tr>\n\n</tbody>\n\n</table><br>\n\n<h4>Seeding the action spaces</h4>\n\n<p>The setup card shows how many different influence cubes you must take from the supply and add to the green bag at the beginning of a round. In addition, you must add all available plague cubes to the bag.</p>\n\n<p>Once the cubes are in the bag, mix them thoroughly. Then distribute a certain number of randomly drawn cubes onto each action space on the game board. The number of cubes per action space is also shown on the setup card.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/seedingactionspaces.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Note: If there are fewer influence cubes of one color available in the supply than the number you are supposed to add to the bag, then add only the available cubes. (Since some cubes remain in the bag each round, you will still be able to fully seed the action spaces). The starting player then takes his turn.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Taking your turn</h2>\n\n<p>On your turn, you must take one influence or plague cube from an action space of your choice. If it is an influence cube, put it on your farmyard. (You may store any number of influence cubes on your farmyard).</p>\n\n<p>If it is a plague cube, immediately return it to the supply and lose 2 time. This means you must move your life time track marker 2 spaces forward in clockwise direction.</p>\n\n<p>You may then perform the action of the action space from which you took the influence or plague cube. You are allowed to only take the cube and not carry out the action. </p>\n\n<h4>The currency time</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/currency.jpg\" class=\"floatr\"><p>Whenever you perform an action that costs time (every hourglass represents one unit of time), you must move your marker on your life time track forward (clockwise) the appropriate number of spaces. In addition, you lose 2 time whenever you take a plague cube. As soon as your marker passes the bridge, one of your oldest family members passes away.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>The actions</h2>\n\n<h3>Grain harvest</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/grainharvest.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If you have one or more family members on your farmyard, then they may perform a harvest action. Immediately take 2 bags of grain from the supply and place them onto the appropriate spaces of your farmyard. If you do not have any family members on your farmyard, then you cannot perform this action.</p>\n\n<p>If you also own a horse and a plow, take 3 bags of grain instead. If you also own an ox and a plow, take 4 bags of grain instead.</p>\n\n<p>(You may never use more than one combination, i.e., several family members, plows, oxen, or horses are of no additional use during a harvest).</p>\n\n<p>Your goods are not used up during the harvest. So - for example - when using an ox and a plow with the harvest, you do not need to discard them. Your family members remain on your farmyard.</p>\n\n<p>Note: Each farmyard has a capacity of 5 bags of grain! You can never own more than 5 bags of grain at once.</p>\n\n<h3>Family</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/family.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>This action represents a new family member being born. Immediately take one family member of your color from the general supply and add it to your farmyard. You must always take the family member with the lowest available number from the supply.</p>\n\n<p>Example: Peter has one family member with the number \"2\", two with the number \"3\", and two with the number \"4\" left in the supply. He must take the \"2\" family member.</p>\n\n<p>Important: Instead of taking a new family member from the supply, you may use this action to instead return one of your employed family members (not yet deceased) from the game board to your farmyard.</p>\n\n<p>Note: Family members added to the game board during one of the following actions (or added to the black bag by means of the \"church\" action) must always come directly from your farmyard.</p>\n\n<h3>Crafts</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/crafts.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>This action allows you to produce one good in one of the 5 craft buildings. (Take the corresponding goods tile and put it next to your farmyard). At the mill, you get 2 coins instead. There are two ways of producing a good. At each craft building (except the mill), you may choose:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>a) to pay for the produced good with time (for this you also need a family member in the craft building) OR</li>\n<li>b) to pay for the produced good with influence cubes (or bags of grain, depending on the good)</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<h4>a) Acquire good by losing time</h4>\n\n<p>If you want to pay for a good with time, you first need to train a family member in the appropriate craft building. Place a family member from your farmyard onto the craft building that you want to use. This costs you a certain amount of time (the number of hourglass symbols next to the image of the gray family member on the building's roof).</p>\n\n<p>You may then immediately produce the corresponding good by paying as much time as indicated by the production arrow on the building's roof.</p>\n\n<p>Your family member will remain on the same craft building for the rest of the game (unless he dies or returns to the farmyard by means of the \"family\" action). As long as he remains on the craft building, you may produce a good again by means of the \"crafts\" action. In doing so, you now only pay as much time as indicated in the production arrow (since your family member is already trained).</p>\n\n<p>Note: Family members may only produce the good of the craft buildings they are placed onto. (A blacksmith can only produce plows, not scrolls). There is no limit to how many family members, regardless of colors, may be on any building. (Exception: Players may not place family members onto the mill).</p>\n\n<h4>b) Acquire goods by paying with influence cubes (or bags of grain)</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/acquiregoods.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Regardless of whether you have a family member on a craft building or not, you may purchase the good that the building produces by returning the specified amount of influence cubes (or bags of grain in the stables) to the supply. You do not need to have a family member on the craft building. (In the example on the left, Philipp could have also acquired the wagon by returning 1 orange and 1 pink influence cube to the supply - without placing a family member and losing time).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/overview.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h3>Market</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/market.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>This action triggers a market day in which all players can participate. This action must be carried out. A market day must be held.</p>\n\n<p>If you triggered the action, then you are the first player allowed to serve one available customer. Available customers are all customers directly in front of the stalls on spaces with blue borders. (The customers on the remaining 5 spaces are in the waiting line and cannot be served).</p>\n\n<p>Each customer wants certain goods and/or bags of grain. To serve the customer, return the required goods and/or the required amount of grain to the supply, take the customer tile, and put it face down next to your farmyard. At the end of the game, this customer is worth however many prestige points are printed on it.</p>\n\n<p>Then - in clockwise direction - the remaining players take their turns. Each player may choose one of the remaining customers. However, in addition to delivering the required goods and bags of grain, the other players must also pay 1 green influence cube and 1 time. Players that do not want to or are unable to sell anything must pass and may not later re-enter the current market day.</p>\n\n<p>When it is your turn again, you may serve another of the remaining customers. This time, however, you must also pay 1 green influence cube and 1 time. (Only your first sale is free).</p>\n\n<p>The market day continues in clockwise direction until all customers have been served or all players have passed.</p>\n\n<p>The market day then ends. Depending on the number of players, fill up the blue bordered spaces with new customers. This is done by moving the waiting customers up in order. Then refill the waiting line with new customers from the pile. (If no customers were served, all customer tiles remain in place).</p>\n\n<p>Note: Should all customers be served at some point, then the market stalls remain empty for the rest of the game.</p>\n\n<h3>Travel</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/travel.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>This action allows you to send a family member out into the world. If you do not have any family members on the travel map of the game board, then take a family member from your farmyard and place him on one of the two neighboring cities that can be reached from the village. You must pay the cost of the trip, shown on the path. You will certainly have to pay 2 time and return 1 wagon to the supply.</p>\n\n<p>Additionally, depending on which way you go, you will also have to return either 2 brown or 2 pink influence cubes to the supply. Take one of your markers and place it onto the city traveled to. This gets you the reward shown in the circle (3 prestige points).</p>\n\n<p>If you already have at least one family member on a city on the travel map, you can choose:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Either send another family member from your farmyard to one of the two neighboring cities OR</li>\n<li>move one of your family members that is already on a city to an adjacent city. Adjacent cities are all cities directly accessible via a path (without skipping over another city). You must again pay the cost of the trip and put a marker onto the city you reached. You then receive the city's reward (2 influence cubes of your choice from the supply, 1 coin, or 3 prestige points).</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<p>Note: You can only place a marker and thus receive a city's reward once per city. Should your family member travel to a city where you already have a marker, then you may neither place another marker nor receive the reward.</p>\n\n<p>There is no limit to the number of family members and different colored markers allowed on any city. At the end of the game, you will receive prestige points depending on the total number of cities that your family visited during the game.</p>\n\n<h3>Council chamber</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/councilchamber.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>This action allows you to exert influence in the council chamber. You may use the action in 3 different ways:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>a) Take a family member from your farmyard and place him on the 1st stage of the council chamber. This costs 1 time and 2 green influence cubes OR 1 time and 1 scroll. You may perform the privilege action of this stage (to become the next starting player). OR</li> <li>b) Move one of your family members already in the council chamber one stage forward. This again costs you either 1 scroll OR 2 green influence cubes. Additionally, you must pay either 2 or 3 time depending on the stage. You may perform the privilege action which is shown below either the current or a previous stage of your family member. OR</li> <li>c) If you already have at least one family member in the council chamber, then you may perform a privilege action without moving a family member. In this case, perform the privilege action shown below either its current or a previous stage for free.</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<h4>Overview of the privileges:</h4>\n\n<ul>\n\n<li><p><b>1st stage:</b> Take the next starting player marker from the council chamber. If the marker has already been taken by another player, you receive nothing. If you take the marker, then you will be the starting player in the next round. At the beginning of the next round, take the starting player marker and return the next starting player marker to its designated space in the council chamber.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>2nd stage:</b> Take 2 influence cubes of your choice from the supply.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>3rd stage:</b> Take 1 goods tile of your choice from the supply and put it next to your farmyard.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>4th stage:</b> Pay exactly 1 coin to the supply in exchange for 3 prestige points on the prestige track.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/stages.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<p>There is no limit to the number of family members allowed on any stage. At the end of the game, each family member that has reached at least the 2nd stage in the council chamber is worth prestige points.</p>\n\n<h3>Church</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/church.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>You may add one family member from your farmyard to the black bag. For doing this, you must pay either 1 brown influence cube (returned to the supply) OR 3 time.</p>\n\n<p>Family members added to the black bag may be drawn and placed onto the church during a mass. A mass is said at the end of each round as well as at the end of the game.</p>\n\n<h3>Well (substitute action)</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/well.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Instead of taking a cube from an action space, you may instead return 3 same-colored influence cubes to the supply (but not plague cubes). For this, you may carry out any one of the previously listed actions.</p>\n\n<p>Note: The well action is only possible as long as there is at least one cube left on any action space. By the way: This is the only way to perform an action when there is no cube left on the corresponding action space.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of a round</h2>\n\n<p>When a player takes the last cube from the board (i.e., all action spaces are empty), he first carries out his action as usual. The current round is then finished and a mass is said.</p>\n\n<p>Each mass consists of 3 phases:</p>\n\n<h4>1. Draw 4 pieces from the black bag</h4>\n\n<p>Thoroughly shuffle the family members and black monks in the black bag. Then draw exactly 4 pieces from the bag, either at random or deliberately by paying coins. Beginning with the starting player and then continuing in clockwise direction, each player may pick one or more of their family members from the bag by paying 1 coin per family member. (Since there are always 4 black monks in the bag, this is the only way to make sure that your family members are drawn).</p>\n\n<p>Once a total of 4 family members have been bought from the bag, no more pieces may be drawn. Should fewer than 4 family members have been bought from the bag, bring the total count up to 4 pieces by drawing the rest randomly. Once you have drawn 4 pieces, return all black monks to the bag. Place any family members drawn on the large rightmost glass window of the church. Family members that are still in the bag remain there and may be drawn during the next mass.</p>\n\n<h4>2. Move family members up in the church hierarchy</h4>\n\n<p>Once 4 pieces have been drawn from the bag (even if they were only black monks), each player may move one or even several of his family members up in the church hierarchy (move them leftward on the windows). Beginning with the starting player and then continuing in clockwise direction, each player may do this once. To move a family member to the next window on the left, you must return as many bags of grain to the supply as are shown between the windows. Your family members may even move up more than one window, provided you pay enough grain to cover all movement.</p>\n\n<h4>3. Award 2 prestige points for the church majority</h4>\n\n<p>At the end of the mass, the player who has the most family members in the church immediately gains 2 prestige points on the prestige track. In the case of a tie, the prestige points are awarded to the player whose family member is on the window the furthest to the left. If there is still a tie, then each of the tied players gains 2 prestige points.</p>\n\n<p>At the end of the game, each family member in the church is worth prestige points, depending on how far up it has moved.</p>\n\n<h4>Beginning a new round</h4>\n\n<p>If a player has acquired the next starting player marker during the previous round, then he now takes the starting player marker and returns the next starting player marker to its designated space in the council chamber. Otherwise, the starting player remains the same. The new round starts again by filling the green bag with cubes and seeding the action spaces.</p>\n\n<h4>The coins</h4>\n\n<p>You get coins at the mill or while traveling. There are 3 possible ways to use coins:</p>\n\n<ol>\n\n<li><p>To buy prestige points in the council chamber (final stage).</p></li>\n\n<li><p>To ensure your family members are chosen from the black bag during a mass.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>As a JOKER for any one influence cube.</p></li>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p>At the end of the game, each coin you did not spend is worth 1 prestige point.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>A family member passes away</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/passesaway.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>During the game, you must often pay for actions with time by moving the marker on your life time track forward in clockwise direction. Once you move the marker past the bridge, one of your oldest family members passes away. You first get to finish carrying out your chosen action in full and must only decide which of your oldest family members dies at the end of your turn.</p>\n\n<p>Exception: Anyone who moves his marker past the bridge during a market day must immediately choose which of his family members dies.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/graves2.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Of your family members, it is always the one with the lowest number that has to die. If you have several family members with the lowest number, you can choose one of them. A dying family member must be visible at the time of his death. This means that he must be either on the game board or on your farmyard. (Family members still in the black bag cannot die, nor can ones that have not yet entered play).</p>\n\n<p>Example: Peter chooses the \"crafts\" action by taking a plague cube from the corresponding action space. He loses 2 time in doing so, moving his marker on the life time track past the bridge.</p>\n\n<p>Before one of his family members dies, he may still perform the \"crafts\" action. He places a \"1\" family member from his farmyard onto the smithy (which costs him 3 time) and produces a plow (which costs him yet another 3 time). Now that his action is over, his family member with the lowest number must die. He has two \"1\" family members on the game board and decides to choose to let the craftsman he just placed onto the smithy die.</p>\n\n<p>For a dying family member, there are always two possibilities:</p>\n\n<ul>\n\n<li><p><b>a) There is still a free space in the village chronicle</b></p>\n\n<p>The village chronicle records the stories of the great residents and their deeds. The village chronicle has a few spaces open for each professional category. Depending on where the family member \"worked\" at the time of his death, he is added to one of the following empty spaces:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/banners.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>At the end of the game, you receive prestige points depending on how many of your family members were immortalized in the village chronicle.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>b) There is no proper grave left in the village chronicle</b></p>\n\n<p>In this case, the family member is put onto one of the anonymous graves next to the church. Here he can rest in peace, but is not worth any prestige points.</p></li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<p>Note: Family members that have died should always be laid down so you can easily tell them apart from the still living, upright family members.</p>\n\n<p>Hint 1: It is an effective strategy to add family members to the village chronicle quickly. So don't be afraid of paying for actions with time.</p>\n\n<p>Hint 2: If you are putting a family member from your farmyard onto the game board, you should always consider the family member's number. \"1\" family members are likely to die during the game. If you want to score in the church or council chamber at the end of the game, placing family members with higher numbers is usually the better choice.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the game</h2>\n\n<p>The end of the game is triggered when a family member is put onto either:</p>\n\n<ul>\n\n<li><p>a) the last empty space in the village chronicle or<br><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/village_chronicle.jpg\"><br></p></li>\n\n<li><p>b) the last empty anonymous grave next to the church<br><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/grave.jpg\"><br></p></li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<p>The player who put his family member onto the last empty space of the village chronicle or the last empty anonymous grave does not get another turn.</p>\n\n<p>All other players may perform one last action in clockwise player order. As always, you must either take an influence or plague cube from an action space or pay 3 same-colored influence cubes to perform the action. Should the final cube be taken from the game board (even though there are players left to act), the action spaces are not reseeded. Instead, the remaining players may perform any action without having to return 3 same-colored influence cubes to the supply.</p>\n\n<p>Note: In this case, the usual mass at the end of a round is skipped. The final mass is not said until all players have taken their final action.</p>\n\n<p>Note: If family members die during the final actions and there are no proper village chronicle spaces or graves left, then they are simply removed from the game.</p>\n\n<p><b>Special case:</b> If the end of the game is triggered during a market day, finish the market day completely. Afterward, determine who has triggered the end of the game by occupying the last chronicle space or grave. If it is the same player who also triggered the market day, then he has taken his last turn and everyone else has one action left.</p>\n\n<p>If it was triggered by a different player, then all players, in clockwise player order, may carry out one more action. (The final turn of the game is then taken by the player who triggered the market day). After each player has taken his last action, the last mass is said. Final scoring then takes place.</p>\n\n<h3>Final Scoring</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/final_scoring.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Each time you receive prestige points, score them by moving your marker forward on the prestige track. Whoever gained the most prestige points wins the game.</p>\n\n<p>In the case of a tie, the tied player who has served the most customers wins. If there is still a tie, the tied player with the higher number of \"living\" family members wins.</p>\n\n<h4>Travel</h4>\n\n<p>Count the number of cities that your family has visited on the travel map (= number of markers of your color) and gain prestige points accordingly:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>1 city = 1 point</li>\n<li>2 cities = 3 points</li>\n<li>3 cities = 6 points</li>\n<li>4 cities = 10 points</li>\n<li>5 cities = 14 points</li>\n<li>6 cities = 18 points</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<h4>Council chamber</h4>\n\n<p>Each family member on the 4th stage is worth 6 points. Each family member on the 3rd stage is worth 4 points. Each family member on the 2nd stage is worth 2 points. On the 1st stage, there are no points awarded.</p>\n\n<h4>Church</h4>\n\n<p>Each family member on the rightmost window is worth 2 points. Each family member on the second window is worth 3 points. Each family member on the third window is worth 4 points.</p>\n\n<p>Each family member on the leftmost window is worth 6 points. Family members in the black bag are not worth any points.</p>\n\n<h4>Village chronicle</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/village/family2.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>You gain prestige points depending on how many of your family members are immortalized in the village chronicle.</p>\n\n<p>1 or 2 are worth no points. 3 family members are worth 4 prestige points. 4 family members are worth 7 points. 5 or more family members are worth 12 points.</p>\n\n<h4>Customer tiles</h4>\n\n<p>At the end of the game, each player reveals their concealed customer tiles and receives the prestige points printed on them.</p>\n\n<h4>Coins</h4>\n\n<p>Each coin is worth 1 prestige point.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"buy-board-game.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Village Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:51:49.224Z"),

  294 if (existingRule) {

→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 105
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Terra Mystica Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/terra-mystica.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<h2>Game Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<ul>\n<li>1 Game board and 1 Cult board</li>\n<li>7 Faction boards</li>\n<li>56 Terrain tiles</li>\n<li>65 natural-colored Workers</li>\n<li>40 small Coins, 25 medium coins, 20 big coins</li>\n<li>65 purple Power tokens</li>\n<li>7 x 8 Dwellings</li>\n<li>7 x 4 trading houses</li>\n<li>7 x 1 stronghold</li>\n<li>7 x 3 temples</li>\n<li>7 x 1 sanctuary</li>\n<li>7 x 7 priests</li>\n<li>7 x 7 Markers</li>\n<li>7 x 3 bridges</li>\n<li>1 orange Starting player token</li>\n<li>17 Action tokens and 1 Game end token</li>\n<li>5 \"100 Victory points\" tokens</li>\n<li>28 oval Favor tiles</li>\n<li>10 Town tiles</li>\n<li>9 Bonus cards</li>\n<li>8 rectangular Scoring tiles</li>\n<li>5 \"Actions\" Overview tiles</li>\n<li>12 zip-lock bags</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p>The <a href=\"setup.php\">setup of Terra Mystica</a> is quiet complex.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the game</h2>\n\n<p>At the end of the game, the player with the most Victory points wins the game. Victory points are depicted as brown squares containing a laurel wreath.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Tutorial Video</h2>\n\n<iframe width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"//www.youtube.com/embed/xw__3g9B414?rel=0\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game play</h2>\n\n<p>Each of the six rounds goes through three phases:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li>Phase I: Income Phase</li>\n<li>Phase II: Action Phase</li>\n<li>Phase III: Cult bonuses and Clean-up Phase</li>\n\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Phase I. Income</h2>\n\n<p>Collect new Workers, Coins, Priests, and Power.</p>\n\n<p>You also go through this phase on the 1st round. Consequently, you first collect your faction-specific starting income and then also the income for the 1st round.</p>\n\n<p>Your income depends on the Structures you have built, on the Bonus card you have chosen, and (later in the game) on the Favor tiles you own. On all components, income is symbolized by an open hand.</p>\n\n<h4>Basic income for Structures</h4>\n\n<p><b>Workers:</b> Take a number of Workers from the general supply equal to the number of visible Worker symbols on your Dwelling track.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/basicincome.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p><b>Coins:</b> Take a number of Coins from the general supply equal to the number of visible Coin symbols on your Trading house track.</p>\n\n<p><b>Priests:</b> Take a number of Priests from your supply equal to the number of visible Priest symbols on your Temple track. Another Priest symbol will be visible once you have built your Sanctuary.</p>\n\n<p>Both the Swarmlings' Sanctuary and the Darklings' Sanctuary provide 2 Priests.</p>\n\n<p>Put the newly gained Workers, Coins, and Priests on your Faction board. If the supply of Workers or Coins runs out, replace the missing components with something else. Only your supply of Priests is limited.</p>\n\n<p><b>Power:</b> Power is gained according to the visible Power symbols on the Trading house track. The Stronghold usually provides additional Power (except for the Alchemists who collect 6 Coins instead, or the Chaos Magicians who collect 2 Workers instead, or the Fakirs who collect 1 Priest instead).</p>\n\n<h4>Additional income for cards and tiles</h4>\n\n<p>Beside the income collected via your Faction board, add the income depicted on your Bonus card.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/additionalincome.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>The Bowls of Power</h4>\n\n<p>Each player has 12 Power tokens that are distributed among three Bowls. Power actions require Power in Bowl III (the one on the right).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/bowls1.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Whenever you gain Power in the game (as income, when an opponent builds Structures, or by advancing on the Cult tracks), you do not get new Power tokens, but rather move the existing ones from Bowl to Bowl. Also, when spending Power on a Power action, you do not lose Power tokens, but move them around again.</p>\n\n<p>Power tokens move (always in clockwise order) according to the following rules:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/bowls2.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>When gaining Power, proceed in the following order.</p>\n\n<ol>\n\n<li><p>If there are Power tokens in Bowl I, for each 1 Power you gain move one token from Bowl I to Bowl II.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Once Bowl I is empty, for each 1 Power you gain move one token from Bowl II to Bowl III.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Once all Power tokens are in Bowl III, you cannot gain further Power.</p></li>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p> You can only spend Power tokens that are in Bowl III. Move them to Bowl I when spending them.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Phase II. Actions</h2>\n\n<p>During the Action phase, beginning with the Starting player and in clockwise order, each player takes exactly one Action. Continue to do so until no player wants to take any more Actions.</p>\n\n<p>There are eight possible Actions to choose from. Except for passing, all Actions can be taken multiple times during the same Action phase (but only once per turn).</p>\n\n<h3>1. Transform and Build</h3>\n\n<p>First, you may change the type of one Terrain space. Then, if you have changed its type to your Home terrain, you may immediately build a Dwelling on that space.</p>\n\n<h4>Building a Dwelling</h4>\n\n<p>In order to build a Dwelling on a Terrain space, this space needs to be:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>of your color (i.e. it needs to be your Home terrain)</li>\n<li>unoccupied</li>\n<li>directly or indirectly adjacent to one of your</li>\n<li>Structures (\"Adjacency\" is defined in the next section).</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<p>Also, you need to pay its building costs. Each Dwelling costs 1 Worker and 2 Coins. (Exceptions: The Engineers build Dwellings for 1 Worker and 1 Coin, the Swarmlings for 2 Workers and 3 Coins).</p>\n\n<h4>Transforming a Terrain space</h4>\n\n<p>To ensure the first condition is met, you are allowed to transform one unoccupied Terrain space into your Home terrain immediately before building a Dwelling. Place a Terrain tile of your color on that space.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/spade.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>Transformation has its price: Each step between the source and destination terrain on the Transformation cycle of your Faction board costs 1 Spade. Thus, transforming adjacent types of terrain (on the Transformation cycle) into one another costs 1 Spade, with a maximum cost of up to 3 Spades if they are on opposite sides of the cycle as you can move in either direction on the cycle.</p>\n\n<p>(Exception: Giants always have to pay exactly 2 Spades to transform any type of terrain into their Home terrain).</p>\n\n<p>Spades can be acquired in a variety of ways. You may exchange Workers for Spades. The Exchange track of your Faction board displays the Exchange rate: At the beginning of the game, this is usually 3 Workers for 1 Spade (see Action #3).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/exchangerate.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>1 or 2 Spades can be acquired via certain Power actions. One of the Bonus cards provides 1 Spade.</p>\n\n<p>(Halflings and Giants gain additional Spades for immediate use after building their Stronghold).</p>\n\n<p>Spades may only be applied to a single Terrain space. However, there are two special cases:</p>\n\n<ul>\n\n<li><p>If the Spades gained via a Power action or Bonus card do not suffice to transform a Terrain space into your Home terrain, you may exchange Workers for the missing Spades (at the current Exchange rate of your Exchange track).</p></li> <li><p>When gaining 2 Spades, if you only need one of them to transform a Terrain space into your Home terrain, you may apply the second Spade on another Terrain space. However, you may not place a Dwelling on this second space.</p>\n\n<p>(The same is true when the Halflings build their Stronghold, immediately gaining 3 Spades, see last page).</p>\n\n</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<h4>Details on building Dwellings</h4>\n\n<p>When building, take Structures (incl. Dwellings) from left to right off your Faction board. If the current Scoring tile depicts a Dwelling, you get 2 Victory points for each Dwelling you build. This Scoring tile awards 2 Victory points for building Dwellings.</p>\n\n<h4>Details on using Spades</h4>\n\n<p>You may not save Spades for future Actions. Spades need to be used immediately.</p>\n\n<p>If the left side of the current Scoring tile depicts a Spade, you get Victory points for using Spades during the current Action phase. This Scoring tile awards 2 Victory points for using Spades.</p>\n\n<p>After transforming a Terrain space, you do not need to build a Dwelling immediately. You can do this in another Action at a later point in time.</p>\n\n<p>You do not need to transform a Terrain space into your Home terrain, you may stop at any other type of terrain (e.g. if you can not afford more Spades). However, during their turns, your opponents may claim that Terrain space for themselves. (Terrain spaces with Terrain tiles on them but no Structures are considered unoccupied).</p>\n\n<p>Even when transforming a Terrain space without building a Dwelling, the transformed Terrain space needs to be directly or indirectly adjacent to one of your Structures.</p>\n\n<p>You may not transform a Terrain space containing Structures. You may also get Spades via Cult bonuses. As these Spades are gained outside the Action phase, you may not build a Dwelling immediately afterwards, nor do you get to exchange Workers for more Spades. (You have to wait for the next Action phase to build a Dwelling).</p>\n\n<h4>Adjacency</h4>\n\n<p>Due to some other rules, it is important to distinguish between direct and indirect adjacency of Terrain spaces. (This distinction does not matter when building Dwellings, which is what this section is all about).</p>\n\n<h4>Direct adjacency</h4>\n\n<p>Terrain spaces and Structures are considered directly adjacent to one another if they share a hexagon edge. Additionally, Terrain spaces and Structures separated by a River but connected via a Bridge are also considered directly adjacent to one another.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/adjaceny1.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>Indirect adjacency</h4>\n\n<p>Terrain spaces and Structures are considered indirectly adjacent to one another if they are (not directly adjacent to one another, but) separated by one or more River spaces and your Shipping value is high enough to cover the distance. (Shipping is another Action and will be explained in the next section).</p>\n\n<p>Terrain spaces and Structures that Dwarves can reach via Tunneling and Fakirs via Carpet Flight are also considered indirectly adjacent to one another.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/adjaceny2.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Note: When building Dwellings, your opponents get the chance to gain Power. This will be explained in Action #4 \"Upgrading a Structure\". Before that, let us have a look at the following two Actions that facilitate building Dwellings for the remainder of the game: advancing on the Shipping track and lowering the Exchange rate for Spades.</p>\n\n<h3>2. Advancing on the Shipping track</h3>\n\n<p>Terrain spaces and Structures need to be indirectly adjacent to one another if you want to expand beyond River spaces.</p>\n\n<p>In order to transform Terrain spaces or build Structures beyond River spaces, as an Action, you may move the Marker on your Shipping track forward one space. Your Faction board displays the costs of this Action: 1 Priest and 4 Coins.</p>\n\n<p>As a reward for taking this Action, get a number of Victory points as indicated on the Shipping space you move to.</p>\n\n<h3>3. Lowering the Exchange rate for Spades</h3>\n\n<p>At the beginning of the game, Spades cost 3 Workers each (see Action #1). In order to reduce this cost down to 2 Workers or even down to 1 Worker, as an Action, you may move the Marker on your Exchange track up one space. Your Faction board displays the costs of this Action: 2 Workers, 5 Coins, and 1 Priest.</p>\n\n<p>Exception: Halflings pay fewer Coins, and Darklings do not even have an Exchange track as they exchange Priests for Spades.</p>\n\n<p>As a reward for taking this Action, you get 6 Victory points.</p>\n\n<h3>4. Upgrading a Structure</h3>\n\n<p>Structures can be upgraded step by step. The costs for each upgrade are depicted on the Faction board to the left of a Structure.</p>\n\n<p>Always take newly placed Structures from left to right off your Faction board.</p>\n\n<p>When upgrading, you are replacing Structures by one another. Take the Structure that you wish to upgrade off the Game board and return it to your Faction board. This reduces your income for the given type of Structure. (When returning Structures to your Faction board, always put them as far to the right as possible on their proper track). Place the new Structure on the same space on the Game board where the just removed Structure has been. When building a Trading house, return a Dwelling to your Faction board.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/upgrade.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>There are four possible upgrades (two of which can only be done once per game).</p>\n\n<p>Upgrading a Dwelling to a Trading house costs 2 Workers and 6 Coins. If there is at least one opponent's Structure directly adjacent to that Dwelling, you only need to pay 3 Coins instead of 6. If the current Scoring tile depicts a Trading house, get 3 Victory points for this upgrade.</p>\n\n<p>Upgrading a Trading house to a Stronghold costs a number of Workers and Coins depending on the faction. After building its Stronghold, each faction gains a specific special ability.</p>\n\n<p>If the current Scoring tile depicts a Stronghold, get 5 Victory points for this upgrade.</p>\n\n<p>Upgrading a Trading house to a Temple costs 2 Workers and 5 Coins. As a reward, immediately choose and take one Favor tile and put it face-up in front of you. You may immediately take advantage of the newly gained Favor tile, or use it during the current Action phase, respectively). You may not take a Favor tile that you already have.</p>\n\n<p>Upgrading a Temple to a Sanctuary costs a number of Workers and Coins depending on the faction. This is also awarded with a Favor tile. If the current Scoring tile depicts a Sanctuary, get 5 Victory points for this upgrade.</p>\n\n<p>Finally, more about the already mentioned rewards you get when an opponent builds a Structure.</p>\n\n<h4>Power via Structures</h4>\n\n<p>Each Structure has a Power value. The Power value of each Structure is depicted to the right of its track on the Faction board:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/power.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>When building a Dwelling (Action #1) or upgrading a Structure (Action #4), you must inform the owners of Structures directly adjacent to your Structure that they may gain Power.</p>\n\n<p>In order to determine the total number of Power an opponent may gain, add up the Power values of their Structures directly adjacent to your newly built Structure.</p>\n\n<p>You do not gain Power for your own Structures. Power can only be gained when an opponent builds Structures.</p>\n\n<p>Beginning with the player to the left of the active player and in clockwise order, each affected opponent needs to decide whether to actually gain the Power or not. The next section explains why you might want to refuse to gain Power.</p>\n\n<h4>The price of Power</h4>\n\n<p>Unfortunately, Power gained via Structures is not free. To gain that Power, you need to lose a number of Victory points equal to one fewer than the number of Power gained.</p>\n\n<p>Thus, gaining 1/2/3/4/… Power costs 0/1/2/3/… Victory points.</p>\n\n<p>You may not end up with a negative score when losing Victory points.</p>\n\n<p>You may not gain less Power in order to save Victory points. Either take it all or gain nothing. (Exceptions: If you have not enough Power tokens in Bowls I and II, gain as many Power as needed to move all of them to Bowl III and lose Victory points accordingly. Also, you may gain less Power to avoid a negative score. In this case, only gain as many Power as needed to end up with 0 Victory points).</p>\n\n<p>You only lose Victory points when gaining Power via Structures. You do not lose any Victory points when gaining Power otherwise.</p>\n\n<p>You gain Power:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>when an opponent builds Structures (as explained above).</li>\n<li>as income from your Trading houses and Stronghold (and Temples if you are playing the Engineers).</li>\n<li>as income from two specific Bonus cards.</li>\n<li>as income from two specific Favor tiles.</li>\n<li>as a one-time reward when founding a Town and taking the specific Town tile (see page 14 for details on founding a Town).</li>\n<li>as a one-time Cult bonus in Phase III if the specific Scoring tile is up for the current round.</li>\n<li>when advancing on the Cult tracks.</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<h4>Power via Cult tracks</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/culttracks.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Power can also be gained on the Cult tracks of Earth, Water, Fire, and Air. You gain 1/2/2/3 Power when advancing to the 3rd/5th/7th/10th space of a Cult track. You only gain this Power once when advancing to or passing by these spaces.</p>\n\n<p>The Nomad player (yellow) gains 4 Power for advancing these 3 spaces in the Cult of Air. Only one player on space 10 Only one player may advance to space 10 of each Cult track. To do so, you also need to have founded a Town for each space 10 you want to advance to. See page 14 for details on founding a Town.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>5. Send a Priest to the Order of a Cult</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/priest.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>There are 4 spaces below each of the Cult tracks of Earth, Water, Fire, and Air that each can hold exactly 1 Priest. As an Action, you may place one of your Priests on one such space to advance 3 or 2 spaces (as indicated on the space) on the corresponding Cult track.</p>\n\n<p>You may gain Power when advancing on a track (see \"Power via Cult tracks\" above).</p>\n\n<p>There is no way of getting these Priests back. Keep in mind that you only have a total of 7 Priests at your disposal.</p>\n\n<p>If you do not want to lose a Priest, alternatively, return him to your supply (next to your Faction board) and only advance 1 space.</p>\n\n<h3>6. Power actions</h3>\n\n<p>There are two types of Power actions: fully-fledged Actions and auxiliary Actions.</p>\n\n<h4>Power actions on the Game board</h4>\n\n<p>The Power actions on the Game board (indicated by orange octagons) may only be taken once per round. First come, first served.</p>\n\n<p>Whenever taking one of these Actions, move a number of Power tokens from Bowl III to Bowl I equal to its indicated cost. Then, put an Action token on its space on the Game board to indicate that this Action may not be taken any more this round.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/poweractions.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/conversions.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>Sacrificing Power</h4>\n\n<p>f you do not have enough Power in Bowl III to take a specific Power or Conversion action, on top of your Action, you may move Power tokens from Bowl II to Bowl III and then immediately take the desired Action. However, for each Power token moved in this fashion, you need to remove 1 Power token from Bowl II from the game. From now on, you will irrevocably have to deal with fewerPower tokens in your cycle. (You may not sacrifice Power if you only have 1 Power token in Bowl II).</p>\n\n<h3>7. Special actions</h3>\n\n<p>Each Special action may be taken only once per round.</p>\n\n<p>Special actions, like Power actions, are indicated by orange octagons and can be gained in a variety of ways.</p>\n\n<p>Some factions unlock a Special action when building their Stronghold.</p>\n\n<p>One Favor tile and one Bonus card provide a Special action to advance 1 space on a Cult track. Another Bonus card provides a free Spade for transforming a Terrain space.</p>\n\n<p>Use Action tokens to cover taken Special actions.</p>\n\n<h3>8. Passing and new Starting player</h3>\n\n<p>On your turn, if you cannot or do not want to take any more Action, you have to pass and stop taking Actions for the remainder of this round.</p>\n\n<p>The first player to pass becomes the Starting player for the next round (and takes the Starting player token).</p>\n\n<p>When passing, immediately return your Bonus card and take one of the three available ones. This may be a card another player has already returned this round.</p>\n\n<p>Exception: Do not take any Bonus cards in the last round of the game - round 6). If there were Coins on the newly taken Bonus card, put them on your Faction board.</p>\n\n<p>You may get Victory points when returning certain Bonus cards.</p>\n\n<p>When passing and returning the Bonus card depicted on the right, get 1 Victory point for each of your Dwellings on the Game board. When passing and returning the Bonus card depicted on the left, get 2 Victory points for each of your Trading houses on the Game board.</p>\n\n<p>When passing and returning the Bonus card depicted on the right, get 4 Victory points if you have already built your Stronghold and/or 4 Victory points if you have already built your Sanctuary.</p>\n\n<p>Hint: Do not forget to get these Victory points. Always pay attention to the current Scoring tile: you may get Victory points for building certain Structures, for using Spades, or founding Towns.</p>\n\n<p>Freely choose which one of the three available Bonus cards you want to take. (You may not immediately take the card that you have just returned).</p>\n\n<p>You may wish to put the newly taken Bonus card face-down in front of you to indicate that you have already passed.</p>\n\n<p>There is no limitation for how many resources you may keep for the next round.</p>\n\n<p>You may take as many Actions as you wish, even if all other players have already passed. As long as there is at least one player left taking Actions, the current Action phase continues.</p>\n\n<h3>9. Founding a Town</h3>\n\n<p>During the course of the game, one or more Towns may be founded. Towns are founded automatically whenever these two conditions are met:</p>\n\n<ul>\n\n<li><p>There are at least 4 Structures of one color directly adjacent to one another.</p>\n\n<p>Exception: Only 3 Structures are required if one of them is a Sanctuary.</p>\n\n</li>\n\n<li><p>These Structures have a combined Power value of at least 7.</p></li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/founding.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Indicate a founded Town by choosing and taking a Town tile and placing it under one of the Structures forming that Town.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/towntile.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>Benefits of founding a Town</h4>\n\n<p>Immediately get a number of Victory points as indicated by the chosen Town tile. Get additional Victory points if the current Scoring tile depicts a key.</p>\n\n<p>Immediately and only once, collect the rewards depicted on the chosen Town tile (either +1 space on each of the Cult tracks, 1 Priest, 2 Workers, 6 Coins, or 8 Power).</p>\n\n<p>Each Town provides a key. Each key allows you to advance to the last space of one Cult track (space 10). (Without a key, you have to stop at space 9).</p>\n\n<p>When founding a Town, all Structures directly adjacent to one another form that Town (Bridges are key here), even if there are more than the required number of Structures.</p>\n\n<p>Indirect adjacency (especially via River spaces) has no relevance when founding a Town. (Exception: The Mermaids may ignore any one River space when founding a Town).</p>\n\n<p>Building new Structures directly adjacent to an existing Town expands that Town rather than forming a new one.</p>\n\n<p>When a Structure is built combining two existing Towns to one larger Town, these Towns do not lose their individual rights or functions (despite the fact that you cannot tell anymore where their borders are).</p>\n\n<p>The total number of Towns for one game is limited to 10.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Phase III Cult Bonuses and Clean-Up Phase</h2>\n\n<p>When all players have passed (see Action #8 on the left), the current Action phase is over. In rounds 1 to 5, the Action phase is followed by a Clean-up phase preparing the next round.</p>\n\n<p>There is no Clean-up phase after the last round.</p>\n\n<h4>Cult Bonuses</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/cultbonus.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>First, the Cult bonuses depicted on the current Scoring tile need to be awarded. Each player with enough progress in the depicted Cults gets the depicted reward, multiple times if need be.</p>\n\n<p>The Cult bonuses are awarded in the play order of the next round. This is relevant for Spades.</p>\n\n<p>You may not acquire additional Spades when getting them as a Cult bonus. Neither may the Fakirs do a Carpet Flight, nor the Dwarves do Tunneling when getting Spades as a Cult bonus. A Carpet Flight and Tunneling have costs that cannot be paid outside the Action phase. Also, if the Giants get only a single Spade as a Cult bonus, this Spade will be forfeit.</p>\n\n<p>You may not save Spades for future turns. You may apply these Spades on different adjacent Terrain spaces.</p>\n\n<p>You may not build a Dwelling in Phase III.</p>\n\n<h4>Return Action tokens</h4>\n\n<p>If there are any Action tokens on: Power action spaces on the Game board, Special action spaces on Faction boards, or Favor tiles and Bonus cards, remove them from there.</p>\n\n<h4>Coins on Bonus cards</h4>\n\n<p>Put 1 Coin from the general supply on each of the three leftover Bonus cards. (If a card has not been taken by any player for two rounds, it will now have 2 Coins on it).</p>\n\n<h4>Turn the Scoring tile face-down</h4>\n\n<p>As the last act of the current round, turn the current Scoring tile facedown so that only the Scoring tiles of the following rounds remain face-up.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the game</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/box.jpg\" class=\"floatr margin-top-5 margin-bottom-10\">\n\n<p>The game ends after all players have passed in the Action phase of the last round. Afterwards, there is a final scoring. (As indicated by the Game end token, there are no Cult bonuses in the final round).</p>\n\n<h4>Cult scoring</h4>\n\n<p>Score each of the four Cult tracks individually:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>8 Victory points for the player highest on a track.</li>\n<li>4 Victory points for the player second highest on a track.</li>\n<li>2 Victory points for the player third highest on a track.</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<p>These values are also depicted in the top left corner of the Game board. You cannot gain any Victory points when being still on space 0. In case of a tie, evenly divide the Victory points of the respective tiers among the tied players (round down if necessary).</p>\n\n<h4>Area scoring</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/terra-mystica/areascoring.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Determine the number of your Structures directly or indirectly adjacent to one another. With the proper Shipping value, scattered areas may be indirectly adjacent to one another (and, thus, considered connected).</p>\n\n<p>The player with the highest number of connected Structures gets 18 Victory points. The player with the second highest number of connected Structures gets 12 Victory points. And the player with the third highest number of connected Structures gets 6 Victory points.</p>\n\n<p>These values are also depicted in the top left corner of the Game board. In case of a tie, evenly divide the Victory points of the respective tiers among the tied players (round down if necessary).</p>\n\n<h4>Resource scoring</h4>\n\n<p>Finally, get Victory points for left-over resources: get 1 Victory point per 3 Coins. (All other resources may be converted to Coins for this purpose).</p>\n\n<p>The Alchemists get 1 Victory point per 2 Coins.</p>\n\n<h4>The winner of the game</h4>\n\n<p>The player with the highest number of Victory points wins the game. In case of a tie, there is more than one winner.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"setup.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Terra Mystica Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:52:12.138Z"),

  295   // Update existing rule
→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 106
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Sagrada Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/sagrada/sagrada.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n\n\n<p>You are an artist competing with fellow artists to create the most beautiful stained glass window in the Sagrada Familia. Your glass pieces are represented by dice, which have a color and a shade - indicated by the values on the dice (the lower the value the lighter the shade).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/sagrada/shades.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Each round, players will take turns drafting from a pool of dice, placing these dice on their window.</p>\n\n<p>Players must place them within the color and shade restrictions on their Window card, and never have adjacent dice of the same color or value.</p>\n\n<p>After 10 rounds, players score points based on public and private objectives - the highest scoring artisan is the winner!</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<h3>Player Setup</h3>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">1</s> Shuffle the Private Objective Cards (Gray die on the back) and give 1 to each player face down. Players may secretly look at this card.</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">2</s> Give each player 2 random Window Pattern Cards and 1 Window Frame Player Board. Each player selects 1 of the 4 Window Patterns to play (front or back), the other card isn't used. +Note: Windows have varying difficulty from level 3 (easiest) to 6 (hardest) as indicated near the name. Difficult windows give more Favor Tokens</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">3</s> Give each player the number of Favor Tokens indicated by the difficulty number on their card.</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">4</s> Slide the selected Window Pattern Card into the bottom of the Player Board.</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">5</s> Place a Score Marker that matches the color of each player's board next to the Round Track, these are used during End Game Scoring.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/sagrada/setup.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel2\">A</s> Place the Round Track near the center of the play area.</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel2\">B</s> Shuffle all of the Tool Cards and place 3 face up in the center of the play area.</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel2\">C</s> Shuffle all of the Public Objective cards (Blue die on the back) and place 3 face up.</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel2\">D</s> Place all 90 dice in the Dice Bag.</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel2\">E</s> Randomly select a player to be the Start Player and give them the Dice Bag. One suggested method is whoever most recently visited a cathedral.</p>\n\n<p>Set aside all remaining Objective, Tool and Window Cards, they are not used during the game.</p>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> Setup is the same for 2, 3 or 4 players.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>Each game of Sagrada is played over 10 rounds.</p>\n\n<p>Each round, the Start Player (the player with the Dice Bag) pulls dice out of the Dice Bag at random and rolls them. The number of dice pulled depends on the number of players (2 per player, plus 1 additional die):</p>\n<ul>\n<li>2 Players - 5 Dice</li>\n<li>3 Players - 7 Dice</li>\n<li>4 Players - 9 Dice</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Once rolled, these dice form the Draft Pool.</p>\n\n<p>Beginning with the Start Player, each player takes a turn in clockwise order. On a player's turn, they may perform each of the following actions in any order:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><b>Select 1 die</b> from the Draft Pool and place it in an open space on their Window</li>\n<li><b>Use 1 Tool Card</b> by spending Favor Tokens</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Each action is optional - A player may choose to perform both actions, only one action or pass their turn taking no actions.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p>Turns proceed <b>clockwise</b> with each player taking a turn or passing.</p>\n\n<p><b>Example:</b> Emily takes a turn <s class=\"tokenlabel3\">1</s>, then Ben <s class=\"tokenlabel3\">2</s>, then Mari <s class=\"tokenlabel3\">3</s>.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/sagrada/example.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Once the last player has completed their first turn, the round continues in reverse order (counterclockwise).</p>\n\n<p>Beginning with the last player, each player takes a second turn (selecting a second die from the Draft Pool, etc).</p>\n\n<p><b>Example:</b> Mari takes her second turn <s class=\"tokenlabel3\">4</s>, then Ben <s class=\"tokenlabel3\">5</s>, then Emily <s class=\"tokenlabel3\">6</s> Once the Start Player has taken their second turn, proceed to the End of the Round.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Placing Dice</h2>\n\n<p>When placing a die on a Window:</p>\n\n<blockquote class=\"white\">\n\n<p><b>First die:</b> Each player's first die of the game must be placed on an edge or corner space.</p>\n\n<p><b>Every other die</b> must be adjacent to a previously placed die, touching diagonally (different row and column) or orthogonally (same row or column).</p>\n\n<p>The die must match the color or value restriction of the space. White spaces have no restrictions Example - A red space on the window may only be filled by a red die (any value). A space showing a 3 may only be filled by a die showing a 3 (any color).</p>\n\n<p>Dice may never be placed orthogonally adjacent to a die of the same color or the same value. Example - Two red dice or two dice showing a 3 may not be placed side by side.</p>\n\n<p>Players may choose not to draft a die during their turn.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> Any die may be placed on a white space as long as all the above restrictions are obeyed</p>\n\n<p><b>Tip:</b> Try to avoid placing dice next to a matching space (such as a 2 die next to a 2 space or red die next to a red space) so a future die can still be placed in that space</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Tool Cards &amp; Favor Tokens</h2>\n\n<p>Players may spend Favor Tokens to gain a special ability from 1 Tool Card during their turn:</p>\n<ol>\n<li>Place Favor Tokens on the Tool Card - 1 if there aren't any tokens on the card, otherwise place 2.</li>\n<li>Use the ability listed on the Tool Card.</li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>Players may choose not to use a <b>Tool Card</b> on their turn.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/sagrada/cardstokens.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p><b>Tip:</b> Being the first to use each Tool Card costs the fewest Favor Tokens. However, Tool Card abilities become more useful later in the game as player's Windows fill with dice.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End Of The Round</h2>\n\n<p>All remaining dice are placed on the <b>Round Track</b>, covering the number space for the just completed round. If multiple dice remain (due to players skipping a draft action) these do not cover additional number spaces.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/sagrada/end_of_round.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>The <b>Dice Bag</b> is passed clockwise to the next player. This player is now the Start Player - players then begin another round.</p>\n\n<p><b>Example </b>- Ben is now the start player for the second round.</p>\n\n<p>If this was the end of the 10th round, it is the end of the game - proceed to End Game Scoring.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>The game ends at the end of the 10th round.</p>\n<ol>\n<li>Clear the dice off the <b>Round Track</b> and flip it over to the <b>Score Track</b> side.</li>\n<li>Use each player's <b>Score Marker</b> to track their position on the Score Track, flipping the marker if they exceed 50 points.</li>\n</ol>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/sagrada/end_game_scoring.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Each player tallies their Victory Point total, gaining points from:</p>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n<ul>\n<li><b>Each Public Objective Card </b>- Players may gain points from each card multiple times. Row/Column-based objectives only score for completed Rows/Columns (no open spaces).</li>\n<li><b>Their Private Objective Card </b>- Summing the values of their dice of the specified color.</li>\n<li><b>Favor Tokens </b>- 1 Victory Point for each unspent token.</li>\n<li>Players <b>Lose 1 Victory Point</b> for each open space on their window.</li>\n</ul>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>The player with the highest Victory Point total is the winner.</p>\n\n<p>Ties are broken by most points from Private Objectives, most remaining Favor Tokens, then finally by reverse player order in the final round.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Dice Placement Mistakes</h3>\n\n<p>If a Player's Window is ever found to break any of the placement restrictions, that player must immediately remove dice (of their choice) from their Window until all restrictions are obeyed. These dice are out of play and any resulting open spaces will count against their score as normal.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"the-great-facades-passion.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Sagrada Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:53:08.805Z"),
