  293 
  294 if (existingRule) {
  295   // Update existing rule
→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 108
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Reef Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<p>Observe the growth of nature's most beautiful and exotic natural structure: the coral reef Found primarily in the Indo-Pacific region, it has taken reefs thousands of years to grow. Over that time, they have mesmerized marine life and created amazing aquatic ecosystems. Prepare yourselves to do the same... and open your eyes to the beauty of the oceans.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>112 coral pieces (28 pieces of each color)</li>\n<li>88 point tokens</li>\n<li>60 cards</li>\n<li>4 player cards</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>Collect the most points by cleverly acquiring and playing cards that let you grow your reef and score its patterns.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef3.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Sort the 112 coral pieces by color to form 4 separate supplies <s class=\"tokenlabel\">A</s>. Depending on the number of players, each of these 4 supplies must comprise a certain number ofcoral pieces:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>In a 4-player game: Use all 28 coral pieces of each color.</li>\n<li>In a 3-player game: Use 24 coral pieces of each color.</li>\n<li>In a 2-player game: Use 18 coral pieces of each color.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Return any unused coral pieces to the box. Sort the point tokens by their value (I, 3, 5,10,20) and form separate supplies for each value <s class=\"tokenlabel\">B</s></p>\n\n<p>Give each player three l-point token <s class=\"tokenlabel\">C</s>, which he places in front of him as his personal point stock. This is where he collects all of his point tokens.</p>\n\n<p>Shuffle the 60 cards and deal 2 cards face down to each player <s class=\"tokenlabel\">D</s>. Each player takes his cards into his hand, concealing them from the other players. Then set the card deck face down aside for later.</p>\n\n<p>Take as many player boards <s class=\"tokenlabel\">E</s> as there are players. Make sure the one with the starfish <s class=\"tokenlabel\">F</s> is included. Shuffle them and place one at random in front of each player. The player with the starfish board will be the first player.</p>\n\n<p>From the coral supplies, each player takes 1 coral piece of each color <s class=\"tokenlabel\">G</s>. Then each player places one of his 4 coral pieces onto each of the 4 center spaces of his player board <s class=\"tokenlabel\">H</s> (in any order).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef7.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If all players know the game, we recommend the following setup variant: Each player places his 4 pieces on any spaces of his player board other than the 4 central spaces. He may even stack them up any way he likes.</p>\n\n<p>Next to his player board, each player should leave some room for a face-up discard pile <s class=\"tokenlabel\">I</s>. Take the deck of cards set aside earlier and place it as a face-up draw deck <s class=\"tokenlabel\">J</s> in the middle of the table.</p>\n\n<p>Draw 3 cards from that deck and place them in a face-up row next to the deck. That row of 3 cards forms the card display <s class=\"tokenlabel\">K</s>.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>Reef is played over a series of rounds. Each player will take one turn each round, starting with the first player and going clockwise until the game end is reached. On your turn, you must perform one of the following two actions:</p>\n<ol type=\"A\">\n<li>Take a card from the card display (or from the deck) into your hand.</li>\n<li>Play a card from your hand to grow your reef AND (if possible) score a pattern</li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>Then it is the turn of the player to your left.</p>\n\n<h3>A. Take a card from the card display (or from the deck) into your hand</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef8.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Choose one of the 3 cards from the display and put it in your hand. If there are any point tokens on that card, place them in your personal point stock.</p>\n\n<p>Then bring the display back up to 3 cards by moving the top card from the deck to the display.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef9.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Instead of taking one of the 3 cards in the display, you may take the top card from the face-up draw deck and put it in your hand. However, to do so, you must immediately place one l-point token from your personal point stock onto the card with the lowest printed point value (the number in the bottom right corner) in the display.</p>\n\n<p>If there is a tie for the lowest printed point value, place it onto the tied card of your choice. If your personal point stock is empty, you cannot take the top card from the draw deck.</p>\n\n<p><b>Attention:</b> You have a hand limit of 4 cards. If you already have 4 cards in your hand, you cannot take another card. You must perform action B instead.</p>\n\n<h3>B. Play a card from your hand to grow your reef and (if possible) score a pattern</h3>\n\n<p>Play a card from your hand by placing it onto your face-up discard pile, next to your player board. Then perform the two following steps in this specific order:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef13.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>1. From the supplies of their respective colors, take both coral pieces shown on the top of your played card and place each of them anywhere on your player board: Each can be on any blank space or on top of a piece or stack.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef14.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>You are free to stack these two pieces in any order onto one another or place them separately. However, once you have placed them, they remain where they are for the rest of the game.</p>\n\n<p><b>Attention:</b> There is a stack limit: If a stack already contains 4 coral pieces, you are not allowed to place another piece on top of it.</p>\n\n<p>2. Afterwards, you may score the pattern shown on the bottom of the card. To do so, check how often the pattern appears throughout your reef:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>If the pattern does not appear at all throughout your reef, nothing happens.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>If the pattern appears once in your reef, take from the points supply the number of points shown in the bottom right corner of the card and place them in your personal point stock.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>If the pattern appears multiple times throughout your reef, take the shown number of points as many times as the pattern appears.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>To determine if and how often the pattern appears in your reef, bear the following rules in mind:</p>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<p>Patterns can appear in any right-angle orientation.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef15.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<h4>Only The Topview Is Relevant!</h4>\n\n<p>This means that it is always the color of the top coral piece of any stack that counts for the pattern, no matter what color any of the pieces below it are.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef16.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>This also means that if a pattern on a card shows pieces with no printed numbers within them, your top pieces' heights do not matter when completing that pattern.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<p><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef17.jpg\"> Printed numbers, however, relate to specific heights:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef22.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef23.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>So for a pattern with a printed number, only your top pieces of the right color and height count.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<p>If a pattern shows printed numbers with a \"+\" next to them, all of your top pieces of the right color and with a height equal to or higher than the printed number count.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef18.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<p>If patterns show wild pieces (a 4-colored shape) with printed numbers, only the height of those top pieces is relevant, not their color.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef19.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<p>Each of your top pieces can only count towards one completion of the pattern. Therefore, to have a pattern appear multiple times throughout your reef, each of its completions cannot share any pieces.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef20.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote class=\"radius\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef24.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>There are 8 cards that show a special pattern like this one.</p>\n\n<p>All of them have different color combinations but basically work the same.</p>\n\n<p>For example, the pattern on the right means: Take 2 points for each purple top piece that is adjacent (orthogonally or diagonally) to your highest coral stack with a yellow top piece.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/reef/reef21.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If there is a tie for the highest, choose one of them. (It does not matter how high any of the stacks of other colors are - including the purple ones - as long as there is no higher stack with a yellow top piece).</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>As soon as at least one color of coral pieces runs out, the game will end after players finish out the current round of play.</p>\n\n<p>In rare cases, the game also ends immediately if the card deck runs out.</p>\n\n<p>Each player who still has any cards left in his hand may now score the patterns of those cards (without taking any coral pieces first). However, for each card a player still has in his hand, that player may only score a completed pattern once, even if the pattern appears multiple times throughout his reef.</p>\n\n<p>Once this is done, the player with the highest score wins the game.</p>\n\n<p>In case of a tie, the tied player who has the most covered spaces on his player board wins. If this does not breakthe tie, the tied player who has the most stacks of 4 corals wins. If this still does not breakthe tie, the victory is shared.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>General Notes</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>puring the last round, when you must take coral pieces of a color whose supply does not contain enough pieces, take as many as you can from that supply and continue your turn as usual.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>&amp;t any time, you may exchange point tokens between your personal point stock and the points supplies (or between a card in the display and the point supplies) to get different denominations of the same value.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>During the game, you are allowed to stack your point tokens to conceal your actual point total.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>The supply of point tokens is considered unlimited. If you run out of tokens,</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"buy-reef.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Reef Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:53:17.818Z"),
            ~~~~~~~~~
        ?   language?: String | StringFieldUpdateOperationsInput,
        ?   setupInstructions?: String | NullableStringFieldUpdateOperationsInput | Null,
        ?   victoryConditions?: String | NullableStringFieldUpdateOperationsInput | Null,
        ?   game?: GameUpdateOneRequiredWithoutRulesNestedInput
          }
        })

          where: {
            id: 109
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Kingdomino Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/kingdomino/kingdomino.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/kingdomino/intro.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>You are a Lord seeking new lands to expand your Kingdom. You must explore all the lands, wheat fields, lakes, mountains in order to spot the best plots. But be careful, as some other Lords are also coveting theses lands...</p>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> Before your first game, assemble the 4 small castles.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/kingdomino/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>4 starting tiles</li>\n<li>4 3D castles</li>\n<li>48 dominoes</li>\n<li>8 wooden kings in 4 colors</li>\n<li>Instructions</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<div class=\"box blue2_border\">\n\n<p>Connect your dominoes in order to build your kingdom in a 5x5 grid in a way to score the most prestige points.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/kingdomino/setup.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Place the box as indicated to the right. Each player takes:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>2-player games: two kings of their color.</li>\n<li>3- and 4-player games: one king of their color.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Each player takes a starting tile (a square) and the castle of their color. They place the tile, face up, in front of them and then they place the castle on it.</p>\n\n<p>ALL the dominoes are thoroughly shuffled, numbered side up, and then they are randomly placed in the box insert to form the draw pile of the game:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>2 player games: first, remove 24 dominoes randomly, set them aside. Use the remaining 24.</li>\n<li>3 player games: remove 12 dominoes randomly. Play with remaining 36.</li>\n<li>4 player games: use all 48 dominoes.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">A</s> Then, from the draw pile, take the same number of dominoes as the number of kings in play (i.e. three dominoes for a 3-player game and four dominoes for a 2- or 4-player game). Display them next to the box, numbered side up. These dominoes must be displayed in the ascending order (the lowest number next is always placed next to the box). Finally, turn them on the lands- cape side.</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">B</s> A player takes all the kings in their hands, shuffle them thoroughly and then they get them out of their hands one after the other. When your king appears, place-it on an empty domino in the line. Each tile can only have one king. It means that the last player doesn't have any choice. (in a 2-player game, each player will choose 2 dominoes, one for each of their kings)</p>\n\n<p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">C</s> When all the dominoes have been chosen, form a new line, as you previously did, by drawing new tiles.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/kingdomino/setup2.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>The playing order is determined by the positions of the kings on the dominoes line.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/kingdomino/gameplay.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The player, whose king, is placed on the 1st domino of the line (the closest to the box) starts. He must take the following actions:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">D</s> 1 : Add the chosen domino to their territory according the connection rules.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><s class=\"tokenlabel\">D</s> 2: Choose a new domino in the new line by placing their king on it.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Then, it is the turn of the player whose king is on the second domino to take their two actions, and so on, until the last player has taken their two actions.</p>\n\n<p>In a 2-player game, each player will take the <s class=\"tokenlabel\">D</s> 1 and <s class=\"tokenlabel\">D</s> 2 actions twice, once for each of their kings.</p>\n\n<p>Then, form a new dominoes line and a new turn can start.</p>\n\n<p>The game is played in 12 turns in 3- or 4-player games, and only 6 turns in 2-player games (as each player plays twice each turn).</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Connection Rules</h3>\n\n<p>The players must build a kingdom in a 5x5 grid (each domino is composed of two squares).</p>\n\n<p>In order to place down their domino, the player must:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>Either connect it to their starting tile (the starting domino can be considered as a wild domino, any landscape can be connected to this domino),</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Or connect it to another domino matching at least 1 of its landscape (horizontally or vertically only).</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>If you can't add a domino to your kingdom fol- lowing these rules, the domino must be discarded and you will not get points for it.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/kingdomino/gameplay2.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>All your dominoes must fit in 5x5 grid. If, due to bad planning, one or more of your dominoes could not fit, they are discarded. You will not get points for them.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<div class=\"box blue2_border\">\n\n<p>When the last dominoes are lined up, the players will take a last turn but they will only take the <s class=\"tokenlabel\">D</s> 1 action.</p>\n\n<p>Each player should have in front of them a 5x5 grid forming their kingdom. (some kingdoms may not be complete if a player was forced to discard any dominoes - see above). Then, each player will calculate their prestige points for their kingdoms in the following way:</p>\n\n<p>A kingdom is composed of different properties (groups of connected, either horizontally or vertically, squares of the same type of landscape).</p>\n\n<p>Each property will give you as much prestige points as the NUMBER OF SQUARES multiplied with the number OF specific crowns appearing on the property.</p>\n\n<p>You can have multiple properties with the same type of landscape in the same kingdom. ZA property without a specific crowns will give you no points.</p>\n\n<p>Each player will add the points given by all their properties, the result is their final score. The player with the highest score is the winner.</p>\n\n<p>In case of a tie, the player with the most extended property (whether he owns any crowns or not) wins the game.</p>\n\n<p>If it is still a tie, the player who has the most crowns wins the game. If there is still a tie anyway, the players share the victory.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/kingdomino/victory.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Additionnal Rules</h2>\n\n<div class=\"box grey5_bg\">\n\n<p><b>Dynasty:</b> Play 3 rounds in a row. At the end of the 3 rounds, the player with the highest number of points wins the game.</p>\n\n<p><b>The middle Kingdom:</b> score 10 additional points if your castle is in the center of your kingdom.</p>\n\n<p><b>Harmony :</b> score 5 additional points if you territory is complete (no discarded dominoes).</p>\n\n<p><b>The Mighty Duel:</b> With 2 players. After one or two practice games, the real champions battle to build the largest kingdoms: use all the dominoes to build a 7x7 grid (a pen and paper might be useful to keep your final score).</p>\n\n<p>You can mix these different variants if you want according to what you prefer.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"age of giants.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Kingdomino Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:53:41.301Z"),
            ~~~~~~~~~
        ?   language?: String | StringFieldUpdateOperationsInput,
        ?   setupInstructions?: String | NullableStringFieldUpdateOperationsInput | Null,
        ?   victoryConditions?: String | NullableStringFieldUpdateOperationsInput | Null,
        ?   game?: GameUpdateOneRequiredWithoutRulesNestedInput
          }
        })

→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 110
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Betrayal Legacy Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/betrayal-legacy.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<p>In Betrayal Legacy, you play a member of a family exploring a house-a house that seems to invite trouble. At some point during the game, one player triggers what is called the haunt.</p>\n\n<p>At this point, one player usually becomes a traitor bent on defeating the rest of the players. The rest of the players become heroes struggling to survive. From then on, the game is a fight between the traitor and the heroes-often to the death.</p>\n\n<p>Each game will change the house in some way and tell more of its story. At the end of 13 chapters (plus a prologue), you will complete the campaign portion of Betrayal Legacy. From there, you may play the game in \"free play\" mode. In free play, very few changes will be made to the game.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n<ul>\n<li>1 sealed box and 1 sealed envelope</li>\n<li>2 haunt books</li>\n<li>1 Bleak Journal</li>\n<li>1 sticker sheet</li>\n<li>1 Folium Infernum</li>\n<li>12 tiles (including 4 starting tiles)</li>\n<li>1 numbered track</li>\n<li>5 plastic family figures</li>\n<li>5 colored plastic bases</li>\n<li>5 Family cards</li>\n<li>20 plastic clips</li>\n<li>8 dice</li>\n<li>7 Item cards</li>\n<li>11 Event cards</li>\n<li>1 Traitor card</li>\n<li>1 Monster card</li>\n<li>2 Legacy decks</li>\n<li>1 Purgatory deck</li>\n<li>20 tile planks</li>\n<li>122 tokens</li>\n<li>1 rulebook</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>Explore the house and make your family member stronger until the haunt begins. After that, your goal is to complete your side's victory condition first, as either a traitor or a hero.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>What is a Legacy Game?</h2>\n\n<p>Betrayal Legacy is a legacy game, so some things that happen in one game will carry forward to future games. Sometimes you will add cards or add stickers to materials.</p>\n\n<p>Other times you may destroy components or otherwise permanently alter the game. Each group's journey and history of the house will be unique. Which families will have a penchant for madness? Which tiles will become focuses of evil?</p>\n\n<h4>How Does Betrayal Legacy Work?</h4>\n\n<p>The campaign is played over a series of chapters, each one a different game. Each chapter, players will play a member of a family. It may be the character who played in the previous chapter (if they lived) or a descendant-perhaps a nephew or child or lost cousin.</p>\n\n<p>Each game is self-contained: it starts mostly the same way and proceeds until there is a winning side. At the end of the game, players will follow instructions to shape the start of the next game (and games beyond that).</p>\n\n<p>Along the way, the house and its environs will change, sometimes outside the players' control.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h5>Key Terms</h5>\n\n<p>Everyone: Each player, monster, or other inhabitant of the house.</p>\n\n<p>Figure: The plastic pawn controlled by a player. People/Person: Anyone in the house who isn't a monster.</p>\n\n<p>Traitor: Any player who has turned evil after the haunt has started. Traitors are still players.</p>\n\n<p>Hero: Any player who remains good after the haunt has started. Heroes are still players.</p>\n\n<p>Monster: Large or small Monster tokens during a haunt.</p>\n\n<p>Item/Omen/Object: Things that are carried by players. Items and Omens are cards.</p>\n\n<p>Objects appear in some haunts and are represented by tokens.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/game.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Elements</h2>\n\n<p>Read here <a href=\"game-elements.php\">all detailed information of the game elements</a>.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<p>Attach four plastic clips to your character's Family card. Each one should point to one of the starting values for their Speed, Might, Sanity, and Knowledge. The starting values are colored green.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Find the four starting tiles. Place them reasonably far apart on the table to create regions of the house and its environs.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/game22.jpg\"><br><br>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Select a figure to represent you and place it into a base matching the color of your Family card.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p><i>(Campaign only)</i> Privately give your character a first name and an age, and write both on the back of your Family card. (You can make up any age you like). This will likely be a new character, but if you survived the previous chapter, you may use the same character again, now older.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<i>\n\n</i><p><i>(Campaign only)</i> Introduce yourself to the rest of the players, stating your character's name and age.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p><i>(Campaign only)</i> Read the top card in the Legacy deck.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p><i>(Free play only)</i> Shuffle all card decks separately. Shuffle the tiles to make a stack. Set out any other cards you may have found.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p><i>(Free play only)</i> Randomly decide who goes first.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/game16_.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>The Families</h4>\n\n<p>There are up to five families who will create the history of the house. Each player will play a member of the same family in each game. At the start of each chapter, write the name of your family member on the card, as well as their age.</p>\n\n<p>At the end of each campaign game, record their fate (such as \"Vanquished a demon!\" or \"Died near a well from poison\"), whether they died, and whether they were a traitor.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/game5.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Traits, Dice and Tiles</h2>\n\n<h3>Traits</h3>\n\n<p>Each character has four traits, shown on their Family card: Speed, Might, Sanity, and Knowledge. Speed and Might are physical traits; Sanity and Knowledge are mental traits. Character traits are public knowledge.</p>\n\n<h3>Damage, Gaining, Losing, And Healing</h3>\n\n<p>Characters can take damage, causing their traits to decrease. Slide the corresponding clips down the track a total number of steps equal to the damage, divided as you choose. The type of damage determines which traits can be lowered.</p>\n<ul>\n<li><b>Physical Damage:</b> Lower Might and/or Speed.</li>\n<li><b>Mental Damage:</b> Lower Knowledge and/or Sanity.</li>\n<li><b>General Damage:</b> Lower any combination of traits.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>You may also be instructed to lose from or lower a specific trait directly (such as \"Lose 2 Speed\"). That counts as taking physical or mental damage, depending on the trait.</p>\n\n<p>If you take \"1 die of damage\", roll a die and take appropriate damage equal to the result.</p>\n\n<p>If more than one person and/or monster would take damage at the same time, start with the player to the left of the current player and proceeed clockwise.</p>\n\n<p>If you are instructed to gain X in a trait, you may increase that trait X steps (up to its highest step). If you are instructed to heal a trait, you may return that trait to its starting value if it is lower. Do nothing if it is equal to or higher than its starting value.</p>\n\n<h3>Critical Traits</h3>\n\n<p>When a trait is at its lowest step before the skull, it is critical. Before the haunt begins, no trait can drop below its critical value (if it would, it stays at the critical value instead). Once the haunt begins, traits can drop to the skull. If that happens, you die.</p>\n\n<h3>Raising and Lowering from the same Effect</h3>\n\n<p>Many effects in the game require you to lose from a trait in order to gain a benefit. You must be able to pay the full \"penalty\" in order to gain the \"reward\". If you can't, you do not get the benefit. For example, a tile's effect might say \"If you end your turn here, you may lose 2 Might to gain 1 Sanity\". If your Might is 1 step above critical, you cannot lose 2 Might, so you cannot gain 1 Sanity.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Dice and Die Rolls</h2>\n\n<p>There are 8 dice that come with the game. Each die has faces with 0, 1, or 2 dots. When you make a roll, total the number of dots to get the result. You can never roll more than 8 dice and you can never roll fewer than 1 die.</p>\n\n<p>No result can ever be below 0, no matter how many penalties are applied. Then do what the effect says for that result.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/game23.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/game24.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h3>Trait Rolls</h3>\n\n<p>You will often be told to make a trait roll based on one of your family's traits (for example, \"Make a Might roll\"). When that happens, roll dice equal to the number you currently have in that trait.</p>\n\n<p>For example, if you must make a Sanity roll, and you currently have a Sanity of 4, roll 4 dice and total the dots together to get the result. The card's or tile's text will tell you the outcome.</p>\n\n<h3>Roll X Dice</h3>\n\n<p>Some effects require you to roll a certain number of dice. Pretty straightforward; just roll that many dice and add up the dots. These are not trait rolls and are not subject to anything that affects trait rolls.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Regions and tiles</h2>\n\n<p>The house and its environs have four regions: outside, basement, ground floor, and upper floor. Each region is separate from the others. As the house grows, you might start running out of table space. In that case, adjust the tiles as needed to make more space. Do not change how the tiles are connected; move each region as a whole.</p>\n\n<p>Tiles are adjacent if they are both discovered and connected by a doorway or other effect. \"Doorway\" is used regardless of whether the tile is inside or outside. A doorway that is not connected to another tile is an open doorway.</p>\n\n<p>The Ground Floor Staircase is adjacent to the Upper Landing and the Basement Landing (and vice versa). The Front Steps tile, which is in the outside region, is adjacent to the Entrance Hall (and vice versa).</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>At the start of your turn, do the following in order:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p>Set any used Items and Omens you are carrying to unused.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Gain moves equal to your current Speed.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Take your turn, using moves and taking actions as you like until you are out of both or choose not to do any more. You can perform actions in between moves, after you are out of moves, or before moving.</p></li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Moving</h3>\n\n<p>Moves are used most often to travel to an adjacent tile or to discover a new tile. You use 1 move for each tile you leave. No matter how many penalties you have on a turn or how many obstacles you face, you can always move to a tile adjacent to where you started.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/game7.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p><b>Obstacles:</b> Each small obstacle on a tile costs 1 extra move when leaving that tile.</p>\n\n<p>Each large obstacle on a tile costs 2 extra moves when leaving that tile. Also, Small Monster tokens are small obstacles and Large Monster tokens are large obstacles to the heroes.</p>\n\n<p>Whenever you draw a card from the Event, Omen, or Item deck for any reason, you lose any remaining moves you had. You can still take actions.</p>\n\n<h4>Secret Passages</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/game6.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The house has secret passages within it. In the prologue, there is one tile with a secret passage (the Crawlspace). As you play, you will find ways to place Secret Passage stickers on tiles.</p>\n\n<p>A tile with a secret passage is adjacent to every other tile with a secret passage.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/game9.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Discovering a new Tile</h3>\n\n<p>When you leave a tile through a doorway not connected to a tile, look at the back of the top tile of the stack. If it has the name of the region you are in (some tiles can go into more than one region), turn it over and connect it by aligning a doorway on the new tile to the doorway you just passed through. Then move into that tile. You have discovered it.</p>\n\n<p>Add each new tile as logically as you can, connecting as many adjacent doorways as you can. Two tiles (the Entrance Hall and Front Steps) have a bump on one side to show that tiles cannot be placed on those sides.</p>\n\n<p>If the top tile can't go on the region you're currently on, bury it. Keep burying tiles until you find one that matches your region.</p>\n\n<p>Most tiles have a symbol on their face-up side, representing an Event, Item, or Omen. When you first discover a tile with one of these symbols, draw a card with the matching symbol. (Tiles with these symbols are called Event tiles, Item tiles, and Omen tiles). Some tiles also have an action on them.</p>\n\n<p>Some tiles have more than one symbol. When discovering such a tile, resolve each symbol from left to right. Players cannot take any actions before or between resolving these symbols.</p>\n\n<p>Players who enter a previously discovered tile do not draw a card when they enter but still are affected by text on the tile and can take any action printed on the tile.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/game12.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h4>Runestones</h4>\n\n<p>Some tiles contain Runestone symbols. You can ignore these unless a card or haunt tells you otherwise.</p>\n\n<h4>Ghosts</h4>\n\n<p>Most tiles have circles on them showing where ghosts will come to haunt the house. Some tiles start with ghosts on them. Omens harness the energy of ghosts in the house and are more powerful on tiles with ghosts. Some Event cards will be more painful on tiles with ghosts.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/game25.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>Turn Timing when Discovering a Tile</h4>\n\n<p>You might be required to do multiple things when discovering a tile. Resolve them in the following order.</p>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<p>Resolve any symbol(s) from left to right, one at a time. You cannot take any actions while resolving Event cards.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>If you drew an Omen card and the haunt hasn't started, check to see if the haunt starts. If the haunt starts, your turn is immediately over. Do not resolve any other symbols or effects on the tile. Otherwise, your turn contintues.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>You may take any action(s) printed on the tile.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Resolve any text that says \"If you end your turn on this tile . . \". If there are multiple \"end of turn\" effects on a tile, you may resolve them in any order you like.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Infrequent Tile Rules</h4>\n\n<h5>Discovering multiple tiles in a turn</h5>\n\n<p>If you are ever forced to discover a new tile due to a game effect, you draw a card and follow any other text on the tile as if you had discovered it the traditional way. This is true even if you already discovered a tile (and drew a card) this turn.</p>\n\n<h5>False Features</h5>\n\n<p>If it's impossible to match up all doorways, you instead create a false feature (perhaps a closet or thicket). You can't move through these false features.</p>\n\n<h5>No more tiles for that region</h5>\n\n<p>If you try to discover a new tile but have run out of tiles for that region, you do not spend a move since you did not enter a new tile. You may continue your turn as if you didn't just try to walk into a closet. Or thicket.</p>\n\n<h5>Don't Seal Off a Region</h5>\n\n<p>You can't place a tile so that it seals off a region, leaving no unconnected doorways. If the only possible placement of a tile would seal off a region, bury it and draw tiles until you find one that leaves a free doorway. In the unlikely event that all the remaining tiles for a region would seal off the region, rearrange the region until there is are least one unconnected doorway.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/decks.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Cards</h3>\n\n<p>Read here <a href=\"cards.php\">all detailed information about cards</a>.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Actions</h3>\n\n<p>Read here <a href=\"actions.php\">all detailed information about actions</a>.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>The Haunt</h2>\n\n<h4>Making A Haunt Roll</h4>\n\n<p>Before the haunt starts, each time you draw an Omen card, you might trigger the haunt.</p>\n\n<p>When you discover an Omen tile and draw an Omen card, most of the time you will make a haunt roll (in campaign mode, there may be another way to trigger the haunt, explained by the Legacy deck). To make a haunt roll, roll dice equal to the number of discovered Omen cards (including the one you just drew, any carried by other players, and any that have been dropped onto tiles). During the campaign, look at the PAUSE card to see what result causes the haunt to start.</p>\n\n<p>The player who starts the haunt is the haunt revealer. After the haunt starts, if you discover a tile with an Omen symbol, you still draw and keep an Omen card, but you don't make a haunt roll.</p>\n\n<h3>Starting The Haunt</h3>\n\n<p>Haunts are usually found in two books: Secrets of Survival (the heroes' book) and the Traitor's Tome (the traitor's book). Some are found only in one book or another (and you will be told when this happens).</p>\n\n<p>Most of the time a haunt has two teams: heroes and a traitor. Both sides read the same haunt number in their books to learn the rules for that haunt. If a haunt's rules and the regular rules conflict, use the rules in the haunt.</p>\n\n<p>If two or more people could be the traitor, draw a random Crest token from tied families to determine the traitor.</p>\n\n<h4>Variable Player Count {3p/4p/5p}</h4>\n\n<p>Most haunts have different target numbers depending on the number of players. For example, you may need to kill more Rats in the five-player game than the three-player game. Whenever you see braces with three numbers, such as {1/5/7}, this tells you the number you need depending on how many players are in the game. In this case, 1 is for the three-player game, 5 is for the four-player game, and 7 is for the five-player game.</p>\n\n<h4>Public Information</h4>\n\n<p>At the start of each haunt (in both books) are two pieces of information that all sides should hear (the heroes and traitor should hear this starting information in the other book).</p>\n\n<p>First, thematic entries tell you the story of what is happening. The last italicized paragraph starts \"I/ We know this/these things to be true:\" followed by one to three statements. These are hints about what the other side is up to. They may be vague, but they are true.</p>\n\n<p><b>Setup:</b> You might have to put tokens on certain tiles, or adjust traits, or find a tile that hasn't been placed yet. If there's nothing for your side to do, this part will say \"None!\" Players should do setup together so everyone can see what is being put into play.</p>\n\n<h4>Splitting Up</h4>\n\n<p>At this point, the groups usually split up. When the haunt starts, one side (heroes or traitor) should take their book and leave the room, far enough away so neither team can hear each other. The traitor usually learns their haunt alone. It's lonely being evil. But often a good time!</p>\n\n<h4>Learning The Haunt</h4>\n\n<p>After splitting up, each side should read how to win, then all the goals needed to win, listed (where possible) in the order you should complete them.</p>\n\n<p>For example, here's how that looks in Haunt 0 in Secrets of Survival. This is an example haunt to show you how haunts are formatted. It contains no spoilers.</p>\n\n<p>You Win When You Banish The Bride.</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>You may Find the Bride's Diary.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>You may Read the Diary to improve your chances of banishing her.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Banish the Bride to bring her final rest.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Next, facts about the haunt are listed: special rules or other important details that your side needs to know, rather than do.</p>\n\n<h4>Resuming Play</h4>\n\n<p>When both sides are ready, all players return to the room and take their turns in the following order.</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p>The hero to the left of the traitor takes the first turn.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Play continues to the left, with the traitor going after all heroes have gone.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>If there is a monster in the haunt, the monster takes a turn after the traitor. (The haunt will tell you where to put the Monster card to remind everyone when the monster takes a turn).</p></li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>In haunts where there is no traitor (or the traitor starts hidden or unknown), the haunt will tell you who goes first.</p>\n\n<p>Other than the time when the heroes and traitor separate to learn the haunts, everyone must converse only where everyone at the table can hear them; they can't leave and have side conversations elsewhere.</p>\n\n<h4>Moving Past Opponents</h4>\n\n<p>After the haunt starts, opponents act as small obstacles. Heroes are opponents to the traitor and monsters, and vice versa.</p>\n\n<h4>Hidden Information</h4>\n\n<p>Other than what is read aloud at the start of the haunt, all information in the other book is private at the start of the haunt. However, if you don't understand how a goal, reaction, or power works, it is better to ask the other side before doing it so that everyone can agree on the rule. Springing surprises is fun, but it is a tiny issue to reveal information early and get agreement from all players.</p>\n\n<p>Also, when you take an action in a box, the other side can ask you to read the entire text. For example, if a side goal had you make a roll to find a piece of a sacred tablet, once you made that roll, the other side could ask you to read the entire side goal box. When the monster first attacks, the other side may ask about its traits, and so on. You don't have to ask about the other side-some people like to be surprised as they play.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>So You're Evil Now</h3>\n\n<p>When you become a traitor, you get a wonderful little benefits package, which is summed up on the Traitor card. Traitors will be instructed to take this card at the start of the haunt as a reminder.</p>\n\n<p>As the traitor, you gain these abilities:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>You ignore Obstacle tokens (heroes still count as obstacles).</p></li>\n\n<li><p>You don't take damage from tile effects.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>When taking an action on a tile, you may use a result of 5 instead of making a trait roll.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>When you discover an Event tile, you may choose not to draw an Event card (and continue moving if you have moves left). If you draw an Event card, you must resolve it as normal.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>You may ignore harmful effects from Ongoing Event cards. If you do so, you do not benefit from any positive effects from those cards.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>You are immune to any negative ghost effects on Event cards.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>The haunt will state any additional things you can and can't do.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/game31.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h4>Hidden Traitor</h4>\n\n<p>Some haunts feature a hidden traitor, whose identity is secret from the other players. The haunt will tell you how the traitor is determined. Haunts with hidden traitors do not appear in the Traitor's Tome. Instead, the goals and abilities of the traitor are described under the haunt in Secrets of Survival, which everyone reads.</p>\n\n<h5>The Traitor</h5>\n\n<p>Gray boxes show up in haunts with a hidden or unknown traitor. This information is public, but only relevant to the traitor.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Monsters</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/game33.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Monsters behave differently than players. They take a turn when play reaches the Monster card. Usually this is after the traitor's turn. In rare cases, the monster still takes a turn even if it's dead. The haunt will note this.</p>\n\n<p><b>Monster Abilities:</b></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>Monsters make a Speed roll at the start of their turn to determine their moves (minimum of 1). This applies to all monsters of the same type.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Monsters don't take damage from tile effects.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Monsters can't discover new tiles.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Monsters may use special movement on cards or tiles (the traitor chooses the result if there is a die roll) unless it would allow them to discover a new tile.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Monsters can't carry or STEAL Items, Omens, or Objects.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Monsters don't take actions (including ATTACK) except for what the haunt says they can take.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>The haunt will state any additional things monsters can and can't do.</p>\n\n<p>Most monsters can't be killed. If a monster would take damage, it is stunned instead. Flip its token over to the stunned side. A stunned monster's entire next turn is spent getting unstunned. The only thing it does is flip its token back to the unstunned side. Skip all text in the monster box for a stunned monster, even mandatory reaction text. Stunned monsters aren't obstacles.</p>\n\n<p>Small Monster tokens are numbered from 1 to 20. Small monsters always take their turns in number order from lowest to highest.</p>\n\n<p>Each monster moves and takes all its actions before the next one goes, unless the haunt says otherwise. (Some act as a swarm, moving all at once and then attacking as a group).</p>\n\n<p>Monsters act as obstacles depending on their size. Small monsters are small obstacles (they cost 1 extra move to leave) and large monsters are large obstacles (2 extra moves to leave).</p>\n\n<p>If a monster is allowed to carry Items, Omens, or Objects and is stunned, it drops anything it carried. The monster can't pick them up again until it starts a turn unstunned.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Dying</h3>\n\n<p>Once the haunt begins, if any of your traits moves to the skull, then you die. Tip over your figure on your tile. DROP all your Items, Omens, and Objects. You are now a corpse.</p>\n\n<p>Even if the traitor dies, as long as the monsters can complete the haunt's goals, the monsters still get their turn (under the traitor's control) and the traitor can still win.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/betrayal-legacy/game21.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>The first side to complete its goals for the haunt wins the game.</p>\n\n<h3>During The Campaign</h3>\n\n<p>There are three steps you will take at the end of a game during the campaign.</p>\n\n<h4>1. Read Chapter Ending</h4>\n\n<p>At the end of the game, haunts will direct you to the chapter ending in the Bleak Journal to read more of the story. Use the entry for the side that won the haunt. For example, haunt 72 might tell you to go to entry 800 if the heroes win or entry 666 if the traitor wins. Make sure you go to the correct entry in the Bleak Journal.</p>\n\n<p>The chapter ending will continue the story and tell you which cards from the Purgatory deck to add or intensify (see page 11). There also may be other effects at the end of a chapter.</p>\n\n<h4>2. Record your Fate</h4>\n\n<p>Write down the fate of your character. This has no game effect and is purely for your narrative amusement. Have fun with it.</p>\n\n<h4>3. Return Cards</h4>\n\n<p>Return any cards that were put into the box back to their respective decks.</p>\n\n<h4>4. Record the history of the house</h4>\n\n<p>The back of the Traitor's Tome has three pages where you may record any interesting moments from this chapter so that the history of your house is never forgotten. This has no game effect.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Joining the campaign</h4>\n\n<p>You do not have to use the same number of families, or even the same families, for each chapter. You could have the blue, green, and red families in one chapter and then the blue, green, yellow, and purple families in another.</p>\n\n<p>If a family has missed MORE than half of the played chapters, give them three random Items after step 7 of setup and have them keep one. Shuffle the other two back into the Item deck.</p>\n\n<p>The player may heirloom this item if it has a slot available, following usual heirloom rules, except this does NOT count toward the once-per-game limit on making heirlooms.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n\n<blockquote class=\"white\">\n\n<h5>What if we can't figure out a rule?</h5>\n\n<p>Betrayal games mix effects on cards, haunts, rules, and tiles to create interesting combinations. We have tried to make it easy to understand how all these different effects might work together.</p>\n\n<p>However, the nature of the game means that you will inevitably find combinations that create uncertainty. In addition, legacy games create higher stakes since some effects are permanent. Here are a few guidelines when faced with uncertainty:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>Rules in haunts trump other rules.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Rules on cards or tiles trump rules in the rulebook.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>If you find a single card, rule, or effect that gives you a wildly powerful moment, that probably isn't its intention.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>If you find a combination of several cards, rules, and effects that give you an advantage, that probably is the intention.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>If an effect seems wildly unfair, that is not the correct interpretation.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Although it is a game of murder, insanity, horror, and other savagery, be mindful of other players' experiences as well. Arguing about rules loopholes isn't horror, it's horrific.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"game-elements.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Betrayal Legacy Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:53:50.699Z"),
            ~~~~~~~~~

        ?   game?: GameUpdateOneRequiredWithoutRulesNestedInput
          }

Just as a composer's creation is brought to life by the performing musicians, a game inventor's creation is brought to life by the players of the game.</p>\n\n<p>When the creation is inspired and the players are talented, a true work of art results.</p>\n\n<p>In creating the seven games in this book I have attempted to add a new visual dimension to the art of games. As each is played, a colorful drawing is formed. Because these drawings are reminiscent in style of the works of different modern masters of abstract art - some well known, others not so well - I have named the games in honor of the artists. â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"games-of-art/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"warage/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Warage Card Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/descent/warage.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div><p>Warage is a turn based strategy card game with gameplay similar to a traditional role-playing game. Each player plays a hero characterized by race and class traits, which will grant the hero specific bonuses, abilities, and skills.</p>\n\n<p>In the 1st Edition, you will find:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><b>4 races:</b> Humans, Elves, Orcs, Angels</li>\n<li><b>3 classes:</b> Warrior, Paladin, Mage</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n\n<p>Warage is based on the clash of two or more heroes: a hero is created by choosing 1 race and 1 class card and can be equipped with weapons, armors, helms, spells and other items and abilites using the cards available in your hero deck. â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"warage/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Card Game</a><a>Fantasy</a><a>Dice Rolling</a><a>Deck / Pool Building</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"spite-and-malice/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Spite &amp; Malice Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/descent/spite-and-malice.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div>\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Components</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>110 Cards</li>\n<li>Instructions</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Object of the Game</h4>\n\n\n\n<p>Be the first player to play all of the cards from your Card Stack.</p>\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Setup</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>Separate the cards into 2 decks and shuffle them separately.</p>\n\n<p>One deck will have the cards with the purple borders, like this.</p>\n\n<table class=\"image-description \"><tbody><tr><td>Bordered card</td></tr></tbody></table>\n\n<p>The other deck will have the cards with no borders, like this.</p>\n\n<table class=\"image-description \"><tbody><tr><td>Non-Bordered card</td></tr></tbody></table>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Set the deck of Non-bordered cards aside for a minute.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Deal 8 cards from the Bordered card deck face- down to form each player's Card Stack. Each player turns the top card of his/her stack faceup, creating an \"UP\" card. â€¦</p>\n</li>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</ul></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"spite-and-malice/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Card Game</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"robot-turtles/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Robot Turtles Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/descent/robot-turtles.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div>\n\n\n<h4>Components</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>Game Board</li>\n<li>4 Robot Turtle Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Jewel Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Bug Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Code Card Decks</li>\n<li>20 Stone Walls</li>\n<li>12 Ice Walls</li>\n<li>4 Crates</li>\n<li>Instructions</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Object of the Game</h4>\n\n<p>At the Start of the Game, the Turtle Mover (grownup) should <b>read these rules out loud!</b> for the turtle masters (kids):</p>\n\n\n\n<p>\"The goal of the game is to get your Robot Turtle to the matching colored Jewel! When you land on the matching Jewel you can pick it up. Everyone who gets their Jewel wins!\"</p>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Game Play</h4>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<p>\"You are the Turtle Master. On your turn, you will decide which way you want your Turtle to turn or move. Select one of your Code Cards and place it in front of you but don't move your Turtle\". â€¦</p>\n</li>\n</ol></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"robot-turtles/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Children's Game</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"floating-market/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Floating Market Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/descent/floating-market.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div>\n<h4>Components</h4>\n\n\n<ul>\n<li>30 Coin Cards</li>\n<li>35 Fruit Cards</li>\n<li>25 Player dice</li>\n<li>15 Customer Tokens</li>\n<li>7 Boat Tiles</li>\n<li>2 Ama dice (2/3 player only)</li>\n<li>2 Board dice</li>\n<li>2 Fixed Tiles</li>\n<li>1 Fruit Stand Tile</li>\n<li>1 Game Board</li>\n<li>1 Start Player Marker</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Story</h4>\n\n<p>Ama is tired. It has been a long day of chasing her grandchildren and she needs a break. Ama has been around for a long time and she has a few tricks up her sleeve. last purchased Railway Link is built.</p>\n\n<p>At the end of that turn, any remaining Bank Loans and debt service are paid off, each player adds the intrinsic value of their Railway Links (the large number printed on each Railway Link card) to their remaining cash and the player with the most money WINS the game. â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a Your troops can push or rout those who would block their way across the narrow battlefield.</p>\n\n<p>Coordinate attacks with your ally to secure victory, but make sure to watch your flanks!</p>\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Components</h4>\n\n\n<ul>\n<li>1 board</li>\n<li>6 white pieces</li>\n<li>6 red pieces</li>\n<li>6 blue pieces</li>\n<li>6 black pieces</li>\n<li>Rulebook</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Object of the Game</h4>\n\n\n\n<p>The object of the game is to move at least 1 of your city's pieces into your victory area, marked in your color on the opposite side of the board. â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"nika/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"isaribi/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Isaribi Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/descent/isaribi.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div><p>About 300 years ago in Edo, Japan, when Tokyo was still a coastal town, and nature was greener, one could catch all kinds of fish from the neighboring waters.</p>\n\n<p>Fishermen built their livelihood on sea bream, mackerel, prawn, and clams. They went out in their boats, fished, and sold their catch. The market flourished.</p>\n\n<p>In this game players take on the roles of fishermen, trying to get rich from the wealth of the sea. Just as a composer's creation is brought to life by the performing musicians, a game inventor's creation is brought to life by the players of the game.</p>\n\n<p>When the creation is inspired and the players are talented, a true work of art results.</p>\n\n<p>In creating the seven games in this book I have attempted to add a new visual dimension to the art of games. As each is played, a colorful drawing is formed. Because these drawings are reminiscent in style of the works of different modern masters of abstract art - some well known, others not so well - I have named the games in honor of the artists. â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"games-of-art/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"warage/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Warage Card Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/imperial-assault/warage.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div><p>Warage is a turn based strategy card game with gameplay similar to a traditional role-playing game. Each player plays a hero characterized by race and class traits, which will grant the hero specific bonuses, abilities, and skills.</p>\n\n<p>In the 1st Edition, you will find:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><b>4 races:</b> Humans, Elves, Orcs, Angels</li>\n<li><b>3 classes:</b> Warrior, Paladin, Mage</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n\n<p>Warage is based on the clash of two or more heroes: a hero is created by choosing 1 race and 1 class card and can be equipped with weapons, armors, helms, spells and other items and abilites using the cards available in your hero deck. â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"warage/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Card Game</a><a>Fantasy</a><a>Dice Rolling</a><a>Deck / Pool Building</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"spite-and-malice/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Spite &amp; Malice Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/imperial-assault/spite-and-malice.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div>\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Components</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>110 Cards</li>\n<li>Instructions</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Object of the Game</h4>\n\n\n\n<p>Be the first player to play all of the cards from your Card Stack.</p>\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Setup</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>Separate the cards into 2 decks and shuffle them separately.</p>\n\n<p>One deck will have the cards with the purple borders, like this.</p>\n\n<table class=\"image-description \"><tbody><tr><td>Bordered card</td></tr></tbody></table>\n\n<p>The other deck will have the cards with no borders, like this.</p>\n\n<table class=\"image-description \"><tbody><tr><td>Non-Bordered card</td></tr></tbody></table>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Set the deck of Non-bordered cards aside for a minute.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Deal 8 cards from the Bordered card deck face- down to form each player's Card Stack. Each player turns the top card of his/her stack faceup, creating an \"UP\" card. â€¦</p>\n</li>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</ul></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"spite-and-malice/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Card Game</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"robot-turtles/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Robot Turtles Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/imperial-assault/robot-turtles.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div>\n\n\n<h4>Components</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>Game Board</li>\n<li>4 Robot Turtle Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Jewel Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Bug Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Code Card Decks</li>\n<li>20 Stone Walls</li>\n<li>12 Ice Walls</li>\n<li>4 Crates</li>\n<li>Instructions</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Object of the Game</h4>\n\n<p>At the Start of the Game, the Turtle Mover (grownup) should <b>read these rules out loud!</b> for the turtle masters (kids):</p>\n\n\n\n<p>\"The goal of the game is to get your Robot Turtle to the matching colored Jewel! When you land on the matching Jewel you can pick it up. Everyone who gets their Jewel wins!\"</p>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Game Play</h4>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<p>\"You are the Turtle Master. On your turn, you will decide which way you want your Turtle to turn or move.
