Invalid `prisma.gameRule.update()` invocation in
E:\King Dice\scripts\scrape-ultrabg-rules.js:296:29

  293 
  294 if (existingRule) {
  295   // Update existing rule
→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 114
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Battlestar Galactica Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/battlestar-galactica/battlestar-galactica.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<h2>Game Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/battlestar-galactica/components.png\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<ul>\n<li>Game Board</li>\n<li>10 Character Sheets</li>\n<li>52 Cardboard Tokens</li>\n<li>110 Large Cards</li>\n<li>128 Small Cards</li>\n<li>1 Eight-sided Die</li>\n<li>32 Plastic Ships</li>\n<li>4 Plastic Connectors</li>\n<li>10 Plastic Character Stands</li>\n<li>Rulebook</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p>Follow these steps to prepare to play Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game.</p>\n\n<ol>\n\n<li><p><b>Place Game Board:</b> Place the game board at the center of the table. Set the food and fuel dials to \"8\", the morale dial to \"10\", and the population dial to \"12\".</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Set Up Tokens and Ships:</b> Place the eight vipers and four raptors in the \"Viper and Raptor Reserves\" space of the game board. Then place the fleet token on the start space of the Jump Preparation track. Last, place all other tokens (facedown) and plastic ships adjacent to the game board.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Determine First Player:</b> Randomly choose a player to be the first player, and give him the current player token. This player will choose his character first and take the first turn of the game.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Choose and Place Characters:</b> Starting with the first player and proceeding clockwise, each player chooses a character of the character type(s) that is most plentiful (political leader, military leader, or pilot). This restriction does not apply to support characters, who may be chosen at any time.</p> <p>After choosing a character, the player receives the corresponding character sheet and stand-up character token, as well as a piloting token if applicable. He then places his character token on the location specified on his character sheet.</p> <p>Example: The first player chooses Laura Roslin (a political leader) as his character. The next player may choose any military leader or pilot (since they are the most plentiful). He could also choose a support character.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Distribute Title Cards:</b> The President title is given to the first available player in the following list: Laura Roslin, Tom Zarek, and Gaius Baltar. The Admiral title is given to the first available player in the following list: William Adama, Saul Tigh, and Helo Agathon. The Admiral is then given the two nuke tokens, and the President shuffles the Quorum deck and draws one Quorum Card.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Set Up Loyalty Deck:</b> Set up the Loyalty deck according to the \"Creating the Loyalty Deck\" sidebar.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Set Up Other Cards:</b> Shuffle the Quorum deck, Crisis deck, Super Crisis deck, and Destination deck and then place them next to the game board. Then separate the Skill Cards into five decks by type, as shown on their faces. Shuffle each deck separately, and then place them (facedown) below the matching colored regions at the bottom of the game board. Lastly, place the Kobol Objective Card faceup next to the Destination deck.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Receive Skills:</b> Each player, except the starting player, draws a total of three Skill Cards from among any of the cards he can draw during his Receive Skills step. The starting player does not receive Skill Cards now, but will draw Skill Cards at the start of his turn.</p></li>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/battlestar-galactica/setup-ships.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<li><p><b>Create Destiny Deck:</b> Deal two Skill Cards of each skill type facedown onto the \"Destiny deck\" space on the game board and shuffle them thoroughly.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Set Up Ships:</b> Place one basestar and three raiders in front of Galactica. Then place two vipers below Galactica and two civilian ships behind Galactica (as shown right).</p>\n\n</li>\n\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>The object of the game for a given player depends on which team he belongs to. A player's team is determined by the Loyalty Cards he receives throughout the game.</p>\n\n<p>All human players win the game if they travel at least eight units of distance (as specified by the Kobol Objective Card) and then jump one final time.</p>\n\n<p>All Cylon players win the game by preventing the humans from reaching their objective. They usually accomplish this goal by running the fleet out of a resource (food, fuel, morale, or population), but can also win by destroying Galactica or successfully invading Galactica with centurion boarding parties.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p><i>Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game</i> is played over a number of game turns. Starting with the first player and proceeding clockwise, players take complete game turns in order until either the human or Cylon players have won the game. Each game turn consists of the following steps, carried out in order:</p>\n\n<ol>\n\n<li><p><b>Receive Skills Step:</b> The current player draws the number and types of Skill Cards listed on his character sheet.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>2. Movement Step:</b> The current player may move to a different location. If he moves to a different ship (from Galactica to Colonial One or vice versa), he must discard one Skill Card from his hand.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Action Step:</b> The current player chooses one action to perform. Options include the actions listed on his location, character sheet, and Skill Cards.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Crisis Step:</b> The top card of the Crisis deck is drawn and then resolved.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Activate Cylon Ships Step</b> (if necessary): If any are in play, Cylon ships are activated according to the Crisis Card drawn.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Prepare for Jump Step</b> (if necessary): If the Crisis Card has the \"prepare for jump\" icon on it, the fleet token advances one space up the Jump Preparation track. If the token reaches the end of this track, then the fleet jumps.</p></li>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p>After the Prepare for Jump step, the current player's turn is over, and he hands the current player token clockwise to the player on his left. This player then begins his turn starting with the Receive Skills step.</p>\n\n<h3>Receive Skills Step</h3>\n\n<p>During this step, the current player draws Skill Cards according to the skill set listed on his character sheet. The player always draws the cards listed on his character sheet regardless of the number of cards already in his hand.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/battlestar-galactica/william-skill-set.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Example: It is William Adama's Receive Skills step. He looks at his skill set, which lists 3 leadership and 2 tactics. He therefore draws three leadership Skill Cards and two tactics cards.</p>\n\n<p>Some character sheets list multi-colored skills known as multi-skills. When a character with a multi-skill receives Skill Cards, he must first decide how many cards he will draw from each type. The total number of cards that he draws must be equal to the number listed on his sheet.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/battlestar-galactica/multi-skill.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Example: It is the start of Lee \"Apollo\" Adama's turn. He therefore draws two piloting and one tactics Skill Cards according to the skill set listed on his character sheet. He may then decide to draw two leadership or two politics Skill Cards - or one of each - since he has a 2 leadership/politics multi-skill.</p>\n\n<h3>Movement Step</h3>\n\n<p>During this step, the current player may move his character token to another location if he wishes. If he moves to a different ship, he must discard one Skill Card from his hand. Human characters may not move to Cylon locations, and revealed Cylons may only move to Cylon locations.</p>\n\n<p>Example: It is Lee \"Apollo\" Adama's movement step, and he wishes to move from \"Command\" (on Galactica) to the \"Press Room\" (on Colonial One). He discards a piloting Skill Card from his hand and moves to the \"Press Room\" location.</p>\n\n<p>If the player's character is piloting a viper, he may move to an adjacent space area during this step, or may discard a Skill Card to move to a location on Galactica or Colonial One and return his viper to the \"Reserves\".</p>\n\n<h3>Action Step</h3>\n\n<p>During this step, the current player chooses one action to perform. The action types are listed below, and are usually identified by the word \"Action:\" followed by an ability.</p>\n\n<ul>\n\n<li><p><b>Activate Location:</b> The player may perform the action listed on his character's current location.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Skill Card Action:</b> The player may play a Skill Card from his hand to perform the action specified on the card. Note that not all Skill Cards have actions on them.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Character Action:</b> The player may perform an action listed on his character sheet. Note that only some character sheets have actions listed on them.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Activate his Viper:</b> If the player is piloting a viper, he may activate it to move or to attack a Cylon ship.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Title and Quorum Cards:</b> If the player has a Title or Quorum Card that provides him with an action, then he may perform it during this step.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Loyalty Card:</b> The character may reveal one of his \"You are a Cylon\" Loyalty Cards to perform the specified action on it. He then follows the rules for revealed Cylon players.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Do Nothing:</b> If the player does not wish to perform any actions, he may decide to do nothing during this step and proceed to the Crisis step.</p></li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Crisis Step</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/battlestar-galactica/cyclonattackcrisis.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>During this step, the current player draws the top card of the Crisis deck, reads it aloud, and then resolves it. There are three types of Crisis Cards: Cylon attacks, skill checks, and events.</p>\n\n<h4>Cylon Attack Crises</h4>\n\n<p>These Crisis Cards feature an image of Galactica and some surrounding ships. When resolving a Cylon attack Crisis Card, simply follow the steps listed on it. Then discard the card unless instructed to keep the card in play.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/battlestar-galactica/skillcheckcrisis.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h4>Skill Check Crises</h4>\n\n<p>These Crisis Cards list a difficulty and one or more skill types, listed as colored boxes, in the upper left corner. These cards are resolved according to the rules for skill checks and have outcomes based on whether the players pass or fail the skill check. Some of these cards give the current player, the President, or the Admiral the choice to either resolve the skill check or carry out some alternate instruction.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/battlestar-galactica/eventcrisis.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h4>Event Crises</h4>\n\n<p>Any Crisis Card that is not a Cylon attack or skill check is an event. These crises have instructions that must be immediately followed. Some of them provide a decision for the current player, the President, or the Admiral.</p>\n\n<h3>Activate Cylon Ships Step</h3>\n\n<p>If there is at least one Cylon ship in play, then the Cylon ships may move or attack based on the icon on the bottom left of the Crisis Card.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/battlestar-galactica/bottomcrisis.jpg\"><br>\n\n<h3>Prepare for Jump Step</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/battlestar-galactica/jumpicon.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If the drawn Crisis Card has the \"prepare for jump\" icon on its lower right corner, then the fleet token moves one space ahead (toward the \"Auto Jump\" space) on the Jump Preparation track.</p>\n\n<p>If this causes the token to move to the \"Auto Jump\" space, then the fleet jumps to a new destination.</p>\n\n<p>After this step, the current player's turn is over. He discards any Crisis Cards drawn this turn, and hands the current player token to the player on his left, who begins his turn (starting with the Receive Skills step).</p>\n\n<h3>Losing Resources</h3>\n\n<p>The four resources (fuel, food, morale, and population) are all vital to the survival of humanity. These resources are usually lost due to Crisis Cards, civilian ships being destroyed, or Galactica damage tokens.</p>\n\n<p>Crisis cards list resource loss as text, for example \"-1 population\", while tokens list resource loss as a number of red icons. For example, one red population icon means the same as \"-1 population\". The list of resource icons is found below as well as on the game board.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/battlestar-galactica/resources.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Whenever a resource is lost for any reason, the appropriate resource dial is adjusted to represent the new total. The red color on the resource wheels tells players when a resource is half (or less) full, and is used by sympathizer Loyalty Cards.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Characters</h2>\n\n<p>Each player takes on the role of a character from the Battlestar Galactica universe. Each character has different strengths and weaknesses as listed on his character sheet.</p>\n\n<p>The following information can be found on each character sheet:</p>\n\n<ul>\n\n<li><p><b>Character Type:</b> Each character has a type listed on his character sheet. This type only matters during setup, and exists to help players choose a well-rounded group of characters.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Character Abilities:</b> Each character has two positive abilities and one negative ability. Some of these abilities are passive (always affecting the character) while others require the player to use them as an action.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Skill Set:</b> Each character sheet lists the skills the character has expertise in. At the start of the player's turn, he gains the number and types of Skill Cards listed in his character's skill set. When a character is allowed to draw Skill Cards of an unspecified type, they must be from within his skill set unless specified otherwise.</p> <p>Example: William Adama is in the \"Research Lab\" and uses the action listed there to draw one tactics or one engineering card. He may choose to draw engineering even though it is outside his skill set, because the location specifies the card type.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Setup:</b> Each character has setup instructions on his card. This usually lists the location where the character is placed at the beginning of the game. Some characters have special instructions (such as \"Apollo\", whose sheet instructs the player to launch a viper and place him in it as a pilot).</p></li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<p>Each character is represented by a stand-up character token, which is used to track his location on the game board. After the character tokens are punched out, each one is attached to a plastic character stand.</p>\n\n<h2>Character Sheets</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/battlestar-galactica/charactersheets.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<ol>\n<li>Name</li>\n<li>Character Type (Political Leader, Military Leader, Pilot, or Support)</li>\n<li>Positive Abilities</li>\n<li>Negative Ability</li>\n<li>Setup Location</li>\n<li>Skill Set</li>\n\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Title Cards</h2>\n\n<p>Title and Quorum Cards provide powerful abilities to the player who controls them. Title Cards are assigned at the beginning of the game, but may change hands through the use of certain locations or because of cetain Crisis Cards. In addition to the abilities listed below, the President and Admiral are given many important decisions to make by Crisis Cards.</p>\n\n<h3>The President and Quorum Cards</h3>\n\n<p>The President starts the game with one Quorum Card in his hand and can draw more using the President Title Card, or \"President's Office\" location. These cards provide special actions that only the President can perform and provide him a wide range of powerful abilities.</p> <p>Whichever player has the President title has control over this hand of Quorum Cards. These cards are kept secret, and there is no limit to the number of cards that may be in the President's hand.</p>\n\n<h3>The Admiral</h3>\n\n<p>The Admiral has two important abilities. First off, he starts the game with two nuke tokens. These tokens can be devastatingly effective against basestars, but are an extremely limited resource.</p>\n\n<p>Second, the Admiral is the player who decides which destination the fleet travels to when jumping (see \"Jumping the Fleet\" on the following page). This decision can be extremely beneficial or harmful to the human players.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Line of Succession</h2>\n\n<p>Should the President or Admiral be revealed as a Cylon, the next player in the line of succession for that title claims it. In addition, if the Admiral (but not the President) is placed in the \"Brig\", then the next player in line claims the Admiral title. If an Admiral stripped of his title later moves out of the \"Brig\", he does not automatically reclaim the title.</p>\n\n<p>The orders of succession are:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/battlestar-galactica/characters.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h4>Admiral</h4>\n\n<ol>\n<li>William Adama</li>\n<li>Saul Tigh</li>\n<li>Helo Agathon</li>\n<li>Lee \"Apollo\" Adama</li>\n<li>Kara \"Starbuck\" Thrace</li>\n<li>Sharon \"Boomer\" Valerii</li>\n<li>Galen Tyrol</li>\n<li>Tom Zarek</li>\n<li>Gaius Baltar</li>\n<li>Laura Roslin</li>\n\n</ol>\n\n<h4>President</h4>\n\n<ol>\n<li>Laura Roslin</li>\n<li>Gaius Baltar</li>\n<li>Tom Zarek</li>\n<li>Lee \"Apollo\" Adama</li>\n<li>William Adama</li>\n<li>Karl \"Helo\" Agathon</li>\n<li>Galen Tyrol</li>\n<li>Sharon \"Boomer\" Valerii</li>\n<li>Saul Tigh</li>\n<li>Kara \"Starbuck\" Thrace</li>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p>Note that if the President is in the \"Brig\", he keeps the President title and all associated abilities.</p>\n\n<h2>Component Limitations</h2>\n\n<p>Whenever a deck of cards runs out, the current player shuffles the appropriate discard pile to form a new deck. This includes Skill Cards, Quorum Cards, Crisis Cards, Super Crisis Cards, and Destination Cards.</p>\n\n<p>Tokens and plastic ships are limited to the quantity provided, and can run out during the game. The current player always decides the order in which a component type is placed, and if there are not enough, he decides which ones are not placed.</p>\n\n<p>Example: A Cylon attack Crisis Card is drawn that requires two basestars to be placed on the game board. There is already one basestar on the game board, so there is only one more that can be placed. The current player decides which of the two basestars listed on the Cylon attack card to place on the game board.</p>\n\n<p>If all vipers are already in play and a player wishes to activate the \"Hangar Deck\" location, he may choose to move a viper from any space area to the \"Reserves\" so that he may pilot it.</p>\n\n<h2>Adjusting Difficulty</h2>\n\n<p>Some play groups may find that it is too easy for the human or Cylon players to win the game. A group may decide before the start of the game to make the game easier for the humans or Cylons.</p>\n\n<p>To make the game easier for the human players, start the game with 2 more of each resource (10 food, 10 fuel, 12 morale, and 14 population).</p>\n\n<p>To make the game easier for the Cylons, start the game with 2 less of each resource.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/battlestar-galactica/box.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h2>End of the game</h2>\n\n<p>The game ends when all human players travel eight units of distance and then jump one file time. The human players won the game in this case, else the Cyclon players won.</p>\n\n<p>When the Galactica gets destroyed or being successfully invaded, then the game is also over and the humans lost the game.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"human-players.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Battlestar Galactica Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:54:41.449Z"),
            ~~~~~~~~~

        ?   game?: GameUpdateOneRequiredWithoutRulesNestedInput
          }

  295   // Update existing rule
→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 115
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Dune Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/dune.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n<ul>\n<li>Game Board</li>\n<li>6 Player Faction Sets</li>\n<li>112 Cards</li>\n<li>156 Spice Tokens</li>\n<li>Destroyed Shield Wall Token</li>\n<li>Storm Marker</li>\n<li>Game Turn Counter</li>\n<li>5 Special Emperor Forces</li>\n<li>3 Special Fremen Forces</li>\n<li>Bene Gesserit forces</li>\n<li>Sandworm Token</li>\n<li>Kwisatz Haderach Card and Counter tokens</li>\n<li>Quick Start Guide</li>\n<li>Quick Reference Cards</li>\n<li>Rulebook</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>DUNE has been divided into a Basic and Advanced Game. Learn and play the Basic Game several times before venturing into the Advanced Game.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h2>Basic Game</h2>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>Each faction has a set of unique economic, military, strategic, or treacherous advantages. The object of the game is to use these advantages to gain control of Dune. The winner is the First Player to occupy at least 3 strongholds with at least one of their forces during the Mentat Pause Phase.</p>\n\n<p>A player may win alone or in an Alliance with other players.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p>Place all spice tokens in the Spice Bank.</p>\n\n<p>The Spice Deck and Treachery Deck are shuffled and placed face down next to the game board. Played cards will be piled face up next to the decks as discards and reshuffled to restock the Spice Deck and Treachery Deck as necessary.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/map.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Players now choose factions.</p>\n\n<p>Here are a couple of ways for players to choose their faction.</p>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<p>Use the faction cards from the Prediction Deck to randomly determine what faction each player will play. Shuffle the cards and deal 1 card to each player, or</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Each player randomly draws a card from the Bene Gesserit turn prediction cards and selects a faction in the order of their drawn card, with the highest card choosing first.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>Players may swap factions with each other at this point if they wish.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h5>Two &amp; Three Player Games</h5>\n\n<p>For a three player game, recommended factions are Atreides, Harkonnen, and Fremen. In a three player game an Alliance needs 4 strongholds to win, as in the standard Alliance rules.</p>\n\n<p>For a two player game, try Atreides vs Harkonnen, or play 2 factions each (select factions normally as described above). In a two player game, the number of strongholds needed to win is increased to 4.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h5>Four &amp; Five Player Games</h5>\n\n<p>For 4 player, consider leaving out both the Spacing Guild and Bene Gesserit, while for 5 player games try playing with no Bene Gesserit.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>Players take their Player Shields and player sheets and set up their factions as follows:</p>\n\n<h5>1. Positions</h5>\n\n<p>Players place their Player Marker on the player circle closest to their shield and seat at the table.</p>\n\n<h5>2. Traitors</h5>\n\n<p>Remove the cards for all factions that are not in play from the Traitor Deck. Then shuffle the cards thoroughly. Each player is dealt 4 cards</p>\n\n<p>Each player then secretly selects 1 card to keep. If a player draws any leaders from an opponent's faction, they can choose 1 leader to become their traitor. If they drew no opponent leaders, they can protect one of their own leaders.</p>\n\n<p>Either way, each player places their chosen card face down behind their shield, returning the other cards face down to the bottom of the Traitor Deck.</p>\n\n<h5>3. Spice</h5>\n\n<p>Spice equal to the amount indicated on each player sheet is removed from the Spice Bank and placed behind each shield.</p>\n\n<h5>4. Forces</h5>\n\n<p>Each player's forces are placed on the board as indicated by their player sheet. All forces in reserve are placed next to your shield.</p>\n\n<h5>5. Treachery</h5>\n\n<p>1 card from the Treachery Deck is dealt to each player.</p>\n\n<h5>6. Turn Marker</h5>\n\n<p>Place the turn marker at 1 on the Turn Track.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> A faction has special advantages that may contradict the rules. A faction's particular advantages always have precedence over the rules.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>DUNE is played in turns to a maximum limit of 10 turns.</p>\n\n<p>Each turn is composed of nine specific phases that must be completed in the exact sequence presented below.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game37.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<h5>1. Storm Phase</h5>\n\n<p>The Storm Marker is moved around the map. The faction whose Player Marker the storm next approaches will be the First Player for this turn.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game38.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<h5>2. Spice Blow and Nexus Phase</h5>\n\n<p>The top card of the Spice Deck is turned over and the amount of spice shown on the card is placed in the highlighted territory. If Shai-Hulud appears during the Spice Blow Phase, a Nexus occurs and the players have the opportunity to make and break Alliances.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game39.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<h5>3. Choam Charity Phase</h5>\n\n<p>Players with 0 or 1 spice may claim CHOAM Charity.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game40.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<h5>4. Bidding Phase</h5>\n\n<p>Players bid spice to acquire Treachery Cards.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game37_.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<h5>5. Revival Phase</h5>\n\n<p>All players are allowed to reclaim forces and leaders from the Tleilaxu Tanks.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game38_.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<h5>6. shipment and Movement phase</h5>\n\n<p>Starting with the First Player and proceeding counterclockwise, each player in turn ships forces down to the planet or brings in forces from the southern hemisphere (Fremen) and then moves their forces on the game board.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game39_.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<h5>7. Battle Phase</h5>\n\n<p>Players must resolve battles in every territory that is occupied by forces from two or more factions.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game40_.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<h5>8. Spice Harvest Phase</h5>\n\n<p>Forces in territories that contain spice may collect the spice.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game36_.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<h5>9. Mentat Pause Phase</h5>\n\n<p>Factions either declare a winner (or winners) or take some time to evaluate their positions on the map and then move the Turn Counter to the next position on the Turn Track to begin the next turn.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game36.jpg\"> Phase 1: Storm</h2>\n\n<h4>First Storm</h4>\n\n<p>The first time the storm is moved, the Storm Marker is placed at a random location along the map edge using the following procedure. The two players whose player circles are nearest on either side of the Storm Start Sector will secretly dial a number from 0 to 20 on the wheels.</p>\n\n<p>The two numbers are simultaneously revealed, totaled and the Storm Marker moved from the Storm Start sector counterclockwise around the map for the sum total of sectors.</p>\n\n<h4>Storm Movement</h4>\n\n<p>In all subsequent Storm Phases, the two players who last used the Battle Wheels will independently dial a number from 1 to 3, simultaneously reveal their numbers, add them together, and then advance the Storm Marker from its current position counterclockwise around the map for the sum total of sectors.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game31.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h4>Damage</h4>\n\n<p>Any forces in a sector of sand territory (except the Imperial Basin) over which the storm passes or stops are killed. Place these forces in the Tleilaxu Tanks. Forces that are not on a sand territory find protection from the storm. In addition any spice in a sector over which a storm passes or stops is removed to the Spice Bank.</p>\n\n<h4>Obstruction</h4>\n\n<p>Forces may not move into, out of, or through a sector in storm. Forces may not battle if either force is in storm.</p>\n\n<h4>First Player</h4>\n\n<p>The player whose Player Marker the storm next approaches is the First Player in the Bidding Phase, Shipping Phase, and Movement Phase.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game43.jpg\"> Phase 2: Spice Blow and Nexus</h2>\n\n<h4>Top Card</h4>\n\n<p>The top card of the Spice Deck is turned over.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h5>First Turn</h5>\n\n<p>During the first turns Spice Blow Phase only, all sandworm cards turned over are ignored and set aside, then reshuffled back into the Spice Deck after this phase.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<table class=\"image-description floatr\"><tbody><tr><td><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game41.jpg\"><br>Territory Card</td></tr></tbody></table><br>\n\n<h4>Territory</h4>\n\n<p>This is a Spice Blow. The amount of spice indicated on the card is taken from the Spice Bank and placed onto the territory in the sector containing the Spice Blow icon.</p>\n\n<p>Then this card is placed face up on the Spice Deck discard pile. (If the Spice Blow icon is currently in storm, no spice is placed that turn).</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Shai-hulud</h4>\n\n<table class=\"image-description floatr\"><tbody><tr><td><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game42.jpg\"><br>Shai-Hulud Card</td></tr></tbody></table><br>\n\n<p>A Nexus will occur after the following events:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>All spice and forces in the territory shown on the card now face up in the discard pile are removed to the Spice Bank and Tleilaxu Tanks respectively. Then the Shai-Hulud card is placed face up on the Spice Deck discard pile.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Then another card is turned over. If it is a Shai-Hulud it is immediately discarded and another card is turned over. This continues until a Territory Card appears and spice is placed as defined above. The Territory Card is placed face up on the Spice Deck discard pile.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h4>Nexus</h4>\n\n<p>Revealing a Shai-Hulud card after the first turn also causes a Nexus at the end of the phase. In a Nexus, Alliances can be formed and broken.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game46_.jpg\"> Phase 3: Choam Charity</h2>\n\n<p>Any player with 0 or 1 spice can collect spice to bring their total to 2 by calling out \"CHOAM Charity\".</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game44.jpg\"> Phase 4: Bidding</h2>\n\n<h4>Declaration</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game72.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Before bidding starts, all players must declare how many Treachery Cards they hold. The hand limit is 4. Players with 4 cards must pass during bidding.</p>\n\n<h4>Dealer</h4>\n\n<p>One of the players deals cards from the Treachery Deck face down in a row, 1 card for each player who is allowed to bid.</p>\n\n<h4>Auction</h4>\n\n<p>The first card in the row is now auctioned off for spice.</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>The bidding is started by the First Player. If that player already has 4 Treachery Cards the next player to the right who does not have 4 Treachery Cards opens the bidding.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>The player who bids first must bid 1 or more spice or pass. Bidding then proceeds to the bidder's immediate right. The next bidder may raise the bid or pass and so on around the table until a top bid is made and all other players pass. The top bidding player then pays the number of spice they bid into the Spice Bank and takes the card.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h4>Bid Limit</h4>\n\n<p>Players may not bid more spice than they have.</p>\n\n<h4>Next Starting Bidder</h4>\n\n<p>In subsequent bidding during this phase, the First Player who can bid, to the right of the player who opened the bid for the previous card, begins the bidding for the next card. In this way every player who can bid gets a chance to open the bidding for a Treachery Card.</p>\n\n<h4>End Of Bidding</h4>\n\n<p>Bidding for Treachery Cards continues until all cards available for bid have been auctioned off or a card is not bid on by anyone. If a card is passed on by everyone, all remaining cards are returned to the top of the Treachery Deck and the Bidding Phase is over.</p>\n\n<h4>Transparency</h4>\n\n<p>The number (not the type) of Treachery Cards each player holds must always be open to everyone during the Bidding Phase. No one is allowed to hide the number of cards that they hold. A player can never have more than 4 cards in their hand at any one time. If they have a full hand, they must pass on all cards up for bid.</p>\n\n<h4>Time Limit</h4>\n\n<p>Each player must bid within 10 seconds of the previous player or they are assumed to have passed.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game46.jpg\"> Phase 5: Revival</h2>\n\n<h3>A. Force Revival</h3>\n\n<p>All players may now revive up to 3 forces from the Tleilaxu Tanks.</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><b>Free:</b> A certain number of forces are revived for free as stated on the player sheet.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>By Spice:</b> Any additional forces that may be revived must be done at a cost of 2 spice per force. All spice expended for force revival is placed in the Spice Bank.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Limit:</b> A player can never revive more than 3 forces per turn.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>To Reserves:</b> Revived forces must be placed in the player's reserve.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>B. Leader Revival</h3>\n\n<p>If all 5 of a player's leaders are in the Tleilaxu Tanks they may revive 1 leader per turn until all of their leaders have been revived.</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><b>Fighting Strength:</b> To revive a leader, a player must pay that leader's fighting strength in spice to the Spice Bank.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Revived Leader Status:</b> A revived leader can be played normally and is still subject to being a traitor.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Dead Again:</b> If a revived leader is killed again, place it face down in the Tleilaxu Tanks. This leader cannot be revived again until all of the player's other revivable leaders have been revived, killed, and sent to the Tleilaxu Tanks again.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game45.jpg\"> Phase 6: Shipment and Movement</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/shipment.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The First Player conducts their Force Shipment and then Force Movement. Play then proceeds to the right until all players have completed this phase.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Force Shipment</h3>\n\n<h4>Shipment of Reserves</h4>\n\n<p>A player with off-planet reserves may make one shipment of any number of forces from their reserves to any one territory on the map.</p>\n\n<h4>Payment</h4>\n\n<p>A player must pay spice to the Spice Bank for their shipment. The cost of shipping off-planet reserves is 1 spice per force shipped into any stronghold and 2 spice per force shipped into any other territory.</p>\n\n<h4>Sectors</h4>\n\n<p>When shipping into a territory lying in several sectors, a player must make clear in which sector of the territory they choose to leave their forces.</p>\n\n<h4>Exceptions</h4>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><b>Storm:</b> No player may ship into a sector in storm.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Strongholds:</b> No player may ship into a stronghold already occupied by two other players.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>One Way:</b> No player may ship forces from the board back to their reserves.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Force Movement</h3>\n\n<p>Each player may move, as a group, any number of their forces from one territory into one other territory. Forces are free to move into, out of, or through any territory occupied by any number of forces with certain restrictions and additional movement advantage mentioned below.</p>\n\n<h4>Ornithopters</h4>\n\n<p>A player who starts a force move with one or more forces in either Arrakeen, Carthag, or both has access to ornithopters and may move forces through up to three adjacent territories.</p>\n\n<p>The forces moved do not have to be in Arrakeen or Carthag to make the three territory move. Thus, for example, a player with one or more forces in Arrakeen would be able to move forces starting in Tuek's Sietch through Pasty Mesa and Shield Wall to the Imperial Basin, where they must stop.</p>\n\n<h4>One Adjacent Territory</h4>\n\n<p>A player without a force in either Arrakeen or Carthag at the start of their move does not have access to ornithopters and can only move their forces by foot to one adjacent territory.</p>\n\n<h4>One Force Move</h4>\n\n<p>Each player may make only one force move per turn.</p>\n\n<h4>Sectors</h4>\n\n<p>Sectors have no effect on movement. Forces can move into or through a territory ignoring all sectors. A sector's only function is to regulate the movement and coverage of the storm and spice collection.</p>\n\n<h4>Storm</h4>\n\n<p>As defined above in the Storm Phase section, no force may move into, out of, or through a sector in storm. Many territories occupy several sectors, so that a player may move into and out of a territory that is partly in the storm, so long as the group does not pass through the part covered by the storm.</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>When ending a move in a territory lying in several sectors, a player must make clear in which sector of the territory they choose to leave their forces.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>The Polar Sink is never in storm.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h4>Stronghold Blocking</h4>\n\n<p>Like shipment, forces cannot be moved into or through a stronghold if forces of two other players are already there.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game44_.jpg\"> Phase 7: Battles</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/battle.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h3>I. Battle Determination</h3>\n\n<p>Wherever two or more players' forces occupy the same territory, battles must occur between those players.</p>\n\n<p>Battles continue until just one player's forces or no forces remain in all territories on the map with two exceptions:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>Players cannot battle one another in a territory if their forces are separated by a sector in storm. Their forces can remain in the same territory at the end of the phase.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Players cannot battle in the Polar Sink. It is a free haven for everyone.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h4>First Player</h4>\n\n<p>When resolving battles, the First Player is named the aggressor until all of their battles, if any, have been fought. The aggressor chooses the order in which they wish to fight their battles. Then the player to their immediate right becomes the aggressor and so on, until all battles are resolved.</p>\n\n<p>If three or more players are in the same territory, the aggressor picks who they will battle first, second, etc. for as long as they survive.</p>\n\n<table class=\"image-description\"><tbody><tr><td><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/troops.jpg\"><br>Troop Tokens</td></tr></tbody></table><br>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>II. Battle Plan</h3>\n\n<p>To resolve a battle, each player must secretly formulate a Battle Plan. A Battle Plan always includes the number of forces dialed on the Battle Wheel. If possible, it must include a faction's leader or cheap hero. It may include Treachery Cards at the player's discretion.</p>\n\n<h4>Battle Wheel</h4>\n\n<p>Each player picks up a Battle Wheel and secretly dials a number from zero to the number of forces they have in the disputed territory. Both players will lose the number of forces dialed on the Battle Wheel.</p>\n\n<h4>Leaders</h4>\n\n<p>One Leader Disc is selected and placed face up in the slot on the wheel. A Cheap Hero Card may be played in lieu of a Leader Disc.</p>\n\n<table class=\"image-description\"><tbody><tr><td><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/leaders.jpg\"><br>Leader Tokens</td></tr></tbody></table><br>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>Leaders that survive battles may fight more than once in a single territory if needed, but no leader may fight in more than one territory during the same phase.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>A player must always play either a leader or a cheap hero card as part of their Battle Plan if possible.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>If it is not possible, they must announce that fact.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h5>No Treachery</h5>\n\n<p>A player with no leader or cheap hero must still battle, but they cannot play any Treachery Cards as part of their Battle Plan. (This situation can occur when a player does not have a cheap hero and all their leaders are in the Tleilaxu Tanks or have fought in another territory in that phase).</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>When a player plays a cheap hero, their total is simply the number of tokens on the dial, but the option to play weapon, defense, or worthless cards is still available to them.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game47.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h4>Treachery Cards</h4>\n\n<p>Players with a leader or cheap hero may play a Weapon Treachery Card, Defense Treachery Card, or both by holding them against the wheel. They may play no Treachery Cards as well.</p>\n\n<h4>Revealing Wheels</h4>\n\n<p>When both players are ready, the Battle Plans are revealed simultaneously.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>III. Battle Resolution</h3>\n\n<h4>Winner</h4>\n\n<p>The winner is the player with the higher total of number dialed on the Battle Wheel, plus their leader's fighting strength.</p>\n\n<h4>No Ties</h4>\n\n<p>In the case of a tie, the aggressor has won.</p>\n\n<h4>Weapons</h4>\n\n<p>If a player's opponent played a Weapon Treachery Card and the player did not play the proper Defense Treachery Card, the player's leader is killed and cannot count toward their total. Both leaders can be killed and neither count in the battle. When a player plays a cheap hero, their total is simply the number of forces they dial, but they can play weapons or other Treachery Cards.</p>\n\n<h4>Killed Leaders</h4>\n\n<p>Any leaders killed are immediately placed face up in the Tleilaxu Tanks. The winner immediately receives their value (including their own leader, if killed) in spice from the Spice Bank.</p>\n\n<h4>Surviving Leaders</h4>\n\n<p>Leaders who survive remain in the territory where they were used until all battles in other territories have been resolved. Then they are retrieved by their owners.</p>\n\n<h4>Losing</h4>\n\n<p>The losing player loses all the forces they had in the territory to the Tleilaxu Tanks and must discard every Treachery Card they used in their Battle Plan. Note that the loser does not lose their leader as a result of battle. Leaders are killed only by Weapon Treachery Cards.</p>\n\n<h4>Winning</h4>\n\n<p>The winning player loses only the number of forces they dialed on the Battle Wheel. These forces are placed in the Tleilaxu Tanks. The winning player may also keep or discard any of the cards they played.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h3>Traitors</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/traitor.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If you are in a battle and your opponent uses a leader that matches a Treachery Card you control, you may call out \"Treachery!\" and pause the game.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<p><b>The Traitor Card is revealed.</b></p>\n\n<p>The player who revealed the traitor card:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>immediately wins the battle</li>\n<li>loses nothing, regardless of what was played in the Battle Plans (even if a lasgun and shield are revealed)</li>\n<li>places the traitorous leader in the Tleilaxu Tanks and receives the traitorous leader's fighting strength in spice from the Spice Bank.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<p>The Player Whose Traitor Was Revealed:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>loses all of their forces in the territory</li>\n<li>discards all of the cards they played</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n\n<p><b>Two Traitors</b></p>\n\n<p>If both leaders are traitors, each a traitor for the opponent, both players' forces in the territory, their cards played, and their leaders, are lost. Neither player gets any spice.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n<h2><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game45_.jpg\"> Phase 8: Spice Collection</h2>\n\n<p>Any player with forces in a sector of a territory in which there is spice may now collect that spice. This is done by taking the spice tokens you are entitled to from the territory and placing them behind your shield.</p>\n\n<p>The collection rate is 3 spice per force if the player occupies Carthag or Arrakeen. It is 2 spice per force if the player does not occupy Carthag or Arrakeen.</p>\n\n<p>Uncollected spice remains where it is for future turns.</p>\n\n<table class=\"image-description\"><tbody><tr><td><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/spice.jpg\"><br>Spice Tokens</td></tr></tbody></table><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/game43_.jpg\"> Phase 9: Mentat Pause Phase</h2>\n\n<p>If one player occupies 3 strongholds with at least one of their forces during the Mentat Pause Phase, that <b>player wins the game</b>.</p>\n\n<p>If the required number of strongholds is 4 and the two players in an Alliance separately occupy a total of at least 4 strongholds with one or more forces at the end of a turn, that <b>Alliance wins the game</b>.</p>\n\n<p>For example, if the Atreides are in an Alliance with the Fremen, and the Fremen occupy Sietch Tabr and Carthag and the Atreides occupy Tuek's Sietch and Arrakeen during the Mentat Pause Phase, they win the game together.</p>\n\n<p>If there are no winners, players mull over their positions on the board, consider their options and, when they are ready, move the turn marker to the next position on the Turn Track to begin the next turn.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Alliances (Nexus)</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/dune/alliance.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Once a Shai-Hulud (sandworm) card is turned over on the second or subsequent turns, at the end of the Spice Blow and NEXUS Phase, a Nexus occurs. During a Nexus, all players have a chance to make, join or break Alliances. Once players have had a chance to do so, play continues.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Forming an Alliance</h3>\n\n<h5>Basics</h5>\n\n<p>No more than two players may be in an Alliance and the win condition is now 4 instead of 3 strongholds.</p>\n\n<h5>Discussion</h5>\n\n<p>Players may discuss among themselves the advantages and disadvantages of allying, and with whom.</p>\n\n<h5>Transparency</h5>\n\n<p>The members of the Alliance must be revealed to all. Alliances cannot be secret. Swap Alliance Cards as a reminder of who are in an Alliance.</p>\n\n<h5>Limits</h5>\n\n<p>Several Alliances can be formed during a Nexus, but no player can be a member of more than one Alliance. Once all players have had a chance to ally, no further Alliances can be made until the next Nexus.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Breaking an Alliance</h3>\n\n<h5>Breaking</h5>\n\n<p>Any player may break an Alliance during a Nexus. Players just announce that they are breaking from an Alliance.</p>\n\n<h5>Joining Another</h5>\n\n<p>Players who break from an Alliance have an opportunity to immediately join or form a new Alliance.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>How an alliance functions</h3>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Winning</h5>\n\n<p>Allied players' forces are considered the same for the purposes of victory. If together their joint forces hold 4 strongholds in the Mentat Pause Phase, they have jointly won the game.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Constraint</h5>\n\n<p>Allies may not enter any territory (except the Polar Sink) in which one of their allies already has a force and, thus, may never battle one another.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> If for any reason two factions who became allies during the last turn occupy the same territory at the beginning of the next turn, one of those factions must move out of that territory during the Shipment and Movement Phase.</p>\n\n<p>If the first faction to ship and move does not move out of the territory, the second faction must move out or lose those forces to the Tleilaxu Tanks.</p>\n\n<p>}..</p>\n\n<h5>Ally Secrecy</h5>\n\n<p>Allies may discuss and share strategy and information secretly at any time.</p>\n</blockquote></li>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Bidding</h5>\n\n<p>During the Bidding Phase, allies may help each other by paying some or all of the cost of each other's Treachery Cards so that a player can bid more spice than they actually have.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Movement</h5>\n\n<p>During the Movement Phase, allies may pay for each other's shipments.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h5>Shared Advantages</h5>\n\n<p>Allies may assist one another as specified on their player sheets.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Secrecy</h2>\n\n<p>Players are never required to keep their cards, spice holdings, or the traitors they selected secret. They are never obligated to reveal this information either.</p>\n\n<p>All spice holdings should be kept behind the Player Shield. The number of Treachery Cards held must be kept open during the Bidding Phase, but can be kept secret at all other times.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Bribery</h2>\n\n<p>Players who are not members of the same Alliance can make any kind of verbal deals or bribes between one another. Once made, these deals and bribes must be stated aloud and must be honored. A player cannot renege on a deal or bribe. Spice can be part of the bribe or deal.</p>\n\n<p>A deal or bribe cannot involve the transfer or gift of Treachery Cards, leaders, forces, or faction advantages. This leaves secret information, future actions, and, of course, spice.</p>\n\n<p>A player cannot make a deal or bribe that would contravene the rules or the player's faction powers. These are the only limitations.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"game-elements.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Dune Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:54:48.633Z"),
            ~~~~~~~~~

        ?   game?: GameUpdateOneRequiredWithoutRulesNestedInput
          }
        })

E:\King Dice\scripts\scrape-ultrabg-rules.js:296:29

  293 
  294 if (existingRule) {
  295   // Update existing rule
→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 118
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Avalon Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/avalon/avalon.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/avalon/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n<ul>\n<li>14 Character cards</li>\n<li>10 Quest cards</li>\n<li>5 Team tokens</li>\n<li>20 Vote tokens</li>\n<li>5 Score markers</li>\n<li>1 Round marker</li>\n<li>1 Vote Track marker</li>\n<li>1 Leader token</li>\n<li>3 Score tableaus</li>\n<li>2 Loyalty cards</li>\n<li>1 Lady of the Lake token</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<div class=\"box yellow2_border gold_bg\">\n\n<p>The Resistance: Avalon is the game of hidden loyalty. Players are either Loyal Servants of Arther fighting for Goodness and honor or aligned with the Evil ways of Mordred.</p>\n\n<p>Good wins the game by successfully completing three Quests. Evil wins if three Quests end in failure. Evil can also win by assassinating Merlin at game's end or if a Quest cannot be undertaken.</p>\n\n<p>Players may make any claims during the game, at any point in the game. Discussion, deception, accusation, and logical deducation are all equally important in order for Good to prevail or Evil to rule the day.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n<h2>The Cards and Tokens</h2>\n\n<p><b>Character Cards </b>- Determine the player's loyalty. Character cards on the side of Good have Arthur's sigil on blue background and Evil have Mordred's sigil on red background.</p>\n\n<p>Hereafter references to a player's Good or Evil loyalty are denoted with a special front.</p>\n\n<p>Some characters have special powers during the game - Merlin and the Assasin are included in all games and the remaining special character cards are optional.</p>\n\n<p>A player's character card may not be revealed at any point in the game, nor the character art discussed.</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><b>Leader Token </b>- Designates the player that will propose the Quest Team.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Team Tokens </b>- Allocate positions on the Quest Team.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Vote Tokens </b>- Approve or reject the Leader's proposed Quest Team.</p></li>\n\n<li><p><b>Quest Cards </b>- Determine a Quest's success or failure.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p>Select the tableau corresponding to the number of players. Place the tableau in the center of the play area with the Score Markers, Team tokens, and Quest cards adjacent to the tableau.</p>\n\n<p>Place the Round markers on the tableau's 1st Quest space. Given each player a set of two vote tokens.</p>\n\n<p>Randomly select a Leader; the Leader receives the leader token. Use the chart below to determine the number of Good and Evil players.</p>\n\n<table class=\"table\">\n\n<thead>\n\n<tr><th>Players</th><th>5</th><th>6</th><th>7</th><th>8</th><th>9</th><th>10</th></tr>\n\n</thead>\n\n<tbody>\n\n<tr><td>Good</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>6</td></tr>\n\n<tr><td>Evil</td><td>2</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>3</td><td>3</td><td>4</td></tr>\n\n</tbody>\n\n</table><br><br>\n\n<p>Suffle the appropriate number of Good character cards and Evil character cards. One of the Good character cards will be the Merlin card, all the others will be just \"loyal servant of Arthur's cards).</p>\n\n<p>One of the evil character cards will be the Assassin card, all the others will be just \"minion of Mordred\" cards. Deal one card to each player face down.</p>\n\n<p>Each player secretly looks at their assigned loyalty on their character card.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Evil reveals itself and merlin looks into the future</h4>\n\n<p>True Evil is rampant in the land. Arthur represents the future of Britain, a promise of prosperity and honor, yet hidden among his brave warriors are Mordred's unscrupulous miniona.</p>\n\n<p>The forces of Evil are few in number but have knowledge of each other and remain hidden from all but one of Arthur's servants. Merlin alone knows the agents of Evil, but he must speak of his only in riddles.If his true identity is discovered all will be lost.</p>\n\n<p>After all the players know their loyalty, the leader must ensure that all the Evil players know each other and that Merlin knows all the Evil players by repeating the following script:</p>\n\n<div class=\"box yellow3_bg\">\n<ol>\n<li>Everyone close your eyes and extend your hand info a fist in front of you.</li>\n<li>Minions of Mordred open your eyes and look around so that you know all agents of Evil.</li>\n<li>Minions of Mordred close your eyes.</li>\n<li>All players should have their eyes closed and hands in a fist in front of them.</li>\n<li>Minions of Mordred - extend your thumb so that Merlin will know of you.</li>\n<li>Merlin, open your eyes and see the agents of evil.</li>\n<li>Minions of Mordred - put your thumbs down and re-form your hands into a fist</li>\n<li>Merlin, close your eyes.</li>\n<li>All players have their eyes closed and hands in a fist in front of them</li>\n<li>Everyone open your eyes.</li>\n</ol>\n\n</div>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Tutorial Video</h2>\n\n<iframe width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"//www.youtube.com/embed/WgA4GAWoQ3U?rel=0\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe>\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>The game consists of several rounds; each round has a team building phase and a Quest phase.</p>\n\n<p>In the team building phase the leader proposes a team to complete a Quest - all the players will either approve the proposed team and move to the quest phase, or reject the proposed team passing leadership to the next player and repeating the process until a team is approved.</p>\n\n<p>In the Quest phase those players selected to be on the team will determine if the Quest is succesfull.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Team Building Phase</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/avalon/quests.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>It is a time for great decisions and strong leaders. Not all knights and ladies of Avalon are loyal to Arthur, and yet you must choose only those that are Good to represent him in his quests.</p>\n\n<p>If an open ear and eye is kept, Merlin's sage advice can be discerned as whispers of truth.</p>\n\n<p>Team Assignment: After appropriate discussion, the leader takes the required number of Team tokens and assigns each team token to any player.</p>\n\n<table class=\"table\">\n\n<thead>\n\n<tr><th>Players</th><th>5</th><th>6</th><th>7</th><th>8</th><th>9</th><th>10</th></tr>\n\n</thead>\n\n<tbody>\n\n<tr><td>1st Quest</td><td>2</td><td>2</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>3</td><td>3</td></tr>\n\n<tr><td>2nd Quest</td><td>3</td><td>3</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>4</td><td>4</td></tr>\n\n<tr><td>3rd Quest</td><td>2</td><td>4</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>4</td><td>4</td></tr>\n\n<tr><td>4th Quest</td><td>3</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>5</td><td>5</td></tr>\n\n<tr><td>5th Quest</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>5</td><td>5</td></tr>\n\n</tbody>\n\n</table>\n\n<br>\n\n<p>The leader can be on the team, but is not required to be so. Note a player may only be assigned one team token.</p>\n\n<p>Discus, Discus, Discus. All the players should participate in helping the leader make the right choice of players to be on the team. Active and logical discusion is a great way to catch Mordred's agents in their webs of deceit.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Team Vote</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/avalon/team.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>after appropriate discussion, the leader calsl for a vote on the team assignments.</p>\n\n<p>The leader is proposing the team - but all the players have a vote in wheter they accept or reject the proposal. The leader can be evil, or one of the players chosen could be a mistake.</p>\n\n<p>Don't feel that you need to accept all the proposed teams. If you reject the team then a new leader can propose a different team, maybe one without any evil players on it.</p>\n\n<p>Each player, including the leader, secretly selects one vote card. When all players have their selected vote card ready, the leader asks for the votes to be revealed. All vote tokens are flipped over so everyone can see how you voted.</p>\n\n<p>The team is approved if the majority accepts. If the team is approved, play continues in the quest phase.</p>\n\n<p>If the team is rejected (a tied vote is also rejection), the leader passes clockwise and the team building phase is repeated.</p>\n\n<p>Evil wins the game if five teams are rejected in a single round.</p>\n\n<div class=\"infobox\"><div class=\"info-icon\"><i></i></div><div class=\"infobox-body\">\n\n<p><b>Strategy tips: trust no one</b></p>\n\n</div></div>\n\n<br>\n\n<p>If you aren't confident of every one on the proposed team, then you should strongly consider rejecting the proposal. Rejecting a team is not a sign that you are evil.</p>\n\n<p>A group of skilled players will usually do the vote phase three of more times before agreeing to a team. Watch who approves, and ask them why they approved - sometimes Evil players will approve because they know another evil player was included.</p>\n\n<p>Merlin can also use his voting as a signal, but be careful the evil players will be watching.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Quest Phase</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/avalon/mission.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>You have debated well and wisely chosen the brave knights and ladies with whom you place your trust.</p>\n\n<p>Now, it is time to measure a person's true intent and loyalty to the noble cause for which Arthur fights. Be true and goodness will prevail.</p>\n\n<p>The leader passes a set of Quest cards to each team member. Each player on the quest selects a quest card and plays it face down in from of themselves.</p>\n\n<p>The leader collects and shuffles the played quest cards before revealing. The quest is completed successfully only if all the cards revealed are success cards. The quest fails if one fail cards have been played.</p>\n\n<div class=\" notepad\">\n\n<h4>Notes:</h4>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>The good players must select the quest success card. Evil may select either the quest success or quest fail card.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>The 4th quest (and only the 4th quest) in games of 7 or more players require at least two Quest failed cards to be failed Quest.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>It's suggested that two different players shuffle the played and discarded quest cards before revealing.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>it's best to designate a player not on the team to collect all the discarded Quest cards so that it's clear which cards are played and which are discarded. Shuffle the discarded quest cards.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n</div>\n\n<p>Indicate a successful quest on the tableau by placing a blue score marker with arthur's sigil. A failed quest is shown by placing a red score marker with Mordred's sigil on the tableau.</p>\n\n<p>After the quest has been completed, advance the round marker to the next quest space on the tableau. The leader passes clockwise and the next round begins in the team building phase.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<div class=\"box yellow2_border gold_bg\">\n\n<p>Arthur and Goodness prevail if the team of Good is able to successfully complete three quests without revealing Merlin's true identity.</p>\n\n<p>Mordred's dark forces of Evil win when three quests end in failure or are devious enough to force Merlin into the open.</p>\n\n<p>The game ends immediately after either 3 succesful or three failed quests. The evil players win if 3 quests fail and when 5 teams are rejected in a single round.</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"box tucked_corner\">\n\n<h3>Assassinate Merlin - Evil's Last Chance</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/avalon/merlin.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/avalon/assassin.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If 3 quests are completed succesfully, the evil players will have a final opportunity to win the game by correctly naming which of the good players is Merlin.</p>\n\n<p>Without revealing any character cards, the evil players discuss and the player with the assasin character card will name one good player as Merlin.</p>\n\n<p>If the named player is Merlin, then Evil players win. If the evil players do not name Merlin, then the Good players win.</p>\n\n<p>Four additional characters with special powers are available to play. You can play with these cards in any combination that you would like.</p>\n\n<p>Different combinations will make the game harder to win for one the side of the battle or the other. It's best to add one special character card into a game at a time, adding more or changing when you are familiar with how they play. In most cases, you will want to play with Merlin, but it's not required.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Optional Character Cards</h3>\n\n<p>Click here for more <a href=\"optional-character-cards.php\">information about Percival, Mordred, Oberon and Morgana.</a></p>\n\n</div>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"optional-character-cards.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Avalon Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:55:29.044Z"),

The goal is to score the most points by fighting against and/or running from the Dragon that you just woke.</p>\n\n<p>But beware, your fellow adventurers may hinder (or aid) you in your strategy and the final scoring of treasure cards, gold coins, and bonus points will vary depending on which of 3 ways the games end, so watch your step! â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"dragon-rampage/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Area Control</a><a>Dice</a><a>Dice Rolling</a><a>Fantasy</a><a>Card Drafting</a><a>Game Rules</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"games-of-art/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Games of Art Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/werewolf/games-of-art.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div><p>Games mean many things to many people; to me they are an art form of great potential beauty. Just as a composer's creation is brought to life by the performing musicians, a game inventor's creation is brought to life by the players of the game.</p>\n\n<p>When the creation is inspired and the players are talented, a true work of art results.</p>\n\n<p>In creating the seven games in this book I have attempted to add a new visual dimension to the art of games. As each is played, a colorful drawing is formed. Because these drawings are reminiscent in style of the works of different modern masters of abstract art - some well known, others not so well - I have named the games in honor of the artists. â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"games-of-art/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"warage/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Warage Card Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/werewolf/warage.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div><p>Warage is a turn based strategy card game with gameplay similar to a traditional role-playing game. Each player plays a hero characterized by race and class traits, which will grant the hero specific bonuses, abilities, and skills.</p>\n\n<p>In the 1st Edition, you will find:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><b>4 races:</b> Humans, Elves, Orcs, Angels</li>\n<li><b>3 classes:</b> Warrior, Paladin, Mage</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n\n<p>Warage is based on the clash of two or more heroes: a hero is created by choosing 1 race and 1 class card and can be equipped with weapons, armors, helms, spells and other items and abilites using the cards available in your hero deck. â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"warage/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Card Game</a><a>Fantasy</a><a>Dice Rolling</a><a>Deck / Pool Building</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"spite-and-malice/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Spite &amp; Malice Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/werewolf/spite-and-malice.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div>\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Components</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>110 Cards</li>\n<li>Instructions</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Object of the Game</h4>\n\n\n\n<p>Be the first player to play all of the cards from your Card Stack.</p>\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Setup</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>Separate the cards into 2 decks and shuffle them separately.</p>\n\n<p>One deck will have the cards with the purple borders, like this.</p>\n\n<table class=\"image-description \"><tbody><tr><td>Bordered card</td></tr></tbody></table>\n\n<p>The other deck will have the cards with no borders, like this.</p>\n\n<table class=\"image-description \"><tbody><tr><td>Non-Bordered card</td></tr></tbody></table>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Set the deck of Non-bordered cards aside for a minute.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>Deal 8 cards from the Bordered card deck face- down to form each player's Card Stack. Each player turns the top card of his/her stack faceup, creating an \"UP\" card. â€¦</p>\n</li>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</ul></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"spite-and-malice/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Card Game</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"robot-turtles/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Robot Turtles Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/werewolf/robot-turtles.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div>\n\n\n<h4>Components</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>Game Board</li>\n<li>4 Robot Turtle Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Jewel Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Bug Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Code Card Decks</li>\n<li>20 Stone Walls</li>\n<li>12 Ice Walls</li>\n<li>4 Crates</li>\n<li>Instructions</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Object of the Game</h4>\n\n<p>At the Start of the Game, the Turtle Mover (grownup) should <b>read these rules out loud!</b> for the turtle masters (kids):</p>\n\n\n\n<p>\"The goal of the game is to get your Robot Turtle to the matching colored Jewel! When you land on the matching Jewel you can pick it up. Everyone who gets their Jewel wins!\"</p>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Game Play</h4>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<p>\"You are the Turtle Master. On your turn, you will decide which way you want your Turtle to turn or move. Select one of your Code Cards and place it in front of you but don't move your Turtle\". â€¦</p>\n</li>\n</ol></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"robot-turtles/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Children's Game</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"floating-market/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Floating Market Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/werewolf/floating-market.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div>\n<h4>Components</h4>\n\n\n<ul>\n<li>30 Coin Cards</li>\n<li>35 Fruit Cards</li>\n<li>25 Player dice</li>\n<li>15 Customer Tokens</li>\n<li>7 Boat Tiles</li>\n<li>2 Ama dice (2/3 player only)</li>\n<li>2 Board dice</li>\n<li>2 Fixed Tiles</li>\n<li>1 Fruit Stand Tile</li>\n<li>1 Game Board</li>\n<li>1 Start Player Marker</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Story</h4>\n\n<p>Ama is tired. It has been a long day of chasing her grandchildren and she needs a break. Ama has been around for a long time and she has a few tricks up her sleeve. With the promise of her famous fruit salad, Ama sends her grandchildren down to the Damnoen Saduak Floating Market to collect fruit... and to get out of her hair! â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"floating-market/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Dice</a><a>Dice Rolling</a><a>Worker Placement</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"new-england-railways/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>New England Railways Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/werewolf/new-england-railways.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div>\n<h4>Components</h4>\n\n\n<ul>\n<li>72 Player Locomotives</li>\n<li>46 Commodity cubes</li>\n<li>1 Gameboard</li>\n<li>1 Railway Link deck</li>\n<li>1 Commodity Growth deck</li>\n<li>Game Money</li>\n<li>Bank Loans (red)</li>\n<li>1 First Player card</li>\n<li>2 Dice</li>\n<li>Instructions</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Object of the Game</h4>\n\n\n\n<p>The game ENDS when the last purchased Railway Link is built.</p>\n\n<p>At the end of that turn, any remaining Bank Loans and debt service are paid off, each player adds the intrinsic value of their Railway Links (the large number printed on each Railway Link card) to their remaining cash and the player with the most money WINS the game. â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"new-england-railways/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Auction/Bidding</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"nika/game-rules.php\"><div src=\"scraped_rules/images/werewolf/nika.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div><p>You command a Greek city's hoplite soldiers who must force their way through enemy lines. Your troops can push or rout those who would block their way across the narrow battlefield.</p>\n\n<p>Coordinate attacks with your ally to secure victory, but make sure to watch your flanks!</p>\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Components</h4>\n\n\n<ul>\n<li>1 board</li>\n<li>6 white pieces</li>\n<li>6 red pieces</li>\n<li>6 blue pieces</li>\n<li>6 black pieces</li>\n<li>Rulebook</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Object of the Game</h4>\n\n\n\n<p>The object of the game is to move at least 1 of your city's pieces into your victory area, marked in your color on the opposite side of the board. â€¦</p></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"nika/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"isaribi/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Isaribi Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/werewolf/isaribi.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div><p>About 300 years ago in Edo, Japan, when Tokyo was still a coastal town, and nature was greener, one could catch all kinds of fish from the neighboring waters.</p>\n\n<p>Fishermen built their livelihood on sea bream, mackerel, prawn, and clams. They went out in their boats, fished, and sold their catch. The market flourished.</p>\n\n<p>In this game players take on the roles of fishermen, trying to get rich from the wealth of the sea.
