→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 126
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Steam Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/steam.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<p>Join the select ranks of industrial adventurers who call themselves rail barons. Buy long ribbons of land, rich and poor, laying rails to riches. Challenge your rivals as you civilize the wilds in a quest to connect people and spur the growth of cities.</p>\n\n<p>By carving new trade routes and unleashing increasingly powerful locomotives, you can bring humanity to the heavens. Using clever investment-and plenty of steel and steam- you can bring goods to far away markets... and track the winning way to wealth.</p>\n\n<p>Steam includes both a refined \"Base Game\" and a more detailed \"Standard Game\". If you're a new player or want a shorter game, start with the former. Read on. Soon you'll be ready to start laying track!</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>1 Two-sided Game Board</li>\n<li>96 Goods Cubes (20 each of red, blue, yellow &amp; purple; 16 gray)</li>\n<li>144 Player Tokens (24 each of orange, green, natural, white, brown, black)</li>\n<li>136 Railway Track Tiles</li>\n<li>8 New City Tiles (1 red, 1 yellow, 1 purple, 1 blue, 4 gray)</li>\n<li>68 Money Tokens (1s in copper, 5s in silver, 10s in gold)</li>\n<li>7 Action Tiles (standard game side shown)</li>\n<li>10 City Growth Markers</li>\n<li>Goods Bag</li>\n<li>Turn Marker</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Overview</h2>\n\n<p>Steam is a game about building railroads and delivering goods along the network of tracks. You build the tracks and improve your locomotive to make the longest, most profitable deliveries possible. Moving goods around the map scores points that add to your income or victory points.</p>\n\n<p>Central to the game is a map, depicting the terrain, towns and cities in a region at the start of the railway age. The map of southeastern Canada and the north- eastern USA is ideal for 3 or 4 players. The map of Europe's lower Rhine and Ruhr region is more suitable for 4 or 5 players. We include pieces for 6 players, so you can play on larger expansion maps.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>The maps are divided into hexagonal spaces (called \"hexes\"). Each hex shows either plains terrain (print- ed green), hills or mountains (printed brown), coast (green &amp; blue), or a city (a named and colored hex). Occasionally the hex contains a river (a blue line) or a town (town symbol).</p>\n\n<p>During the game, players build railroads by placing hexagonal track tiles (track) onto the map, connecting towns and cities in the process. Each section of track that connects a city to a city (see A in the diagram to the right), town to a city (see B's), or town to a town (see C) is called a \"link\".</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game1.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game2.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> Mountains and hills, though very different in real life, are the same (and called \"hills\") in Steam. The art and the game rules are identical for both!</p>\n\n<p>Each city starts with a supply of Goods cubes. They represent the establishment of long-term delivery contracts. Goods cubes are delivered along the \"links\" of a railway, either to increase income or score victory points.</p>\n\n<p>Each Goods cube can only be delivered to a city of the same color. As a result of player actions, each city printed on the map may receive extra Goods cubes once during the game.</p>\n\n<p>Gray cities do not appear on the printed maps; these only come into play via New City tiles.</p>\n\n<p>In addition to cities, each town on the map repre- sents an area that you can link to other towns and cities. A town does not supply or receive cubes. A town can expand (urbanize) to become a \"new city\", providing its own goods and delivery opportunities.</p>\n\n<p>A New City tile can replace a town tile already on the board, or it can be placed directly on a hex containing a town. Each new city opens up new opportunities for the railways and supplies extra Goods cubes.</p>\n\n<p>Although you may earn money at the end of each turn, it is often necessary to raise additional capital to pay for track and locomotive upgrades. You can raise additional short-term money by reducing your income level.</p>\n\n<p>There is a score track around the edge of the game board. Use it to record your current Victory Point (VP) score. You win by having the most Victory Points at the end of the game.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Base Game</h2>\n\n<p>The rules in this section) describe the Base Game, which we recommend for newer players or for shorter games.</p>\n\n<h3>Initial Set Up</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game4.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Place all the Goods cubes in the bag. Randomly draw cubes from the bag, placing as many on each city as the number printed on the city hex. If you are using the Europe (Ruhr) map and there are only three players, place one cube fewer on each city.</p>\n\n<p>Place three randomly drawn cubes on each Goods Supply space. If there are only three players in the game, place one cube fewer on each Goods Supply space (applies to both maps).</p>\n\n<p>Place the City Growth markers next to the map. Place the New City tiles next to the map. Each player chooses a set of tokens of one color.</p>\n\n<p>Place one of your tokens on the \"0\" space of the Income track, and another of your tokens on the \"0\" space of the Victory Point Track. You start with no income. In the Base Game, you may start with cash based on the initial turn order.</p>\n\n<p>Place one of your tokens on the \"1\" Locomotive box, marking your starting Locomotive Level. The Locomotive Level represents each railway's investment in rolling stock and engines. When you increase your Locomotive Level, it increases the number of links that a Goods cube can be moved along when you make a delivery.</p>\n\n<p>Appoint one player to be the banker and place the Money token supply near him. Place the turn marker on the \"1\" space of the Game Turn Track.</p>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> If you want to use a scenario map, just place it on top of the map on the board. Then you can still use the other sections of the board.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game5.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Money</h2>\n\n<p>In Steam, players must raise money from the bank to spend on building track, upgrading their locomotives and meeting other costs. You give up income as you receive money from the bank. This represents the shares of company stock, payments, and favors that you have to grant in order to attract such investment.</p>\n\n<p>You receive money from the bank each time that you need to raise money. For every $5 that you receive, your token is moved one space down the Income Track.</p>\n\n<p>If you are already at -$ 10 income and you still need to raise money, you must then reduce your Victory Point (VP) total by 2 for every $5 that you raise. If you are at -$10 and zero VPs, you cannot raise any more money from the bank.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game6.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>You can raise money from the bank any time you have insufficient cash to pay for an item or action. You must spend any cash on hand first, before raising money in this way. You may not take more than the minimum that you need in order to cover any costs.</p>\n\n<p>If the amount you raise is more than you need, you receive cash from the bank for the difference (up to a maximum of $4). You are not allowed to raise extra money-only the money that you need to cover immediate payments.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Turn Order</h2>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h3>Turn Order for Your First Game</h3>\n\n<p>Your position in the turn order is very important in Steam, but during your first game it is hard to know how much turn order position is worth. Accordingly, for your first game, we suggest that you determine the order of play randomly. Put the Action tiles in the bag and draw one for each player. The player who receives the lowest numbered tile goes first.</p>\n\n<p>The order of play will then go clockwise around the table. Mark the order of play using player tokens on the \"Turn Order Display;\" then return the Action tiles to the table. Before the first turn of the game, give $1 to the player going second, $2 to the player going third, and so on (only if using this system).</p>\n\n<p>The turn order in later turns will be determined by the Action tiles that you choose.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>At the start of the game, you determine the initial turn order by auction. If you win an auction, you must raise money to pay for your bid (see below).</p>\n\n<p>Auction the first player position first. Randomly determine a player to start bidding for turn order position (e.g., by using the Action tiles). Then proceed clockwise around the table.</p>\n\n<p>On your turn to bid, you may either increase the amount bid by the preceding player or pass. Once you have passed, you are out of the bidding for that player position. You cannot re-enter the auction until the next player position is put up for auction.</p>\n\n<p>When all other players have passed, you pay for your winning bid by moving your token down one space on the Income Track for every $5 that you need (receiving any change from the bank). Then place your token on the \"1\" space on the Turn Order Dis- play. Once you have won an auction, you may not bid in any of the remaining auctions.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game65.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>The second player position is then auctioned, with bidding, starting with the player to the left of (clockwise from) the player who won the preceding auction.</p>\n\n<p>Continue conducting auctions for turn order until each player has placed a token on the Turn Order Display. There is no auction for last place; the remaining player takes the last spot for free. No starting money is distributed to the players when using auctions to determine turn order.</p>\n\n<p>You determine turn order for all subsequent turns based on the Action tiles you choose. You have to decide how important each action is to your plans, and how that will affect you in the turn order for the following turn.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<h3>Supply &amp; Demand</h3>\n\n<p>Goods cubes and the cities on the map share the same colors. Gray cities come onto the map later using the Urbanization action.</p>\n\n<p>Each city starts the game with a supply of goods (which are placed during setup) that represent commodities available for shipment to other cities. Extra cubes can be added to the map by using the City Growth action.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game2.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Each city demands only goods that match the color of the city. When you deliver a Goods cube along your railway links to a city that accepts that color of cube, you score track points. You must decide whether you wish to add those points to your income level or to your victory point score.</p>\n\n<p><b>Important:</b> If you receive track points from a delivery, you must take either all of the points from the delivery as income, or all of the track points as VPs. You cannot split track points from one delivery between your income and VP tracks!</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>You play Steam in a series of turns. Each turn encompasses 6 distinct phases. Complete each phase before moving on to the next phase. The game ends after phase 4 of the final turn. There are 7 turns in a five- or six-player game, 8 turns in a four-player game, and 10 turns in a three-player game.</p>\n\n<h3>The Six Phases</h3>\n<ol>\n<li>Select Action Tiles</li>\n<li>Build Track</li>\n<li>Move Goods (or Improve Locomotive) (2 rounds)</li>\n<li>Collect Income &amp; Pay Expenses</li>\n<li>Determine Turn Order</li>\n<li>Set Up New Turn</li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Phase 1 - Select Action Tiles</h2>\n\n<p>Each turn, in your turn order, you select one Action tile. The Action tiles provide a special action or advantage that is unique in that turn, and have a value that will determine turn order for the next turn. The possible actions are:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<h4>Turn Order</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game8_.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>You will be in first place in the turn order for the next turn.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h4>First Move</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game8.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>You will be the first player to move a Goods cube in each round of the Move Goods phase this turn, irrespective of your turn order position.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h4>Engineer</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game9.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>You may build up to four track tiles during the Build Track phase instead of the usual three track tiles. You must pay the usual costs for all track built in this turn.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h4>First Build</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game10.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>You will be the first player to build track during the Build Track phase, irrespective of your position in the turn order.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h4>City Growth</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game11.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>During the Build Track phase, you select one set of Goods cubes from one Goods Supply space and add them to any city on the map. You must also place a City Growth marker onto the same city along with the Goods cubes.</p>\n\n<p>You cannot add cubes to a city if there is already a City Growth marker on the city (for example, any city created through Urbanization cannot have a City Growth action applied to it as it will already have a City Growth marker). Add goods to the map during your Build Track phase.</p>\n\n<p><i>You pay $2 when you select this action-this com- mits you to performing the action during your Build Track phase. You may instead pass.</i></p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game12.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>City Growth has a \"Pass Option\". This means that you may select it and then decide not to carry out the action (i.e., you \"pass\"). You must decide whether to perform City Growth or to exercise your Pass Option immediately upon taking the tile.</p>\n\n<p>If you take the Pass Option, flip your Action tile over (to its plain side) and do not pay the $2 cost. You do not carry out the action on the tile if you have chosen to pass.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h4>Locomotive</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game13.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Immediately increase your Locomotive Level by one, moving your token to the next Locomotive box.</p>\n\n<p><i>You must pay the bank the $4 as shown on this tile, plus an amount equal to the Locomotive Level to which you are moving.</i></p>\n\n<p>The maximum Locomotive Level is 6. If you already have a level 6 locomotive, you cannot select this Action tile.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h4>Urbanization</h4>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game15.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>During the Build Track phase, you convert a town into a city by placing a New City tile onto any hex containing a town. If the hex containing a town already has track built on it, first remove the track tile from the map and add it back to the track supply.</p>\n\n<p>You cannot select this Action tile if all of the towns have already been converted into cities, or if there are no New City tiles available.</p>\n\n<p><i>You pay $6 when you select this action-this commits you to performing the action during your Build Track phase. Since Urbanization has a Pass Option, you may instead pass.</i></p>\n\n<p>Add the New City tile to the board when you build track. You can place the tile any time during your part of the Building Track phase. The New City tile does not count as one of your 3 track tiles that you may build each turn (see example below).</p>\n\n<p>Once the New City tile is on the board, select a set of cubes from any one of the Goods Supply places. Place these cubes onto the just-built New City tile. Note that each New City tile has a City Growth marker printed on it; hence a New City tile cannot have more cubes added to it later in the game.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Phase 2 - Build Track</h2>\n\n<p>You build track to connect cities and towns in order to deliver Goods cubes during the game. Track that starts at one city or town and finishes at a different city or town is called a \"link\". Your railway network need not be built entirely of contiguous connecting links (but this is often a successful strategy).</p>\n\n<p>You mark your ownership of a link with one of your tokens anywhere along the link. When you start building a link, it is easiest to put the token at the far (unconnected) end of the incomplete link. When your track reaches a city or town, that link is complete. Track used to make a link can be built over several turns.</p>\n\n<p>In turn order, you build track using the tiles that are available. If you chose the First Build Action tile, you carry out your track building before the player in the first position on the Turn Order Display.</p>\n\n<p>The first tile of track that you build in the game must touch a city hex, so that the track emerges from the city. Mark any track starting a new link with a player token <s class=\"tokenlabel\">B</s>. As you build more track, you must either extend the track that you have already built <s class=\"tokenlabel\">A</s> (placing the next piece of track connected to the previous one) or start a new link from any city on the board (but not a town) <s class=\"tokenlabel\">B</s>.</p>\n\n<p>When you build track, the tiles must line up so that the ends match and the track forms a continuous line (until it reaches another town or a city). All of the track that you build during the game must connect back to a city along track that you own. You are not allowed to build track that extends another player's track.</p>\n\n<p>You may build up to 3 track tiles in a single turn unless you took the Engineer Action tile (which allows you to build up to 4 pieces of track in the turn).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game17.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h3>Other Track Building Limitations</h3>\n\n\n\n<p>You build track by placing track tiles onto the non- city hexes on the map. You cannot place track on non-hex spaces <s class=\"tokenlabel\">G</s>, nor on top of cities <s class=\"tokenlabel\">H</s>.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game18.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>The map has hexes bordered or partially bordered by thick black lines. You cannot place track that crosses or runs into a hex side with a thick black line (D, F), or that runs into the edge of the board.</p>\n\n<p>Track never branches or forms any sort of junction except at a town or city (there are no \"Y\" track pieces). Track may not be placed that both starts and finishes in the same town or city <s class=\"tokenlabel\">C</s>. Players may build a series of links that together form a loop (and you may find it profitable to do so)!</p>\n\n<p>You are never required to build track. However, if you took the Urbanization or City Growth Action tiles and did not \"pass\", you must carry out those actions during your Build Track phase, whether or not you build any track. You can only build track using the track tiles that are available. You cannot play a particular track tile if there are none of that configuration left in the supply.</p>\n\n<h3>Paying For Initial Tracks</h3>\n\n<p>Each track tile built in an empty hex has a cost based on the terrain crossed and the complexity of the track. You pay for your track as you build it.</p>\n\n<p>The cost of placing a track tile on a hex is:</p>\n\n<p><b>Base cost:</b> It costs $1 for each edge of the tile where track exits the tile.</p>\n\n<p><b>Additional costs:</b></p>\n<ul>\n<li>+$1 if there is a town on the hex (see below)</li>\n<li>+$1 if there is a river on the hex (see below)</li>\n<li>+$2 if the tile is placed on a hills hex (see below)</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> The base cost for the most common track (straights and gentle curves) is $2, while the base cost increases to $3 or $4 for more complex tiles. See the Tile Manifest on page 16.</p>\n\n<p>You must pay the cost of the track you build during your building phase, even if you are improving an existing tile as part of your building. However, you do not have to pay terrain costs when you improve or redirect a piece of track.</p>\n\n<h3>Terrain</h3>\n\n<p>The following rules detail the effects of various features detailed on the map:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game23.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h4>Hills (&amp; Mountains) Hex</h4>\n\n<p>A hills hex is covered entirely with the brown hills &amp; mountains art. Each hills hex has a white border completely surrounding it.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game24.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h4>City Hex</h4>\n\n<p>A city hex is either a fully colored city printed on the board, or a hex containing a New City tile placed through Urbanization.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game26_.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h4>Plains (&amp; Coast) Hex</h4>\n\n<p>Any hex that is not a hills hex or a city hex is considered to be a plains hex for building purposes.</p>\n\n<p>Note that coast hexes, despite some being primarily water, are treated the same as plains tiles (you are assumed to be building along the coast). Non-river, coastal water is outlined in white.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game26.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Coastal water is impassable-see Lake Ontario, the New England coast and the inlet southeast of Providence on the New York map.</p>\n\n<p>Impassable water has a heavy black line along certain hex sides. Track may not run into or cross a hex side marked by such a heavy black line.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game28.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h4>Rivers</h4>\n\n<p>A river is depicted on the map by blue with dark edges-this category also includes (purple-edged) canals and smaller lakes. A hex contains a river if it has part or parts of one or more rivers in them.</p>\n\n<h3>Towns</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game22.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>A hex contains a town if it has a glowing town symbol.</p>\n\n<p>Certain track tiles, town track tiles, bear a different, corresponding town track symbol. You can only place a town track tile on a hex that contains a town. You cannot place any other track tile (i.e., non town track tile) on a hex that contains a town.</p>\n\n<p>However, you can use Urbanization to place a New City tile on a hex that contains a town.</p>\n\n<h3>Town Track Tiles</h3>\n\n<p>Some town track tiles have only one piece of track leading to the town; other town track tiles may have several pieces. If you build track on a hex containing a town, you can choose which town track tile to use.</p>\n\n<p>You will own any pieces of track leading from the town unless they are already connected to another player's track (although some ownership might be temporary-see \"Incomplete Links\" below).</p>\n\n<p>You must pay for all track printed on a town track you place. You lose ownership of any incomplete links if they are not extended on your next turn.</p>\n\n<h3>Urbanization</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game25.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If you took the Urbanization Action tile (and did not use the Pass Option), you must place a New City tile with new Goods cubes on the map during your turn to build track. City hexes are considered to have track running to the edge of every side of the hex.</p>\n\n<p>So placing a New City tile may complete one or more links (even links belonging to other players). Placing a New City tile does not count as one of your three hexes of track building.</p>\n\n<h3>City Growth</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game27.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If you took the City Growth Action tile (and not the Pass Option), you must place new Goods cubes and a City Growth marker onto a city hex on the map during your</p>\n\n<p>turn to build track. You cannot place new cubes on a city already containing a City Growth marker (e.g., you can never place new cubes on a New City tile).</p>\n\n<p>If you run out of Goods cubes during the game, do not refill the display. You only place cubes on the board and the display at the start of the game. Never draw extra cubes from the bag during the game.</p>\n\n<h3>Incomplete Links</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game29.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If any track fails to reach either a town or city by the end of your turn, it is an \"incomplete link\". An incomplete link consists of one or more track tiles that do not connect to a town or city at each end.</p>\n\n<p>An incomplete link is still marked with your token, and other players may not extend it while you own it. However, you lose ownership of the incomplete link if you do not extend it on your very next turn.</p>\n\n<p>If you do not extend the track in the next turn, you must remove your token from the track. It then becomes an unowned, incomplete link.</p>\n\n<h3>Unowned Track</h3>\n\n<p>When you place a track tile or a New City tile that extends or completes an unowned, incomplete link, you \"claim\" the link and mark your ownership with one of your tokens. You can only claim an unowned, incomplete link if it either starts at a city or it directly connects to one of your own links.</p>\n\n<p>If you claim an incomplete link and it remains incomplete, you must extend it or complete it on your next turn or you lose ownership of it.</p>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> You cannot lose or relinquish control of your completed links (unless you are eliminated).</p>\n\n<h3>Redirecting Track</h3>\n\n<p>You may \"redirect\" (change) the last track tile placed in an incomplete link so that its track exits in a different direction. You can only redirect an unowned, incomplete link if it either starts at a city or it directly connects to one of your own links.</p>\n\n<p>You cannot redirect track on another player's link. Completed links cannot be altered or redirected. You may either rotate the last track tile of an incomplete link, or remove the tile and replace it with a different tile.</p>\n\n<p>Whether you rotate the track or replace it, you must pay the non-terrain tile costs again-the town and track costs, but not the hills and river costs. The new tile-and its track-must still comply with all of the usual track building rules (for example, you cannot redirect a tile so that it runs off the edge of the board).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game30.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Redirecting a track tile counts as one of your three pieces of track that can be built in a given turn. Redirecting track does not count as extending track for the purposes of maintaining or claiming ownership of incomplete links. However, you can claim such an unowned, incomplete link if redirecting it completes the link.</p>\n\n<p>Track on a hex containing a town cannot be redirected, but it is possible to improve the town track tile by changing it to one with more tracks leading from the town.</p>\n\n<h3>Improving Existing Track</h3>\n\n<p>Sometimes you will want to build new track over or through either your own or another player's track. This is done by replacing the track that has already been built with one of the complex crossing or passing tiles or a town track tile with more tracks leading from the town.</p>\n\n<p>You must preserve the existing track in the hex-you can add new track to a hex but you are not allowed to change or take away existing track (unless redirecting track, as detailed in the rules above).</p>\n\n<p>There is a cost of \"improving\" track in this way. You must pay for all of the track shown on the new track tile that you place on the board, not just the new track added by the crossing, passing, or exits from the town. You must also pay the extra $1 if there is a town symbol on the tile. However, you do not pay any cost associated with the terrain printed on the board (i.e., hills and rivers).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game32.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>When building, you may only use the track tiles available. If you cannot find a tile with the track configuration that you need, you cannot build that track. Improved track counts as one of your three track builds for the turn.</p>\n\n<p>You may choose to build one of the complex crossing or passing tiles on an empty hex. If you do this, all the usual building rules and terrain costs apply.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Phase 3 - Move Goods (or Improve Locomotive)</h2>\n\n<p>Each turn, in your turn order, you must choose and perform one of the following activities:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>improve your locomotive,</li>\n<li>move a Goods cube, or</li>\n<li>pass (and do nothing).</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Once each player has performed one of these activities, each player (in turn order) once again chooses and performs one of these activities. If you improved your locomotive with your first activity, you may not choose it as your second activity in the same turn.</p>\n\n<p>If you took the First Move Action tile, choose and perform your activity before anyone else in each cycle.</p>\n\n<h3>Improving Your Locomotive</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game34.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>You start the game with a level 1 locomotive. This allows you to deliver a Goods cube along a route with a maximum length of one link. During the game you may improve your locomotive, both by taking the Locomotive Action tile or by using one of your activities during the Move Goods phase.</p>\n\n<p>You can use a level 2 locomotive to deliver a Goods cube along a route of up to two links; a level 3 locomotive can travel up to three links, and so on.</p>\n\n<p>You may only choose to improve your locomotive level once per turn during the Move Goods phase. This improvement costs nothing and scores no victory points. With your other Move Goods activity, you must either move a Goods cube or pass. You get nothing for passing.</p>\n\n<h3>Moving a Goods Cube</h3>\n\n<p>As one of your activities during the Move Goods phase, you may move one Goods cube from one city to another city-you deliver it. You can only move a Goods cube along completed track links (yours and your opponents; see below). The maximum number of links moved along must be less than or equal to your locomotive's level.</p>\n\n<p>You can only move a Goods cube if its final destination is a city of the same color as the cube. You cannot move a Goods cube so that it finishes its journey in a town or a city of a color different from the Goods cube.</p>\n\n<p>The cube is delivered as soon as it reaches the first city on its journey that is the same color as the cube. You are not allowed to move such a cube any further. You cannot return the cube to the city where it started, and you cannot move it into or through the same city more than once on its journey.</p>\n\n<p>When you deliver a Goods cube, you must move it along at least one of your links. You can use opponents' links to deliver cubes, but you must use your own links at least as much as you use any other player's links. You cannot deliver the cube if it only travels along links that belong to other players.</p>\n\n<p>Remove delivered Goods cubes from the game and place them back in the Goods Bag.</p>\n\n<h3>Track Points</h3>\n\n<p>When you deliver a Goods cube, you score 1 track point for each completed link of your track that the cube was moved along. Each opponent whose track you used also gets 1 track point per link of his that you used.</p>\n\n<p>Each scoring player must immediately decide whether to use his track points to increase his income or to increase his victory points. You cannot split your points gained from a single cube movement between income and victory points. (See example at right).</p>\n\n<p>If two or more players receive points from the same delivery, the player moving the Goods cube chooses whether to take his points as income or victory points first, and then the rest choose in turn order.</p>\n\n<p>If your victory point total exceeds 50, place one of your tokens in the +50 box. Use your other VP token to track your points over 50. Use the +100 box in the rare case you acquire more than 100 victory points.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game35.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Phase 4 - Collect Income &amp; Pay Expenses</h2>\n\n<p>In player order, each player collects income or pays all expenses.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/steam/game37.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Check where your token is on the Income Track. If the figure is positive, you receive this amount from the bank. If the figure is negative, you must pay this money to the bank (a situation that is very likely to happen at the beginning of the game).</p>\n\n<p>If you do not have the cash necessary to pay your debt, you will have to raise more money from the bank and move further down the Income Track (or VP track if you are already at -$ 10). You pay according to where your token is at the start of the phase.</p>\n\n<p>In the unlikely event that your token is at -$10 on the Income Track, and you cannot afford to make a required payment, then you must raise the necessary money by reducing your VP total by 2 for each $5 required. If you do not have sufficient VPs to meet your costs, you are bankrupt!</p>\n\n<p>Your tokens are removed from the board and you are out of the game. Any completed links that you owned remain unowned for the duration of the game (no one may claim them).</p>\n\n<p>Remaining players may claim any incomplete links that you owned in the usual manner. If a Goods cube is moved along an unowned link, no victory points or income are scored for that link.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Phase 5 - Determine Turn Order</h2>\n\n<p>Adjust the players' tokens on the Turn Order Display according to the actions selected at the start of the turn. The order of play goes from lowest value action to highest value action. Mark the new turn order on the Turn Order Display.</p>\n\n<p>If a player selected an action but then chose to pass, the value of the action still determines his position in the order of play.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Phase 6 - Set Up New Turn</h2>\n\n<p>The players return all of the Action tiles to beside the board. Move the turn marker forward one space on the Game Turn Track and a new turn is started (unless you have reached the end of the game).</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>If you are playing with 3 players, the game finishes after 10 turns. A four-player game lasts 8 turns, and with five players the game lasts 7 turns. On the final turn, skip phases 5 and 6.</p>\n\n<h4>Calculating Victory Points</h4>\n\n<p>First, increase your VPs by one point for every two points of income that you have at the end of the game, rounding down if necessary (e.g., if you had an income of $5 then you would receive 2 VPs).</p>\n\n<p>If you have negative income, reduce your VPs by twice that amount (e.g., if you had an income of -$2 then you would lose 4 VPs). You receive no VPs (or penalty) for zero income.</p>\n\n<p>Next, remove all of the player tokens on incomplete link segments. Then you score 1 point for every com- pleted link that you own at the end of the game. Add these to your VP score on the VP Track. You do not score any points for incomplete links.</p>\n\n<p>If you have the <b>most Victory Points, you win</b>.</p>\n\n<p>In the case of a tie, the tied player with the highest income level wins. If there is still a tie, then the player who took the lowest numbered Action tile in the final turn wins. Only one player can win.</p>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> Nick earned 37points during the game for deliveries. His Income Track token was on -1 at the end of the game, and he had 10 completed links on the board. His final score is: 37-2 + 10 = 45 Victory Points.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"standard-game.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Steam Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:59:03.944Z"),
            ~~~~~~~~~

→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 127
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Acquire Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/acquire/acquire.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/acquire/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h2>Game Components</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Plastic gameboard</li>\n<li>7 plastic buildings</li>\n<li>108 corportate tiles</li>\n<li>7 set of stock certificates</li>\n<li>stock market tray</li>\n<li>6 information cards</li>\n<li>paper money</li>\n\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p>The first time you play, remove the game parts from the plastic bags. Discard the bags. Carefully punch out the information cards. Then, set up the following each time you play:</p>\n\n<ol>\n\n<li><p>Put the gameboard on the playing surface and cluster the gray tiles facedown near it.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Choose a player to be the stock market banker. The banker sets up the stock market tray.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>The banker gives each player an information card and $6,000 (four $1,000 bills, three $500 bills and five $100 bills). The rest of the money is separated by denomination and placed into four separate piles.</p></li>\n\n</ol>\n\n<h5>Determine who goes first</h5>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/acquire/board.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Each player draws a tile from the facedown cluster and puts it faceup on the matching letter/number space on the gameboard. The player who plays a tile closest to 1A goes first.</p>\n\n<p>(9A is closer than 1B). Leave the tiles on the gameboard.</p>\n\n<p>Note: If two or more of these tiles are adjacent, they are considered unincorporated tiles. If an additional tile is added later, then they become a corporation.</p>\n\n<p>All players draw six tiles and stand them up so that the other players can't see them.</p>\n\n<h5>Show or hide assets</h5>\n\n<p>Players must now decide as a group whether the money and stocks they acquire will be openly displayed. An open display is strongly recommended for new or inexperienced players.</p>\n\n<p>If money and stock are not displayed, the game is even more challenging because players must try to remember how much stock each player has purchased.</p>\n\n<p>Note: At any time during the game, a player may ask how many stocks of a company are still unpurchased.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>Each player does the following three things in order:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li>Play a tile onto the gameboard by putting it on its matching space.</li>\n<li>Buy stocks of any active corporations. There is a limit of three total per turn.</li>\n<li>Draw a new tile from the facedown cluster.</li>\n\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n<h2>1. Playing a Tile</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/acquire/tiles.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Depending upon where a tile is played, it may form a corporation or it may merge two or more corporations. (Of course, a tile may also be played which does nothing).</p>\n\n<h3>Founding a corporation</h3>\n\n<p>When a player places a tile next to an unincorporated tile already on the gameboard (vertically or horizontally - not diagonally), a corporation is founded. The corporation founder first selects an available corporation building marker from the stock market tray and places it on any one of the corporation's tiles. The player then receives a free founder's bonus stock (of that corporation) from the tray.</p>\n\n<p>Note: If players are already holding all the corporation's stock cards, then no founder's bonus stock is given out.</p>\n\n<p>Any tile that would form an eighth corporation cannot be played. (There are only seven corporations in the game). However, such a tile might be played later in the game if a merger makes a corporate building marker available again.</p>\n\n<h3>Merging corporations</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/acquire/acquire.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>When a player places a tile so that it connects two (or more) corporations, a merger takes place. The larger corporation (the one with more tiles) survives and the smaller corporation becomes defunct. During the merger, the merging tile does not add to the size of either corporation for any riurpose.</p> <p>If the corporations are the same size, then the mergemaker decides which corporation survives. The surviving corporation absorbs the defunct one. The corporation building marker of the defunct company is removed from the gameboard and returned to the tray.</p>\n\n<p>Note: If more than two corporations are merged by one tile, see Multiple Mergers section below for details.</p>\n\n<h4>Safe corporations</h4>\n\n<p>A corporation that contains 11 or more tiles is considered \"safe\" and cannot be absorbed by another corporation for the rest of the game. A safe corporation can absorb a smaller corporation, but two safe corporations cannot merge. Any tile that would merge two safe corporations is permanently unplayable and can be discarded and replaced later in the turn.</p>\n\n<h3>Majority and minority stockholders' bonuses</h3>\n\n<p>At the time of a merger, all players must reveal the exact number of stocks in the defunct company that they own. The players with the most and second-most stocks are declared majority and minority stockholders. The banker pays them the majority and minority stockholders' bonuses as described below.</p>\n\n<p>If only one player owns stock in the defunct corporation, that player gets both bonuses. If there is a tie for majority stockholder, add the majority and minority bonuses together, divide evenly and round up to the next payable dollar amount if necessary. (The minority shareholder gets no bonus). If there is a tie for minority stockholder, split the minority bonus among the tied players. Round resulting bonuses up to the nearest $100 if necessary.</p>\n\n<p>To determine the bonus amount, find the defunct corporation's name on any information card. Then look down the card to the number of tiles in the defunct corporation. Then look across the card to the majority and minority bonus amounts. This bonus money comes from the bank.</p>\n\n<p>Note: Stockholders in the surviving corporation don't get any bonuses, but the value of their stock will probably go up because the corporation has grown larger.</p>\n\n<p>After bonuses have been paid out, each stockholder must decide what to do with the defunct stock. Each player, starting with the mergemaker and continuing clockwise, can hold, sell, and trade the defunct stock cards.</p>\n\n<h3>Hold</h3>\n\n<p>Stock may be held in expectation of starting another corporation with that name later.</p>\n\n<h3>Sell</h3>\n\n<p>Stock may be sold back to the stock market at a price determined by the number of tiles in the defunct corporation before the merger.</p>\n\n<h3>Trade</h3>\n\n<p>Stock may be traded. For every two defunct stock cards traded in, the player gets one stock in the surviving corporation. Of course, the supply of surviving stock cards is limited, so you can't acquire stock that is not available.</p>\n\n<p>Note: Players are allowed to choose more than one of the above options. For example, a player could hold onto a few of the defunct stocks, sell some and trade some.</p>\n\n<h3>Multiple mergers</h3>\n\n<p>It is possible that one tile could cause the merger of three or four corporations. The largest corporation survives and the smaller ones become defunct. The mergemaker breaks any ties.</p>\n\n<p>The smaller corporations are dealt with - one at a time - from largest to smallest. Majority and minority stockholder bonuses are paid out as described previously, and then the defunct stock is held, sold or traded. As usual, the mergemaker goes first.</p>\n\n<br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/acquire/stocks.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<h2>2. Buying Stocks</h2>\n\n<p>After placing a tile, the player may buy stock in any active corporation. This is optional. A player may decide to buy none or up to three stock cards on a turn.</p>\n\n<p>For example, a player can buy one stock card in three different active corporations - or one in one corporation and two in another - or three stock cards in one corporation.</p>\n\n<h4>Price per share</h4>\n\n<p>This is determined by first finding the name of the corporation on any information card, looking down the card to the number of tiles in the corporation and then looking across the card to the stock price. Money is paid into the stock market tray. Remember, there are only 25 stocks for each corporation, so when all 25 are sold, no more can be purchased.</p>\n\n<h4>Running out of money</h4>\n\n<p>Aggressively competing to become the majority stockholder in a corporation can be risky. Invest wisely in corporations that are small and close to bigger ones.</p>\n\n<p>A player who runs out of money cannot buy stock. A player with no money still places a tile on each of his/her turns, if possible, but must wait for a corporation in which he/she owns stock to go defunct in order to get money. Remember, a player can sell a corporation's stock only after the corporation has gone defunct, and at the end of the game. No loans are allowed from other players or the stock market bank.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>3. Drawing a Tile</h2>\n\n<p>A player takes a tile from the facedown cluster to replace the one he/she played. This is not done until the end of the turn. At this time, if a player has any permanently unplayable tiles (ones that merge two safe corporations), that player puts the unplayable tiles to the side (faceup) and draws an equal number of replacement tiles.</p> <p>This can only be done once per turn. If more unplayable tiles are drawn, the player must wait until his/her next turn to discard them. Tiles that would form an eighth corporation cannot be traded in.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>The game ends when one player, during his/her turn, announces that either all active corporations are safe or that one corporation has 41 or more tiles on the gameboard.</p>\n\n<p>A player does not have to announce that the game is over if it is to his/her advantage to continue playing. After announcing that the game is over, the player may finish the turn.</p>\n\n<p>Majority and minority shareholders' bonuses are paid out for all active corporations, and all stocks are sold back to the stock market bank at current prices (as shown on the information cards).</p>\n\n<p>Stock in a corporation that is not on the board is worthless. The player with the most money wins the game.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"tips.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Acquire Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:59:15.523Z"),
            ~~~~~~~~~
        ?   language?: String | StringFieldUpdateOperationsInput,
        ?   setupInstructions?: String | NullableStringFieldUpdateOperationsInput | Null,
        ?   victoryConditions?: String | NullableStringFieldUpdateOperationsInput | Null,
        ?   game?: GameUpdateOneRequiredWithoutRulesNestedInput
          }
        })

→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 129
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Qwixx Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/qwixx/qwixx.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>6 dice ( 2 white, 1 red, 1 green, 1 blue, 1 yellow)</li>\n<li>1 score pad</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>Score the most points by crossing out as many numbers in the four color-rows as possible while avoiding penalty points.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<p>Each player takes a score sheet and something to write with.</p>\n\n<p>Before playing it's important to understand the one basic rule of Qwixx, which is that numbers must be crossed out from left to right in each of the four color-rows.</p>\n\n<p>You do not have to begin with the number farthest to the left, but if you skip any numbers, they cannot be crossed out afterward.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/qwixx/game8.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> In the red row first the 5 and then the 7 were crossed out. Therefore, the red 2, 3, 4 and 6 may not be crossed out later in the game. In the yellow row only the 11 and the 12 may still be crossed out. In the green row you can only cross out numbers to the right of the 6. In the blue row you can only cross out right of the 10.</p>\n\n<p><b>Tip:</b> Put a small horizontal line through the numbers that you skipped, so that you don't cross them out later by accident.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/qwixx/game.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>The first player to roll a 6 takes on the role of \"active player\". The active player rolls all six dice. The following two actions are now carried out in order, always one after the other:</p>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/qwixx/game1.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The active player adds up the two white dice and announces out loud, the resulting sum.</p>\n\n<p>All players may then (but are not required to) cross out the number that the active player announced in any (but only one) of the color-rows.</p>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> Chris is the active player. The two white dice show a 4 and a 1. Chris announces, \"five\". Tony crosses out the yellow 5 on his score sheet. Caroline crosses out the red 5. Annie and Nora choose not to cross out a number.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/qwixx/game2.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The active player (but not the others) may then (but is not required to) add one of the white dice together with any one of the colored dice and cross out the number corresponding to this sum in the color-row corresponding to the color of the chosen die.</p>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> Chris adds together the white 4 with the blue 6 and crosses out the 10 in the blue color-row.</p>\n\n</li>\n</ol>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Penalties</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/qwixx/game9.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If, after the two actions, the active player doesn't cross out at least one number, he must cross out one of the penalty boxes. Each penalty box is worth -5 points at the end of the game. (The non-active players do not take a penalty if they choose not to cross out a number).</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of a Round</h2>\n\n<p>Once all players are ready, the player to the left becomes the new active player and re-rolls all six dice. Then the two actions described on the left are carried out again, one after the other.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Locking a Row</h2>\n\n<p>If you wish to cross out the number at the extreme right end of a color-row (red 12, yellow 12, green 2, blue 2) you must have first crossed out at least five numbers in that row.</p>\n\n<p>If you cross out the number on the extreme right, then also cross off the lock symbol directly next to it. This indicates that the color-row is now locked for all players and numbers of this color cannot be crossed out in future rounds.</p>\n\n<p>The die of the corresponding color is immediately removed from the game.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/qwixx/game3.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> Alison crosses out the green 2 and after it, the lock symbol. The green die is removed from the game.</p>\n\n<h5>Notes:</h5>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>If a row is locked during the first action, it is possible that other players may, at the same time, also cross out the number on the extreme right and lock the same color-row. These players must also have previously crossed out at least five numbers in that row.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>The cross on the lock counts toward the total number of crosses marked in that color-row.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>The game ends immediately as soon as either someone has marked a cross in his fourth penalty box or as soon as two dice have been removed from the game (two color-rows have been locked).</p>\n\n<p>It may occur (during the first action) that a third row is locked simultaneously with the second row.</p>\n\n<h4>Scoring</h4>\n\n<p>Beneath the four color-rows is a table indicating how many points are awarded for how many crosses within each row (including any locks marked with a cross).</p>\n\n<p>Each crossed out penalty box scores five minus-points. Enter your points for the four color-rows and the minus-points for any penalties in the appropriate fields at the bottom of the scoresheet</p>\n\n<p>The player with the highest total score is the winner.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/qwixx/game4.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> Alison has 4 crosses in red, which gives her 10 points; in yellow, she has 3 (=6 points); in green 8 (=36 points); and in blue 7 (= 28 points). For her two penalties she must subtract 10 points. This means that Alison's total score is 70 points.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"deluxe.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Qwixx Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:59:38.509Z"),

          where: {
            id: 130
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Railroad Ink: Deep Blue Edition Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/railroad-ink.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<p>A game of Railroad Ink is played over 7 rounds. The goal is to connect as many Exits <img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/u.jpg\"> to each other as possible by drawing Routes that can create Networks. The more Exits <img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/u.jpg\"> you connect to the same Network, the more points it will be worth. Bonus points can be earned for your Longest Railway, your Longest Highway, and by drawing on the Central Spaces of your Board.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/components.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n<ul>\n<li>6 Markers</li>\n<li>4 Route Dice</li>\n<li>6 Boards</li>\n<li>2 river dice</li>\n<li>2 lake dice</li>\n<li>Rulebook</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p>Each player takes a Board and places it in front of them.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Each player also takes a marker.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Place the Route dice in the middle of the table.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>The River and Lake dice are only used in the Expansions.</p></li>\n</ol>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/game1.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<p>At the beginning of each round, the Route dice are rolled once. The results of the roll will determine which Routes all players must draw that round. After the roll, all players play simultaneously, drawing the Routes rolled on their own boards.</p>\n\n<h4>Rolling Dice</h4>\n\n<p>Take the Route dice and roll them in the middle of the table. Place the dice so they are easily visible to all players.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/game3.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>There are 2 kinds of Route dice.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<p>3 dice show these 6 kinds of Routes:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/game2.jpg\"><br><br>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>1 die shows these 3 kinds of Routes:</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/game6.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> Stations allow you to connect a Railway Route to a Highway Route. Overpasses allow the two to cross without being connected to each other.</p>\n\n<p><b>Hint:</b> To more easily keep track of the Routes you have to draw, you can use the dice reference on your board to mark the available Routes, if you so desire.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Drawing Routes</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/game8.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>After the dice roll, all players must draw the Routes on their boards at the same time.</p>\n\n<p>There are a few drawing rules you need to follow:</p>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<p>Each Route you draw must be connected by at least one side to either one of the Exits <img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/u.jpg\"> or a preexisting Route. If you can't connect a Route, you can't draw it.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>You must draw all 4 Routes shown on the dice each round (if possible, and each Route showing can only be drawn once, of course).</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<p>You can't draw Routes in a way that directly connects Railways to Highways or vice versa (you need a Station to do that).</p>\n\n</li>\n</ol>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Important:</b> When drawing Routes, you can freely rotate and/or reverse the pattern you see on the die.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/game9.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n\n\n<br>\n<h2>Using Special Routes</h2>\n\n<p>Each player can also use 6 Special Routes, displayed in the top part of the boards, that do not appear on the Route dice. These Routes2 may allow you to connect different Network4 together and/or make bigger Networks.</p>\n\n<p>You may draw a Special Route once per round, in addition to the Routes shown on the Route dice, but you may use each Special Route only once per game.</p>\n\n<p>After you use a Special Route, you must mark it off on your board as a reminder that you can't use it again. Also, you can only use up to 3 Special Routes during the entire game (and remember, only 1 per round).</p>\n\n<table class=\"image-description\"><tbody><tr><td><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/game10.jpg\"><br><b>Remember</b>: Only 1 Special Route per round, and only up to 3 per game!</td></tr></tbody></table><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Round</h2>\n\n<table class=\"image-description floatr\"><tbody><tr><td><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/game13.jpg\"><br>Example: The end of the 5th round.</td></tr></tbody></table><br>\n\n<p>Once all the players have drawn all of the available Routes, the round ends.</p>\n\n<p>Each player must mark the spaces where they drew Routes this round by writing the number of the current round in the white boxes of each space they drew on. You can never erase the Routes you drew in a previous round.</p>\n\n<p>After that, roll the Route Dice to start the next round.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/game12.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/game14.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>The game ends after the 7th round. Now it's time to count your score!</p>\n\n<p>Each player counts the points they earned for their connected Exits <img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/u.jpg\">, their Longest Railway and Longest Highway, and the Central Spaces they drew on, marking their points on the designated spaces of the Scoring Table on their boards.</p>\n\n<p>Then, each player must check for incomplete Routes. Each end of a Route that does not connect with any other Route or the outer edge of the board counts as an Error. Mark each one of these Errors with this symbol: <img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/x.jpg\">.</p>\n\n<p>You lose 1 point for each Error on your board. Mark these penalty points on the matching space of your Scoring Table.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> If you are playing with an Expansion <img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/s.jpg\">, mark any additional points on the expansion space of your scoring board.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>Finally, add up all the points you earned (subtracting any points from Errors) and write your total score on your Scoring Table. The player with the most points wins! In case of a tie, the winner is the player with the fewest Error marks on their board. If they're still tied, the victory is shared.</p>\n\n<h3>Scoring</h3>\n\n<h4>Connecting Exits</h4>\n\n<p>Connecting Exits <img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/u.jpg\"> is the main way to score points in Railroad Ink. At the end of the game, each set of Exits that are connected to each other via the same Network of Routes is worth a number of points determined by the number of Exits connected together, as shown on the Network Values on your Board.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/game16.jpg\"><br>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Note 1:</b> Overpasses only allow you to make two of your Networks cross each other, but they don't create a connection between the two.</p>\n\n<p><b>Note 2:</b> You can use Stations to connect Railway Routes and Highway Routes to each other.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<br>\n\n<h4>Bonus Points</h4>\n\n<p>While the points you get for connecting Exits <img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/u.jpg\"> may end up being the bulk of your score when you add up points at the end of the game, do not underestimate the importance of the bonus points you can earn from your Longest Highway, Longest Railway, and Central Spaces.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/game31.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>Your <b>Longest Highway</b> is ; the longest unbroken streak of adjacent spaces where you drew Highway Routes that are connected to each other (not counting any loops or branches), such as the route marked in blue to the right. You score 1 point for each space that makes up your single longest Highway branch. Stations do not interrupt your Highway. This example show a Longest Highway of 8 spaces.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/game32.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>Your Longest Railway is determined the same way as the Longest Highway,, only counting Railway Routes instead of Highway Routes, like the one marked in red to the right (worth 5 points).</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/game21.jpg\" class=\"floatl\">\n\n<p>Your <b>Central Spaces</b> are the 9 spaces in the middle of your board. You score 1 point for each Central Space you drew anything on.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/game22.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/railroad-ink/game20.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>If you have two Longest Routes (with the same number of spaces), only 1 counts towards your final score.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"expansions.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Railroad Ink: Deep Blue Edition Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:59:44.858Z"),

→ 296   await prisma.gameRule.update({
          where: {
            id: 131
          },
          data: {
            rulesHtml: "<div class=\"post-header post-author\"><div class=\"post-title\"><h1>Welcome to your Perfect Home Game Rules</h1></div></div>\n\n<div class=\"post-thumbnail\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/welcome-to.jpg\" alt=\"\"></div>\n\n\n<p>In Welcome To, players are American architects in the 50s during the Baby Boom. But beware of the competition! Who will best accomplish the city's plans by creating the nicest housing estates in the three streets they've been assigned? Will your luxurious parks and fancy pools be enough to earn you title of Best Architect?</p>\n\n<p>Welcome To is a game where everyone plays at the same time with the same cards. It's all about cleverly combining the house numbers with their associated effects in order to become the greatest architect of tomorrow !</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Components</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>\n\n<h5>29 City Plan Cards</h5>\n\n<p>18 City Plans for the basic game &amp; 10 City Plans for the advanced variant (marked by a ). One Solo card included for the solo variant. Cards numbered 1, 2, or 3 with a Project side &amp; an Approved side.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game2.jpg\"><br><br>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h5>81 Construction Cards</h5>\n\n<p>(House number on one side &amp; effect on back)</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game6.jpg\"><br><br>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h5>4 Player Aids</h5>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game8.jpg\"><br><br>\n</li>\n<li>\n\n<h5>100 Player Sheets</h5>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game9.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Object of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>Architects gradually develop their three streets by building houses, identified by their numbers. Houses will be grouped into housing estates, but only fully-completed ones count at the end of the game.</p>\n\n<p>Parks and pools help to improve the neighborhood. Architects can raise the quality of their constructions in order to promote their estates' value. All of this while trying to be the first to complete the City Plans!</p>\n\n<p>Finally, by increasing recruitment through temp agencies, architects can hasten the construction and get in the mayor's good graces.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Setup</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>Each player takes a pen or pencil (not provided) and a sheet from the player sheet. y Distribute the Player Aids to the players.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Shuffle and randomly choose 3 City Plan cards from the basic set: one n°1, one n°2, and one n°3. Place them \" Project \" side face up so all players may see. Return all remaining City Plans to the box.</p></li>\n\n<li><p>Shuffle the Construction cards. Deal 3 equal stacks of 27 each, house number face up. Place these in a column with room for discards to their right.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game13.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Game Play</h2>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game15.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>At the beginning of each turn, flip over the top card of each construction stack and place it to the right with its effect displayed. These stacks create three combinations, comprised of a House Number and an Effect. These combinations are used to perform actions.</p>\n\n<p>Players take turns simultaneously. Each player individually chooses one of the three combinations available to perform an action on their sheet. Multiple players can pick the same combination.</p>\n\n<p>Each player must write the number from the chosen combination in a house on one of the three streets on their sheet. Numbers must always be written in an empty house and must be written in ascending order from left to right.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game19.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>The same number can never appear twice in the same street.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<h4>Note</h4>\n\n<p>When filling in houses, players may leave as many empty houses between two built houses, and then fill them in later. Numbers must still be in ascending order.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game16.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Also, players may skip numbers when filling in houses, like placing a 10 directly after a 7.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game17.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game18.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>If a player cannot follow the placement rules, they do not fill in a house number and receive a building permit refusal. Cross off the top-most, lowest-numbered space.</p>\n\n<p>The player's chosen combination also allows them to perform an effect. Players may perform the effect only if they did not receive a building permit refusal. Note: performing an effect is optional.</p>\n\n<p>Once all players have built their houses and carried out effects, a new turn begins. If the construction stacks are ever empty, reshuffle them and deal out as before.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>Effects</h2>\n\n<h3>Surveyor</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game22.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Allows the player to build a fence between two houses on the same street. To build a fence, choose any available, white-dotted space and draw a line on it. Permanent fences are present on both sides of each street.</p>\n\n<p>Fences determine the boundaries of housing estates. A completed housing estate is a row of 1 to 6 neighboring houses, all numbered (no blank spaces between them) and built between two fences.</p>\n\n<p>Completed housing estates are necessary to fulfill City Plans and may be split further, as long as they have not previously fulfilled a City Plan).</p>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> The architect has written a 5 on the third house of the second street in order to start a 3-house estate. Then they built a fence between the first and the second house of the first street, therefore splitting a 3-House estate into 1-house and 2-house estates.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game23.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h3>Real Estate Agent</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game24.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Promotes and increases the value of completed housing estates. To use the Real Estate Agent, choose a Real Estate column and cross off the top-most, lowest- numbered space.</p>\n\n<p>At the end of the game, each completed estate (size 2, 3, 4, etc..). scores as many points as the smallest, unchecked number from its corresponding column.</p>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> After crossing off the top-most space in the 2-House estate column, each 2-house estate now scores 3 points at game end. The 3- and 4-house estates score points equal to their initial amount.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game26.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h3>Landscaper</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game27.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Allows the player to build a park. The player crosses off one of the trees at the end of the street. Parks must be crossed off on the same street that the house number is written. Parks are crossed off, left- to-right in ascending order.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game28.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<h3>Pool Manufacturer</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game29.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Allows a player to score points when building houses that have a planned pool. If a player writes the house number associated with the Pool Manufacturer effect in a house with a planned pool, then the pool is built. Cross off the top-most, lowest-numbered space in their pools column.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> A player can use a house number/effect combination without a Pool Manufacturer effect to write a number in a house.</p>\n\n<p>Oppositely, a player can write a number associated with the Pool Manufacturer effect in a house without a pool. However, in both cases, the pool is not built; therefore the player does not cross off a new pool in their pools column.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game26_.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<h3>Temp Agency</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game30.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Allows the player to add or subtract 1 or 2 to the house number they are building. The Temp Agency allows the player to write numbers from 0 to 17. For each use of the Temp Agency, cross off one box from the Temp Agency column. At the end of the game, the player who crossed off the most Temp</p>\n\n<p>Agency boxes scores 7 points. The next highest scores 4 points, and the third highest scores 1 point. In case of a tie, players score the same amount of points.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game34.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p><i>Example:</i> Using a number 8 card, build a house with the number 6, 7, 8, 9, or 10. Then, cross off one box.</p>\n\n<h3>«bis»</h3>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game31.jpg\" class=\"floatr\">\n\n<p>Allows the player to duplicate a house number on any street. The new house must be directly adjacent, to the left or right of the house with the same number. Duplicate houses can never be separated by fences.</p>\n\n<p>When duplicating a number, write \"bis\" next to the number in the new house. A house can be duplicated multiple times, and the duplicated number does not have to be associated with the number/effect combination.</p>\n\n<p>Cross off the top-most, lowest-numbered space in the \"bis\" column. At the end of the game, subtract the smallest, unchecked number from the final score.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game35.jpg\"><br>\n\n<br>\n<h2>City Plans</h2>\n\n<p>A City Plan presents a goal set by the City to its architects, as in building a certain number of housing estates with mandated sizes.</p>\n\n<p>The first player(s) who meet the required conditions of a City Plan during the same turn immediately score the points indicated. Write the higher amount from the \"Project\" side of the City Plan card in the corresponding box (n°1, 2, or 3) in their Plans column.</p>\n\n<p>Turn over the City Plan to its \"Approved\" side. A player can only score each City Plan once.</p>\n\n<img src=\"scraped_rules/images/welcome-to/game37.jpg\"><br><br>\n\n<p>Other players who later achieve the same City Plan score the lower point amount.</p>\n\n<h3>Housing Estates Plans</h3>\n\n<p>To fulfill these City Plans, the player must complete all of the required housing estates.</p>\n\n<p>The estates do not have to be in the same street. There is no restriction to the location of a Plan's estates.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Note:</b> After an estate has fulfilled a City Plan, it cannot be further subdivided with a Surveyor's fence. Also, it cannot fulfill another City Plan. The player marks out the fence above each house to indicate it has already fulfilled a City Plan.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>The first player who completes a goal can choose to reshuffle the 81 Construction cards and deal three new stacks of cards as in game setup.</p>\n\n<br>\n<h2>End of the Game</h2>\n\n<p>The game ends immediately when:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>A player crosses off their third Building Permit Refusal or</li>\n<li>A player achieves all three City Plans or</li>\n<li>A player has built all of the houses on their streets.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Add up the points for City Plans, parks on each street, pools, temps, and completed estates Subtract the points from the \"Bis\" column and the Building Permit Refusal column.</p>\n\n<p>The <b>player with the most points wins</b>.</p>\n\n<p>In case of a tie, the player with the most completed estates wins. In case of another tie, the player with the most 1-house estates wins, then 2-house, etc... In case of another tie, (seriously?) players play another game of Welcome To.</p>\n\n<br class=\"break\">\n<a href=\"solo.php\" class=\"nextpage\">Continue Reading</a>\n\n\n\n\n<br><br>\n",
            rulesText: "Welcome to your Perfect Home Game Rules",
            updatedAt: new Date("2025-08-15T14:59:51.294Z"),
            ~~~~~~~~~

        ?   game?: GameUpdateOneRequiredWithoutRulesNestedInput

Just as a composer's creation is brought to life by the performing musicians, a game inventor's creation is brought to life by the players of the game.</p>\n\n<p>When the creation is inspired and the players are talented, a true work of art results.</p>\n\n<p>In creating the seven games in this book I have attempted to add a new visual dimension to the art of games. Each player turns the top card of his/her stack faceup, creating an \"UP\" card. â€¦</p>\n</li>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</ul></div></a><br class=\"break\">\n<div class=\"tags\"><a href=\"spite-and-malice/game-rules.php\" class=\"readmore\">Read More</a><a>Card Game</a></div></div><hr>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"post\">\n<a href=\"robot-turtles/game-rules.php\"><div class=\"post-header post-author\"><h3>Robot Turtles Game Rules</h3></div>\n<div class=\"post-title-body\"><div class=\"post-thumbnail\" data-toggle=\"How to play {name} | Official Game Rules\"><img src=\"scraped_rules/images/clever/robot-turtles.jpg\" alt=\"\" height=\"160\"></div>\n\n\n<h4>Components</h4>\n<ul>\n<li>Game Board</li>\n<li>4 Robot Turtle Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Jewel Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Bug Tiles</li>\n<li>4 Code Card Decks</li>\n<li>20 Stone Walls</li>\n<li>12 Ice Walls</li>\n<li>4 Crates</li>\n<li>Instructions</li>\n</ul>\n\n\n<h4>Object of the Game</h4>\n\n<p>At the Start of the Game, the Turtle Mover (grownup) should <b>read these rules out loud!</b> for the turtle masters (kids):</p>\n\n\n\n<p>\"The goal of the game is to get your Robot Turtle to the matching colored Jewel! When you land on the matching Jewel you can pick it up. Everyone who gets their Jewel wins!\"</p>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<h4>Game Play</h4>\n<ol>\n<li>\n\n<p>\"You are the Turtle Master.
